description:
I stopped here with a friend for a snack and we ordered a couple small bites. We ordered the vegan gyoza and edamame, as well as some house sake and wine (why not?). The vegan gyoza was very good and the simple fact that they have vegan options makes this place pretty unique! They also have vegan ramen which I didn't have the appetite to try at the time but would love to come back for it.

Would definitely recommend this place if you want to go somewhere that has great options for both vegans and non-vegans. Seems like this place gets busy so there may be a bit of a wait.
author: Eva R.

description:
It's not everyday that I stumble upon great ramen by accident. Having been wandering around Japantown with 5% battery life remaining on my cell phone and minimal access to wifi, I saw that there were a few people lined up at the door so opted to eat here for lunch. Only later did I realize that Hinodeya has a well established, multigenerational history of ramen making success.

As a single diner I was seated right away at the bar. I appreciated that they have hooks where I could hang my purse and shopping bags. The restaurant itself is fairly sizeable with some larger tables that seat up to 8 people and some private booths towards the back of the restaurant. 

I ordered the house ramen ($14) which came within 10 minutes of me ordering it. The dashi broth was clear, nicely seasoned and light without the heavy handed saltiness, a nice change from many of the heavier broths I'm accustomed to finding at most other ramen places. The noodles were freshly made and thicker and maintained a nice chew throughout my meal. The finely chopped scallions and menma which I would normally eat around actually helped elevate the overall flavour and texture profile of the delicate broth. Two generously sized pieces of chashu came with the ramen and these were flavourful and not too fatty. The soft boiled egg helped add a bit of richness to the meal. 

On the merit of the ramen itself I would return when in the area. But what I really appreciated was that when I asked if by chance there was a cell phone charger available to charge my depleted battery, my server didn't miss a beat and offered to plug it in near the cash register. It felt somewhat strange not having my phone to take pictures of my food when it first arrived, but that short charging session allowed me to enjoy my meal without the distraction of technology and allowed me to carry on my food adventures in the area with sufficient charge to make it back to my hotel.
author: Arlene B.

description:
Stumbled on this on a Monday night when most of the better Japanese restaurants close.   Has to do with fish delivery over the weekend so a good idea.  One famous ramen (think movie) has ONE customer inside.  But Hinodeya has a full dining room.  Doesn't take a YELP Elite to figure that one out.  One please...

Hamaguri Clam ramen?  I am in!  $18?  Give me a side of char siu and a order of gyoza!   Super friendly wait staff that keep bugging me to put her name in (no name tag... sorry).  Ok, she coughed it up. HOA!  Delightful!  She a bit crazy!  But wonderful. 

Back to food.  Soup was piping hot!  The critical first step to ramen greatness.   Yup, 10 clams just like in the picture.  Honest menu.  Tasty broth and the clams not over cooked.  Some sliced negi onions and mizuna for freshness.  Gyoza give it a B.  Could have caramelized it a bit more.  I like crunchy.  Great side of fatty char siu.   All about the pork belly.   A little hot sake and I am now I will be a repeat customer. 

The finale is a little bingo kind of game for small prizes.  Just for fun but all the customers get a kick out of it.  1st prize is a bowl of ramen.  

Yuppp.  I worked in Japan.  This place is pretty legit!  Give it a try!
author: David W.

description:
Reminds me of an authentic ramen stop right out of Japan. Waiting in line in the cold SF weather until you finally make it through the curtains to be seated. Menu and design of place is very contemporary modern. Tree branches hanging on the ceiling giving it a trendy look as well. 

House ramen: Soup base was crisp and light in a pleasant way. It was unlike other broths that are rich and fatty. Cha sui pork was tender and flavorful with a bit of a sweet taste. Poached egg was a beautiful sight... a dark orange melting yolk surrounded by the solid white outside shell. Noodle texture were decent, but I prefer the thinner traditional style of ramen noodles. 

Came here because of the long wait at Marafuku and I would recommend this place. The broth is unique and is refreshing to say the least. It is not overly rich and flavorful, ideal for a light dinner. Servers were friendly and polite highlighting the well-earned reputation in Japanese culture.
author: Ronald M.

description:
In Japan Town, this ramen place seems to always be packed inside and I understand why! Good service, good ramen and clean place!!

Came here spontaneous after a spa treatment and we were just hungry. Good thing we had found street parking early or you would have to pay at the parking garage. My daughter and I ordered simple, just their house ramen and I had an Asahi on tap. 

Their house ramen was very good. Clear broth with lots of bamboo shoots, one seaweed, half egg, onions/cilantro and two slices of pork. Pork was very tasty. You can also add more flavor from their condiments: choice of Tabera or Umami paste.

Service was very good even though it was busy. Prices are a little high but then it's expected in SF. I would come back here for more and try their other ramen meals. [131/100]
author: Edna G.

description:
What I love about Hinodeya is they have a limited menu. It can get overwhelming to eat out when some menus are vast and there are too many options to choose from. They have 3 main ramen entrees, so you know they've worked hard to pare down the ingredients and choose the best combinations to make their ramen delicious.

The house ramen and vegan ramen are quite good. Salty and thick in all the right places. The yams were incredibly delicious as well.

The restaurant is also baby-friendly and service-dog friendly. There's enough background noise that if you're eating here and an infant starts crying, customers around you don't really notice because of the humming of activity that's already happening. 

This place is small, but I've never had to wait more than 15 minutes. It can be difficult to find if this is your first time, but the signage out in the square is helpful. Something else to note is that the bathrooms are clean!
author: PaHoua L.

description:
Since ramen is one of my favorites, I was excited to try this place out! 

My friend and I ordered Hinodeya ramen, seafood/clam ramen (limited offering), and karaage (5pcs). 

1) Hinodeya ramen (3.5/5): I find the broth to be not as flavorful compared to other places around. It was too bland to my taste. Also, I hope it provided more options (spicy level, thickness of the noodle, heaviness of the broth...etc.) for us to choose from! 
2) Seafood/clam ramen (3/5): My friend had this one and although he find the soup to be somewhat refreshing, he did not want to try it again. There were a lot of empty clam shells. 
3) Karaage (3/5): Nothing special. Typical karaage taste!

Overall, I would recommend this restaurant if there are long waits in other restaurants and you really want to have a bowl of ramen!
author: Justyn P.

description:
Impatience over at Marufuku led to the discovery of Hinodeya. What was great was that were was no wait during lunchtime on a Saturday.

What was not as great were the options and actual ramen that I ate. Another strange indicator was that they don't do any kind of spice levels. For vegans and vegetarians, this would be an amazing ramen shop. However if you're more on the meaty and "I need some good a** ramen that's gonna hit my pent up cravings" kinda person then it's best to practice your patience and head over to another ramen spot. 

The house ramen's broth just doesn't do the job of meeting the ramen expectations. Not that I'm always looking for heavy broths, but the broth tasted lackluster as it was too light. The meat was also so-so, and there just wasn't much excitement in the meal altogether. 

Recommend for vegans and vegetarians, skip for the meat and broth-focused ramen lovers
author: Annie N.

description:
I was completely shocked at how much I like this spot! There are countless of ramen spots in the city but this place was pretty good for the price point. My friend and I went an hour before closing and there wasn't any line. We were greeted and promptly seated as soon as we entered the restaurant.

I got the Hinodeya Ramen and when I received it I thought the soup looked bland because of how clear the broth was. I had one sip of the broth and was surprised by how much flavor was packed into it. I am use to thick heavy broths but this was a nice change. The noodles had a good bite to them. Sadly, the chashu was okay. I am usually most excited for chashu but it just didn't have a good texture in my mouth. 

Overall, this is a good spot to eat at for very simple ramen. I heard the desserts here are amazing. I will definitely come back to check that out.
author: Ada H.

description:
Little gem in Japantown that we discovered because we didn't realize that joining the line for Marafuku when you arrive to Japan Center is a huge rookie move (hour 30 wait)

+ beautiful interior with dangling lights from large branches on the ceiling
+ hinodeya ramen: such a clear and beautiful broth that didn't weigh me down as the usual rich and creamy ramen broths usually do! large pieces of meat cooked well without too much fat. sauces on the side are optional, but i found them to be quite delicious. plenty of bamboo shoots included and soft boiled egg was great.
+ attentive and polite staff - really liked that they kept us updated while we were in line
author: Annie D.

description:
I've come here once at 11:30am on a Sunday thinking there'd be a wait but it was empty. Perfect, I love ramen with a side of no wait.

The ramen was good but not that memorable. I would come back but not if there is a wait.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Came here on a Monday night around 7:30PM and there wasn't really a line. Might have gotten very lucky :)

I got a vegan zen ramen and that was excellent. The broth was super flavorful. In my experience, non-meat based ramen broths tend to be and afterthought of salted vegetable water. This is definitely not the case here. It definitely hit the spot!

They also had these awesome sides/garnishes you could add to your ramen: a crispy onion with chili oil & "umami sauce" made from scallop powder and other stuff. Go for both!
author: Calvin C.

description:
We came here around 9 pm on a weekend night.  It is always surprisingly packed even so late. 

Food 4/5
Fried yam - really crispy and the sauce is flavorful. Would definitely order again.
House ramen - I am always surprised how clear the broth is here. The texture of the noodles are unique. Its thicker than other ramen places. I love the additional sauce with garlic and onion with chili and umani paste Bonito and scallop powder with garlic oil.
We also ordered the barley tea. Quite pricey for barley tea with free refills.

Would definitely be back! Love the atmosphere and how close it is to late night bars and karaoke places in japantown.
author: Stella S.

description:
Came on a Thursday morning when it opened and of course there wasn't much of a line. If we came half an hour later, there'd prob be a much longer wait. Def try and go when it's during their down times or when they first open; the wait would be so much shorter!

My friend's recommendation brought me to try this place. We each ordered a different bowl; Hinodeya Ramen for me and the chicken one for my friend. Of courage, I had to get the karaage as well. Overall, the food is good and had good flavor. Service was good, taste was good.
author: Karen Y.

description:
I really want to like the dashi broth concept but I think it just strays a bit too far from my typical ramen preferences. So take this review with a grain of salt, because the ramen I typically eat raises your blood pressure by 200% and puts you on Lipitor for 6 months.

First of all, line wasn't that bad but the service was really slow. I think since we came towards the end of the lunch hour the staff was starting to wind down (they were sort of just huddled in the corner on their phones), and weren't paying attention to us at all. It was a bit annoying for sure but probably our fault for coming so late (around 2pm).

Anyways, we ordered the house ramen and the chicken ramen. The house broth was super light, but had a pretty nice flavor--definitely not bland. The chicken broth had a bit more depth to it as expected but wasn't rich or fatty by any means. Both broths had an amazing initial flavor, and the meat was very good.

My issue with this style of ramen is that the tongue very quickly acclimates to the light flavor and it gets boring 1/3 into the bowl. I did try using the extra flavors they offer as add-ins, but it didn't complement the overall flavor (just masked). Although the initial flavor was amazing, the excitement just wore off too quickly.

Overall, I did not get the "umph, ahhhh" that I desire at the end of every ramen meal, but definitely praise this restaurant for succeeding at delivering a unique, interesting, and delicious flavor.
author: Nova W.

description:
My friends and I came to Hinodeya after encountering a 2 hour (!!) wait time at Marufuku. While we were bummed to miss out on Marufuku as we've been trying to go for a while, we were pleasantly surprised with Hinodeya. 

We came around 6pm on a Sunday. The line outside looks intimidating but our party of 5 was seated within ~10-15 min. 

To start, we got the spicy edamame, pork gyoza and kara-age (fried chicken). The kara-age was great (can't really go wrong with fried chicken) and the edamame was what could be expected. Unfortunately, the gyoza was a bit of a disappointment... it was pretty soggy and not at all crispy. However, the sauce it came with was good.

One of us got the chicken ramen and the rest got the house. The house ramen had great flavor and was some of the best I've had in the city.

While I can't compare the ramen to Marufuku as I've never been, Hinodeya seems like a great alternative if you want to skip an outrageous wait!
author: Jessie K.

description:
I visited Hinodeya Ramen Bar for a 3rd Bumble date. My date and I were both recovering from a cold, so I thought the ramen soup would be soothing. We arrived at 8PM on a Friday night and waited less than 20 minutes for a table. My date were luck and got seated at a 4-seater  table with plenty of elbow room. The restaurant also has 2 community tables and a few two-seaters. 

I love the decor. The wood chandeliers are beautiful. I only wish they would dim the lights just a little, so that it felt more intimate, but other than that I love the interior. 

Fried yam: crispy on the outside and flavorful. Wish it was cooked more thoroughly, but it was still good.

Gyoza: Mmmm, mmmm, mmmm! Delicious. Perfectly cooked in the inside and seared crispy on the outside--exactly how I like it.

House ramen: The noodles were fresh and perfectly al dente. The broth had a lot of delicious umami flavor. I did wish there were spicier options. There are condiments on the side, including typical Japanese chili powder. I really liked the crispy garlic condiment, too.  

Service: Overall, service was great. We felt very well tended to. Everything came out at a normal pace and the server regularly checked the table.

Overall, I highly recommend. This is probably my favorite ramen shop in Japantown!
author: Joanna S.

description:
FAVORITE RAMEN PLACE TO DATE! I had no idea vegan ramen could taste so delicious. The sesame and soy milk broth was unbelievably creamy and flavorful, and the spinach noodles and nori and all the toppings went perfectly with it. I usually have a hard time finishing an entire bowl of ramen but in this case I couldn't get enough of it! 
We went here after seeing a 1.5 hour wait at the nearby Marufuku. Hinodeyas had a small line out the door, maybe 30 min wait, and totally more worth it. Service was quick and friendly, and very reasonably priced ramen. Would absolutely recommend to meat lovers and vegans alike.
author: Jessica H.

description: We came here on Thursday around 5:30 and got seated right away. I ordered hinodeya ramen ($14). Their noodle was chewy and bit firm but I loved it. The broth reminds me of udon broth. It was good but I prefer chicken broth my friend got. It was more flavorful. Pork was good but nothing special. I love the ambiance and atmosphere of the ramen bar. Price was reasonable. I'd definitely be back to try other ramen!
author: Clare L.

description:
Holy Moly. Hinodeya is probably the best ramen place that I've been to in the Bay Area.

I came here with a friend on a Wednesday for dinner and waited about 30 minutes before we got seated at the booth. They give little hand towels and tea/water. We both ordered the Hinodeya ramen and loved it. I don't think I've ever seen such a clear ramen broth before! Kept drinking the broth because even though it had a strong flavor it was pretty light unlike typical heavy/creamy ramen broth. Noodles were very chewy too! Super satisfying!

Service was a little slow, but it was also packed so it's understandable; however, they were playing some hard-core Japanese rock music...felt like you had to eat quickly because of the fast paced music
author: Jenna W.

description:
Even in a foodie town like SF, there weren't a lot of options for ramen after 9pm. We turned to Yelp to find this restaurant in Japantown.

We had the chicken ramen and the house ramen.

Flavors were very good and the portion was a good size. Definitely worth a return visit.
author: Joanna S.

description:
I've heard great things about Hinodeya Ramen Bar so it was finally time to give it a try. We went around 6:00. The restaurant wasn't very full yet so we got seated right away.

We ordered the chicken karaage, which came in 5 large pieces with a slice of lemon, a Shishito pepper, and a side of green tea salt. I loved the crispiness of the chicken on the outside and the tenderness of the chicken on the inside.

We each ordered the Hinodeya ramen (the house ramen). Each bowl comes with soft and chewy ramen noodles served in a clear dashi broth topped with a soft boiled egg, menma, and a couple of pieces of tender chasu. The flavor was on point and so delicious. 

The server came to take our order almost right away. And the food came out pretty fast.

I highly recommend coming here for the ramen, but make sure that you come early to avoid the crowds. By the time it was 7:00, there was a line outside.
author: Andrea G.

description:
I got the vegan ramen here and it's the best vegan ramen I've had so far in the Bay Area. I've recently gotten very into ramen so I've been exploring quite a bit in my vegan ramen search. This one actually had flavor and taste unlike many other vegan ramens I've tried that taste bland and flavorless. I'll definitely be back for more.

There was a bit of a wait when we went but it wasn't too long. The place is popular and a little small to accommodate everyone that wants to eat there so it makes sense.
author: Karishma M.

description:
5 stars, period. and that's a lot coming from someone like me, who isn't the biggest fan of ramen. My brother, the ramen enthusiast, recommended this place for lunch and said I just have to try it. I came in with low expectations and little to no hope, but I agreed because it was a bit chilly. boy was I ever so wrong. 

I can proudly say that their house ramen is the best bowl of noodles I've ever had in my entire life. The broth is a clear base. I believe it is bonito and scallop based, along with a couple other ingredients. It's the perfect amount of flavor. I didn't feel the need to add the chili powder or the garlic oil that was on the table at all. The noodles are also very unique, perfectly al dente. We also had the karage with matcha salt, which was fantastic as well. Perfectly crispy on the outside, juicy and tender on the inside. Now that's a good karage. 

The service here was great as well. All the staff greeted us very warm welcome and goodbye, and everyone was a very attentive. We walked in at around 2pm, 30 mins before they closed out for lunch, and were seated immediately, although I would think it would get pretty busy here for dinner/weekend.
author: Maggie L.

description:
There's a reason why there was no wait here on a Sunday during prime lunchtime. This is a VEGAN ramen spot.

There were two (I think?) options for meaty ramen. Pork and chicken. The broth tasted like chicken broth with no salt added. Like literally out of the can. The only good part of this meal was the soft-boiled egg. Too bad they only gave half :(

There is no spicy option, and no hot sauce or spicy stuff on the table to add in, either! I should've went out and got some Sriracha from the Nijiya Market or something. Even after adding in the umami flavoring and the other garlicky stuff with "chili oil" into the broth, it was just...still....so bland.

With my craving unfulfilled, I think I will just make some instant Shin Ramen. With a FULL egg. :) Next time, we will be a bit more patient for Marufuku (you should arrive 30 minutes before opening for Marufuku!).
author: Michael K.

description:
This is one of the best ramen joints I've ever been to. I am by no means vegan or even vegetarian, but their vegan ramen is amazing. Who knew a soy milk based soup could be so flavorful?! The Hinodeya Ramen is great too. It is clear that the soup is made with a lot of thought and care. The flavors are truly delicious. We also had the chicken karaage, which was served with a really unique matcha salt. The chicken was perfectly fried and super juicy. 

Service is super friendly and efficient. There was no wait around 1pm on a Saturday. The prices are very reasonable for SF. I cannot wait to go back for more.
author: Emily C.

description:
Came here for lunch with a group of 7. We waited for around 10-15 minutes for a table, which was pretty fast for large group! They gave us a table in this curtained room, which I thought was very nice. All of the servers were extremely nice and polite, which felt like traditional Japanese hospitality. My friends and I ordered the Ka-Rage, Fried Oysters, and bowls of the Hinodeya Ramen with various add ons.

The Ka-Rage came perfectly fried with a side of Matcha Salt. The Matcha Salt did not make too much of a difference, but it looked cool. The Fried Oysters were fried nicely and came with a dark vinegary sauce. They were good, but nothing too different from your usual fried oysters. The peppers that came with both appetizers were nice for presentation, but made no difference when it came to flavor and spice.

The ramen bowls came shortly after we finished the appetizers and looked delicious! We asked for a side of something spicy and they brought us a black oil that had a slight hint of spicyness to it. The broth was delicious and different from what I usually order. On our table, there were containers of Umami Paste (Bonito & Scallop Powder w/ Garlic Oil) and Tabera (Garlic & Onion w/ Chili Oil). After adding a couple of scoops of them and the black oil to my bowl, it was really delicious in the end!

Overall, a good ramen spot to eat at when you're walking around Japantown. The wait isn't too bad like other ramen spots in the area and the service was wonderful!
author: Anthony N.

description:
Craving late-night ramen? This is probably the place for you. (Seriously--there's basically nothing else open after 9pm in the city.) 

Luckily, it's good ramen regardless of the lack of other restaurants open. And going late means no line. 

I ordered the house ramen (Hinodeya Ramen.) The dashi broth was oddly light, which contrasted with the noodles which were thick and very flavorful. I loved the cha siu pork (just right amount of fat and flavor) and the soft egg. 

The service was alright. It wasn't very fast or attentive but got the job done. I wish they gave everyone tea. 

Regardless, I'll be back to Hinodeya for the house ramen and to try some of the appetizers in it's great location in Japantown.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
At first I couldn't imagine vegan ramen to be so flavorful but Hinodeya's version didn't disappoint (and never has!) and it has since become a personal favorite of ours. It doesn't look like the average ramen with their green spinach noodles sitting in the creamy broth, kale and kobucha slices. 

The wait here can be a tossup. There's been times when there is hardly a wait and other times with a line trailing outside the door at or around meal times. The latter always seem to happen on colder days, I suppose, when people are in the mood for a hot steaming bowl of ramen. 

Service is always friendly as we usually see the same workers everytime. They're always accommodating, courteous and quick. Love this place. 

This place remains a favorite.
author: Esther A.

description:
Solid ramen spot!

I'm not vegan, but I tried the vegan ramen and I have to say it did a really good job of imitating the fattiness you usually have in ramen. The broth was cream/milky based with fried kale, mushrooms, and other veggies. The portion is a little bit smaller than usual spots and their menu is pretty small, but if I'm in the mood for vegan ramen I'd go again!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Discovered this place per recommendations from an amazing and successful Japanese chef. 

Portion size was perfect, not crazy expensive, good service, no wait time on Saturday 1PM. 

Zen Ramen (Kombu and shitake dashi broth, Champon noodles with shitake mushroom, dried seaweed, momiji carrot yuba chips, kale, and goji berries) - Delicious, light, and flavorful. Perhaps one of the best vegetarian/vegan ramen I've had. 

Hinodeya Ramen (Japanese dashi style soup & whole wheat noodles soup, bonito,kombu & scallop, chashu pork, menma, soft cooked marinade egg, dried seaweed, sesame seeds, green onion, red pepper) - The right balance of noodles per soup ratio. Chashu and egg were spot on.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
Ordered the Hinodeya ramen as that is their speciality and it did not disappoint. The soup base isn't super salty  like most ramen places. It wasn't too rich but still had plenty of flavour. Very delicious (the broth is brimming with umami). Soft boiled egg cooked to perfection (too bad they only give you half an egg though). This ramen shop comes directly from Japan and is my new favourite ramen restaurant in the city.

Asahi beer on tap: delicious, crisp, goes well with ramen.

Karaage: nice chunks of fried chicken served with matcha powder

Pro-Tip: ask for mayo for the karaage
author: Tom P.

description:
Wow, I am still dreaming about their Vegan Ramen almost a year later...

This experience has brought my significant other and I closer, as he also very happily enjoyed his Pork Ramen. I wish I was kidding. As his frustrated girlfriend, let me tell you that he is the MOST difficult person to please when it comes to food!!!! As a closet foodie, I am also not easy to impress.

Thanks to Hinodeya, our lives will never be the same. Now we just have to find a way to move to San Francisco...
author: Erica L.

description:
We just beat the dinner rush by 30 minutes on a Saturday night! After exploring the Japantown Mall across the street, we were craving some good ramen. Our taste buds were satiated after coming to Hinodeya. 

We walked in around 5:14PM and immediately were greeted with kindness from staff. Opted to sit at the bar (ladies it has hooks for your purses), ordered some sparkling sake ($15) and two house ramens. 

The ramen was flavorful, came out quickly, and the slices of pork weren't fatty compared to other ramen houses I've dined at. I really appreciated this because I prefer having more meat than anything. 

If I came on an empty stomach (which unfortunately I did not), I'd have finished my bowl without any discomfort...I still finished it - too good to stop eating - but I was so FULL. 

The service was great. Waiters ninja'd their way to refilling our water glasses whenever they were empty. Barely even noticed them. And the check came with a paper crane and a sticker. Really awesome takeaways to remember them by. As we made our way out of the restaurant, there was a line out the door! Lucky us. 

I heart Dashi!
author: Melanie B.

description:
This was a great find in San Francisco!

While visiting Japantown, we were looking for a place to eat and we found Hinodeya Ramen Bar. Luckily, there was no wait so we were seated right away at one of their community tables with other customers.

Hinodeya serves traditional dashi ramen similar to what you would find in Japan. I ordered the Hinodeya Ramen (House Ramen) which was topped with chashu pork, menma, egg, seaweed, sesame seeds, green onion and red pepper. The broth was delicious! It was very rich and savory. I wished I had a bigger bowl.

Their ramen bowls are little pricey around $14-$15. However, I kind of expected that being in San Francisco.
author: Glenn A.

description:
Hinodeya Ramen, in my case, played "hard to get". The first time, they had run out of broth and the second time, we had to wait ~35 minutes in San Francisco wind to get in.. buuuut, it was totally worth it!!

The dashi soup is so good! My favourite part of Hinodeya is that 2 of their 4 ramen choices are vegetarian/can be made vegan!! And their vegan ramen is SOOO good. The clear broth is soul food!! I've also had their chicken broth; the broth itself is okay, but the chicken is so well cooked, it nearly melts in your mouth.

The karage and bamboo shoots make great appetizers! We liked it so much that we went back the next weekend. 

Hinodeya is not my favourite ramen bar in SF but it's pretty high on the list!!
author: Divya S.

description:
Fabulous vegan ramen, and it doesn't just stop there. I had vegan gyoza and vegan shishito peppers. They serve meat as well at this restaurant, and the bf was incredibly impressed. This place stacked up well against LA ramen, and did a good job at satisfying a craving for Japanese ramen (nothing in the US really comes close). 

All in all service was fast, and you'll find tons of Vegan options.
author: Hong T.

description:
Came around 1PM on the day of the Cherry Blossom festival and was pleased to see the line move so quickly! We got seated within five minutes (although I think we came at a very lucky time). 

Hinodeya Ramen Bar is the underrated Marufuku of Japantown. The ramen is just as good, but without the monstrous lines. The service is fast , and there's quite a bit of space for a ramen joint. I came here with a party of 7 and we asked if we could split up to expedite waiting. They were very accepting of this request and promptly notified us as soon as two tables relatively close to one another were available. This was super appreciated.

I ordered the Vegan ramen - it was ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS. I have NO idea how the broth was SO creamy, considering that vegan diets are plant-based. It was both rich and flavourful and I was thoroughly impressed... didn't know vegetables could pack such flavour! My friend on the other hand ordered the House special and was disappointed - he said the last time he came, the house tonkotsu was much much better. Perhaps there's inconsistency with the ramen quality here.

They even give you take out containers if you cannot finish :) Bonus!

Overall, I was very pleased with Hinodeya ramen and would come back.
author: Monica X.

description:
Quick, delicious, friendly. What more could you ask for from a restaurant? We were greeted and seated right away at 9pm on a Thursday evening. I ordered the house ramen and it came out very promptly. The brother was sooo good and I loved the noodles. Tasty egg and good portion of meat as well. Highly recommend. 

We parked for free across the street from the plaza.
author: Emma W.

description:
Pretty good ramen, but its expensive for the size! I love this area, but it always seems to be super crowded. Definitely plan to wait for a bit (here or anywhere around). 

Broth is very savory and rich. The quality and flavor of the food is very good, but leaves me hungry.

Ambiance: 4/5
Food: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Overall experience: 4/5
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Saw the stellar reviews and thought I should give this place a try as well. It was amazing. The service was great, no complaints. The ramen was phenomenal, it was almost like the broth was prepped for weeks before serving it was so good. The egg at the bottom of the bowl was full of broth flavor and was delicious as well. Overall, it was the best ramen I've ever had so far. I will be coming back!
author: Christian C.

description: Definitely one of the best ramen in town. It's soup base is quite different from other stores. Fried oyster is excellent. The bruised wings are a little over cooked. Although the meat falls off the bones, the meat is not tender.
author: Stink C.

description:
Hinode-ya or hinode-nah was the question I sought to answer on a lazy Sunday afternoon. Previously, I had gone to Marafuku (which was exceedingly good but more overhyped than a dumb streetwear brand) and then Ramen Underground (which wasn't as much) in SF so my expectations were all over the page like my hormones in sixth grade. 

Well, I found my answer when the sinewy yet light dashi broth dabbled itself on my tongue. Ramen is at its peak when its either creamy to the point where it resembles your boss' half and half, or when it's as transparent as a pond. We ordered the Hinodeya classic dashi ramen. The meal was immaculate. So good. Would come back here and camp out on the streets for this ramen. Is it just me or things that are divvied into smaller portions taste better than large-volume dishes? Would have appreciated a bigger portion size.
author: Celena C.

description:
This ramen shop is pretty A-OK though it has its high points. We came by on a Sunday at 6 and had almost no wait for a party of two, although it was busy the entire time and there were periods where there was a line.

First off, we ordered the Takowasa ($5) as an appetizer. It had a very good wasabi taste and was spicy but not overpowering. Most of the pieces were tender, although a small percentage was too chewy. That's octopus for you though, so this dish was a success.

Then, the ramen. Overall it was fine but a little uneven. I ordered the Hamaguri Ramen (Limited Clam Ramen, $18). The clams were really good and generous, and props for being very clean meaning no residual grit or shell pieces floating around. But it had literally no other toppings beyond the bare minimum (seaweed and some onions.) The broth was light and clear, but flavorful. The noodles though sadly, needed help. I appreciate that they were whole wheat, but the consistency was odd and they didn't have the "spring" that ramen should have...it honestly felt and tasted more like packaged udon. 

The other bowl we got was the Hinodeya Ramen ($14), because we might as well order the house ramen. This one was more like a classic ramen, with pork chashu, bamboo, and a soft boiled egg. Like the clam ramen, the toppings were good and in this case more plentiful. But they used the same (or similar) broth, which didn't quite work as well for a classic pork ramen as it did for the seafood one...it was too light and a bit fishy to stand up to the chashu. The noodles were the same with the same issues too.

They did have interesting condiments. One jar had an "umami paste" made with bonito and scallop powder, and another had crispy onions and garlic in chili oil. They did help add more depth to the broth, esp. for the Hinodeya Ramen.

Overall it gets about 3.5 stars, but I'm rounding it down to three because it's a tad overpriced. I'd come back though and could see this place being really good if they tighten up their noodles and make some of their touches a bit less awkward (i.e. make a more meat-friendly blend of broth for the Hinodeya Ramen, use a less messy part of the chicken than the wing for the tori paitan ramen.)
author: David A.

description:
I love it yet I'm not sure if I'm in love it. 

The menu is pretty simple. We ended up going with 2 house ramens, an appetizer, and a beer.  

My favorite kind of ramen is more in the traditional tonkatsu style, but their broth did not disappoint. It tastes homemade. Like clear, rich, chicken broth. It was not salty, you could taste that someone spent time on it. The noodles were cooked perfectly. Just the right amount of chewy. The ramen also comes with half an egg, chashu, and bamboo shoots. 

Have to gripe about the egg. It had no flavor and didn't really add anything to the dish. Chashu was yummy. Bamboo shoots were well flavored. 

We also ordered the stewed chicken wings as a starter with our beer. They have Asahi on tap here. The wings were flavorful but meh. I only say meh bc of the texture. They were fall off the bone and had great flavor, but the texture was mushy. I've had similar style of wings were they were flavorful but still crisp. 

We came in a Thursday night around 6:30 and there was no wait.
author: Junella T.

description:
I've walked by here on weekends and seen the line crazy long. I was ecstatic to be able to come in with no wait at all. So, I'd recommend coming in closer to opening time on a weekday.

I ordered the Aburi Chashu which was really good. Had a nice char so created a slight crisp on the exterior of the meat.

Now... if you are planning on getting the Hinodeya Ramen, I'd suggest trying a different appetizer because the Chashu in the soup is similar to the Aburi.

The Hinodeya ramen was amazzzzzing. The noodles had a nice bite and a bit on the thicker side, just how I like. The dashi broth was very flavorful. Topped off with a perfect soft boiled egg. Yum!!

Service was great. Someone was always available to help whenever I needed. They greet and say good bye very loudly in Japanese, just like ippudo! So fun!
author: Mary R.

description:
I would say Hinodeya is up there on my list of go-to ramen places in SF. We checked out Hinodeya after seeing the long wait at Marafuku. We waited maybe 20mins tops and were seated at our own table (there are communal tables available as well). 

We shared the Aburi Chashu - flame torched pork belly garnished with green onions and sriracha, delicious. Karaage - a must try for me at any ramen restaurant and Hinodeya's version was one of the better versions I've had in SF. I had a bowl of the Hinodeya Ramen - dashi style soup with chashu pork, menma, soft boiled egg, and toasted sesame seeds. I haven't had too many dashi style soups and I'd have to say that it's one of my new favorites. I appreciate the firmness of the noodles and the details of the broth - the toasted sesame seeds add a nice additional flavor to the broth. 

Overall great food, great service, and a shorter wait than other places. A win-win in my mind.
author: Elaine N.

description:
As my ramen journey continues, I headed to San Francisco's Japantown to explore more ramen restaurants, so I landed here at this decades old established restaurant called, "Hinodeya Ramen Bar." Hinodeya Ramen serves the customers of all ages to taste their authentic and spell-bounding ramen noodles and eatable tapas every 365 days a year! The atmosphere is very warming and elegant as I welcomed there. The concept is very modern and contemporary with the original Japanese heritage twist where exotic wooden chandeliers hanging on the ceiling and warm ambiance of interior lights illuminates the visitors/

The employees here from servers and cookers are doing an excellent job for making the customers like me a remarkable and exquisite service! No cons!

Now onto the food! On 2/24/2018 before the doors opened, I ordered the original house ramen noodle soup aka. the Hinodeya Ramen. It contains the original Japanese made dashi soup with whole wheat ramen noodles, two chashu pork, menma (bamboo shoots), soft cooked boiled egg (half cut), a dried seasoned seaweed, green onions, red pepper sliced garnish & sprinkled with sesame seeds. As I ate it, that ramen tasted flawless and  convincing! Perfectly fresh and bold than any ramen noodles elsewhere! The broth was very rich and flavorful which I did felt the dashi taste! The noodles were prepared and boiled for perfection which I can bite the noodles easily. The rest of the toppings in this soup were magnificent and naturally delicious. From chashu pork to garnishes, everything here was wonderful all thanks to the balance of seasonings and sauces. Overall, a great ramen meal for lunch break!

Parking at Hinodeya Ramen Bar can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street parking nor the parking garage if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, Hinodeya Ramen Bar is the finest and the most outstanding Japanese ramen restaurant that I've ever visited. Perfect for friends, family and co-workers gathering. A well received. My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description:
Marufuku had a line at least 30 deep before opening, so we came to Hinodeya instead. I hadn't been to Japantown for ramen since before both places opened, so I was looking forward to comparing them to my already favorites, Yamadaya and Waraku.

Although the house ramen may seem like the signature, I actually think the tori paitan is the star at Hinodeya. The broth is thick and rich, full of chicken flavor. And what I love about Hinodeya is the two kinds of "salts" they have on the side for you to add to your ramen. I like the garlic chili one. You're going to add a lot, because in the beginning, you're not going to taste it. But as you get down more into the broth, the chili will start revealing itself. The flavor slowly changes with more garlic and chili flavor. I really enjoyed that progression of flavors. Highly recommend!
author: Sherry L.

description:
I'd like to give them 4/5 stars because I mostly enjoyed their ramen, but the service and cleanliness of the restaurant really made me feel uncomfortable here.
When you look very closely,  beyond just the food, you'll see very little attention being paid to both cleanliness (hence, their 79 health score) and service.

Service: When I entered, I waited about 5 minutes before I was even acknowledged. Waitresses were running back and forth, but no one even acknowledged my presence. Once seated, though, I felt very rushed. Barely giving me any time to look over the menu, the waitress who could care less about seating me earlier, suddenly wanted to immediately take my order (probably because they were close to closing). Throughout my lunch, she was polite, but not at all helpful. Never once refilled my water glass, even though it had been clearly empty during most of my time there. Felt like I was inside a typical Chinatown establishment.

Sanitation:  I noticed their 79 Health Inspection Score. That translates to a letter grade of "C". Not good; not for something you're actually eating! When I was in the restaurant, I saw how they slacked in this area...The restroom was filthy and they were out of seat covers and barely any toilet paper was left, let alone the filthy floor. If they're not cleaning their public restroom, I'm sure they're not cleaning much in the kitchen, an area we won't even see.

Also, they were seating customers at the bar. However, I chose not to be seated there because I saw a multi-level racks stored there with kitchen items. Why are they storing something like that in the public dining area, which should be  clearly stored in the kitchen? That entire section behind the bar seemed very cluttered, including another rack of cleaning items and multiple garbage cans (see photo). They're probably having an outflow of clutter in the bar because the kitchen is overwhelmed with clutter!

Food:  Got the Hinodeya ramen, which I enjoyed because of the noodles itself. For me, ramen is  made squiggly and al dente, as they've accomplished. I also prefer their light dashi broth compared to  other rich, heavy broths common to most ramen joints.  However, the broth came out just lukewarm. Broth should be pipping hot!

Overall, it's unfortunate, because this restaurant could be so much more, if they just focused on the basics when it comes to cleanliness and service.
author: Lori N.

description: I know Japantown can be overwhelming when it come to Ramen.  I encourage you to explore the streets and if you still can not decide I highly recommend Hinodeya!  Upon entering you bombarded with the warm "Irasshaimase!" greeting followed by the warm smell of Ramen.  The staff is great and the ramen is even better!!!
author: Patrick B.

description:
Good place to go to if you like yummy noodles in a light broth.

I came here with a party of 2 on a Friday night at around 6:30 and wasn't seated until 7:20. The wait definitely felt long considering there weren't many people in front of us. My boyfriend and I both got the house ramen ($14) which came with a dashi broth, ramen noodles, half of an egg, bamboo shoots, two slices of pork and a slice of seaweed. 

The broth of the ramen was clear and super light and savory. They also have an umami paste and some fried garlic/onion with chili oil to add to your ramen. I felt like both really elevated the flavor of the ramen broth without overpowering it. The noodles were thicker than other ramens I've had which nice, but I felt like because the broth was so light, the noodles didn't hold the flavor of the broth very well. The pork didn't really feel like any thing special, it wasnt very melt in your mouth or flavorful, however it was thicker slices than I've had at other places. I loved how the egg was super marinated and perfectly cooked, super tasty!

Overall food was good, staff was friendly, but I think I definitely prefer a thicker, heavier flavored ramen broth.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Really nice place with tasty broth and noodles.  A bit crowded and pricey, but found it worth the wait.

House Hinodeya was good and had some gyoza that match well together.

Service was outstanding and the place was very tidy and clean.

Go here if you are craving ramen!
author: Ernest G.

description: Oh my God, the vegan ramen is INSANELY GOOD. I feel like I died and went to heaven. The vegan appetizers are killer as well -- don't miss out on the green gyoza!!! We went at 5:40, right before this place got REALLY busy. The line grew and grew until it wrapped around the outside of the building. But for us, the wait was short and the food came out immediately. The servers were very gracious and patient as well. I will absolutely come here every time that I visit San Francisco!!!!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
I was thoroughly impressed with this place! Although we had originally came here for another hyped ramen spot in Japan Center and used Hinodeya was our backup plan, we had a pleasant experience. 

Service was great. The host was more than friendly and welcoming. As we entered, all of the workers greeted us in Japanese and big smiles. He elegantly led us to our table and even pulled out my seat for me. The food came out fairly quickly for how busy they were. We also received the check right after we finished eating. We were greeted kindly by the staff as we left. 

Now on to the food.. the house ramen was fantastic. Inside the bowl was filled with chewy whole wheat noodles, 2 pieces of chasu, half a marinated egg, bamboo shoots, and seaweed. The soup was topped off with green onions and plentiful sesame seeds. Firstly, the broth is clear but VERY rich and flavorful. It was a perfectly balance of umami without being overly salty or watery. It felt very light and enjoyable with the noodles. The noodles were unique in that the texture was different than your typical packaged ramen. The thin noodles had some edge to it so it was chewy and light. The chasu was soft and tender. The egg was cooked to a perfect soft boil and a subtle marination. The bamboo shoots were amazing. It had a good crunch and marinated well. They also have a dessert menu which looks really interesting if you like matcha! 

The only thing I could think of that could use improvement are the prices. $14-$16 per bowl of ramen is a bit steep. However, the high quality ingredients and professionalism in the service made our experience worth it. The food didn't make me feel like I just had a heavy bowl of MSG. It was actually quite refreshing after a chilly day in SF. 

Pro tip: they serve vegan ramen! 

Highly recommend trying this place at least once!
author: Sandra N.

description:
This place is decent! I think I prefer the ramen at Menshou; however, given the fact that we didn't have to wait here (as opposed to like a 1-2 hour wait at Menshou), my friend and I enjoyed the food here. 

The ramen was good/average, definitely not the best I've tried. We also ordered some sort of potato fries - I think it was a little too pricey given the fact that it was just a chunk of potato. But the sauce that came with it was good and made up for it.
author: Angelina H.

description:
I wish they have a store in South California, too bad for me.  I have to drive to SF for a good ramen
The noodles is different then here, I think they make to own noodles.  The broth they have is so delicious not too oily and too salty. That was perfect
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Best ramen I had so far!! thank you yelp!!
the unami sauce is sooo good unfortunately not for sell
the matcha deserts are very good too!
Highly recommanded authentic Japanese ramen :)
author: Isabelle Z.

description: I ordered the vegan ramen and had no idea what to expect. It wasn't just good for vegan ramen, it was just incredibly delicious. Creamy broth but not too rich and the spinach noodles were perfectly chewy, some of the best ramen noodles I've ever had. Mmmm, I'm craving it as I write this review.
author: Anne P.

description:
I stumbled across Hinodeya Ramen Bar by chance- I was trying to go to Mensho, but didn't realize they were close for the day. I am so glad they were closed because Hinodeyo is deeelicious!

The waiting experience is a little odd, there's no real line or list to put your name down- just a gentleman who remembers you in order. Luckily, his memory seems to be pretty decent and there were no mix ups. Be prepared to wait out in the San Francisco cold air for a little bit since the waiting area is pretty small. 

My friend and I both ordered the regular ramen- so delicious. The broth was so unique, it's so flavorful and sweet! Their noodles had the perfect texture and I happily slurped up the entire bowl. 

Hinodeya Ramen really surprised me in the most pleasant way possible. What a gem in Japantown and I cannot wait to come back!
author: Tiffany U.

description:
I've come here multiple times.  I think Ramen Yamadaya across the street is actually better. I would choose them over Hinodeya any day.  Both have ramen around $15 bucks which I think is too much for ramen.  Below Ramen Yamadaya is ramen tanpopo which is the worst.

House ramen: this was the last ramen I had here.  It was good.  My biggest complaint is the quality of the cha shiu.  The pork tastes so old.  They really need to buy fresh pork more regularly because it was really off putting especially since it's the only meat in that bowl. 

TL;DR: The cha shiu pork tastes old. The need more fresh meat. Ramen Yamadaya across the street is better. Both have ramen about 15 bucks which I think is too much. Ramen tanpop is below Ramen Yamadaya and is the worst of the three.
author: Jon P.

description: Located in the middle of Japantown. If you're willing to stand in line and wait for the food, it's definitely worth it. On this visit I chose to have the vegan ramen which had a soup base of sesame, soy milk with spinach noodles. It was a creamy almost sweet broth then your typical ramen base. It had a variety of vegetables in it. I got mine with a side of chicken in it. It was really good. My son ordered the house ramen which came with pork and a softly cooked egg amongst a variety of vegetables. Overall it was really good and I would go back. We washed it all down with the house sake which was a definite plus!
author: Debbie K.

description:
After spending the majority of my day traveling around SF with my family, I found Hinodeya to be the perfect dinner meal to end a day of adventure.
My family and I ordered the chicken karaage appetizer and four hinodeya ramens (as suggested by many yelpers). Both were very hearty and a comfort from a long day, though they are both on the pricey side. 

Chicken Karaage (5 pc for $8) - while tasty, the appetizer wasn't anything special. It came with a side of matcha salt (though you can't taste any matcha) and came nice and fresh! My personal tip is to save a few pieces so you can put it in your ramen!

Hinodeya Ramen ($15) - the one thing you'll notice about the food here is that it's not that rich. The broth in the ramen was quite unusual as it had a consistency similar to that of pho and not the richness that typical ramen has. I read the reviews and already prepared for that so I enjoyed it, but make sure that if you decide to come that you don't expect a super rich broth! Despite how thin the broth felt, I loved how chewy the ramen noodles were and the whole meal felt very refreshing. There are also some great condiments on the side that you can add to spice up your ramen the way you'd like! 

Finally, as a little bonus I thought it was super sweet that they give out little paper cranes with your receipt! It may be small but it's such a genuine sentiment of time taken for their customers!
author: Christopher K.

description:
Pretty good ramen in the shopping plaza of Japantown. Came here on a Saturday at 12:30 for lunch and had to wait less than 5 minutes for a table for two. I was prepared to wait for way longer, since the nearby Marufuku Ramen always has at least a 30 min wait. 

Hidoneya is clean, and you're greeted in Japanese by the staff and chefs as you enter. My friend and I shared a small communal table with two other parties, but there's ample private seating as well. 

We both got the House Ramen (Hidoneya). The noodles were chewy and thick, and the egg was perfectly poached. The char siu was a little tough, but still good nonetheless. I added the chili garlic onion, but be careful since that stuff is pretty strong! Definitely underestimated how spicy a few spoonfuls could be. 

Quick service, nice servers - overall a good experience and I'll be back!
author: Victoria L.

description:
I feel that they made ramen carefully. I ordered a house ramen and chicken ramen. 

The deep soup tasted good. House Ramen was clams and seafood base soup, but chicken ramen was more delicious to me because I was sensitive to seafood taste.

 The materials such as noodles and bamboo are definitely compared to other ramen dishes at other restaurants. It would be nice to ask them to leave out the green onions if you don't like it. 

I went to here at one o'clock, but I ate without waiting. The servers were friendly, the interior was very impressive.
author: Da Won L.

description: This is a popular ramen spot with good reason...it's really good! I came here with a friend a couple months ago during a trip to Japantown. We came in for a really late lunch and there was virtually no wait. I heard this is not normal and that there is usually a line that wraps around the front...yay for us. We both ordered the Hinodeya Ramen and a glass of yuzu soda. They were so good! The broth was really flavorful and the yuzu soda was tart and refreshing. It was a perfect lunch. The service was also speedy. It's not my absolute favorite spot for ramen, but it's definitely in my top 3. I highly recommend Hinodeya if you're in the area.
author: Rosalie N.

description:
My favorite ramen spot in Japantown! Everyone I brought here has also enjoyed the ramen. My favorite is the vegan ramen which is delicious and savory. My boyfriend really liked the Hinodeya ramen. The chicken karaage and gyoza are also very good. Their barley tea and green tea are very delicious too. Service is friendly and quick. Can't wait to come back for more!

Pro Tip: Go early since there is often a line to get in, but it moves pretty quickly.
author: Jacqui C.

description:
I've been looking for a good clear and light dashi broth based ramen for quite some time now, and Hinodeya serves exactly that with their amazing house ramen. 2 thumbs up.

(I also got the karaage, which was subpar. But that's okay because the ramen was soooo good.)
author: Josh L.

description:
Had enough of the rich, decadent foods this holiday season, but don't want to give up that ramen life?

Hinodeya is your answer. 

Admittedly, I'm more of a tonkotsu broth fanatic, but I really like the different style that this ramen bar specializes in. The dashi broth is light in taste, but not bland. Their noodles have a nice chew to it. If you read the yelp reviews, the Tori Paitan gets a huge following but I can honestly say, that Mensho's Tori Paitan is TOPS. 

Hinodeya Ramen ($14) has whole wheat noodles, chasu pork (too fatty), menma, perfect soft egg and other toppings. My husband liked the Shoyu veggie ramen ($15) and it looked so amazing! with the acorn squash and kale, it's a great departure from the usual. My friend liked her vegan ramen as well. 

If you come with a large group, get the flame torched pork belly! It was melt in your mouth delish. I found the kaarage too bland so use the matcha salt it came with. 

Service is really friendly and for a group of 7, we only waited 20 minutes. Having a sister ramen restaurant in the Land of the Rising Sun gives Hinodeya serious street cred, so if you want to experience a lighter stye broth, I highly recommend it.
author: Janice C.

description:
My wife and I's first time ever having authentic ramen and  we were more than impressed! We arrived at 4:50 and waited for the doors to open. At 5:00 we were the third table seated and were promptly brought warm hand and face towels which was much appreciated after standing in the cool SF wind. We ordered gyoza to share and each a different bowl of ramen. The food came out very quickly and was nothing short of amazing. One of our servers recommended adding the garlic/chili oil seasoning and it added the perfect amount of heat. The origami and I love Doshi sticker was a nice touch at the end of the email as well

All in all we were out of the restaurant by 5:30 with full bellies, smiles on our faces, and warmth in our soul
author: Brenden S.

description:
There are few things more satisfying than a bowl of ramen after a morning at the spa. I walked in and sat at the bar while in a daze from relaxation. I looked like an absolute mess but didn't care. I took a seat at the bar and ordered the Hinodeya (House) Ramen off the menu. It's a limited menu, but it has everything you'd need.

The warmth of the broth and flavors of the ramen put me into more of a trance. It's like I was meditating while eating. Weirdest thing ever. I noticed people sitting down and getting up to leave around me. I started doing crossword puzzles on my phone to bring me back to reality. My experience at Hinodeya was very smooth in terms of food and customer service. I'd love to come back here again, at least as a ritual after every spa visit!

EDIT: Make sure to get the shishito peppers! These are some of the best I've ever had. The "dashi soy glaze" is addicting.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Ramen and San Francisco hasn't been a love connection so far. Lots of mediocre places, especially (and ironically) around Japantown. Things started to change with the arrival of Orenchi on Valencia in the Mission, and things now really seem to pick up - at least I believe that after paying Hinodeya a visit.

I was warned about a 20+ minute wait (shows you how San Francisco craves ramen!) but when we showed up on a Tuesday night around 6pm only one couple was ahead of us.

From the menu we tried a few starters (Shishito Peppers $5, Edamame $4, Takowasa $5), and especially the juicy Kara-Age ($8) was a hit.

For the ramen you can choose between

House Ramen
Clam Ramen
Chicken Ramen
Vegan Ramen

and add topics like extra egg, mushroom, pork etc. for an additional fee.

My vegan ramen was perfectly balanced and very tasty, definitely makes me come back. Also the service was top notch and friendly.

I did a small lemonade at the end during the raffle, but trust me, this review is unbiased. Ha.
author: Sebastian F.

description: It's okay. Noodles are nice and t h i c c just the way I like them with lots of chew, but the broth was way too salty. The gyoza was also $7 for 5 but it sorta just tastes like the stuff I can get frozen at a supermarket. Decent portion of noodles, however, so that's nice.
author: Calvin Z.

description:
Hinodeya is definitely one of my favorite spots for ramen! The line can get long during "peak" times, whatever that means; every time I have been I've had to wait. But not too long they crank out the ramen pretty quickly for the volume. 

I always get the hinodeya special ramen and the broth is so good I don't even feel the need to add chili oil or any additives. I do like to add kale as just a bonus. Also, for you vegans out there the vegan ramen is legit! The broth is amazing and even the most carnivorous person (probably me) has seriously considered ordering it. They put a lovely portabello in the vegan ramen and it is cooked to perfection. 

They have beer and a great sake selection. I always opt for the matcha green tea pot though. All in all a great meal and worth the wait and trek to Japantown!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
During our day in Japantown, my mom and I were on the search for some good ramen. I had bookmarked a few places on Yelp that offered a vegetarian/vegan ramen option, and Hinodeya was one of them. While walking to Benkyodo to buy fresh mochi, we passed by Hinodeya and decided to give it a try. We went in at 2:15 (closing time is 2:30) and they were more than happy to serve us.

The interior of the restaurant was clean and modern looking. Service was great - both our servers were friendly, polite, and efficient. The servers and chefs greeted and said goodbye to us in Japanese. There were 3 types of ramen. I went with the zen ramen (their vegetarian/vegan option), while my mom went with the Hinodeya (house) ramen. 

The zen ramen ($15) came with a light both, shiitake mushroom, fried kale, carrot, dried seaweed, and goji berries. Presentation was beautiful. The ramen noodles were nice and chewy, with a bit of pull. The mushroom was huge and soaked up a lot of flavor. The fried kale was also very flavorful, but it was extremely, extremely oily. You could squeeze a whole tablespoon of oil out of 1 piece of kale. I wish they would have drained it a bit before tossing it into the ramen. That was probably my only issue with the dish because overall, it was a well-composed bowl of vegan ramen. 

Portion size was pretty small, considering the bowl was $15, which is more expensive than a lot of other ramen places. However, I could taste the quality of the ingredients and the authenticity of the dish.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Definitely a great place for ramen!

At first I wasn't sure if Hinodeya was worth waiting in line for. I came early around 6pm and there was already a decent line forming. It took me about 20 minutes to get in for a spot for 1 person!

I had the House ramen, which uses only Dashi broth (the most basic of broths). This is one of those broths that can either be tasteless of tiring on the palate, and I am happy to say that they nailed it just perfectly. It was light, yet flavourful. I like the thick pieces of pork belly, and the soft boiled egg. The wheat noodles had a nice chewiness to it. Overall very delish!

Also had the karaage with the matcha salt. I didn't think the matcha salt tasted of anything other than salt, but the karaage itself is good, albeit a bit pricey. I would probably not order it for my next visit.

Overall, a fan!
author: Anthony S.

description:
I've tried several Ramen places around and this is the only one that I didn't like. Prob just not my taste. The cheese tasted great but the chicken Karage taste hard and no flavor.
The ramen are overpriced compared to Mukufu across street which are much more tasty. 
The broth was bland, but prob others might love it. For two people we left the door with two side dishes and ramen for $60 including tips. 
Sure will not return
author: TTrraaccYY H.

description:
Someone had told me to come here and try their vegan ramen because it was delish and their fav. Fast forward a couple weeks and we found ourselves here for dinner on a weekend. There is a line out the door usually but it wasn't too bad.

The staff was friendly and our food came out pretty quickly. We ordered some potatoes for our appetizer and I thought it was pretty tasty. I really really enjoyed it. 

Our vegan ramens came out shortly after and it was piping hot! I understand it's supposed to be hot but after blowing it for a while, it still burned my whole mouth off. Now, I personally don't prefer my ramen sweet. I like my ramen a tad bit spicy, garlicky and definitely more on the savory side. That being said, I don't agree with a lot of people saying it's the best ramen they've ever had. Everything was probably ruined for us because we sat in the bar and could see that the "chefs" were microwaving EVERYTHING! That was a bummmer. Nothing fresh comes out of that kitchen unfortunately.
author: Reese E.

description:
One of my other favorite ramen places in SF.  There's usually a line but it's worth it!  Customer service is great and their side dishes are also yummy! 
Ordered: hinodeya ramen ($14), zen ramen ($14), gyoza ($7), chicken karaage  ($8), shishito peppers ($5)
author: Mikayla M.

description: Hinodeya was solid (3.5-4 star range), it didn't have the WOW factor but I did appreciate the simple broth. I took my parents here and they seemed to enjoy the meal quite a bit. Although I certainly wouldn't line up to eat ramen at this joint since I prefer my broth to have more flavor.
author: Denise L.

description:
This place is a busy late night spot in Japantown that serves Ramen. Their service is pretty good. But, their food is amazing. They have a GREAT vegan friendly menu and awesome drinks. 

I ordered the Crispy Yams and the Japanese Sansho Ale. So amazing

9/10 - recommend
author: Mere S.

description:
Came here after being the 52nd party for Marafuku Ramen (what how is that possible!) Internally, I calculated the wait time to be four hours, but the hostess said over an hour, which was very doubtful. I counted 15 tables. 

Anyways, my friend and I went to Hinodeya after being deterred by the long long line at Marafuku. We were referred to this place before, and it did not let us down. 

When we arrived at Hinodeya on Sunday around 1PM, there were only a couple parties ahead of us, so we were seated within five minutes. There is no sign in sheet, but it works for them. My friend and I both ordered the House Ramen, which arrived in a little while. And can I just say, it was amazing?! 
It is the perfect bay area ramen in my eyes. Springy noodles, clear and soothing broth. My friend particularly loved the broth as we had never had dashi ramen before. She declared the ramen would be perfect if only it was raining. She also praised the menma heavily. Price for house ramen was $14, and was well worth the price. She liked dachi ramen more than the usual ramen at Marafuku. 

I really am glad I was able to try this, even though our original plan was to go to Marafuku.
author: Jessica H.

description:
This is my all time favorite ramen spot in SF for many reasons (1) the line is tolerable and often, there is no wait at all; (2) the service is decent as compared with other ramen establishments; (3) the decor and atmosphere are quite unique - I love the unique wood lighting; (4) the menu is simple with just a few items done extremely well but not so few that you are left wishing it could be more diverse; and (5) last, and last for a reason- the long anticipated remarks on ramen...

The vegan ramen is absolutely hands down the most perfect bowl of ramen in SF!!! First, the spinach noodles are cooked to the right chewy consistency. Second, the broth is a beautiful creamy savory umami of soy milk, sesame, and magic. Third, the handmade tofu that is soft on the inside and crisp on the outside is ever so well balanced with the vegetables and sesame undertone in every bite. Last, that crispy piece of kale finished on top is the last little (but truly significant) touch, making this bowl my absolute favorite - the bowl of ramen that has filled my stomach with goodness when it was growling in anger; and filled my heart with joy when it has been broken.
author: Vivienne K.

description: If you're looking for a bowl of ramen outside of the Japan Center mall, walk a block to Hinodeya for the classic bowl of ramen. In the Hinodeya (house) ramen the soft boiled egg is cooked to perfection with a silky soft yolk. The chashu pork is soft, delicious and has a delicate texture even though it's pork. The bamboo shoots are a great addition for flavor and texture. Other ramen houses may offer more flavorful or different types of ramen but for the classic bowl that satisfies the ramen craving, Hinodeya hits the nail on the head.
author: Rey L.

description:
Came here for a late lunch and didn't have to wait at all to get seated. I ordered the Tokyo Style Ramen (with soup) and didn't have to wait long at all to get my ramen. On top of that, I also ordered the chashu pork add-on as well.

The ramen itself was pretty good but I thought that the soup was a little bit too thick for my taste and also wasn't a huge fan of the peanut-flavor. However, dipping the chashu pork into it was amazing. The soup complimented the taste of the chashu pork extremely well and I think that was probably my favorite part of the meal. 

Service was great. Immediately got seated by some nice waitress and never had a problem with getting her attention when we needed something. Interior was also really nice and clean. 

Overall, great place to dine at but if you're more into what I guess "regular" ramen tastes like, this may not be the best fit for you. This place is sort of like a Chinese-Japanese ramen fusion place (which is cool as well :-) ).

Taste: 4/5
Service: 5/5
Interior: 5/5
author: Timothy H.

description:
Okay, let's get right to it - I was expecting/hoping for so much more.  After my awesome meals at Mensho, Nojo Ramen Tavern, and nearby Marufuku Ramen, I couldn't help but think that the party would keep going here.  Between their successful location in Tokyo, as well their founder's legit resume, Hinodeya has some serious street (ramen?) cred to their name!  Which, sadly, only makes this all the more disappointing...

Located on the cobblestone-ish street across from the Peace Plaza in Japantown, Hinodeya sits in Sushi Aka Tombo's old space...and right across from two other ramen joints - Yamadaya  (pretty solid) and Tanpopo (not nearly as good as it used to be, despite my now outdated 5-star review).  By comparison though, Hinodeya is a bit more interesting.  Not only did they do a nice job of renovating the space, but their selection of dashi ramens (albeit limited) are rather appealing.

-- KARAAGE - Fried Juicy Boneless, Cage-Free Organic Chicken...$8
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hinodeya-ramen-bar-san-francisco?select=fYY5jivsxAkoXR8gswrTEw)
I know it's all about the ramen here, but even still...this was super disappointing.  While each piece had just the right amount of batter to it, in addition to being well cooked, the chicken was super bland.  An aioli would've helped, but even just more seasoning (probably) would've done the trick.  Pass.

-- HINODEYA RAMEN with Traditional Japanese Dashi-Style Soup & Whole Wheat Noodles, Chashu Pork, Menma, Soft Cooked Marinated Egg, Dried Seaweed, and Green Onion...$14
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hinodeya-ramen-bar-san-francisco?select=BxE2d1mRw-dNqtGAmJU5uw)
At a glance, this looked great.  The chashu was tender and just slightly fatty, the soft boiled egg was cooked perfectly, and the noodles were fine.  At the same time, the bowl left me wanting; the portion felt a little light and the broth was more oily than flavorful.  Definitely had more than my fill of green onions and menma though, thanks to the overwhelming amount they threw in...

Given how I usually opt for tonkotsu soup bases, it wouldn't be entirely fair to directly compare Hinodeya and their dashi broth to some of my favorite spots.  However, it certainly wouldn't be unreasonable to say Hinodeya's ramen missed the mark for me.  Toss in how there's usually a wait (only about 20 mins or so, but still) and I really don't have much of a reason to come back.  If I'm going to stand around, or even be around Japantown for ramen, I might as well hit up the amazing Marufuku nearby or the likes of Waraku and Yamadaya for something quick.

TWO AND A HALF STARS rounded up.
author: Mike L.

description: It seemed like everyone who couldn't get into Marafuku came here. But it was good..good enough to be a first option actually. I have to take a star off if the noodles are not hand-made in-house . Also, I wasn't a big fan of the broth here-- a bit too thin for my liking, but overall ramen was good! Sugoi
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
When the weather begins to become slightly chilly, it's perfect ramen weather! Rich suggested we go to Japantown before the Legion of Honor so we wandered a little before heading to Hinodeya.  Located a block from the Japan Center, there was a line in front of us when we arrived around 11:30 am on a Saturday. We waited for about 15-20 minutes before being led into the back of the restaurant.

I ordered the barley tea and asked for water as well. Rich and I decided to both order the Hinodeya Ramen ($14 house ramen).  It comes in a traditional Japanese dashi style soup with whole wheat noodles soup made from bonito, kombu, and scallops.  The toppings are chasu pork, menma, soft cooked marinated half egg, dried seaweed and green onion.

We were quickly served. The ramen was nice and chewy, the broth was rich and not salty.  The chasu pork was thinly cut and very tender. The meal was filling but I could have done with a little more of the noodles to make the meal complete.

Service was excellent as the servers would pop by to look in to see if anything was needed.  There is one gender neutral restroom which was clean.  I would definitely come back again but I would suggest people come early to avoid the noon-time line.
author: Olivia C.

description: Bright clear broth with oodles of flavor paired with a warm, open decor . I ordered the house ramen. It arrived with lots of scallions, bamboo shoots and tender cuts of pork. The noodles were delicate and not the usual gooey starch that can sometimes arrive at other places. The Asahi on tap paired very well with the dish, so if it's not your usual Japanese beer, give it try. I arrived at 2, a little before their lunch seating ended on Friday, so the usual line was a non-issue. A nice little gem in a crowded, usually ho-hum sector of ramen houses.
author: Adam F.

description:
One of the best ramens I've had period- I don't even mind the wait in line, it was that good. 

Venue / service: decor is somewhere between modern style and traditional Japanese izakaya/ramen style; the overall effect is a slightly more upscale version of a homey, comforting place to eat.  We got seated in a little area blocked a bit by little clothes, providing minimal privacy (which you don't really expect in a ramen shop).  This place doesn't take reservations so you will have to be ok standing outside (sometimes in the cold) to eat here; we waited maybe 15-20 min on a weekday night at 8pm.  B/c this place is popular, service is on the quicker side but not to the point you feel rushed; in fact, we were able to casually enjoy our meal, which came out quickly and efficiently.

Food: the best way I can describe the food is light and yet rich and flavorful.  Somehow felt different from all other ramen places (which would leave you super heavy and such). Price overall seemed reasonable too, especially given the portion size of the items.

-- Edamame (izakaya snap peas snack)($4) - simple, lightly salted, not too watery and not overcooked.  

-- Oysters Fried (from Hiroshima Japan)($9) - wish all fried oysters could be like this.  The oyster inside was still soft and juicy and had a great briny, sweet taste without being too oily.  The crispy panko shell was also not super thick and goupy but fine and thin, so that you can still taste the oyster inside.

-- Hinodeya Ramen (House Ramen)(traditional Japanese dashi style soup & whole wheat noodles soup made from bonito,kombu & scallop.
toppings: chashu pork,menma, soft cooked marinade egg,dried seaweed & green onion)($14) - I ordered this with extra menma (+$2).  The ramen noodle is different than expected- thinner and flatter, in a way that reminded me of slightly chewier and wavier Inaniwa udon.  I personally liked how the chashu pork was on the meatier side so it's not fatty (which I'm not a fan of) and added a bit more richness to the bowl.  My oh my is that broth amazing!  The broth is super flavorful without being too oily/fatty and is clear too.  

TLDR: yes, the waiting line can be annoying but this ramen is one of the few that I'd wait in line willingly to have because it is THAT good.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Came here around 1:30pm. Must've just missed the lunch rush because we were seated pretty quickly. Staff greeted us as we were escorted to our seats at the bar. Staff was very friendly and attentive. All of the food came out pretty quickly too. 

We got the Kara-Age and the Hinodeya House Ramen. 

The Kara-Age was delicious! Very crispy and it came with a roasted pepper, not sure what kind it was, a lemon wedge and matcha salt. I love spicy so I went straight for the pepper, but was disappointed that it was only there for show and added nothing to the dish. I've never heard of matcha salt  before, but it was really good. Every place I've been to usually serve Kara-Age with spicy mayo, and I was about to ask for some until I tried the matcha salt. I felt it really enhanced the flavor of the chicken. 

The ramen had a very nice presentation and looked appetizing. Either that or I was just really hungry. The dashi broth was very flavorful! The broth also tasted very clean, and the toppings complemented it very well. The soft boiled egg was almost perfectly cooked, the edge of the yolk was bright yellow, but it was very soft and was delicious. The chashu was on the thinner side, but was not fatty and had good flavor. There was nothing bad about this ramen.

Will definitely be back. I like this place more than marufuku, and it doesn't have the long wait that marufuku always has.
author: James L.

description:
