My husband and I really enjoy ramen. We've been making our way through the newer ramen places that are opening in SF. We last tried the ramen joint inside the J-Town mall which was really delicious. We both really love Dashi so we knew we needed to come here. We got there when they opened and was seated right away. The restaurant is actually very spacious and open with a couple more tables in the back. I liked that it didn't feel cramped. We were given wet towels to wash our hands. We ordered the spicy menma and two bowls of the Hinodeya Ramen. No option for extra noodles. 

Hinodeya Ramen - plenty of noodles, half egg (perfectly cooked as the yolk is soft), 10+ bamboo shoots (we love bamboo shoots), two very soft and only slightly fatty pork slices, and a lot of green onions. The noodles are the thicker kind. I really enjoyed the noodles. They kind of remind me the Chinese style noodles. They give a lot of noodles. The broth was light but full of flavor. I loved the broth but I tend to like food that is lighter. 

I can see myself coming back here again and again. The broth and the ingredients that I love and enjoy eating on a daily basis. The ramen here is unique and very different from the standard ramen joints (pork base) and that makes it difficult to compare. Obviously, there are always food preferences but for their specific dashi style ramen it is a winner. They do it very well, service is amazing (I feel like I am getting service compared to other ramen joints), and the ambiance is nice (can take a date here). 

Two unisex bathrooms in the back (one is behind the door) Uber or public transportation. garage parking is expensive. Street parking may be difficult.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This is not my kind of ramen. The broth is very thin but I thought it was good. The soup had a lot of flavor and it was comforting. I would be begging to go back but I enjoyed it. 

My sister got the fried oysters and thought they were amazing.
author: Tina L.

description: Simple and delicious ramen. The gyozas were amazing as well. They have a good variety of vegetarian and vegan options.
author: Laura F.

description:
Came here for the chicken ramen, house ramen, and fried chicken.

One positive is that the line wasn't that bad. Waited like 10 minutes.

The fried chicken just didn't have any flavor. Sure they give you salt on the side, but it's so fine grained and was just really hard to stick it on. Texture and temperature were good though.

The house ramen had some aftertaste in the broth. Note that this is a seafood broth so it's going to a bit lighter than tonkatsu or any other meat broth. The noodles were good, chasu was meh.

The chicken ramen was really thick and was interesting how they had chicken wings in there. I thought it was a bit too thick and couldn't really enjoy the broth that much.
author: Victor D.

description: We order the house token with shiitake mushrooms and it was amazing! We also ordered spicy edamame to share as an appetizer and it was delicious. The environment was fun and lively. The wait wasn't bad. The line was out the door the entire time we were there, but they have quick, efficient and sweet staff who took care of everyone
author: Alicia D.

description:
YESSS my new fave ramen bar!!! I'm so bummed I only tried this recently on my trip to SF (coming from LA) but I'm also so glad i found this place!
Was actually trying to hit up marafuku but wasnt down for the wait so my cousins and I came here instead but no regrets!!!

I'm actually not a big ramen fan these days bc the broths always tend to be really thick, heavy, oily, and salty but this place isn't like that at all! They do make their broth out of fish (correct me if I'm wrong!) but it's definitely different from all the other places I've tried. It's so tasty without being too much and the noodles are not ur boring stick straight ramen noodles - they're thicker and a little curlier and chewier and I'm kinda in love with that. The portions are filling & it was the perfect spot for lunch! You know imma be back the next time I'm in town! 

Oh also they have those fancy toilets that u find in Japan so bonus points for that LOL
author: Trish P.

description:
Finished all of dashi soup!
If you are originally from Japan, you'll almost cry from joy of finally meeting an authentic light ramen soup deep in dashi. 
There are many stores serving tonkotsu or spicy ramen soup in Bay Area, but no one serves good dashi soup like Hinodeya.

Price is twice as high as Hinodeya in Japan.
author: Sakura A.

description:
The Hinodeya Ramen, the Michelin star ramen:  

This place sets the bar so high that I probably need to take off a star from all of my previous ramen reviews. 

I'm the type of customer that don't mind waiting for the perfect food. A lot of times, good restaurants are so caught up with the long line of customers that they start to skimp the details of their food. Not at Hinodeya.

I had ramen from Tokyo to Kyoto and l can say Hinodeya ramen is comparable to ones I had in Japan. 

First, close your eyes. Take a sip of the Hinodeya broth and you automatically noticed the dimensions of this clear broth. It is so deceiving because it looks clear yet possessed a depth of flavor.

Open your eyes, look at the details of each ingredient and ask yourself why it belongs to this bowl of ramen. The green onions were diced sideways which looks visually better. The menma was different, it was high quality. The chashu pork was perfectly slow cooked, it had the right balance of fat and meat, and still retained the flavor of the seasoning. Lastly, take a second and appreciate the soft cooked egg on how it absorbed the marinade with the almost runny yolk instilled in front of your eyes. Wait, is that red stuff the mighty expensive saffron?!!! At this point, I don't even know what to think. 

I suppose it's time for me to slurp the noodles while I follow up with my spoon of broth. It met my expectations, probably exceeded it. Suddenly the subtle flavor of the sesame lifts the noodles a tiny bit. The noodles were perfectly cooked and drained properly. If you noticed, their noodles were different than other ramen places like they put thought in selectively import the perfect type of noodle to go with their ramen. I begin to lose all self control and couldn't stop eating. 

For a short period of time, I fell in love. It's like a cute girl giving you attention. Like accidentally touching your hand, or was it an accident? I'm head over heels now.
author: Daniel L.

description:
A great ramen place to try out when in Japantown. This place had a line on the weekend, but didn't have a long one on the weekday. We came here for lunch and realized that they have a more limited menu during lunch.  The shishito peppers tasted good...just be careful as some may be hot! The karaage was cooked perfectly and came with some matcha salt. The Tori Paitan here was rich in flavor and was not too dense. It came with braised chicken wings in the broth.  Thit
These wings literally fell off the bones.  My friends had the curry, house ramen, and the Zen ramen (vegan friendly). Everyone was satisfied with their dish. 

The service was good as the waitresses made sure our water glasses were filled up.
author: Charlie T.

description:
Hinodeya Ramen Bar is a great, smaller spot located right in Japantown. A friend and I came in late on a Friday night with about a 15 minute wait. Be prepared to potentially sit next to strangers at a larger size table if it's crowded. I didn't mind but others may.

For food, I got the house ramen, and the pork was very flavorful! If you have the chance, try the fried oysters too. Service was fine, but the menu felt a bit small and limiting for those who want lots of variety. If I'm in the area, I wouldn't hesitate to return and try out a new ramen!
author: Brandon S.

description:
This place is very traditional Japanese. Their ramen is a Kombu base which I like because it has a very light taste to it. Definitely will be one of my go to places for ramen in the City after looking for so long. 

Chairs were slightly uncomfortable. We had a booth style setting with no backing and no cushion on the wooden bench. 

Karage (Japanese fried chicken) is very good especially paired with their matcha salt. I asked them what it was made of and my answer? Match and salt LOL. 

We also ordered black sesame ice cream and a creme brûlée. Some of the desserts weren't available because he pastry chef was on vacation. I only ate the black sesame seed. It was a nice nutty and toasty flavor to it which can be over done sometime in other places.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
Not bad for a ramen spot in jtown. The wait time on a Sunday around noon took probably 20-30 minutes for us to get our seats. Pretty good ramen. We ordered the normal hinodeya house ramen and the chicken karaage. The chicken karaage came with a matcha salt. It ended up being too salty for me and my boyfriend. The ramen on the other hand was very delicious and had a bunch of seasonings that you could add to it. 

Staff was friendly and we were lucky enough to find parking on the street.
author: Heather I.

description:
My favorite ramen spot in SF (for the broth, ramen noodles and GARLIC CHILI OIL...oh and the chicken karaage with the MATCHA SALT. I'm drooling), but be prepared to wait or door-bust before opening! 

I had a hard time deciding how many stars to grant this place, because I've had some pretty rough experiences of waiting in this line even when I thought I was going during "off-hours". The staff is great and super responsive, and they get your ramen out to you super quick! However, I do think more could be done by the staff to ensure that customers aren't overstaying their welcome and taking their time even after they've paid their bills. It's incredibly rude seeing parties sitting at their tables chatting for an extra hour after they've finished, holding up the line even more. It'd be great to have the Hinodeya staff be more assertive about establishing boundaries and making sure customers are aware that once they've finished up, it's time to let space for the next parties to come in. 

Obviously I keep coming back here because the ramen is delicious and it's hyped for a reason!
author: Jazzica D.

description:
Got here right at opening on a sunday night so there wasn't a wait, but a hour later, there was a line forming at the door.

Ordered the house ramen and the kara-age with the matcha powder. The kara-age was pretty good and the matcha powder was interesting. It gave a very slight green tea flavor to the chicken and I'm a sucker for anything with green tea. The ramen was decent, not the best I've ever had. I feel like it wasn't flavorful enough. Didn't like the type of noodles they served the ramen with- it's more thick. But pretty solid place for ramen.
author: Jenny J.

description:
Dashi & Umami is thrown around in the industry like Costco samples on a Sunday morning. 

Hinodeya ramen gets it. They bring out the full potential of their ingredients: konbu (dried sea kelp) and katsuo bushi (shaved skip jack) into a delicate broth as their base. Combine that with al dente noodles with every chomp that brings out more flavor. Top it off with soy sauce/Mirin half boiled egg, sliced pork chaashu and green onions sliced diagonally vertical. All parts of this ramen is prepared with care creating a exceptionally well balanced dish.  

20$ for a standard ramen with tip and tax. A little pricey compared to Japan but still deserving 5 stars .
author: George T.

description:
Out of two or three ramen places in Japantown, I decided on Hinodeya due to its high rating and one of the mostly reviewed. 

Coming in for lunch time, I believe you're limited to what's available on the menu for that time frame, because there wasn't a lot of options to choose from. Besides ramen they do offer the Dashi Curry. We ended up ordering both ramen specialties. 

"Hinodeya Ramen" ($14). This is considered their House Ramen. On top of the whole wheat noodles is pork, bamboo shoots and a soft egg. "Tori Paitan" ($15). First off, this chicken ramenbowl was just a dollar more. I was disappointed for the two tiny pieces of braised chicken wings, that small add-on looked really sad to me. Also, in the soup is the shitake mushrooms. 

I did like their Dashi broth on both bowls, it's like having miso soup, so it was solid. It wasn't too salty and it does have a mild flavor unless seasonings are added to it. However, the seaweed that sits on the wall of the bowl gives it a fish taste. My overall take on their ramen bowls is that the soup and noodles are good, but It felt like there wasn't much from the small portions served, It's almost like having a large side item order. I wish they could've put in a little more into it, so I can be satisfied in what I've paid for. 

We did get friendly service, and our wait time for seating didn't take long. Under their sweets menu I wanted to try out the Matcha Cappuccino, but it was unavailable. 

Unfortunately, my experience didn't align with the current four star overall rating, but with a few minor adjustments it would move up a needle.
author: Jon B.

description:
Came in on a Saturday around 2PM, so the wait was hardly a wait! We were seated within 10-15 mins. since the restaurant is so spacious inside!

I've never tried "dashi" ramen, so I wasn't sure what to expect! 

I got the Hinodeya House Ramen, which is a dashi style broth. I enjoyed that the broth was a good balance of flavor, not too salty, but also light enough that I didn't feel like I was clogging any arteries or anything while drinking the broth. I don't really care for the type of ramen served here since they reminded me of the thicker noodles from ramen packages. The actual ramen noodle was still good, but not anything exciting for me (I'm one of those firm, thin, ramen noodle type of people I'm sorry).

I tried my friend's Chicken Ramen and surprisingly really enjoyed the creamyness! You'd think chicken ramen sounds super plain, but it was good :)  I might get it next time just to try it and see how it pairs with my noodles since I never get "creamy" type of ramen bases when choosing ramen.

I've had better Chicken Karage elsewhere. Although it was "cool" to have matcha salt paired with the karage, it just tasted like normal salt LOL ...

Fried Oysters were crispy and tasted fine too!

Service was of course on point, decorations, and ambiance of Hinodeya is spacious and well decorated. I would come back here if friends wanted to come. 

Although I would come back to Hinodeya if my friends wanted to come, I would prefer to go to Marafuku in the center of Japan Town because of their firm noodles and chicken karage is much bigger and tastier!

TLDR: Definitely a good ramen experience, especially if you're into dashi soup bases. I'd give this place a shot if you've never tried it before :)
author: Jackie H.

description: So first of all, I heard great reviews about this place so I wanted to try it out. Little did I know I definitely was in for a treat. There was no wait on a friday night around 6 pm which was cool. Employees were friendly and it seemed like a nice atmosphere. I was super excited until the chaos unfolded in my soup. I left very quickly after finding a maggot in my ramen. Unbelievable. I will never be returning. Check your soup before eating if you even think about coming to this place. I had such high hopes too..
author: Patty I.

description: Ramen was good - noodles were firm yet bouncy, dashi/broth deceitfully looked bland but actually was out of this world delicious, pork was tender and delicious.  Service was ehhh - 1) they didn't offer us wet towels in the beginning but they offered them to everyone else at the restaurant, 2) they seated us at a big communal table where we had to share with lots of strangers, and 3) annoyingly they actually packed the table so tightly that it was uncomfortable for us to be there; the restaurant seemed to worry more about profit and getting as many customers as possible than caring for their customers' good experience.  One last complaint is their condiments were soooo bad compared to months ago when I last visited this place.  The umami condiments all clumped up and had a stale texture ewww; and the garlic one had an old, stale smell, double ewww...
author: Kev H.

description: The place wasn't open yet but a line was forming 30 minutes before the dinner hour began. They only have five types of Ramen I chose the traditional one. I was delicious!
author: Emiko T.

description: Best ramen I've had in the city thus far. Super flavorful and the noodles were awesome. There was a bit of a line but it moved fast. I'll be back soon!
author: Kelly G.

description:
The line starts around 4:30 but they don't let people in until 5 and they let people in one group at a time (with what felt like 5-10 min intervals between two groups) so be ready to wait if you want to eat here. 

The interior is nicely furnished. I'm the back, there are semi private spaces for groups of 4. 

This is probably my favorite ramen place in the city. 

We got the Hinodeya Ramen and the Kara*Age. Both are amazing! 

Dashi style, the broth is made of bonito (similar to tuna), kombu (seaweed), and scallop. 

Very subtle scent of the sea. Delicious but doesn't taste high in sodium. It has a rich flavor and yet it is not at all greasy. 

The green onions help make the soup more refreshing. Even the menma (fermented bamboo shoots), which I don't normally like, taste amazing! 

The Kara*Age is nicely done, crispy outside and very tender inside. Be careful it's very hot because it was cooked in very high temperature to make sure of the crispiness. 

The matcha salt is just delightful. It doesn't taste too salty and adds a subtle refreshing flavor to the fried chicken. 

As SF gets cold and rainy, I foresee myself going there a lot in the next few months.
author: Iris H.

description:
Arigato.

It's been a little over a year when I popped my Japan cherry, taking a seven day dream tour. 

My trek to find the best ramen in San Francisco led me here on the advisement of Cherylynn N. (https://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg) (who else?!).  On a recent midweek afternoon, I found time to come here for lunch.  Upon walking in, I noticed that most of the tables were taken and, since I was dining alone, there were ample counter seats which is where I landed.  After parking my bags under my seat, I studied their one page menu of lunch offerings.  Scanning around the other tables was no help as most diners were either done or didn't have food yet.  As a result, here's what I tried: 

Appetizer
1) Hinodeya salad, half portion (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hinodeya-ramen-bar-san-francisco?select=Xer2gSgt6majzjRYecr2zA) - This was a welcome surprise as I didn't expect a salad that was colorful, ingredient and flavor packed too.  There were small pumpkin pieces too.  Would order this again if in a healthy mood.

Main
2) Chicken paitan ramen (https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hinodeya-ramen-bar-san-francisco?select=oU2CoyGJsUU23pXdz1MHEg) - The bowl is modest in size so, if you are starving, you'll likely need to add other things to avoid eating again.  The broth was clear and hearty, but not overly rich.  The wings, well.....  the meat just falls right off the bone on a touch.  Liked the egg, semi runny, and the crunch from the nori.

Service was efficient but not particularly warm.  As more diners arrived, I gathered my pre shopping wares and placed them under my seat.  My water glass was refilled and dirty plates removed when needed.  The lunch scene seems, from reading other reviews, less hectic than dinner and weekend times.  

There was a lunch special rice dish that pulled my strings to order, but, being a ramen place, I stayed the course.  I hope to try that on my next visit and then try their more traditional ramen offering.

That makes at least two more trips here... yes, please.
author: Mike C.

description: Great for vegan, veggie or meat eaters. Fast service usually. Incredibly popular. Reasonably priced. Traditionally served. Will return.
author: Heather L.

description:
Went there for the first time yesterday with my family.  Line was long but it moved fairly quickly. Staff was great, fast, friendly and efficient! However, food was not that great. I ordered the chicken ramen and the hubby ordered the house ramen. Broth in the chicken Ramen was overly salty to the point where I couldn't eat it. The most disappointing part for me was that the ramen didn't come with any chasu or veggies, such as bamboo. You had to pay an extra $2-$4 for the extras that usually comes in ramen. The house ramen was very bland also. I think the most disappointing part me was that they didn't have some chili oil for the ramen since I like my ramen a little spicy. 

I felt like this place was overpriced and a little overrated but the experience was good
author: May P.

description:
During a brief visit to San Francisco,  I visited this place at a friend's recommendation. We were pretty happy with our experience! Service was quick, friendly,  and efficient; and the food was delicious.

Their black sesame icecream was probably my favorite thing there.
author: Erika M.

description: The best ramen restaurant in SF. My favorite one is Hinodeya Ramen, that has the same name as their restaurant. The one is using dashi very much and I can feel more umami than other Japanese restaurant.
author: Keisuke W.

description:
This is probably the best vegan ramen I've had (and as an egg-allergy sufferer, I've tried quite a lot). For the record, I'm not vegan, but I am vegetarian.

I came to catch up with a friend over dinner in her neighborhood and this was her suggestion, as she (a non-vegetarian) also was a fan of the vegan ramen here, and I'm always up for trying recommendations from friends :) Wow, she was not wrong! We both got the vegan ramens, she got the normal clear broth and I got the one with the creamy soy broth, which was surprisingly rich and filling! I also tried a sip of her ramen, and it was also very flavorful, so I will certainly have to try that next time I come by! We also shared the fried yam (naga-imo, so not like the orange yam/sweet potato thing you might be thinking of), and the sauce is very much key in that dish, as well as getting the warabi mochi dessert--everything was absolutely top-notch!

I'm already looking for a good excuse to come back here again, and hopefully bring my husband with me XD Thank you so much for having such fantastic vegan options!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Totally OK ramen place.  But since it's still relatively new, there's often a line outside, and there are not that many tables inside.  (plus several seating spots at the counter)

The food is fine.  Karaage was on the dry side, and the broth of the house ramen was OK.  But I give a thumb up on their hamaguri ramen because it is good and you don't see it at other places.
author: Harue J.

description:
One of the best ramens I've had to date!

I always try to find ramen that isn't tonkotsu-based, since my stomach just doesn't handle the pork fat as well anymore. The dashi-based broth of the Hinodeya ramen was divine! Very umami and flavorful without feeling heavy or oily. The bamboo toppings were tender, the half soft-boiled egg was on point, and the chashu was delicious without being too fatty. 

My girlfriend got the vegan ramen and it was also amazing! She loved that special attention was paid to making a standalone vegan noodle dish, as opposed to something that just had meat removed. The soy milk-based broth was very good and the mushroom substituting for fish cake was fantastic. No wonder many people ordered it around us!
author: Andrew M.

description:
Hinodeya House ramen is tasty! Good dashi broth, pork, and additional toppings. I enjoyed the side condiment of chili oil with garlic. That umami paste? I'll pass. Too fishy for me. 

Very friendly service here, and the line went relatively quickly on Friday night. I would definitely come back for the ramen.
author: Joanna L.

description:
One of the only ramen spots in Japantown that offer wheat style noodles! Definitely not what you think of when you think of ramen in the traditional sense. The noodles are wider and more chewier but I really like them! I usually get the house ramen and the broth is super flavorful and not too salty! I love adding the garlic and umami paste at the end and drinking all the soup. 

I've also tried the cheese appetizer which was good but I would skip on dessert at this place and just go to one of the ice cream spots in the mall.
author: Anna H.

description:
We got here around 7PM and had no wait. ::score!::

They only have one vegan ramen option, so I opted for that +egg (yum).

The ramen was interesting in that the soup is thick, the thickest soup I've ever gotten with ramen. My friend who ordered their house ramen, got the normal clear soup with her ramen. 

Note: the vegan ramen also comes with spinach like, green colored, thicker noodles. Since they are much thicker, they don't really seem like ramen noodles to me. If I were to come back in the future, I would certainly opt for the normal ramen.

Service was good. I really liked that the staff were attentive and always willing to help or answer your question. I did notice that it took them a while to give us our credit cards back, compared to what I'm just to experiencing even though it didn't seem like the restaurant was all that packed yet.

While the vegan ramen was a bit saltier than normal, I would be willing to come back for some ramen if I'm not checking out new ramen joints.
author: Jade F.

description:
The Ra-men at Hinodeya which means House of the Rising Sun is the antithesis of the wildly popular TonkOtsu/pork bone soup based Ra-men which is cooked for hours on end making the pork bones release milky, cloudy calcium from the bones as well as adding pork lard to add to the richness. (BTW, I see reviews that say TonkAtsu which is a fried, Panko breaded pork cutlet.)

The soup base is more close to the roots of traditional Japanese cuisine using dried Katsuo/bonito based soup stock for a deep sea meaty yet clear & Assari/refreshingly simple purity. This is what distinguishes Hinodeya from the Kyu-shu- based Tonkotsu Ra-menya. 

The cha-shu- here is less spiced w/ hakkaku/star anise or Sansho no Mi/Japanese pepper as well as being more lean and seasoned mostly w/ Sho-yu/soy sauce. 
Addition of Memma/Sho-yu braised bamboo shoot; chopped green onion to add a sulphurous funk; sprinkling of toasty, nutty Goma/sesame seeds; half egg that has a creamy, thick, gooey orange-yellow yolk. 

The Ra-men noodle has Koshi/springiness & Hagotae/al dente. Miraculously this "hybrid" noodle doesn't get mushy for a long time in the Dashi/soup broth. 

Condiments: red chile pepper, toasted garlic; Umami filled paste of dried Iwashi/sardines.  

Service is energetic w/ Irasshai or welcome greeting & a hearty farewell. Some of the staff are not Japanese so it feels as though there is still a bit of awkwardness, but the service is friendly and responsive. 

I tried their 3 Sakè (sah keh) flight that came w/ a small accompaniment of cream cheese marinated in a Umami rich Sho-yu Dashi base. It paired best w/ Tomoju which had a subtle Sugi (soo ghee)/Japanese cypress aromatic, woody scent. 

In the classic, traditional aphorism, Hara Hachibunmè,  means keep your stomach 80% filled for health. The Ra-men here is not the rich, gut filling, hunger killing fattiness of Tonkotsu Ra-men. Order an appetizer instead of complaining that the amount of Ra-men is not satisfyingly enough. Enough of our bad American habit of super sizing ourselves to oblivion. 

4+ Yelp stars for a more sophisticated Washoku/traditional Japanese cuisine approach.
author: Gary I.

description: I enjoyed this joint! There was no line, everyone seemed happy! The ramen was really good, I'm not use to Japanese ramen, loved the broth!
author: Jeremy G.

description: Decent little ramen place. Good food, good service. Their chicken ramen is the better choice. Savory broth but not deep flavor. Not a bad place for a quick bite.
author: Jimmy S.

description:
Super impressed with this place! One of the best ramen I've had in San Francisco. 

Service is super on point. We arrived a bit before closing time but they still seated us and a few other groups and were completely friendly and welcoming. All the food came out promptly and was  nice and hot. 

We started with the *Chicken Kara'age* which is basically fried chicken. This version arrived with matcha salt, which gave the chicken even more flavor. Apparently not all chicken kara'age is created equal! This one is superior to most.

Now I have to rave about the ramen. I couldn't believe how much perfection could fit in a simple bowl of ramen. We all got the *Hinodeya Ramen* (house ramen) which comes with all the goodies: chashu pork slices, bamboo shoots, seaweed, half of an egg that was soft-boiled just right, and don't get me started on the noodles. Ramen noodles are one of those things that aren't always done right. These were the perfect texture and has just the right amount of bounciness to it. Just amazing!!! 

Our table ate in silence. We just couldn't be distracted from our ramen.

Finally, the dessert. I expected the *Matcha Cappuccino* to be a hot coffee but it's actually a chilled pudding with red bean at the bottom and a delightful layer of cream on top. The red bean was quite a nice surprise. This dessert is a work of art and a great palate cleanser too.

TIP: You could essentially come here with people you don't care much for, because the ramen will be everyone's focus. But of course great company makes for even better dining experience, even if it's quiet! :)

DATE TIP: Start off with that Kara'age and end with the Matcha Cappuccino, with Ramen of course in between. This is the formula for success!
author: Denise L.

description:
Wow! This place was SO good. We stumbled onto this place after refusing to wait 1+hr at another ramen joint, and boy am I glad we did. There was a bit of a line but it went by fast, at maximum a 20 min wait. We ordered the takowasa as an appetizer, which is raw octupus in a wasabi sauce. It was different and delicious! 
Following that, I had the house ramen and added some umami paste to flavor the broth a little. The noodles were cooked perfectly and the broth, though different, tasted amazing. I had never tried this style of ramen and broth and it definitely didn't disappoint. 
For dessert, I recommend the Warabimochi or the Kuro-Goma Ice Cream w/ Granola. We couldn't decide on one, so we got both! 
This place is a must when visiting Japantown. Great location, friendly staff and delicious food. I loved it!
author: Gabriela R.

description:
This is a medium sized restaurant across the street from the Japan Town plaza. There's street parking available in the area, and I usually don't have too much trouble looking for a spot. This is a clean, family-friendly place, with attentive staff. 

The food was meh. My husband and I ordered the Hinodeya ramen and the Tori Paitan. The noodles were chewy and had a great texture, but I didn't like either of the broths. The Hinodeya Ramen had a clear, light broth which was too bland for my taste. The bamboo shoots tasted fresh and were crunchy. I liked the Tori Paitan a bit more--the broth was also very light but slightly more flavorful than the Hinodeya ramen. The Tori Paitan had braised chicken wings in it which were too tender. You're probably thinking, "How can chicken be TOO tender?!" but it was at a point where even the bones were crumbling and I was getting bone shards in my soup. The wings were also bland, as if they just stuck it in a pressure cooker for too long and forgot about it. The only thing I really liked was the mushroom in the Tori Paitan. 

My main gripe was the wait and price. I came for dinner one night and the line was long. Standing outside in the cold for a tiny $15 bowl of mediocre ramen? No thanks. There are better ramen shops out there that give you more bang for your buck. If I had to come back, I'd skip the ramen and probably try some appetizers--they sounded pretty good on the menu.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Have you ever had the sensation of where certain foods really give something special to you? Hinodeya Ramen Bar feels like a warm hug from a good friend that you haven't had in awhile. A total recommend & a great place to try if you're in the mood for some bomb ramen!

Hinodeya Ramen- ($14). You know that scene in Ratatoille where the food critic eats the Ratatoille & he gets transported back to the time when he was a kid & then devours the rest of the Ratatoille? Their House Ramen gives me similar -hit the home, very comforting feels. LOL

The sensation I've had with their ramen felt like they were giving me a gentle warm hug from within. The warm but light broth paired with their delicious house noodles was really warm & comforting combo. It definitely wasn't something I was exepcting, so I was surprised at how pleasantly surprised I was when I tried it out. Mmmmmm. Their egg was also cooked perfectly and their side of Chasew? HEAVENLYYY. I'd recommend it for sure.

Curry Special (15$)-  Apparently only available on weekdays, their curry was very earthy, and it wasn't something I normally expect from traditional style Japanese Curry. It came on a LONG plate with their salad and fried potato balls (I forgot what they're called, sorry eep), as well as their rice. Definitely very good, however it wasn't as memorable as their ramen to me. But still a nice option to have if you're here on a week day craving something besides ramen. It's also perfect to share!

The waiters here are also very attentive and kind, frequently asking if I needed anything despite the fact they seem kinda busy. Also is kinda entertaining hearing them yell Japanese phrases here and there, though it's not bothersome to the atmosphere of the restaurant.

Overall I'd give Hinodeya Ramen Bar a very solid 4 going to a 5. Definitely worth checking out, and I was blown away. The only reason why I couldn't give it 5 stars is because I really wish they had more variety, but for what they have, it's pretty solid ramen. I'd definitely come back for sure!
author: Allison O.

description:
Hidden gem. 

-Fantastic Service
-flavorful ramen
-modern clean decor 
-great matcha tea
-great yuzu beer
-cool 'Japanese tapas'

Bf and I originally went to try Marufuku at the Japanese Plaza Center across the street, there was 18 parties waiting before us.... and this was at 5:50 pm..... on a Thursday..

We weren't gonna wait that long, and so we decided to check this place out. Glad we did. 

Eats:

-fried oysters (4/5) came with lemon, and a sweet sauce

-house ramen (4.5/5) pork had perfect ratio of fat and tender meat, bamboo shoots, perfect egg, think chewy noodles (my fav), nori, and a clear broth. There is chili, garlic, and umami powder on the side.. I like the option of being able to add more to your bowl. 

Downside:

I really was wanting to try the 'matcha cappuccino' which actually is a pana cotta, with red bean on the bottom! But they were sold out.. not sure what that means, but was a little disappointing. 

Overall, I'd definitely be back, I love the house ramen so much not sure if I would vary from it, but I would love to try more of the tapas, and other dishes. 

Great service, very clean, and nice decor!
author: Janessa H.

description:
This is easily one of the better ramen spots in Japantown. I tried the Hinodeya ramen (house ramen) and was pleasantly surprised! The standard bowl comes with cha shu pork, bamboo shoots, half a soft-boiled egg, green onions, and seaweed. What really distinguishes this bowl from the rest is the clear broth (as opposed to the popular thick and creamy tonkatsu broth). It is packed with flavor! The ramen noodles are unique and offer a great texture. 

One thing that could be improved - I wish the egg was less well-done as I prefer them runny! Will be coming back to try other bowls and apps!
author: Mandi H.

description:
By far my favorite vegetarian Ramen  shop in the city. I think the pricing is better than Mensho. I'm a fan of heavier but creamier broth Ramen and this Ramen shop surely delivers on my expectation. Additionally, this restaurant has plenty of seating but do expect some wait time during peak hours and days. I enjoy bringing my friends here to try their Ramen but I heard their meat options are certainly a little bit different since they use options like chicken. I will certainly check out their menu before visiting.  

I would also order their pepper for appetizers as well as their veggie dumplings. For place that serves Ramen they surely did a fine job creating a Ramen for vegetarians that is both tasty as well as well proportioned.
author: Johnny H.

description:
Get the: 
Vegan Ramen + wings + pork
Spicy Menma

The Hinodeya Ramen was mediocre. Vegan Ramen was better
author: Linda L.

description:
My boyfriend and I were walking around japantown pretty late at night when most of the restaurants were closed. Luckily this place was still open and it seemed very popular so we decided to give it a try.

The place was very busy but we managed to get two seats at the bar which was great to kinda see how the bar/kitchen workes nonstop. The waiters would also yell things out in japanese, I guess to easily communicate if someone needs something since its very busy and loud in there... me and my bf found it to be entertaining.

To the service and food... my bf and I were so thirsty and had asked for water, which we were given water right aftwr asking, but then 5 mins later thr bar tender gave us another glass of water. So we were well hydrated! My bf and I both got the house ramen which was simple yet tasty. We both have never had ramen that had such a light broth but in the end we loved it. We also had the shishito peppers and matcha mochi ice cream which were good too but nothing special.

Overall definitely good food and fast service. The only reason I didnt give it 5 stars is because I found the menu selection to be a bit limited and wish they had more ramen selections.
author: Melanie M.

description:
Had a roommate dinner here including one vegetarian and one chicken-only eating roommate-- so yes, they can probably accommodate your friends with dietary restrictions!

I buy into Yelp hype sometimes and the hype here was on the matcha salt with the chicken karaage. The chicken was quite firm and while not dry, was not moist either. The matcha salt was disappointingly un-matcha-y. The chicken was crunchy with an appropriate amount of batter, but I think I prefer the chicken at Roka Akor.

The noodles were very al dente which was kind of nice. They're known for their dashi broth here, which is made from a combination of bonito, anchovy, and scallop. Good seafood flavor without being fishy at all. The half egg was okay but could be less well done. I think I preferred the egg at Marafuku Ramen a bit more. The cha siu pork was cut thick, but a bit lacking in cha siu flavor. The portion size was definitely on the small side given that I could have finished the entire bowl in one sitting. The broth was definitely less heavy / warm than a tonkotsu broth, which was perfect for summer. As good as Marafuku, though in a different way.

The condiments on the table were fairly tasty. The tabera was a mixture of crunchy garlicky yum. They also provided umami paste, which was a more potent version of the dashi broth.

Interior was modern casual. I really liked the wooden chandeliers they had on the ceiling. In true Japanese fashion, the waiters also greeted guests in unison as they departed.
author: Nicole H.

description: Excellent food with a great attitude.  I had the vegan ramen. Green gyoza and yams.  Definite recommend if you are in San Francisco's japantown
author: Michael R.

description:
Came to this place on a Sunday night with two other friends. We were surprised to see the line not being long. We waited for ~15 min before being seated. 

Hinodeya offers limited ramen options. I tried its pork ramen and glad to see the broth is not too oily but super flavorful. This broth reminded of me of the ramen I tried when I visited Japan last year. I am personally not a fan of Tonkatsu ramen because I don't like when food getting too rich in fat. I have tried Mensho and Ippudo. I can accept Ippudo but Mensho is wait too oily for me. Besides liking the broth, I also really enjoyed the ramen texture. 

In addition to ramen, we also ordered a couple appetizers: chicken kaarage and chasu. Love both the appetizers! 

If you ever crave for some light but flavorful good ramen, Hinodeya is the place to go!
author: Clare L.

description:
Vegan ramen seems to come in all sorts of delicious forms. This vegan ramen is rich and creamy and is almost like a winter comfort food. Good for chilly SF days.

Seriously, I've never encountered such a thick ramen broth in my entire ramen-eating life. But it's so good and well-flavored, yet difficult to finish because it's so rich. I love the veggie options included in the ramen too, such as the kale and bell peppers (but not the squash so much). The thick green noodles are also one of my favorite aspects of dish, they were cooked perfectly during each visit. 

Bottom line, this place is definitely part of my vegan ramen rotation.
author: Christina M.

description:
I came to a ramen restaurant with a large group and everyone got ramen except for me. Bad move, I know! I can't use chopsticks well, the bonito broth terrified me, and I can't abide yellow shimmering sliced eggs and I don't eat pork. So now you know.

Anyway, I liked the atmosphere (staff was helpful) our large group got a nice private seating area. My friend afterwards told me that the staff were speaking in Korean more than Japanese, so he felt it wasn't super authentic. Little would I know....! 

I ordered rice and little fried chicken appetizers. I probably should have ordered the salad, which looked delicious. The chicken was ok, a little chewy but crispy and tasty. The rice was really, really fishy. Like tuna fish in rice. I don't really like fish, so it was really hard to eat it. My favorite was the green tea, we each got our own little cast iron teapot and a cup. Atmosphere and Service 5 stars, I'm not convinced I'm qualified to rate the food as I didn't sample the main draw (ramen). Reasonable cost and pleasant (albeit loud) atmosphere.
author: Geneva L.

description:
I rarely wait in a long line for ramen.  But I know from past experiences (Ippudo NY, Ramen Dojo), is that if you want GOOOOOOD ramen, you're going to have to wait in line for it.

I went to Hinodeya on a Sunday night, and arrived at around 5:15pm and there was already a line outside.  I didn't have to wait too long though, I got seated at their bar in about  20 minutes.

Hinodeya Ramen -- http://bit.ly/2mj1eKh
dashi broth made from bonito, kombu, & scallop, with whole wheat noodles, chashu, soft cooked egg, nori, green onion
Although I was craving Paitan Ramen, I decided on getting their namesake bowl.  I enjoyed everything in this bowl.  The noodles had a nice chew, the egg was runny, and the broth was tasty.

Kara-Age -- http://bit.ly/2miXsRl
boneless deep fried chicken thigh with matcha salt.
Usually when I go to a ramen joint, I almost always order Kara-age with my ramen.  Hinodeya's kara-age was good.  Fried nicely and the chicken was juicy and flavorful.

Matcha Cappuccino -- http://bit.ly/2miZCAl
matcha green tea panna cotta w/ sweet red beans, nata de coco, vanilla whipped cream & matcha sauce
I was just intrigued by the photos on yelp that I had to try it.  I was a very delicious dessert.  I'm a sucker for panna cotta and the matcha added a light sweetness to it.

So, was Hinodeya worth the wait?  I think it was.  Service was great and everything I had was delicious.  I would probably refrain from going here on the weekends though so I won't have to wait too long.  I do want to go back to try their Chicken Paitan Ramen.  Of all the ramen joints around SF Japantown, I highly recommend it!
author: Rodney H.

description:
I recently read an article on the origin of dashi in the March 2018 issue of Food & Wine magazine, and let me tell you, this place exemplifies. every. word. Hinodeya's broth is light but extremely flavorful -- a perfect umami blend created from sun-dried seaweed (kombu) and smoke-cured fish shavings (katsuobushi). 

If you're looking to dive right in, order the following: Hinodeya Ramen (house ramen) -- whole wheat ramen noodles topped with 2-3 chashu pork slices, 1/2 a soft boiled egg, bamboo shoots, seaweed, and green onions. Noodles have just the right amount of chew, and the broth the perfect amount of depth. For those with vegetarian/vegan/picky friends, fortunately there's options for them too.

Standout service, beautiful modern interior makes for a wonderful dining experience in Japantown. 10/10 would recommend for a cold wintery date. Come prior to 5:30pm to avoid the line.
author: Deanna C.

description:
STOP THE PRESSES THIS IS THE BEST RAMEN I HAVE EVER HAD THE HONOR AND PLEASURE TO GRACE MY TASTE BUDS!!! 

I've had a good deal of ramen. It's usually always consistent from one restaurant to another, generally delicious, and I usually add seasoning to enhance flavor. 

The Zen Ramen at Hondeya is an exquisite piece of art. It does not need to be tampered with any extraneous tabletop spices or seasoning. It is complex in its simplicity. The noodles are perfectly chewy, the kale is crispy and smoky - an absolute delight to gnaw on, the shiitake mushroom robust and meaty, and the broth is quite frankly the best soup broth of any kind that I've come across. 

The spicy edamame were equally as delicious and bursting with flavor. 

The venue is cute, clean, bright, and the service excellent. Truly recommend.
author: Christina S.

description:
Finally. We found Tokyo-level ramen. On the hunt for years. We were going to go to the "other" spot in the mall that has lines out the door the second it opened, so we got lazy and decided to try Hinodeya since the lines have calmed. It was epic. Just simply delicious. And the service was lovely and prompt.

We sat at the bar; my boyfriend had the house ramen and I chose the chicken. The broth was perfection - just enough taste to accompany the delicious, chicken pieces, but not overwhelm. The noodles were perfectly dense. Apparently the clam one is supposed to be heavenly. We also started with the chicken karage app - incredible and cooked to perfection; meat just slipped right off the bone.

I can't wait to keep coming back for more.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Ordered the karaage, house ramen, and chicken ramen. Every dish was delicious. The green tea salt was unexpected. It definitely paired well with the chicken. As for the ramen, the broth was so rich and flavorful. With the seasoning on the table it added a very nice touch to the broth. Noodle was nice and chewy, very fresh! I read from somewhere that this ramen place is the best in the city. Definitely a must try!


Staff were extremely friendly and they greet you as you enter and as you leave the restaurant. Everyone working there is Japanese and that's how you know the restaurant is an authentic ramen restaurant!

Parking is tough unless you park in the garage. If not, it will be Meyer parking or 2 hour parking if you are lucky enough to find a spot. Not difficult, but will need to circle around at least twice.
author: Amabel Y.

description:
Parking: there's plenty of street parking around the neighboring blocks. There's also a parking structure (sorry, don't know the cost) 

Line/Wait: Luckily, we arrived at 450pm and started waiting in line. We were the third party and when they opened at 5pm, they took each party one at a time and got people seated. The first rush of us who got seated were able to be served within 10-15 mins. 

Food: The ramen is good but I'm not sure if it's worth the price or hype. I ordered the house ramen ($14) and added the extra chashu for $4. My friend ordered the vegan ramen ($15). It was good but nothing too memorable. The only thing I really liked was the chili edamame appetizer and the garlic chili in the jar you can add to your meal. 

Staff: Everyone is SO friendly!! At the end of your meal, they give you your bill in a box with a origami bird. I'm a sucker for those cute things and the waiter went back and brought a bowl full of them so I could take a couple back home. 

Environment: It's a nice but small place. There's tables for any size party and if it's an odd number, they'll ask to see if you want to join a table and share it. I don't think that's weird but I guess it could possibly happen if I was in a party of 2 or 3. 

I would definitely try this place and check it out. The food is good but nothing extremely amazing caught my eye or taste. It's a nice place to get some ramen if you're craving it. All the ramen (4) listed seem to be similar in taste for broth but the toppings are different.
author: Jennifer K.

description: Great ramen.  Different from most of the other places we've been to:  this place uses a very clean dashi base instead of the really fatty, porky broth base that seem to be really popular now.  Makes for a really light, clean flavor.  The noodles had really good bite and the soft boiled egg was perfect.
author: Dave K.

description:
We've been regulars since opening and besides the few caveats (charge for tea and no option for extra noodle), this was our second favorite ramen restaurant in the bay area. It was solid due to its dependability (consistency of food and service) but that all changed tonight when the waiter clearing our neighboring table stealthy finished up their leftover food in two bites (something small as he used his hands, maybe an appetizer or side dish).

I've worked in the restaurant industry for a long time and the only time I've seen non-customers eat already served food was if it came back with a complaint (too salty, not fresh) to taste it as a safety measure. Once the food is served, there is a long list of rules to prevent contamination (reserving leftover communal rice/bread). You're not suppose to give another table a plate served in error even if it was untouched (although I've seen this done often enough to know it occurs frequently). So the tall male, non-spectacled server eating the leftover food, while not for contamination reasons, is a no-no. We alerted a waitress, asked for the manager (he was out but wife was there) and gave her a quiet account of what we saw. She gave us an apology but was not concerned enough to ask who it was until we offered it to her. Given her tepid response, who knows if he was reprimanded? 

Going out to eat is a lesson in trust as so much happens behind the scenes and given our discomfort, we will not be going back.

(Also, the state of the restroom left much to be desired. It was generally pretty clean and smelled nice with the incense they burn but not today with a dirty toilet, floor, and mildewy smell).
author: Empress C.

description:
I hopped into this place recently and went with :

Hinodeya Ramen (House Ramen) $14 
w/ tradional Japanese dashi sytle soup & whole wheat noodles soup made from bonito, kombu & scallop. 
Toppings: Chashu pork , menma, soft cooked egg , dried seaweed, green onion , sesame seeds & red pepper 

Kara-Age 8 
fried juicy boneless cage free organic chicken  with Sea Salt 

The ramen was very underwhelming for me especially since I compared to two other venues that I'd been to recently. On my scoring scale for (taste of broth/taste of noodles/taste of other stuff in soup) i have it as a 4/4/4 . As others have noted the quantity and size of the ramen/toppings is a little bit wanting in comparison to other venues as well. 

The service was nice but I can't say that I'll be returning.  See my ramen rankings below. 


I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank most of the Ramen Places in the Bay Bay Bay similar to lists I have for Boba.


Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings. 

Rod Ramen Rating = (Taste of Broth / Taste of Noodles/Taste of other stuff in soup) on a Scale of 1 to 10 (10/10/10) being the best score possible

* Please note that I don't have a preference for thick or thin noodles or thick or clear broth I just call it like I feel it. 

# 1 Marufuku Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 9/8/8 *Rod's Yelp Rating *5 stars 
# 2 Mensho Tokyo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 8/8/8 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 3 Orenchi Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 8/8/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 4 Orenchi Beyond  *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/8/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 5 Ramen Parlor *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 6 Ramen Dojo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 7 Nojo Ramen Tavern *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 6/6/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 8 Yokohama Lekei Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 6/5/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 9 Ippudo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/6/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 10 Santa Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/5/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 11 Ramen Yamadaya *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/5/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 12 Sobo Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 13 Ramen 101 *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 14 Ramen Shu *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/5/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 15 Suzu Noodle House *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 3/3/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 16 Hinodeya Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 17 Slurp Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 18 Tadamasa *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 3/3/3 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 starships
author: Rod M.

description:
Why Hinodeya Ramen Bar:

1) It is the sister restaurant of a ramen place in Japan. #RamenCred

2) Minimal waiting if you go at the right time (i.e. when they open).

3) Cool wooden thingamajig on the ceiling over the communal table. Tables in the back aren't as scenic but will get it done.

4) "Refreshing" yuzu soda that was like a tangy Sprite. ($3)

5) Crispy, juicy Kaarage with matcha salt and mostly mild Shishito Peppers (how did that hot one sneak in there)?

6) House Ramen. Broth, noodles, egg = #SLAY (Also tried the Chicken Ramen but preferred the House Ramen). 

7) Itty bitty paper cranes made by the staff. #OrigamiGoals

8) My ramenholic nephew (who used to swear by Neoguri) gives Hinodeya 5 stars too. ("My tastes have evolved.") #ItsAboutTime
author: Amy C.

description:
A Japanese ramen restaurant located in Japan town.  The inside is pretty spacious.  Servers are really friendly.  I like how they have complimentary eel paste you can add to your ramen.

House Ramen - $14 - Decent, 3.5/5
The house ramen is pretty good.  The broth is a clean broth; it's a clear broth but it feels clean when you eat it.  It's not over the top salty and it doesn't try to do anything complicated.  It's pretty good.  Noodles are cooked perfectly, 5/5.  My few gripes?  The serving size is kind of small.  Also, only 2 pieces of meat served per ramen.  Don't come here super hungry.

TIPS:
-Located in Japan town, close to Daiso
author: Mike T.

description: I went to Hinodeya with a group of friends for lunch and got there just in time because they only open for three hours, worth the rush:) I got the vegan ramen and I have to say that it was the best ramen I have ever tasted in my life. The noodles were cooked to perfection and mixing with the broth that was spiced so well, all the tastes blended with the noodles to get an extraordinary experience!! We also got cold sake that was delicious as well since they had so many options or sake.
author: Eric T.

description: There is a reason why there is a wait.  I came for the vegan option and was really happy with the food.  The broth was noodles were perfect.  Price is right too.  If dining solo, skip the line and ask to sit at the bar.  Works great when pressed for time and want a solid bite.
author: MarcAnthony C.

description: I've been to quite a few ramen places and this one is pretty good. We tried the Zen ramen and the broth was pretty flavorful. I'm more a fan of tonkotsu broth so if you like lighter/less creamy broths then this may be the place for you. I give it 4 stars because the chashu pork leaves a lot to be desired in my opinion. However, wait on a Saturday wasn't too bad for lunch and this place is dog friendly!
author: Grecia O.

description:
Very light sauce and right serve size. 
Love the interior decoration more than the food. 
It is a place to go and try but not somewhere I will go back all the time.
author: Sunny B.

description:
This place is amazing! The two vegan ramen options are out of this world. 
Friendly staff and good service. Love!
author: Pep G.

description:
I find this place to be slightly underwhelming for the amount of hype they received before they even opened. Don't get me wrong it's still quality ramen and I have revisited a few times already, but it's definitely not my personal first choice when I crave ramen.

Hinodeya offers plenty delicious appetizers on their menu, especially the Karaage with matcha salt! But there's very little ramen options. They have the house ramen, chicken ramen, seafood ramen (limited amount per day), and vegetarian ramen. For most non vegetarian customers the options are down to two unless you come early when the seafood ramen is available. I'd love to see them introduce a couple more options on the menu! Perhaps a spicy option and a permanent Pescatarian option :)
author: Mandy H.

description:
I was under impressed by this place. I got the chicken ramen, and it just wasn't that flavorful. The broth was kind of plain and the noodles weren't anything special. The chicken was gross too. My sister got the House Ramen which had better broth. I will say the mushrooms were DELICIOUS. My sister made the right choice, getting the House Ramen and subbing the pork for mushrooms.

I'm not saying this place is bad, because I know it's popular and a lot of people like it, but it wasn't for me.
author: Jenna G.

description:
The sister and I were hungry and still roaming around in japantown. Not many places were open, but lucky for us we saw a line of people and decided to join. The line moved slowly, but we finally got a table. Service was very friendly.

EDAMAME- izakaya snap peas snack
The typical dish of salted peas. I liked that it came out hot and not super wet.

AGE-DASHI FRIED TOFU- covered in dashi sauce, topped with grated daikon radish, and bonito flakes
The flavors in this dish was very light, but the tofu was cooked perfectly. I wouldn't really say it was fried, but it had a really mushy consistency and only a slight crisp skin. The bonito flakes added a nice saltiness to the dish. Overall, this dish was sweet and light.

OYSTERS FRIED
I'm not a huge fan of fried oysters, but these were really fresh and good. I like the crispy batter. It wasn't oily and the oysters were flavorful.

KARA-AGE- fried boneless cage free organic chicken
This is the best fried chicken I've ever ordered from a japanese restaurant. It was so moist and I love the matcha salt that they provide. The skin was crisp and the inside was juicy. Definitely one of my favorites.

HOTATE SMALL RICE BOWL- with traditional dashi taste steamed rice and dried scallops made with tamanishiki rice
This is a very simple dish. I could definitely taste the salted scallops. For its simplicity, it was still good and filling, but just a bit dry.

HINODEYA RAMEN- house ramen with traditional japanese dashi style soup and whole wheat noodles soup made from bonito, kombu, and scallop, topped with chashu pork, menma, soft cooked marinade egg, dried seaweed, and green onion
The broth is very light and simple. The noodles were cooked perfectly and were soft, but also had a slight firmness. The pork was very fatty and the egg wasn't as runny as I would've liked and they only give half an egg. The ramen tasted fresh, but in terms of flavors, it was just too light for me.

KURO-GOMA ICE CREAM W/GRANOLA
I absolutely loved the black sesame ice cream. It was so good and the granola went perfect with it because it was crunchy and the ice cream was cold and smooth. The whipped cream was like the icing on the cake because it just added another layer of sweetness, which was perfect because the ice cream was rich in black sesame flavor and not overly sweet.

They have fried garlic at the table and it's the best thing ever! It made everything taste even better. My sister and I finished the whole jar! It had a nice chili and garlic-y flavor. 

My sister and I left on full stomachs. I was satisfied. I would come back here, but I wouldn't order the same ramen, but I definitely would get the small dishes.
author: Anh L.

description:
This is another one of those ramen spots that you're likely to wait in line if you don't arrive promptly once they open.  With that said, I refused to wait last time but had every intent on returning to try their infamous dashi ramen!  Hinodeya definitely set themselves apart from many other ramen joints.

Before they opened, my honey and I could hear the staff doing some motivational chanting in Japanese prior to opening for business for the day.  As patrons entered, we were enthusiastically greeted.  The atmosphere is lively, pleasant and fun.  The modern, minimalistic decor with dark browns and those fancy chandeliers with glossy branches and Edison bulbs dangling are quite chic.  The food and service is also on point.

Both of us ordered the Hamaguri (clam) ramen.  We really enjoyed the clear, flavorful, buttery broth as opposed to the usual thick oily types.  I added shitake mushroom and chashu pork.  The shitake mushrooms were soft and flavorful and tasted like they'd done more to them than throw them in the soup.  The chashu pork was pliable and juicy- far from dry and tasty!  They had condiments on the table I'd never seen before:  Unami oil (Bonito flakes & scallop oil) & Tabera garlic & onion w/chili oil) I didn't use any as the clam ramen was excellent already.  There's many other excellent items on the menu I'd like to try with the Hinodeya ramen next time I'm in Japantown.

This is one of the best ramen joints in Japantown.  -love their cleaner style of ramen!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
This is probably going to be known as the backup place to marafuku ramen just 3 minutes walk away but when accounting for wait times, probably an equal choice. I found the house ramen to lack flavor, possibly because I'm comparing it against tonkotsus from other ramen bars. The chashu in the ramen was also tough and put together just a subpar ramen for $14. 

The chicken ramen ($15) however was a welcome choice, slightly off the beaten trail. It was flavourful and the chicken wings were marinated and the meat literally falls off the bones. The half mushroom in the chicken ramen was also done properly and a good fit into the dish. Both ramens came with half an egg, done as expected of a top Ramen place. I'd definitely return here for the chicken ramen, and possibly look forward to try the clam ramen once it is back in season as well! 

My only complaint is that the hot tea, although comes in a fancy pot, was not very hot. Perhaps this is some next level matcha that is meant to brewed at a room temperature but I am merely too pleb to appreciate.
author: Alfonso C.

description:
The short: my go-to ramen spot in SF

The ambiance is very warm and welcoming. As I enter, a waiter welcomes me in Japanese and is so animatedly happy that it's cute. Looking around, the place has a warm, modern, and pared back simple aesthetic, save for the unique branch lighting piece. 

The Hinodeya Ramen's broth is pleasantly light and refreshing, which in my book is solid. The noodles were on the firm side and the condiments were all prepared well. Service was also very attentive and similar to how I remember it when I visited Japan.

Tip: All members of party must be present... Friend #1 arrived - wouldn't be seated even though the place was fairly empty. I arrived: and then they sat us down, though we mentioned friend #3 would arrive much later in the evening. The host was calm about the situation and we were understanding, and he was excited too so we didn't mind complying.

Verdict: Would definitely be down to come back
author: Catherine W.

description:
I was intrigued to try this new kind of ramen that emphasizes a dashi broth - think light, savory, and clean - rather than a creamier type of broth as I've had at Mensho. It's delicious, but I have to say that Mensho's paitan, with the creamier brother, is INSANELY delicious. 

Things they did well: the egg was cooked to perfection - a littttttle bit runny on the inside with a golden yolk but the egg white shell still held the form.

Needs improvement: the chashu - not creamy at all. Kind of a thick cut. I like the chashu at mensho that melts in your mouth and every bite makes you want to ask for more. Now that's the stuff of legends. 

TLDR: glad I tried it, but will be lining up again for Mensho.
author: Cindy W.

description:
I was originally planning to eat at Marufuku Ramen until I saw a huge line that went past the door. I did not feel like waiting for an hour or two to get inside because I wanted to spend most of my Friday night at home. Therefore, I ended up going to Hinodeya Ramen Bar. 

I made a good choice coming here for these reasons:
1. I was seated very quickly.
2. My food came in less than 5 minutes.
3. My Vegan Ramen ($15) was delicious. The soup was very creamy and flavorful. At other ramen places, the vegetarian broth tends to lean toward the plain side. The kale was a little long and hard to bite into, but I liked how it was very seasoned. I will say that my bowl looked smaller than the Hinodeya Ramen, but it still made me full. 
4. The waiters/waitresses were nice. They thanked us for coming into the restaurant.
5. We were given warm towels to clean our hands before we eat! I have never seen this before.
6. The check came with a mini swan origami, a sticker that said "I love Dashi" (which my dish did not have), and a piece of paper that said we could subscribe to their newsletter to get great deals. 

If I am in the area, I will come back for sure.
author: Kristina M.

description:
3.5 Stars

The staff at Hinodeya Ramen Bar was absolutely fantastic and very welcoming. Got seated right away on a Friday night and our food came out fast. 

We ordered:

- Hinodeya Ramen ($14) - this was the house ramen with one slice of chashu pork, half boiled egg, green onion, and dried seaweed. Broth was flavorful and so were the noodles too!

- Tori Patan ($15) - chicken ramen with braised wing and shitake mushroom. The noodles texture was different than the Hinodeya ramen. As for the broth, it was on the sweet side and the portion was kind of small too!

- Matcha Cappuccino ($8) - matcha green tea panna cotta with red sweet bean. It was very light and tasty. 

I hope you give this ramen place a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description:
Ramen that has a different style broth (dashi). I really enjoyed it! I ordered the house ramen with a side salad which was huge! The ramen was full of flavor, not too salty, broth not too thick, and the noodles had a nice bite to it. They offer two different add ons on the table. One was a chili oil with fried garlic and onions and the other was some sort of sardine paste. I added a little of both and it complemented the dish beautifully. The side salad was bursting with different veggies typically not found in boring salads. It came with squash, radishes, cucumbers, and quinoa! It was a nice palette cleanser in between the bites of ramen. 

The servers were all really nice and attentive. Customer service here was wonderful. Definitely coming back!
author: Marie N.

description:
Chicken Karaage: a bit too fried and dry, but matcha salt is pretty good as a side.

Chasu: pretty decent, some pieces a bit fatty

Fried oysters: osyters tasted fresh!

House ramen: pretty tasty, too much noodles - remember to not add peppers next time
author: Ariel Z.

description:
Hinodeya is always a sleeper on my go-to noodle short list.

Then when I'm there it's like, how did I forget about this place?!  Very solid bowl of noodles.  Their broths are extremely clean, and may taste simple if you're used to the unctuous richness of tonkotsu or Mensho's toripaitan.  But simplicity is nice change of pace in a city full of heavy broths.  

If you're looking for something rich and creamy, I'd actually recommend the vegan ramen which is made with a soy milk base and in my opinion heavier than their toripaitan.  It was really good, especially for not containing any meat or dairy!

Tips and Tricks
-Come here if you want to get back to the basics of ramen
-Fried mountain yam was yumm
-Tea is not free (what?!)
-Dessert was okay, but not mind-blowing
author: Jessica L.

description:
Visited this place on a Saturday night during the Cherry Blossom season. Considering that it was packed inside, we didn't wait for a table for too long.

I would give this place a 3.5/5 stars but would round up to 4 stars. 

The menu list is limited. They have 4 kinds of ramen (Hinodeya, Hamaguri, Chicken, and Vegan). Their ramens run out though, so you may only be able to order what's left if you come late. I got the Hinodeya Ramen with dashi broth, chashu, marinated egg, bamboo shoots, seaweed, and green onions. It was different from my usual ramen orders. I typically get a tonkotsu ramen because I love the heavy pork flavor. Their dashi broth was good, but a little on the salty side. But, it was a good change for me because it was lighter for my tummy. I also ordered a chicken kaarage as appetizer and it was good. It was crunchy and tender.

Overall, would come back again if I am in the area.

Tip: Parking in Japantown is very difficult. I suggest parking a few blocks away to avoid paying the fee if you park in the garage.
author: Natascha E.

description: Solid 3.5 stars, I'll round up to 4. Ordered the tori paitan. The broth was 5 stars, solid taste, saltiness, and balanced flavor. The noodles were al dente, nothing special (3 stars). The chicken was ok (3 stars). The broth is a good rival to the other "newcomer" Marufuku Ramen. Check them both out... share a bowl and hop to the other one and share another. Gluttony, it's only a sin if you don't partake... mua-ha-ha-ha!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Place is located a few doors down from Benkyodo. 

We went there on a weekday at lunch. Just a few in line before opening. Got to choose our own table. Place filled to capacity within a few minutes. 

Started with fried oysters. Oysters arrived hot and were melt in your mouth great. You get five per order with dipping sauce. 

I ordered the House ramen bowl and my friend had the chicken ramen.

House ramen arrived warm but not boiling hot. Standard toppings include green onions, nori, half a soft cooked egg, 2 chashu slices, and bamboo shoots. Bamboo shoots were very tasty. Noodles were thick and chewy as I prefer. These were perfect for grabbing the broth. Broth was clean and light. I prefer a rich tonkotsu broth, but the clear fish-based ramen was a nice change of pace.

If tonkotsu broth is a heavy workout for your palette, this dashi broth is a leisurely walk; but a pleasant one. 

Tonkotsu broth is a quite popular with ramen lovers. With dashi broth they're doing counter programming which is a smart strategy. 

Chicken ramen bowl includes three chicken wings, shiitake, green onions, nori and half a soft cooked egg. Chicken wings were fall off the bone delicious. Tastewise; I preferred the chicken ramen broth. Given a choice, I would rather have chicken meat slices in lieu of chicken wings. That would be the perfect chicken ramen configuration for me. 

If you're a protein fiend like me, you will have to load up on extra chashu toppings or appetizers to appease your dietary needs. For light eaters, the ramen bowl as is will suit you. There is a vegetarian ramen bowl option if you are so inclined. 

Standout for me was the service and atmosphere. Very friendly staff and orders shouted out ramen house style. They yell irasshaimase like in Japan as you enter. Noren curtain at the entrance. Nice interior touches for an authentic feel. 

Ramen houses tend to cram customers in like sardines for logical reasons. This place is airy and bright. The outlying tables are nicely spaced. Gives you some breathing room to enjoy some personal space.
 
Private dining is available in the back. Patrons get a shout out as they leave. There was a short line as we left. Busy place, but not a mob scene. Had a great time. I will return
author: Jaqen H.

description: Great ramen!!! Went here for lunch and got hinodeya ramen(house ramen) and karage(fried chicken). They were both delicious!! Note: this place only has three ramen dishes and they're all dashi based ramen. So if you wanted a variety of ramen, this place might not be right for you!
author: Theresa H.

description:
Love this place especially for the vegetarian/vegan options. There are two vegan choices for ramen. The zen is a lighter traditional clear broth and the vegan is a creamier soy milk broth. The ingredients are fresh and all the veggie appetizers are great! 

Recommend:
Either ramen depending on your mood
Spicy menma (bamboo shoots without the preserved smell if other places)
Salad 
Shishito peppers 

Sake tasting because it comes within a flavored cheese bite 

Dessert is equally delicious!
author: Crystal F.

description:
The chicken Paitan ramen was pretty tasty. I like the broth and noodles. I didn't like the choice of the other ramen selections.  

The chicken karage and dumplings were okay.
author: Jboogie L.

description: Overall the place was nice. Menu selection on ramen was few and the only disappointment.  Nothing to write home about. The soup was bland and lacked flavor.
author: Andrew M.

description: This place is way way way over hyped. The atmosphere is good, servive is decent, however, anything else, not so much. I cant recall the name of the ramen I ordered, but it's called house special or Hinodeya ramen or something. Anyways, I could make better ramen than they do. It came with a some seedweed, half of an egg, and two or three pieces of pork. Overall, I didn't enjoy my food at all.
author: Lawrence C.

description:
Wait, hold the press. Did Japantown finally get a legit good ramen shop? My mind absolutely cannot comprehend this. After so many just meh and okay and blegh bowls of ramen in Japantown, I can honestly say that Hinodeya has blown my mind. If you know me, I'm an actual ramen snob and I don't just toss out 5 stars when it comes to ramen restaurants. So Hinodeya is something special. 

Hinodeya serves up a bit different style of ramen that what I'm used to. Fish based broth instead of my usual soy sauce base. I was a bit skeptical at first to be honest. Fish based? Am I about to eat the ocean? But holy heck, this was delicious. Most bowls of ramen I've had lately have been lacking in certain qualities, but Hinodeya was so solid across the board. Noodles were firm and tasty, veggies were plentiful and fresh, and the meat was just perfect in terms of amount of flavor and tenderness. Really though, the main thing when it comes to ramen was the broth, and Hinodeya has it just right. Perfect amount of flavor that tied every ingredient together just right. 

Thy really do just get everything right. I loved the sake flight that we ordered along with our meal. Service was very attentive and friendly. Price was right about what I thought I'd pay. Just all around solid, like their ramen. 

A good bowl of ramen to me is like a puzzle, where each piece completes the other. Hinodeya gets that puzzle picture perfect. So happy with my meal here. Would gladly come back to satisfy any and all ramen cravings I will likely have in the future.
author: Sean H.

description: I'm probably in the minority here, but I don't like super thick broth for ramen, which is why I really enjoy the ramen here. I ordered the House Ramen (Hinodeya Ramen). The broth is clear and lighter than your typical tonkatsu type broth. It had a few pieces of char siu (roasted pork), half an egg, and bamboo shoots. Overall, I liked the ramen. We had a pretty big group (8 people) and the wait was about an hour when they told us it would be about 15 minutes. It also took awhile for us to get the waiter's attention after being seated. Knocking off a star for that. I would definitely come back with a smaller group.
author: Annie L.

description:
Hands down, this was the best vegan ramen I've had so far! I got the vegan ramen and it came with a delicious creamy broth. I dream about this ramen almost daily now. Sooo good! 

We also got the shishito peppers made vegan, which made them a little bland,  because I guess the sauce is what makes them not vegan? Maybe they have a different kind of sauce you can dip it in, otherwise I don't recommend the shishito peppers if you are vegetarian/ vegan. 

My (vegetarian) boyfriend had the black sesame ice cream afterwards, and said it was really good! 

**expect to wait in line to eat here. The line was out the door just past the restaurant when we came, but it went by pretty quickly. Maybe 20-30 minutes you will wait. But worth it!
author: Mariah F.

description:
Was looking forward to some gelatinous heavy creamy tori paitan broth, failed.  It was very thin and a bit oily and salty, not much chicken flavor.  Noodle texture was cooked well, had bite but didn't care much for the flat narrow style.

Hinodeya ramen broth tasted similar to paitan , just slightly salty.  Chashu wasn't soft melty enough.

Hamaguri broth was best, although most salty of the three, it was very clammy and flavorful.

There was a vegan broth made with soy milk, yea no thanks LOL. 

Portion size was the only thing most resembling Japan, very small.   Price opposite of Japan, very expensive.  Price to satisfaction ratio, another failure.

Apps - chicken karaage, kaki fry, flavorless batter.

Tebasaki cooked too much, yes fall off bones but not marinated deep enough to flavor the actual meat.  The soup of shoyu tsuyu was needed to compensate, which was salty again.

Overall, ramen is a hard success in USA.  Chains like santouka is consistent and good at best.

Luckily didn't wait in line and would never do so for a new ramen shop despite all the hype.  Got people to do and things to see.
author: Kevin L.

description: Came here for lunch with a friend on Sunday around 12 PM, and the first thing I noticed when I walked in was the vibe of the restaurant and the tastefully decorated interior. Both of us ordered the house ramen, and we both loved it! Personally, I love thicker and creamier broths, and the house ramen soup was definitely on the lighter side, but I was really surprised by how tasteful it was. The noodles were made perfectly, and the topping were plentiful in proportion to the rest of the bowl.
