And at the end of the meal they gave us this cute little box with a sticker and a little paper crane in it! Would definitely recommend trying this place out!
author: Lydia S.

description:
There was a reason why there's a line to get into this restaurant. One of the best ramen I've had. I got here at 7:20pm and had about 4-6 people ahead of me. We got seated ~7:35, and there were about 10+ people behind me. The line moves fairly quick though. The host was nice enough to seat us before our whole party arrived. 

Service: I appreciated that servers were described each of the meals like they do at the very expensive restaurants. How else would I have known it was green tea salt or cage-free chicken? They seemed a little rushed at times, but it was understandable. The restaurant was packed with a line outside. 

Food: 
Chicken Karaage - Cage-free chicken with green tea salt, chicken was soft and perfectly crispy
Hinodeya House Ramen - This was the first clear broth type of ramen I've tried, and it was delicious. If you aren't a fan of the thicker/opaque broth, I would recommend this dish. There's less of that sweet taste compared to the thicker broths. 
Green Tea Cappuccino - It's not an actual cappuccino but just the presentation. It's more like a pudding. A good way to end a meal.

Arrive at the restaurant prepared to wait in line. 
Delicious but on the pricier end. I would come back to have my own bowl of Vegan Ramen.
author: Helen H.

description:
My my and my friend decided to come here and eat since we've heard great things. Since we had a super early spa day and this place was around the corner we decided to try it out. Let me tell you that this place is so popular people already line up from the outside to get in. Luckily for us, we finished our spa maybe 30 min before they opened so we didnt mind waiting. 

Service was great, they greet each and every person that comes in. We were seated right away so the wait in line wasn't too bad, but I also think it was because we got there before it opened. We decided to order the chicken karage for starters, my friend ordered the chicken ramen and my mom and I ordered the house ramen. 

The chicken karage came out pretty quick and it was well worth the order The dish came with a green tea sea salt to dip for flavor. The chicken was fired perfectly and the chicken was very juicy. It was cooked well and right and I would highly recommended to order this dish. 

The house ramen was very good and the soup was not salty at all. The ramen was house made and  it was cooked just right. I've eaten at a lot of ramen places and most of the time ramen is pre-ordred and not as fresh as the one I ate. The portions were good and it was just right enough room for dessert if wanted. The soup base was made great, not salty at all and paired right with what came with the ramen such as egg, pork slices and bamboo. 

All in all this place was great, its on the pricer side butI would highly recommend to eat here at least once or if your in the area. Again come early because the wait can be long depending on day and time.
author: Tiffany K.

description: This place has only been here for a year and it's got a fresh, friendly atmosphere with many vegan options! We ordered the Zen and the Vegan ramens and they were beautiful and delicious! All special requests were accommodated and servers were genuinely happy and loving their jobs! Such a delight!
author: Gabor K.

description:
Hinodeya is my favorite ramen place in the city right now. I'm so thrilled to have finally found a clean bowl of dashi with my ramen!! I know that's usually more of an udon move, but I love clean dashis and this was my dream. 

Hinodeya keeps their menu pretty simple and unfortunately I've only visited during the cherry blossom festival so I wasn't able to try their karage. But I did get the House Ramen and it is really well done. The broth is so clean and light yet flavorful and rich with dashi, and the noodles are perfectly chewy and have some bounce while being al dente. I do think that the cha siu here is okay, but I'm willing to forego that when the dashi and noodle balance is so well done. They have an ajitama but nothing memorable to me about that. 

I admit that Hinodeya is definitely on the pricier side, but I think unfortunately ramen is just trending in that direction as SF gets more and more expensive as a city. It's a bummer since ramen is seen as fast casual food in Japan, but hey, you have to pay for good quality. 

I'm a huge fan of Hinodeya and definitely would recommend it. I've read horror stories about the line on Yelp but haven't encountered it myself but have seen small lines forming when I leave. I'd advise to show up when they open and just eat on the earlier side as I haven't had troubles with lines then.
author: Jasmine X.

description:
This is a pretty good Ramen bar, i mean i am not a Ramen connoisseur but it was good ramen. They have a good sake collection too.

There is a line but as you will be sharing the table with other guest you will get a table pretty quick. If you wanna have a private conversation this aint the place.
author: Urvish -.

description:
We got decent ramen here but I wouldn't say it was anywhere near top-notch ramen. The house ramen they offer here is Dashi style, so you taste fermented fish and seaweed in the broth. I know some people might be into this particular type; for me the broth is subpar when compared to the typical creamy broth of other ramen. The egg was a little overcooked in my opinion. The vegan ramen here, on the other hand, was quite good - creamy and flavorful. We also got the 3 sake tasting flight and that surprisingly turned out to be the highlight of the meal. Highly recommend.

The wait here isn't bad. We got here at around 6:45pm on a Saturday and waited for 10-15 minutes.
author: Chang L.

description:
Surprisingly delicious broth. I have my reservations about ramen places, but this place surpassed all expectations! 

House ramen 4.5/5
Thinner broth. Tasty slices of pork. Tasty noodles. 

Chicken ramen 5/5!!!
Thicker broth. Great, deep chicken flavor. Tasty noodles. My favorite if the 2. The waitress had mentioned it's too rich for her, but it's not too rich. It's perfect (and I don't typically enjoy "rich" food). Just a thicker, flavorful chicken broth! 

Karaage chicken 
Delicious breadding. Moist chicken, dark meat. 
Not sure what the matcha salt added but it was aesthetically pleasing. 

Lastly, the garlic/chili condiment was on point! 

Portion sizes were not large but it was filling!
author: J P.

description:
This is an updated review. Since the last review I noticed they now had vegetarian ramen. I decided to go back to try and it tastes pretty awesome! The soy broth is a tad thick especially when you get to the end you can see clumps of the remainders. The fried kale is awesome as well as the spinach noodle. Some may taste a tad of sour in the broth but it's pretty good to me! Thumbs up for the unique vegetarian broth!

Disclaimer: takes them a little longer to make than the other bowls of ramen. More than likely everyone else at your table will have their food before you.

I do wish they had appetisers at lunch...at least chicken karage? Their new competition "marufuku ramen" in the mall has lots of appetisers!
author: Carmen L.

description:
This has become my new favorite ramen place in the city!! 

I ordered the Hinodeya Ramen and it was love at first sip...Their broth was super flavorful and the whole wheat ramen noodles were perfectly chewy. everything about my bowl of ramen was perfect including the soft boiled egg.... I can't wait to come back! :) 
I personally think this place is muchhh better than Mensho.
author: Leilani Y.

description: Probably the best quality ramen I've had in San Francisco and good portion size. A little on the pricey side and the lunch menu was limited to two types of ramen but it was well worth the $15 bucks for a quick lunch. The Hinodeya Ramen broth was quite unique because it's very clear and light but delicious. Come early at 11:30 or earlier because the line was 60 strong for lunch!
author: Billy H.

description: Delicious ramen, great service!! I usually see a line out the door but we decided to get here early on a rainy Friday and were seated immediately in one of the back rooms which only had 2 tables each. The food came out at lightning speed and was delicious. I ordered the house ramen. The broth was very light and different from other ramen places. It made for a light meal which I enjoyed. I also loved the texture of the soft boiled egg and the bamboo shoots. The chashu was not as flavorful as I would like. Overall definitely a very solid and different (in a good way) ramen experience. Will definitely return especially if I'm looking for a lighter meal.
author: Yin H.

description: Pricey but a unique experience of dashi stock ramen. I thought it was decent and a nice break away from the usual tonkatsu broth ramen shops. We had the Hinodeya ramen and chicken karaage. Both were pretty good. The ramen noodles were thick cut whole wheat noodles in a very strong dashi broth. (Dashi is a fish stock type of broth). There was chashu, menma (bamboo shoots), half of a stewed egg, and a lot of green onions. The chashu was very tasty. The noodles were unique and went well with the dashi broth. The karaage chicken was moist and crispy, and came with a matcha dipping salt which was a nice touch. It was a cool experience. The staff was very friendly as well, and gave us hand towels before the meal.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I've heard so much hype of this place. Today was the day I finally I finally got it and I was not disappointed. The ambiance was really modern and clean with the most amazing attentive staff ever! Best part was that their was no wait time! Yay! Alright let's talk food!  Here is what me and my friends ordered:

Fried oysters $8
Chicken kaarage with matcha salt $8
Hinodeya (house ramen) $14
Tori Paitan $15

You must MUST start your meal with both the fried oysters and chicken kaarage that comes with green match salt. The matcha in the matcha salt is very subtle but it does make a slight difference crispy piping hot chicken kaarage. It's the perfect appetizer before diving into rich flavorful ramen. Now why is it so popular? It's all about the execution of the dishes, and the base of the broth that makes people go woah that's different. What drawn me to try this place was that Hinodeya ramen base was dashi! Hinodeya dashi is made of a tuna fish and kombu seaweed. Now let's dissect this ramen. You know it's a good ramen place when the following things happen: the pork was melting in your mouth, the egg yolk was stil runny and the broth didn't need much additional fixings. It's a really good ramen spot to go to when your in the Jtown area. 

Tip: once you tasted the broth and are well into your meal, I suggest adding two teaspoons of the garlic chili oil. ITS A GAME CHANGER! It boosted the broth 100x times. I HIGHLY SUGGEST ADDING that oil! 

Parking: if you come at night, their is plenty of parking. If you come in the afternoon, their is a parking garage, residential parking 4 blocks away, and meter parking. 

Would I come back? 
If I was ever in the Jtown area, then Yes I definitely would come back.
author: Roseanne V.

description:
On a cherry blossom festival afternoon, I happened to come by Hinodeya ramen with no line. Hinodeya has been around for centuries in Japan, I believe this is their first location overseas. 

What we got: 

Tori paitan ramen - Rich broth served with a chicken wing, poached egg, mushroom and seaweed. It's a richer broth but smaller ramen portion for good reason. The broth was pretty heavy, if there was more ramen, I'd be bloated afterward. I've never had chicken wings in my ramen and I thought it was going to be tricky to eat but it actually fell right off the bone! I appreciated this small detail Hinodeya put in. The meat was tender and soft. The egg was perfectly poached too.

Hinodeya ramen - The broth is lighter but there's a bigger portion of ramen. It comes with chashu, bamboo shoots and seaweed. It wasn't too heavy but it could use some more seasoning for flavor. Chashu could be fattier too. 

I recommend getting the tori paitan if you want a richer broth or if you prefer something light, go for the Hinodeya. 

One thing to note, the menu was limited during the festival hours. Given the large crowds and high demand for food, take out ramen was offered for $10.
author: Virginia Y.

description:
Great ramen - the broth here is light and flavorful and an alternative from the fatty broths at other ramen shops. 

We came here as a party of 3 around 6:50 pm on a Sunday night - we only had to wait a few minutes before being seated at a shared table. I noticed that after 7 was when a crowd of people started rolling in - come before 7 pm to avoid a wait! 

We ordered two side dishes to share: a raw octopus mixed with wasabi and some vegetables (I don't think the dish was on the menu.) It was very, very small - the octopus was cut into tiny pieces, such that it's hard to pick up any taste other than the wasabi that covered it (that surface area to volume ratio.) We also had the crispy fried yam. The name of this dish was deceiving for us - my boyfriend ordered our side dishes for us, so our friend and I didn't read the description of the dish. It's actually nagaimo, not the usual yellow/orange yam we pictured. I've never had nagaimo before and wasn't a huge fan of this dish - it tasted like deep fried lotus root.... and that doesn't go well together. 

We all ordered the Hidoneya house ramen. It was delicious! There's also an assortment of sauces available on the dining table, such as umami oil. The dashi soup was unexpectedly rich in flavor. The whole wheat ramen noodles were also great - I like the chewy texture. The only complaint is that the soup was too flavorful... as we neared the last bites of our ramen, the dish was especially salty. We had to drink so much water to overcome the saltiness. 

The atmosphere of the restaurant was bolstering and friendly. The waiters were very outgoing and checked on us to make sure all our dishes arrived.

Overall, I would definitely come here again, and try their vegan ramen and desserts!
author: Christine L.

description:
3.5 stars.

This was my first time trying both dashi and chicken broth, and while they weren't bad, I'm definitely still loyal to my tonkatsu. My friend and I came for late lunch during the Cherry Blossom Festival and were able to be seated after waiting about 5 min - they actually seated us ahead of someone who was there first but whose party had not arrived yet, so make sure everyone in your group is there to get seated!

The star of the chicken paitan ramen was definitely the chicken wing, whose meat just fell off the bone and had a flavor reminiscent of braised Chinese food LOL. The noodles were perfectly chewy, but I felt like the portion size was a little small, especially for the price. The broth was creamy and flavorful, but definitely heavier and more oily than the tonkatsu broths I'm used to. I actually preferred the dashi broth, which was light and had a hint of seaweed flavor but no fishiness, so I would probably get the Hinodeya ramen if I came here again.

While I wasn't disappointed by their ramen, it wasn't exactly mindblowing either, but I was also only able to order from the limited menu available during the festivities. I'd be willing to come back to try the tsukemen off the regular menu, and if you've never had these two broths before you should at least give it a try. I'm just not sure the pricing is justified when you can find cheaper and equally (or more) delicious ramen elsewhere in the city.
author: KC W.

description: I decided to get out of my tonkotsu comfort zone and come here for a birthday meal. Quite an incredibly different experience, but I do recommend it if you want the same. I started off with the fried rice and karaage and they were definitely worth it. If you're not familiar with this kind of ramen, it's a seafood dashi broth. It still retains a saltiness but it's very light and doesn't put you to sleep. The noodles were thicker but there was a quality to it that paired very well with everything else. The egg was my favorite part, they nailed that for sure. Among their special ramen, they do have a chicken ramen which I wanted to try as a transition to a lighter flavor but I'd honestly just go for their special.
author: Krysta M.

description:
We were around japantown on a Friday night because of my uji time craving and figured we should just get dinner here. Unfortunately most of the restaurants inside the Japan center are notoriously terrible and marufuku had an enormous line as always. We came across Hinodeya after initially deciding to go to Yamadaya. There was no wait for a table for 2 when we arrived but the place was fairly full.

We both got the house hinodeya ramen. The broth was light and flavorful at the same time. The noodles had great texture and were perfectly al dente. The only thing was that the meat was a bit dry but it was ok.

Be sure to use their chili garlic oil on the side of the table!!
author: Dani T.

description:
Even though the wait was long, this place gets five stars from me for making ramen that reminds me of my mom's. Service is relatively fast considering how crowded it is here, and they're all friendly -- yay! 

The broth is dashi based, not tonkotsu like those at many other ramen spots, so it's lighter and less salty. Still has a great depth of flavor while being more refreshing. The bowl comes with bamboo shoots, soft-boiled shoyu egg, green onions and chashu. The soft-boiled egg was not overcooked, and was so flavorful with a creamy orange yolk. Definitely high quality ingredients used here, so I didn't feel completely horrible for spending $14 on ramen.
author: Hana S.

description:
When I walked in during lunch time on Sunday, I was immediately greeted by the lovely smell of ramen. This was what I needed for a cold SF day! There was only one party ahead of us, so we ended up waiting around 10 minutes before a table opened up. 

When I suggested Hinodeya, I wasn't expecting dashi ramen. Before Hinodeya, I've only experienced chicken and pork-based broth ramen, never fish broth! The Dashi broth was perfect for a lunch meal! The broth is on the lighter side, so I wasn't compelled to slip into a food coma afterwards. 

I ordered the House Ramen ($14), and there was a good amount of menma, one piece of nori, half an ajitama egg, two slices of chashu, and lots of green onion. The ajitama egg was meh. While the egg was perfectly soft-boiled, it wasn't very marinated and tasted flavorless. The chasu was very tender and not overly fatty. 

We also ordered the Chicken karage. The inside was very juicy, but overall pretty light on the flavoring. While I enjoyed dipping it in the matcha salt, I would probably skip this next time I find myself here. 

Overall, would definitely swing by again when I'm craving a lighter bowl of ramen.
author: Angela W.

description: This review is based solely on the house Hinodeya Ramen, which is a traditional Japanese dashi style soup made from bonito, kombu, and scallop (according to the menu). The broth was as good as any ramen I have had. It has an incredible depth of flavor while at the same time being light unlike many pork or chicken-based ramen broths. It was simply delicious.
author: David Y.

description:
I ordered the house ramen and fried yams.
Its really good. The broth was light and not too salty. The noodles were so good. Tasted very fresh.
The fried yams came out different than what I imagined. I thought I was going to get something that resembled yellow sweet potatoes but it was white and lightly fried sitting on a bed of peanut sauce. It wasn't sweet, it was starchy. The peanut sauce was sweet which gave a nice balance to the plain tasting yams. When the yam is in your mouth you feel a sliminess close to that of okra. If you mind this type of texture maybe the yam isn't for you but i found the fried yams had a medley of taste and texture which I enjoyed greatly. 
The staff was nice and efficient.
author: Carmen L.

description:
One of my favorite ramen spot in SF. This was my second time here and it was as good as the first.

I got Shishito peppers and house ramen. In my opinion the shishito peppers were a bit undercooked. The ramen on the flip side was great, the egg was cooked perfectly and so were the noodles. 

I would definitely come back!
author: Josh Giosue D.

description: First time here. Ordered the edemame which were warm and salty. Yum! Had the House (Hinodeya Ramen) which was wonderful. The service was friendly and efficient. No wonder there is s kind as soon as they open. I will definitely return.
author: Mary K.

description: Was excited to try this place since it has good reviews.  There wasn't much ramen choices to choose from.  We got the house ramen and the chicken ramen, and also chicken karaage.  Upon receiving our bowls we notice how small and empty it looks compare to other ramen places.  The house ramen came with 2 thin slices of meat and was pretty bland.  The chicken ramen came with 2 chicken wings that didn't have any taste to it.  The chicken karaage was decent.  However the service was great and the staff are very friendly.
author: Len L.

description:
Came here after a suggestion from a friend...glad I did!

There is a line as soon as you come up to this place-usually a good sign for quality food. The ambiance is fantastic and the ramen  is TOP Notch  with great pricing and a wonderful Sake Flight special at $10 . 

I had the House Ramen but next time will definitely try the Clam Ramen next time I'm in the Bay Area. This is a must come to Spot! Make this Ramen bar the top of your list when visiting San Francisco!
author: Michael M.

description:
Came the week after they opened and the line didn't start forming until 11:20 a.m. 10 minutes before opening. The restaurant filled up immediately after opening and when we left about an hour later there were still about 6 people waiting outside to be seated. 

Overall, it was just okay to me. The ramen isn't bad but it's also not mindblowing. 

I tried both the Hinodeya house ramen and the Tori Paitan and they were both just average. The broth didn't have enough depth in flavor and the noodles were just okay. The Tori Paitan is not as creamy and thick as Mensho's for those who are wondering. 

I don't think I'll be coming back.
author: Mai Y.

description:
I came here on a Thursday at 7 PM for a solo dinner.  I was able to get seated right away but I took the last seat at the bar ;) I saw that other parties also started forming lines to wait for a table. 

I was quickly approached to get drinks and to get my stuff set up (they give you a warm, wet towel, pretty coool!) the selection isn't that big, so it was easy to choose which ramen I wanted. I just got the typical house one. 

I was quickly served luckily! They forgot the order of the dude next to me, so he actually got his ramen (same ramen) like 10 mins later than me when I was seated after him. I felt so bad for him! 

Overall, the food is okay. It's not the best ramen I've had. The noodles were a bit too hard for my liking. The broth was not that rich. It was very clear but it tastes decent! Maybe that's their specialty? The best thing about the ramen was the chashu. It tasted amazing.

I just feel like this restaurant is a little overhyped though. The atmosphere is Great, but I tend to like the one across the street more. The food is a 3 stars! Service for me was 4, but I'm gonna stay at 3 stars because they forgot the order of the dude next to me. Poor guy.
author: Jen K.

description: Mmm, house ramen, your crisp, clean broth warms my stomach and my heart. Appetizers here are so, so, but if you're looking for something to nosh on before your big bowl of housemade ramen noodles and succulent char siu, get a plate of kara-age (5 pieces w/lemon and matcha salt). It won't be the best fried chicken and batter you've ever had at a Japanese restaurant, but it'll pair well with a big plate of shishito peppers. However, when that ramen comes, it will come piping hot and chock-full of green onions. For $14, this is a pretty good portion of food, especially if you're not a big eater. There's no kaedama here, so do not expect a refill, but service is fantastic, and seating is not difficult. Will be back!
author: Danny C.

description: I got the Chicken Paitan Ramen. It tasted good, but beware the size of the bowl is incredibly small. My husband and I both left super hungry and had to get more food elsewhere.
author: Grace M.

description:
This place has been on my bookmark list for a long while. I was visiting Japantown for the cherry blossom festival and decided to give this place a try!

* * * EXPERIENCE * * *
I arrived before 11:30am which is supposed to be their opening time on Sunday, saw this place was half full already. I guess they have special open hours because of the festival? Outside the door they actually divided the waiting line area into "to-go" and "dine-in". I'm not sure if the to-go is a thing they always do or just for this weekend though. 

Went into the store with the usual "Irasshaimase" welcome. Service was quick and every staff really paid attention to each customer. The lunch menu wrote "Limited menu for Cherry Blossom Festival" but I didn't find anything special there. Oh well, in terms of ramen there were only two choices - Hinodeya Ramen which is a house ramen, and Tori Paitan with chicken broth flavor. I was very tempted to try the Tori one as I wanted to see how its compared with Mensho which I regard as pretty much the best ramen in SF. But to give a fair judgement to the restaurant I felt I should go with the House ramen instead.

* * * FOOD * * *
Hinodeya Ramen: A.
Surprisingly good! First look of the soup, I hesitated if I really made the right choice because it's very clear (with some oil drops) and a lot of times clear/watery can be two interchangeable descriptions. But after I took the first sip I had a lack of word to describe the clear yet rich, non-salty soup base. According to their website, the soup base is made with kelp, dried bonito flakes, dried small sardines mainly with some chicken and scallop to complete it. So it's all seafood and a bit of white meat, but how they made it so rich and flavorful with these ingredients remains unknown to me. 

The noodle was pretty spongy (hard boiled) which is my favorite style. This ramen comes with half egg by default but I added two halves as additional toppings which was perfect, the eggs were very flavorful and very soft, one of the best soft-boiled egg I have had. Chashu was to the point in terms of flavor and tenderness but nothing spectacular, and it only came with 1 piece. What I think as an amazing touch was actually the green onion - it's not the usual tiny circular shape green onion, those were more of long oval shapes and they were super fresh, it enhanced taste of the soup to be even better, richer.

This ramen costs $14 and with the addition of egg ($2 extra) and tax the total was $17.36, so we are talking about the expensive spectrum of SF pricing for a ramen. But it was really good I think it could be justified.

I will definitely come back again and try the Tori ramen!
author: Simon C.

description:
I write this review with great pleasure to honor an incredible restaurant, but also with resentment because I don't want y'all to make the waits any longer. And the waits aren't even that bad.

*food*
This is the go-to-ramen-joint when you want unpretentious ramen. The flavors here are light, not greasy, and still give you pep in your step after eating a steamy bowl of ramen noodles. No food comas, thanks. 

You will usually find me ordering a starter of karaage chicken or fried oysters. More often than not, I will order the crispy, delicate chicken that comes with some green tea salt on the side and a lemon wedge. They come perfectly breaded and crispy in sizes that last 3-5 bites depending on how hungry you are. After carefully squeezing the lemon wedge with one hand over the chicken and the other covering the splatter of acidic juices darting towards my friends' eyes, you dab the chicken in some of the matcha-like salt, take a bite and tasty that tender, chicken juiciness.  After 2 minutes, you look at the final piece of chicken with a little bit of guilt, wondering if it would be possible to split the last piece with everyone else. The answer is usually yes, just use your hands and don't try to pry it with your chopsticks like a fool.

With perfect timing and graceful fashion, a server picks up your empty chicken plate and another server quickly arrives delivering bowls of magical noodles. The first thing you notice is the presentation - beautiful bowls that look like gardens of springy, ramen noodles, crispy, roasty nori, perfect little rectangle bamboo shoots, large oval chunks of clean looking chashu pork, and green onion shavings - all swimming in a glistening, but not overly oily pool of dashi broth. Tableside you have some condiments of garlic chili oil and an umami paste made from Bonito & Scallop - I overload on these condiments sometimes because they're just so damn good. The noodles have a perfect springy bite to them and I find myself attempting to slurp as loud as possible to pay my respects. Still an amateur at slirping. After eating all the goodies, you lift the bowl up to your face to give a good slirp of the soup until all you see is the art painted onto the beautiful bowls they use. And after all that food, you don't feel nasty or oily, just perfectly content and satisfied. 

Morover, their selection of Sakes is on point. 

*Decor* 
The space is broken up into a large main area with community tables in the center, 2-4 seating side tables along the walls, a ramen bar on the right side. And towards the back rooms, they have barriers that separate 2-4 seating side tables that have a corridor to the back where the restroom is. There is Japanese decor right when you enter the front, modern wood textures and when you look up above the community tables you see lightbulbs intertwined with a wooden branch chandelier. All together, it feels real, authentic, and right- it feels balanced. 

*Service*
Over the 10+ times I've been here, there hasn't really been waits, and if there was, they weren't longer than 15-20 minutes. Just prepared to line up outside and have enough to wear as it can get cold because it is San Francisco. As soon as you are seated, water arrives to the table and you are welcomed with a smile. Service is quick and courteous. What I love most is that last time I came with my sister who has a laundy list of food restrictions, and the server listened intently and with caution to make sure she got it right. The food came and one thing was off and they quickly came up with a creative solution to provide my sister with a tasty bowl of custom ramen. 

I will most likely be coming back here for life.
author: Geronimo Carlo R.

description:
Excellent ramen with a much lighter dashi broth. We went for lunchtime and there was no wait. We ordered the Chicken Paitan and the house ramen, both of which were soooo incredibly good. The noodles were the perfect consistency, the broth was ideally seasoned, and all of the condiments inside the noodles complimented each other greatly.

Definitely different from the normal tonkotsu ramen, but a refreshing difference. Give it a try! I loved it.
author: Alisha R.

description:
My family and I came across this ramen place when we were walking to Japan Town. There was a line already formed outside the restaurant 20 minutes before opening, so we lined up without knowing much about the place. I was surprised that this place had so much popularity already with only 200 reviews on yelp.

The ramen here is dashi based, meaning all of the ramen broths are relatively light on the stomach. I ordered the original ramen and the broth was delightful. It was light yet flavorful and came with a perfectly cooked egg. The noodles were clearly fresh by their elastic texture and bounciness. 

This place is pricey. The cheapest ramen is the original ramen and it comes to $14 a bowl. The ramen portion is average sized, it comes with one tiny slice of meat, only HALF an egg, and a bamboo shoots. For a price that high it should definitely be coming with multiple slices of meat and a full egg at least! The meat was also very bland and had no texture or taste. 

Overall, the ramen is really good, but it's not worth the price. My family of 4 ordered 4 ramen bowls and our bill came out to $70 with tax and tip. That was with no appetizers as well! I would say this is a place to try once, but then not come back.
author: Ashley D.

description:
Fine, not great. Swung by in a pinch today after realizing that Marufuku's closed on Mondays.

-Ordered the House Ramen, which visually looked better than it tasted. I didn't like the broth (very basic) or chashu (rubbery) in particular. The soft boiled egg was good.
-It didn't take long to get seated since I was by myself, yet my one ramen order took 25 minutes. 

Probably won't return soon.
author: Leah F.

description:
I'm more into the deathly ramen that clogs your everything, so this was a slight departure.

First off, $15 for a bowl of ramen is pretty redic. Bae got that one, and though he liked it, he didn't feel that the price was justified. I tried it, but my opinion wasn't so strong that idr how I felt lol

I settled on the chicken version, and preferred the chicken ramen in Costa Mesa more. It was definitely veered on the clean palette.

The broths are on the lighter side, and I was expecting a punch of flavor and guilt, but I suppose my hopes were too high. It helped that the various condiment tray was available to heighten the flavors.

On a rainy day , we waited in a slightly long line that was around 30m. 

We also got the chicken wings and those were interesting. The flavor of the wings was nothing to write home about.

Service was nice so that's good :)
author: Angela B.

description:
After a strenuous 9 mile hike around Muir Woods, we were craving ramen. 

We happened to come across this one & decided to try it out. Parking sucks in Japan town & one thing I learned about SF is that there's always parking next to a church. So we parked at the cathedral & walked to Japan town.

Their menu is limited, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing. I got chicken karage ($8) & their house ramen ($14). A bit on the pricier side, but that's what the city is like.

I usually get tonkotsu broth, but that wasn't an option here so I got their traditional house ramen. Their broth is flavorful & savory. They had Tabera (garlic & onion w/ chili oil) & Umami oil on the side. I love garlic so I added like 6 spoons of the oil & decided I'd try a few spoons of their Umami oil as well. The garlic oil is self explanatory & the Umami oil (after trying it for the first time) really brought out the ramen's flavor. No regrets!

Overall, it was good. I'd come back again!
author: Janelli B.

description:
No line today !! I am glad I tried and see what is the hype.
Small menu, small portions great service and atmosphere.
author: Alison W.

description:
Food

-The fried oysters: yum
-Fried chicken: yum, but small, still yum. 

The green tea seasoning powder should not be on the oysters though (don't be confused if you get both), it's for the chicken and it's really good. And the sauce is for the oysters not the chicken. But you could dip the chicken in it.

House Ramen: pretty good. I never had the original whole wheat noodles it came with, but apparently that's bomb. My cousin and I copied his friend and got a different noodle substituted in from one of the other ramens.. Since I've never had the whole wheat noodles that the House Ramen usually comes with so I thought it was good, but my cousin said the Whole Wheat is actually better. 

There weren't that many noodles.. my cousin said there is usually more.

I think the biggest thing for my party was that the only beer on tap was flat. And they didn't believe us. It was most definitely flat. So they asked their friend who knows how to ask anything without sounding like a jerk.. that didn't work though..

But, I really liked the Sansho beer though that they have in bottles. It's a Japanese herb ale. 

I'd eat here again.. maybe just with my cousin or cousins or depending on which friends of theirs... 
-

I'm so sorry to whoever (specifically one waitress) had to deal with our table. We were a party of seven (six were all guys) and of which.. three (less than half) were a smidge rowdy. I think it was sweet how the older waitress asked if I was okay sitting there. I think she was just making sure I didn't want to be somewhere I didn't want to be. So I appreciate that. 

The younger waitress who was also helping us was so happy and friendly the entire night. So I was glad that at least one person wasn't bothered. My party really liked her. I liked both of them.
author: Lilian L.

description:
Came after a massage with the gf.  Tried the chicken karage which came with 5 pieces and was pretty moist and juicy.  It came with a green salt to dip the pieces.

Ordered the Hinodeya ramen which had a clear broth and 2 pieces of pork.  A tad on the salty side, but otherwise soup tasted good.  Added in some of the garlic/onion/chili oil condiment and it made the soup even better.
author: Allen M.

description: Food was outstanding.  The less than 5 star rating was simply due to the service which was a little slow after the ramen was brought to the table (water glasses sat empty for quite a while).
author: Brittainy M.

description:
We were lucky to get seated right when we arrived because a huge line formed immediately afterwards. I enjoy that they have a simple menu with just two ramen choices for lunch, which made my decision-making that much easier --especially when I'm hungover and hangry. We both ordered the Hinodeya Ramen ($14). Although I usually opt for a spicy ramen, it was still great because they had the spicies on the table for you to add yourself. They even have bonito flakes and fried garlic too!

The bowl of ramen included bamboo shoots, half an egg, one slice of chashu, and chopped green onions. There was a bit too much green onions for my liking, but everything else was cooked wonderfully. For a light broth, I was surprised at how much flavor it had. I pretty much finished my entire bowl to the last drop of broth. The meal is small and pricey, but satisfactory.
author: Cindy Z.

description: You win some, you lose some. I've been disappointed by some places, and awed by others. I love it when I walk into a place holding few expectations and am blown away. Hinodeya Ramen Bar is that kind of place. Authentic, carefully prepared, healthy, delicious ramen. Creative beer selection, including the delicious herbal Sancho Japanese Ale. And top-notch, friendly, knowledgeable people who make dining here a memorable experience. Really want to try all 3 of their Ramens. The house Ramen was a total winner. I wanna come back sood get blown away again...
author: Kelly P.

description:
I heart dashi. When my time comes, please immerse me in a bathtub full of dashi broth and I will die happy. 

Hinodeya took a little while to find its stride. At first, the food was inconsistent, but over time they seem to have gotten good momentum in the kitchen. On most visits, the ramen is fantastic. The side dishes are all very well done. The service is very good. 

Hinodeya is now my favorite ramen place in Japantown.
author: Horace A.

description: Best ramen in Bay Area. I couldn't find anything similar or closer to this in New York, L.A., Cupertino,  San Mateo, or anywhere else in the City.
author: Fiona K.

description:
Their "off menu" vegetarian ramen is BOMB. So good! I LOVE porky ramen, but lately my true test of the quality of a ramen spot is how they do the veggie ramen. This place was DELICIOUS. That said, I leaned over and tried my friend's porky ramen... wow! I'll get that next time.

I normally don't like anything but the curly noodles, but these impressed! Delicate portions but filling. 

Kaarage chicken - some of the best I've ever had. 
Eggs - cooked to perfection!
Beer selection - hitachino!
author: BeckyZão A.

description:
Update: I went back to the ramen bar. Same fast service but this time we tried the limited edition lemon pepper (cold) as well as the clam broth (warm) ramens. They were amazing with depths of flavors and surprising flavors. It totally hit the spot and definitely going to come back for more seasonal dishes! 

Fast service. Tasty fish-based broth (house ramen). Al-Dante noodle. No crazy thirst after drinking most of the broth. Well done!
author: Eve H.

description:
I was in Japantown Sunday morning, took a break from it, and then I ended off my Sunday with Japantown at night.

- Hinodeya Ramen: the soft boiled egg was perfect. The noodles were chewy, and the cha siu literally melted in my mouth. However, I thought the portions were small for the price, and there weren't that many toppings, but I was full from the bowl, so at least I was satisfied. It was a good bowl of ramen, but not mind-blowing at $16. Nevertheless, it was a good way to warm up on a rainy evening and to end off my Japantown festivities.
author: Joanna C.

description:
Overdue review! Excited to hear there is a new ramen chain in town. Came here during lunch time and waited about ~20 minutes. There's no waiting list so you are pretty much have to stand in line

After doing some research this is the first shop that opened outside of Japan! Hinodeya Ramen Bar specializes in dashi style ramen. The restaurant uses dashi stock of Skipjack tuna fish and seaweed which is different than normal tonkotsu broth (pork stock). Interesting concept since dashi style soup aren't normally used for ramen. 

I really wanted to try the karaage with matcha salt but it's only during dinner time.
author: Frances K.

description:
Hinodeya standard dashi ramen - RamenRating overall 3.5/5:

Noodles 3/5 - Good for whole wheat noodles, not as firm as regular
Broth 3.5/5 - On the thinner side, but not too fishy, flavorful. Interesting.
Chashu 3/5 - Cooked well 
Toppings 3.5/5 - Egg was cooked perfectly soft, good green onions and bamboo, sesame seeds
Spicyiness - not spicy, but the garlic/chili oil topping was a great addition 
Value 4/5 - $14 for a medium sized portion
author: Billy D.

description:
What I absolutely LOVE about Hinodeya is how different the noodles are compared to any other ramen shops. They have these whole-wheat noodles that appear and taste more like hand pulled noodles than the thin, curvy, and yellowey ramen noodles we're all used to seeing. The noodles were a bit chewy (i love texture), definetly not overcooked (not mushy), and were able to sit in the broth without sucking up all the soup. Make sense? :) In your bowl, you'll also find a generous portion of fresh chopped scallions (yay!)! 

The Dashi broth was refreshing and light. We loved our first taste of the broth (flavorful, light, full of umami), but then as you slurp more and more, it gets more and more salty, which begs you to gulp down water...... 

Overall, I recommend Hinodeya and am so glad that Japantown FINALLY has a good ramen place! Go around 5 to avoid the line. If you get there around 6, you'd have to wait. Price is a bit high ($16 and $18 for our bowls of deliciousness) but I guess the owners have to pass on some of that expensive SF rent to us.
author: Dana Z.

description: Junk gyoza, horrendous Karage, and mediocre Ramen.  The only decent element was the noodle quality, but, poorly cooked.  Need some actual Japanese in the kitchen, or at least some who have spent time cooking ramen professionally in Japan.  More "Japan Town" garbage.
author: Dan M.

description:
I've been wanting to try their ramen since the announcement that they were opening a permanent location in SF a few years back.  Finally decided to go after the stress of a midterm.

I got the house ramen.

This place is good if you know what you're looking for.  Period.  It's not your typical ramen joint.  The noodles are weirdly shaped, almost like a very skinny linguine.  The broth is absolutely perfect if you're looking for something light and is dashi flavored.  The chashu is good.  The soft boiled egg wasn't perfectly soft boiled, but still passes for a good soft boiled egg.  Service...  Whoever runs this place is doing a great job at hiring.  Service is courteous, fast, and overall great.  Only thing I didn't received was the massive thank you that a lot of the workers say to leaving customers.  No biggie though.

Absolutely gonna come back if I'm looking for some light ramen.

Overall:
Noodles:  4/5
Broth:  4.5/5
Chashu:  4.5/5
Soft boiled egg:  4.5/5
Service:  4.75/5
author: Alvin D.

description: We ordered 2 house ramens and one zen (vegan) ramen. The best meal we've had in the city. The ramens were all extremely well-balanced, layers of flavors, refreshing but fulfilling. Would recommend this to anyone visiting SF and living here.
author: Keren G.

description: Best ramen I've ever had. Miles better than ippudoo in Berkeley. I got one of the pork ramens and there was plenty of meat inside it. The broth has so much flavor, I can't even describe it. The wait can get petty long and there's no electronic system of notification so you just have to hang around the area and check in when you think it's time. But defiantly worth it.
author: Kalani R.

description:
I love their take on chasu and the egg is just perfect! I ordered the house ramen and it's the best! The only downside I have to add is that the texture and style of noodles is not to my highest preference (as compared to noodles from ipuudo) 

I loved the broth and the garlic chili oil! You must try your ramen with the garlic chili oil, I wanted to keep adding more and more (lol) 

I will be back!
author: Cari Y.

description:
RAMENNNN!!!! This is the spot if you're in the mood!! Any type of ramen here hits one juuuuust right~

I've actually had the privilege of dining here twice before getting the courage to write this up. It was an epic meal BOTH times that I hope I can do again soon.

I tried both the bowls of ramen in my exploits here. The TORI PAITEN was amazingggggg with a full umami taste. It has braised chicken or "tepasaki" to go with it and the whole wheat noodles were brought out very well. The second time I was able to come, I was able to try their classic dashi broth version, HINODEYA RAMEN. It was cooked with a solid amount of depth and just like the other had a even balance with the noodles. To be honest, I prefer the first one or the tori paiten. Just loved the way the classic chicken ramen broth flavor was brought out. Will be back soon!
author: Daniel O.

description:
Hinodeya Ramen Bar has seriously become one of my favorite ramen places. Originating from Northern Tokyo, owner Masami Kuribara has brought his Ramen genius and powerful flavors to SF and you can definitely taste it! 

For starters, the karagge chicken and fried oysters paired with the green matcha salt are the perfect start to a meal. When it comes to ramen, the Hinodeya Ramen is where it is at! Not like your regular broth and noodle, this ramen has a dashi (fish based translucent broth) and home made wheat noodles. No MSG, no unnecessary fats. It also has one of the runniest and sexiest eggs in SF. In addition, they also have a good not so thick Tori paitan and are working on a vegetarian and seafood ramen. 

To end my wonderful meal, their dessert was A true star. The Kuro Goma with granola (Black sesame ice cream with Japanese rice crispy) was the perfect palette cleanser! If you want to treat yourself even more, you must get the Matcha Cappuccino (jelly consistency but soft and Mouth watering texture). While the wait might seem long, it only takes 30 minutes tops and it's way better than waiting for Mensho!!!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
There was a long line for lunch on a weekend but it moves really quickly. It was only about a 15 minute wait. The service is exceptionally friendly and efficient. They asked what we wanted to order the moment we sat down.

Unfortunately for lunch they don't serve fried oysters but we got the cheese royal ($5) side dish. It was small blocks of soft cheese (cream cheese texture) that had been marinated in a unique, strong Japanese flavor. I liked it but couldn't have too much of it. We tried both the Hinodeya Ramen ($14) and Tori Paitan ($15). I liked the clear, lighter flavor of the Hinodeya Ramen but definitely preferred the richer flavor of the Tori Paitan. The noodles had a great springy texture and the egg was perfectly cooked!

Overall if you love ramen this is definitely a place to check out in SF.
author: Linda X.

description:
I'm not an expert on ramen in the city, but I have had ramen in Japan so I kind of know what I'm talking about ;)

I discovered this place on Yelp, looking for a ramen spot that had both meat and vegetarian options. The reviews looked good, menu was simple, so we went here. 

I've now been here twice because it's just so great. I get the zen ramen and add a marinated egg for $2. This place is a little pricy but it's so worth it. The broth is amazing, I love the big mushrooms, the noodles are perfect, and the egg is soooo good.

Service is always really quick. And you are always greeted as soon as you walk in.
author: Mika S.

description:
TL;DR: Great service with two delicious ramen offerings. I'd totally rate this place in the Top 5 of ramen places in San Francisco. 

I've been dying to try this restaurant since it opened up. My party of 3 showed up around 6:00pm on a weeknight and were seated in less than 10 minutes. The interior was super clean and modern. I'd recommend coming early or during a non-busy dinner time to avoid the lines. By the time we finished our ramen, there was a pretty long wait. 

Today, I ordered the Hinodeya Ramen ($14), which was their traditional dashi-ramen with a light broth. Toppings included: ramen noodles (whole-wheat) chashu pork, menma (mhmm), soft-cooked marinated egg (perfectly cooked), dried seaweed and green onions.

I couldn't believe how delicious the broth was. It was jam-packed with a subtle flavor of bonito, kombu and scallop - a truly culturally taste of a traditional Japanese style soup.

Pro-tip: Although they give you a lot of noodles, make sure to savory each and every bite! Yes - that means eat slow! It's totally worth it. They only give you a slice of chashu pork, so if you're a huge meat eater, feel free to add additional toppings. 

Overall, I'm a believer of this recently hyped new ramen place. I'd totally go here again. I paid about $17 bucks for a bowl with tip and tax.
author: Chinsin S.

description:
3.75 but rounding up. House ramen was decent, though only two very paper thin slices of pork. Broth is a Dashi broth (ALL SOUP BROTH JS DASHI BROTH). Very light. 
I ordered extra Menma, but because it was cold, it made the soup lukewarm. 

Fiancé had the clam ramen, which was perfect with the Dashi broth. Very generous clam portion and flavor was sweet and just like the ocean. 

We would come back, for the clam ramen. 

Had a sake and chicken karaage too. Chicken was ok. Matcha salt - you can only taste the matcha on its own. With the chicken, it disappears.
author: Olivia C.

description:
Takeaway: great bowl of ramen. Broth is different from other places. Portion is kind of small.

Their whole premise is based on the dashi broth. It's much lighter and cleaner, and kind of reminds me of a clarified chicken broth. The house ramen ($14) is based around the dashi broth, while the chicken ramen ($15) is a thicker, starchier version of the broth that is more traditional with other ramen places.

Breaking down the bowl:
- Broth- excellent. I liked both house and chicken.
- Ramen noodles- I wouldn't mind if it were a bit chewier. It's also a little bit of a thicker noodle.
- Half of an egg- perfectly cooked soft-boiled egg. Too bad it's only half.
- Protein- either chashu with the house ramen (fine) or braised chicken wings (excellent and tender).

Plus some green onions, and that's it. A pretty simple bowl. Ramen portion is kind of small, but leaves you fullish, just not satisfied.

One thing I really loved is the umami paste and garlic in chili oil on the table. Both are delicious accompaniments to the ramen bowl. Definitely try both.

Line moved pretty quickly. We got there around 6pm on a Saturday and only waited 15 mins.
author: Alice T.

description:
I hate writing reviews but I couldn't keep quiet about this place. Everything we ordered was super tasty!

We ordered the Hinodeya ramen, tori paitan and the karaage. We also got a sake flight and it came with three pieces of the cheese royal. Delicious stuff!! The broth for both ramens was flavorful and not overly salty, and the balance of toppings were perfect. They let me get my tori paitan with bamboo shoots instead of shiitake. My husband said he prefers the char shu for the Hinodeya ramen to be softer but it really hit the spot for me. We both loved the chicken wings! The hearty, chewy noodles go well with the light broth. As for the karaage, just get it. You're not going to regret it I promise.

Also, it may not be for everyone but I highly recommend taking a pea sized portion of the umami paste and adding it to your broth half way through for an extra kick. 

The menu is pretty limited, including extra toppings to choose for your ramen but I get the sense that everything is curated to go well with each other - they have it down to a science. Even the green onions on top was the perfect amount!

PS. Matcha cappuccino was a great refreshing dessert. I thought I wasn't going to be able to finish it bc I was so full, but it was not overly sweet and full of different textures, I finished it in no time :)
author: Lulu H.

description:
Finally got to try out this new ramen restaurant that I've heard so much about, and it was....disappointing.

I went with 4 other friends on a Saturday. We got there around 8 and were initially worried about the wait, but it was about 20 minutes...not too bad! They opened up this private area in the back with two tables for us and another group of four, so it was pretty quiet where we were.

Their whole menu is pretty simple; there aren't a lot of appetizers and their ramen selection is limited to 2 options (at least for now). You can either get there signature Hinodeya Ramen ($14) which is made from a traditional Japanese style soup, or their Tori Paitan ($15) which has a rich chicken and dashi broth. My friends all went with the Hinodeya, but I ordered the Tori Paitan as I was really curious about their version of this ramen compared to Mensho's.

Our food arrived very quickly after ordering, but that was one of the few good things about the meal. 

The biggest problem was the quantity of food felt very little, especially given how pricey the ramen was here. When they tell you there's chashu or a chicken wing in your ramen, they really mean just one small piece. I saw one friend hold up one tiny piece of chashu, and that was all the meat he got for his whole bowl of ramen. If you look at my picture of the tori paitan ramen, everything you see is all the toppings in my ramen (one chicken wing, half of a soft-boiled egg, two shiitake mushrooms, and a piece of seaweed).

The broth for the Tori Paitan was disappointing as well. I love the rich and umami flavor found in a good chicken broth, and I just didn't get that here. Mensho's Tori Paitan broth had much better flavor imo.

The noodles were the saving grace of this meal. We all agreed the noodles, which were nice and firm,and made from buckwheat, were excellent. But beyond that, we all thought this place was overhyped.

Mensho will remain my go to spot for ramen in SF.

Parking was easy to find; I found a residential spot on the next block over without any extra searching. Guess Saturday night isn't a popular time to be visiting Japantown?
author: Dianna H.

description:
Dinner review. 

Karaage - 2/5
Marinated cheese - 3/5

Hinodeya broth - 2/5
Paitan broth - 2/5
Noodles - 3/5
Chashu (Topping) - 2/5
Wings (Topping) - 2/5

Overall, dissapointed. Can't believe this place gets 3.6 on tabelog. Maybe it's the tsukemen that they don't offer here. Regardless, as it is, it's junk. "I've experienced better."
author: Mark O.

description:
While this spot isn't a top contender for ramen in my books, everything was delightfully tasty! I came here with some friends and we tried a little bit of everything.

Aburi Chashu - really good pork belly appetizer and it came with a few generous slices! Nicely charred and crispy on the outside but also incredibly tender and soft.
Karaage - I loved this! Super crispy and juicy chicken thigh pieces with a pinch of green tea salt - you can actually taste the green tea. This would have been better if it came with some kind of dipping sauce. 
Fried oysters - Delicious! I normally don't care for fried oysters since they tend to be on the heavy and oily side but that was not the case at all. 
Hinodeya Ramen - thick al dente noodles with a unique and light dashi broth. It almost felt "healthy" just because the broth wasn't so heavy! The boiled egg was on point.
Tori Paitan Ramen - chicken + dashi based ramen broth that was surprisingly rich and a bit creamy for being made from chicken bones. The consistency is somewhat similar to that of Campbell's chicken noodle soup but not the same of course in terms of flavor, lol. This was good, but I liked the Hinodeya broth more. The chicken leg that came with this was almost a little too soft since it was falling apart in the soup. 

To sum it up, Hinodeya is a pretty good ramen shop and you can taste the quality in their ingredients. It was good to try and a good alternative for a "lighter" ramen meal, but it definitely didn't have that "addictive" quality where I'm always craving it.
author: Jenny O.

description:
It was late... about 9:30 or so? My sister and I decided we were hungry and wanted to share everything so we could try as much as we could.

Fried Garlic. Must I say put this on EVERYTHING THEY SERVE. It's on your table. Might as well. Reminds me of home.

EDAMAME- A typical dish. Nothing stood out. So we smacked that garlic. BAM. Tasty Edamame.

AGE-DASHI FRIED TOFU - I was pretty much indifferent to this dish. Probably because of how mushy it was. Not a mush fan. Bonito flakes made it flavorful but still not to my liking.

OYSTERS FRIED - I'm not sure what it was. but this was delish. Light and fresh. Definitely would try again! Nice crisp and fresh. Not chewy since it wasn't overly cooked.

KARA-AGE - Hands down the highlight of all the dishes. Didn't care much about the matcha salt. Definitely let my sister had that lol. Crispy batter and moist chicken. Thinking about it makes my mouth waters!

HOTATE SMALL RICE BOWL - Definitely one of their simple dishes. Nothing stood out. Rice and scallops.

HINODEYA RAMEN - Bland. Light. Fresh. Clear Broth. It was decent but I wouldn't eat it again. 

KURO-GOMA ICE CREAM W/GRANOLA - Creamy black sesame and not overly sweet. Granola gave it the sweet crunch that was needed.


Overall experience was decent.. Friendly, prompt, and attentive staff. We were one of the last ones to leave and they didn't seem to rush us out. Would I go back? Most likely.
author: Emily L.

description:
This is one of my favorite ramen spots in Japantown but only when there's no wait. 
We lucked out most of the times we visited late at night with a short or no wait. They specialize in light dashi fish broth ramen. Even their chicken paitan ramen has a noticeable dashi fish flavor. I like their chicken karaage with matcha salt. Their matcha cappuccino dessert is good too.

As for the wait, they don't have a waiting list, so if there's a lot of people waiting they won't be able to tell you how long the wait will be. They'll ask you to wait in line, but when we visited groups were waiting in different areas so it's confusing where our place in line would be. We had to rely on the server to remember your face and in which order you checked in.
author: Diana B.

description: Slurp slurp slurp! Hinodeya was a decent find in Japantown! There was a small line at the restaurant on a Saturday night but the wait wasn't too bad. We got the sake flight which came with small cream cheesy cubes that almost tasted like salted caramel (I loved these!). The flight itself had three different sakes, each with a small description of its flavor. We  ordered the tori paitan and while I prefer the one at Mensho for its rich broth, this was enjoyable! I'd only wish the portions were a tad bigger because I left not feeling as full as I would have liked. The servers were friendly and helpful. I will be back next time to try the vegan ramen which my friend raved about. It can get a little loud here so be prepared to raise your voice!
author: Sui N.

description:
At a reasonably priced $14 per bowl, Hinodeya Ramen Bar presents its customers with a decent amount of food which, as a college student, I've come to appreciate. The real winner here is their decently fresh wheat noodles. Sadly, these overshadow the broth. The broth is good, don't get me wrong. It's just not memorable. (Keep in mind I've had spectacular ramen experiences in the last year) Hinodeya also did a great job of perfectly cooking their eggs. Being an egg boy myself, I ordered two extra halves to overcompensate for ramen's notoriously small portion of chasu. 

I ordered the House ramen and was tempted to add on an order of Age-dashi Tofu but wasn't ready to empty out that much money. I saw that they offered Vegan ramen on the menu, so keep that in mind when inviting your veggie friends. I've heard really great things about the Chicken ramen, although it's supposedly slightly less hearty than the House. I can't really see that as a good thing, but I'm an umami fiend. 

The service was exceptional. I liked how they sporadically yelled incoherent Japanese phrases. On my way to the bathroom I noticed that the gray wall of decorations doubled as a door to the above apartment. Pretty neat!

In short, it's a solid go-to place when you're in the mood for a piping hot bowl of ramen! If you're not looking to spend over $20, I would recommend coming to here.
author: Christopher C.

description:
I'm not sure if this is blasphemous in the world of ramen, but I generally think ramen broth is too creamy and thick, and makes you feel kind of gross after consuming a bowl of ramen. The broth for the Hinodeya Ramen (it's an item on the menu, named for the restaurant) is perfect! I've finally found a bowl of ramen that is just the right amount of savory, light enough to drink the whole bowl of soup (which I never do).

What if you (or your friend) prefer creamy broth? Not to worry, the other ramen option on the menu, Tori Paitan, is creamier with more flavor than the Hinodeya Ramen.

The other items on the menu are pretty delicious as well: I recommend the karaage chicken with matcha salt (though to be honest I'm not sure I can taste the matcha in the salt...) and my friends enjoyed the matcha panna cotta for desert, which we were told is a "very traditional" Japanese desert. My only gripes are that tea is overpriced ($4!) and there's often a pretty long wait, so come early!
author: Brittany C.

description: No taste at all for ramen. The worst I ever have. I will not recommend to anyone. And sushi roll not fresh.
author: Dao L.

description:
It looks like I'm in the minority for this rating, but here goes.

I need to get this off my chest first because the biggest thing that stood out to me was the service.
1) The waitress who took our drinks heard "sencha" rather than "Sansho", which is a Japanese herb ale per their menu, but there was no "sencha" on their menu. Okay, honest mistake probably - but if you didn't hear something correctly, maybe ask to clarify rather than guessing incorrectly? I would've said something but my friend ended up drinking it so whatever.
2) The next waitress who took our next round of drinks asked for our ID's but ended up asking how old we are anyway because she couldn't do the math. Maybe I'm just used to bartenders knowing off the top of their head, but I honestly feel you should be prepared if you're asking. After that, it just got awkward with her laughing at herself and switching between "I'm just kidding" and "I'm bad at math".
3) At the end of our meal, I asked the waiter for the dessert menu. He came back and gave it to my male friend sitting across from me. What? If you're only going to bring one dessert menu for a table of 3, you give it to the person who asked for it right? When he came back to take our dessert orders, he also asked my friend what he wanted first. Hello????

Anyway, I ordered the Tori Paitan expecting a thick white soup. But there was nothing thick or white about the very minimal soup in my bowl. It was watery and clear. But the noodles were soft and chewy. The meat from the chicken wings literally fell off the bone from the braising. I added chashu, which was nice, but also made my ramen a whopping $19!!!!!!!!! I think that's too expensive for what it was. I wasn't even full afterwards.

I don't know. Maybe I'm being a ramen snob but this wasn't my cup of tea. And it's such a bummer because I took my two friends here to try it out as their first real ramen experience. If this was my first ramen experience, I probably wouldn't love ramen as much as I do. But they also ordered the Hinodeya (House) Ramen, so maybe their experience was different? Maybe the dinner menu is better somehow? There was definitely no line at 12:30pm on a Friday...
author: Athena C.

description: Been coming here for the past year and it never disappoints me, it's not has heavy and fatty as Marufuku and the staff are always friendly. This is definitely my go-to spot for my ramen fix.
author: Irene R.

description:
Since moving to SF a year ago, I've regularly complained about my terrible luck with ramen and reminisce about my favorite spots in LA.

I can finally say that I've found a place that has what I expect in a good bowl of ramen!  I came pretty early on a Friday evening and didn't have to wait. I ordered the Hinodeya Ramen. The noodles had a nice bite to them and the dashi broth, while a bit salty, was full of umami goodness. The ramen was topped with a good serving of pork, bamboo shoots, and they also have condiments (garlic chili oil, umami paste) that you can add into your ramen. They have a no frills menu with pretty traditional Japanese options - nothing fusion-y here!

$15 for a bowl seems pretty average for SF prices. I can't wait to come back when my next ramen craving hits and also to try out the chicken karage. I noticed that more than half the tables around me had ordered it.
author: Christine C.

description:
We came here around 2pm, waited half an hr for table,
service5/5, 
Curry rice 3/5 just two pieces of chicken and some veggies, $15
Clam ramen 4/5 the broth is good
Pork ramen 3.5/5 the broth is good but only one piece of pork

I forgot to order the matcha dessert at the end:(
I will come back and try it next time
author: Khloe M.

description:
Came about 10 mins before dinner opening and was the second party in line.

-Chicken karaage: crispy, juicy and delicious! Served with matcha salt. 
-Hinodeya ramen: Light, but definitely flavorful. Chashu pork was soft and tender! Egg cooked perfectly.
-Tori Paitan ramen: Even more flavorful with a thicker and dense broth. The broth isn't too thick like Mensho's (there's is like gravy.....), which is much appreciated. Only downside is I personally wasn't a fan of the chicken wing included... the flavor was off to me. 

I would love to come back, but not sure if I would want to wait an absurd amount of time to eat here. Their desserts look and sound delicious, so hopefully I can give the dessert department a try next time!
author: Kris C.

description:
Ok so I can't call myself a ramen expert and only really get ramen when I'm sick or really really craving it. With that being said I absolutely LOVED Hinodeya! The ambiance and service were great and the food was excellent. My bf and I went at about 7:30pm on a Sunday night and there was a short line of about 5-7 parties ahead of us. I heard the line could be much longer so I suggest going slightly off main dinner rush hours. Also there is more seating in the back past where you can see from standing in line in front of the window! We were seated in about 20ish minutes. 

The interior is pretty modern and nice. Different than the whole in the wall places I've been to before. The service was prompt. Less than 5 minutes after we were seated someone took our order. The menu is pretty small. Two main ramen dishes, appetizers, sides, desserts and drinks. We were feeling basic and only order two Dashi Ramens and waters. I HIGHLY recommend the Dashi ramen. The broth is a lot lighter than other ramen I've had before but it is so flavorful! We both were able to finish the whole bowl in one go. I only wish they added a little bit more pork to it but you can add more for about $3 or $4. It came out to about $15 for each of us. A little on the pricey side but overall super good and I will definitely will be back for more!
author: Alex S.

description:
It was my first time here. The Hinodeya Ramen's broth is pleasantly light and refreshing; however, I wish there is option of spicy. Maybe I will like it more here. 
If compared the next-door ramen, I think I like the Marufuku Ramen better. My fiancé likes this better, the chicken ramen better because it is lighter. The portions are good and the price is decent. The customer service is pretty good and staff are pleasant. The tea is overprice I think. Oh well, it is totally optional. We will come back.
author: Meichelle L.

description:
Heard about this place from a friend and decided to stop by after the 2017 sumo competition in Japantown! 

There was about 20 people before they opened waiting in line. Restaurant is pretty big inside so we got seated pretty quick. Environment and decorations were very unique, definitely had nice Japanese feel. I ordered the hinodeya ramen and it came out in 10-15 mins. Soup base was delicious and the noodles were very authentic. Portion size was good and loved all the different types of sauces and seasoning.

Very attentive and friendly servers as well! Will definitely come back again!
author: Raymond C.

description: Ramen here is good, though not excellent. The half egg in the ramen is properly cooked. Service is rushed.
author: Edward S.

description:
Yum!  This is by far my favorite ramen restaurant! I just love the krispy kale and other veggies on top of the ramen. I don't eat at many ramen places because they mostly make their soup from pork bones, but this place has both vegetarian and vegan options. 
Honestly, I go for the veggie toppings, then I drink the broth and then I'm pretty much full and don't eat all the ramen. If you have a bigger appetite, I suggest you try their creative small plates. They also serve a sparkling sake which has a very light, sweet taste.
author: Candy L.

description:
Chicken Karaage appetizer was great
Had the vegan ramen broth with toppings of the house special. Soy milk broth was a little creamy for my taste
author: Twila O.

description:
We got there around 6:30pm on a rainy Sunday.  We got seated right way. 
Two of us. Ordered three bowls of ramen, two cheese dishes, a karaage dish and a dessert. 

Food:
* Hinodeya - light broth, which is different. The portion is decent. 
* Tori Paitan - Thick chicken broth, which is similar to other chicken broth you can get from other places.  But the portion is very small.  
* the cheese dish is amazing.  i never had cheese like that before.  It was creamy and gooey.  Taste of sesame.  It was so good. 
* Matcha panna cotta - its not very sweet.  simple but good.   

Service: 
The server missed one bowl of ramen.  I guess it's because we only had two people. LOL.  But he tried to deliver us the last bowl as quick as possible.  It wasn't a big deal to us. 

I will come back again for the cheese dish.
author: Rachael C.

description:
All I can say is WOW! Such amazing food and an amazing experience. 

First, the ramen. I ordered the Dashi Ramen, and I must say, the broth is absolutely amazing, very light, yet the flavor packs a punch. Make sure you taste the broth on its own before adding any other spices or toppings. The noodles are fresh and hearty, and the choshu and menma are very good.

The atmosphere is exactly what I was looking for in Japanese Restaurant. I've experienced quite a few restaurants in Japan, and it felt good to see it again. When you leave, not only does your server yell out "Thank You" in Japanese. They ALL yell it out. That's one of the things I missed most from my Japan Trips.

A must for any fan of good, authentic Japanese food.
author: Ron Z.

description:
Of course, the bouge SF settles for a bowl of noodles with nothing less than famous ramen from Japan. Cue Mensho, enter Hinodeya, and brace yourself for the arrival of Ippudo. In the true spirit of ramen cult, a wait is expected, though Hinodeya is relatively more under-the-radar.

[TL;DR] The epitome of the zen of ramen, with absolute precision--sipping the broth feels like foodie enlightenment. The plus is the unique concentration on simplicity, while the minus is that the simplicity means modest portions and basic toppings. Bring your soul but not your stomach.

[PART ONE: THE ENTRANCE]

With its recent opening, Hinodeya still has some operational kinks to work out. Perhaps the most bothersome was the absence of a sign-in system; you wait in a line and the host checks periodically to take down the number in your party. Although physically standing in line does contribute to the experience and feels more authentic than technology (such as getting ten reminder emails from OpenTable), it doesn't work great in chilly SF weather. 

Currently the wait is about 30 minutes during dinnertime, and you go through a strange rite of passage waiting in the cold, then being promoted to waiting in a little porch behind a flimsy curtain, and finally inside the restaurant and being reward by chairs. Given the many little shops of Japantown, I think a sign-in list would be a great way to triage the crowd.

[PART TWO: THE RAMEN]

Hinodeya truly excels in the broth. As outlined in the website, Hinodeya has a long history and the broth has been trialed numerous times to perfection. Quality is noticeably outstanding, though the prices are steep and the portions are rather small. On the other hand, this forces you to eat slowly and thoughtfully. I was initially disappointed by the extremely limited quantities of toppings (only one thin slice of chashu in the Hinodeya, and only one tiny chicken wing in the Tori D:); on second thought, this too serves a purpose of placing the focus on the nuances of the wafu broth. 

I liked the mildly wheaty noodles, though I would appreciate it more boldly al dente. Also, our ramen tasted lukewarm but it is possibly because I took too long taking pictures. Of note, the half soft-boiled egg is on point with the quintessential liquid gold yolk.

(+++) Hinodeya ramen ($14): The signature dashi broth, made with kelp, bonito, and sardines, fine-tuned with chicken and scallop. It doesn't taste like a seafood broth, and it was clear yet complex. To add to the paradox, I would describe it as close to umami as you have experienced, but as far from MSG as you can get. 

(+++) Tori paitan ($15): The broth was much richer, but mostly in the sense of a robust chicken flavor rather than being heavy. It's refreshing to have a hearty broth that's not overwhelmingly salty and fatty. The slightly bitter raw green onion slices complemented the roasty overtones flawlessly. While overall it little less precise than the dashi broth, it was a memorable fine-dining-caliber version of chicken noodle soup.

(++) Matcha cappuccino ($8): I applaud the strong matcha taste and layers of various texture, from a predominantly creamy top, followed by a densely flavored panna cotta, and ending with matcha jelly. The composition was creatively reflective of a drink, complete with latte art.

The kara-age with matcha salt sounds interesting and is on my radar. The menu is fairly limited for now (which I actually like because it makes decisions easier). It is expected to expand to include more options such as a vegan ramen. 

$40 for two bowls of ramen and one dessert is pricey even for SF, but the broth is a dining experience in itself.

[PART THREE: THE AMBIANCE]

They stress the concept of dining with five senses and strive for diners to be "entertained by the exquisite harmony of the wafu ramen and the Japanesy surroundings." Hehe such an endearing description! ^^V The ambiance is indeed relaxing, with a spacious and well-lit interior, a minimalist selection of Japanese decor, and photogenic condiments in little wooden jars.

My last logistical gripe is that the bench chairs are a bit of a hassle because there's nowhere to put your coat and it takes quite some coordination to move the bench between two people (good couples activity for date night!)
author: Edna C.

description:
By far, BEST ramen in the bay area. This place is pretty brand new, been opened for 2 months, but word spreads fast so people been lining up! This place is also originally from Japan.

We got here around 4:30PM and were the first ones in one but after a few minutes a long time started to form! Opened right at five, super punctual and fast paced and friendly staff.

We ordered:
Dashi Ramen: If you like broth on the lighter side, this is the perfect ramen for you. Delicious and flavorful and chewy ramen. Amazing toppings with a yolky egg and add extra char siu! Fatty!
Chicken Paitan Ramen: My favorite, must order in my opinion. While most Paitan is super heavy and creamy, this place does it right! Light creamy, amazing noodles and toppings were great with a yolky egg. BEST I ever had for Paitan. Shizz on Nojo Ramen and Mensho by far
Chicken Karage with matcha salt: Pretty good, crispy chicken and tender inside!

Overall, I would definitely come here again, I'm sure this place will only get more packed and popular. They do have a few items not ready yet, like their clam ramen. Portions are a bit small, I see people ordering two bowls :O !
author: Natalie L.

description:
All the foods were tasty and delicious! We got the edamame, fried chicken, cream cheese cubes, shishito peppers, and veggie, chicken and house ramen. The broths were light and flavorful. Would definitely come back again and again. 

They open at 5:30p and we stood in line around 5:20p with about a 30 minute wait from when they opened until we were seated. This was on a Saturday. Well worth the wait!
author: Kim L.

description:
I tried their Tori Paitan and it was pretty good! Chicken was soft and the soup has really good taste!

I like it more than ippudo!
author: Katie T.

description:
Hands down my new favorite ramen place knocking Ramen Parlor down after 4 years. SF has been lacking good ramen, but not anymore.

Came here on a Thursday night, and there was a line. No sign up sheet, just a line. 6 people ahead of us.
