Things looked promising when an older Japanese speaking couple  were in front of us, and then even the waitress could speak Japanese! I've never been to Japan yet , but this place was the closest I've ever felt to it.

Food: 
- Chicken Karaage (5/5): so crispy outside but so juicy inside. and it's served with matcha salt  
-Hinodeya ramen (5/5): so delicious. The lighter of the two ramens served here. The broth is so rich flavored with scallop and other flavors. I ordered extra egg on mine

Dessert:
-Black sesame ice cream (4.5/5): delicious and topped with granola 

-Matcha panna cotta: (4/5): very flavorful and not too sweet

Overall, my bf and I loved it here- and we are pretty picky on our Japanese food. We wanted to come for lunch the next day. Can't wait to be back!
author: Corinna T.

description: I say the noodles for this Ramen bar was good. The texture of the noodles was like Udon. Honestly I give it a 8/10. Like I said every ramen place has their own sense of style and flavor. There's no perfect ramen in this world.
author: Julia D.

description:
This is probably the best ramen I've had in San Francisco, and there are a ton of ramen places here. 

The wait can be long, but it's worth it in my opinion. They only have a few options for ramen and that's a good thing! Some items are seasonal, but most people come here for the house or chicken ramen. 

If this is your first time I recommend the house ramen. Their broth is clear, light, but full of flavor. The ramen noodles are cooked perfectly with a nice chew to them. I can't forget about the pieces of fatty pork that came with the ramen either, absolutely perfect. 

The chicken ramen is another fantastic dish. This broth is a little milkier and has a richer flavor. It comes with 2 chicken wings that have been braised until the meat literally falls off the bone once you grab into it. 

One of their seasonal ramen is the clam ramen. They do not skimp on the clams! Definitely one of my favorite dishes there. Broth is clear, but different than the house broth. 

I took the gf here and it instantly became her favorite ramen joint in the city.
author: robin w.

description:
HEALTH SCORE: 79

"SF Dept of Health: Food Safety Program: Restaurant Safety Scores:
71-85 Needs Improvement 
Multiple violations observed
Typically, several high-risk violations"

Source: https://www.sfdph.org/dph/EH/Food/Score/default.asp
author: Mrs M.

description:
Zii is amazing.  Also this is the best ramen and some of the best food I've ever had.  They truly care about their customers and their experience.

Thank you I really appreciate it.
author: Patrick H.

description:
Tasty ramen for sure! 
I don't eat a lot so the portion was perfect. However, compared to the other ramen restaurant in the area, it is pricey.
author: Kiyomi K.

description:
This large dining room has two very cool branchy wooden chandeliers that are suspended over a long shared center table. Tables that seat four line one wall while bar seating lines the other.

At $5.00 the Shishito Peppers are inexpensive. Ever so lightly fried and glazed in soy these peppers were surprisingly mild and crisp, not at all oily. 

At $8.00 their Crispy Fried Yam in a sesame sauce is a nice change up from potato fries and tomato ketchup.  I did not find them to be overly oily like regular fries and I did enjoy the sesame sauce.

At $8.00 the Kara-Age/boneless Fried Chicken, organic as well as cage free, (yet it still ended up on my plate) arrived moist and tender with a lemon wedge and a green pepper, mmm mmm.

At $14.00 the Hinodeya Ramen (House Ramen) was great. Im told this is a traditional Japanese dashi style soup. These wheat noodles arrived in a delicious broth with pork, a marinated egg, menma, dried seaweed and green onion. Another winner, I'd recommend giving it a try.
author: Caesar A.

description:
1. Overpriced
2. Very oily, especially can you imagine Zen Ramen is all about deep fried kale and deep fry processed tofu in very oily soup?
3.  チャーシュー is very hard
4. Staff is friendly but not professional. Made mistakes for our order and then the bill. 
5. Very crowded and uncomfortable environment. 
 
In short, not worth waiting in the long queue and not worth the price.
author: Liu X.

description: Great ramen with a value added lunch combo that is simply delicious. Service was hectic but that is acceptable during lunchtime rush. Two of us actually shared the combination lunch that came with ramen, gyoza and chicken karrage. We will return.
author: David B.

description:
3.5 stars for first lunch experience yesterday 12.24.16

In short, decent above-average ramen where you don't have to wait for an hour but do have to pay the price since portions are smaller than average.

Two types of dashi ramen with flat buckwheat noodles. Noodles were cooked nicely. Egg could've been cooked less so that the yolk is more runny.
1. hinodeya ramen with broth made from dashi, kombu, and scallop. Served with chashu, bamboo shoots, egg, dried seaweed, and green onion. Broth is clear and light but a bit salty for me. Felt like toppings were skimp bc only one small piece of chashu. Chashu was tender but not much flavor.
2. Tori paitan with dashi chicken broth. Served with braised chicken wing, shiitake mushroom, dried seaweed, and green onion. Broth is rich, but not too rich. One braised chicken wing where meat falls off the bone. Only one mushroom as well. 

Tebasaki- 5 braised chicken wings with dashi and soy sauce glaze. Tender and meat falls off the bone. Tastes like the chicken that came with the tori paitan.
Barley tea- $4 each glass, but had to get as I didn't want to drink cold water on the cold day

In comparison, I like Mensho and Nojo more, especially given the portions and price point. $60 for lunch and I unfortunately didn't feel very satisfied. Customer service was great tho. Staff were polite and attentive. Waitresses kneeled down next to tables to take orders. Interior design is nice, neat, and comfortable. Counter/bar seating, tables, and communal tables available.
author: Iris H.

description: Nice place, ramen is delicious and don't forget to try the mochi ice cream! Is really good
author: Alfredo A.

description: I had ramen here last night, and it was delicious. There were several broths to choose from (including a Vegan option! Wow!). I choose the Hinodeya (house) dashi broth, which was very tasty. The server was very helpful in explaining the options, saying the dashi broth was light, and there were other options that were lighter (the vegan) or richer in flavor. I enjoyed the house broth. It was light, and flavorful, not too heavy. Next time I would like to try their chicken broth and see what happens. Friendly service, good energy, and delicious food. I'm a fan.
author: Jason P.

description: One of my favorite ramen place that is worth the wait for 1 1/2 -2 hours on the weekend. All the servers here can speak Japanese and have very attentive service. We got chicken patan and pork ramen, flavor is very authentic for both, noodles are not the average one you get anywhere (I have tried at least 30 different ramen place and this one will be in my top five list so far) I like the appetizer as well :) the dessert is interesting, and it actually cleanse your palette after eating the ramen
author: Jac L.

description: I was on my way to Kubuki Springs today and wanted to grab lunch.  After a quick search on yelp, I knew that Ramen was definitely what I wanted.  I started at another ramen place but the wait was very long.  I took a walk and found this great place (with good recommends on Yelp).  The line had a few people and I waited about 5 minutes.  The restaurant has nice decor and good service.  I had a draft beer and the "house ramen".  I thought the ramen was great, and I just came back from Japan so I know what I'm talking about.  The pork was tasty and the flavor was excellent.  I'd totally go back again.
author: Keith B.

description:
This place is excellent. The place is really busy so there is a wait but not much because most diners were in and out. Not too noisy.
We ordered the Spicy Raw Octopus. It was nice and fresh. The Pork Belly was cooked just right and tender. Our party had the House Ramen and Chicken Ramen, both excellent. 
When our waiter got held up at another table, the other servers quickly stepped in to help.
We're definitely coming back.
author: Moni H.

description:
Hinodeya easily makes my top 3 list of ramen spots in SF. Came around noon on a Sunday and waited about 45min for a table for two. 

Since they're newly opened, I think they're still trying to figure out the service. They're a bit slow on filling up water and tea and being conscious of clearing empty plates (esp important bc of the communal tables) but everyone was very nice and the food made up for it so no big complaints.

The Hinodeya ramen was SO GOOD. Light, but complex in flavor. Perfect level of saltiness and a perfectly slow cooked egg (I love egg so that's important and I added an extra for $2). The dashi broth was surprisingly good - so tasty, with the flavors with scallop, bonito, and kombu shining through without being overly "fishy." Noodles cooked al dente. 

Will definitely return for dinner to try the dinner apps (they don't serve kaarage at lunch) and the Tori Paitan next time!! 

P.S. Save room for dessert!!!
author: Ashley S.

description: Both house and chicken ramen were good.  Love the lighter taste but still flavorful in house ramen.  Wait was not long.  When we left, the line was quite long.
author: eugene s.

description: Omg best ramen ever, I got the vegan ramen and it was delicious and authentic. The boys got non vegan ramen and they said theirs was the best they've ever had. Can't wait till I'm back in sf to come here again!!
author: Ali P.

description:
4.5 STARS

My friend, Mr. Diva drives me insane sometimes (and I'm sure vice versa). Choosing a restaurant to go to is a whole methodical process - he wants to know who the chef is, his/her bio, where the restaurant originated from, what's on the menu, price points, any cute servers work there...the whole shabang. A link to an article doesn't suffice, he wants everything listed out by text. Shoot, picking a mail order bride is easier. 

And, then when we finally choose a place to dine at and have tasted the food, he says he can do a better job at home. Ok, says the person who constantly checks his reflection out (to his credit, he can really cook...he once delivered a sous vide pork belly with a 63 degree [runny] egg over furikake rice to me and it was bomb).

Last week, I sent him a link to an article about the soft opening of Hinodeya Ramen Bar, and he agreed to go without hesitation. WOOT!

Hinodeya Ramen Bar took over the old Shalala Ramen space in Japantown and is the first U.S. outpost outside of Japan. Their specialty is a dashi based ramen. Instead of the typical pork bone based broth, their broth is made from a combo of preserved skipjack tuna and kombu seaweed. Currently for their soft opening, they have a limited menu with two ramen options: Hinodeya Ramen - dashi broth, whole wheat noodles, chashu, marinated soft boiled egg ($14) and Tori Paitan  - rich chicken + dashi broth, whole wheat noodles, braised chicken wing, marinated soft boiled egg ($15). They do NOT use msg in their broths which I confirmed with their manager. 

For lunch apps, they have a salad or royal cheese. For dinner apps, they have fried oysters and chicken karaage. Beer and sake available. Once they officially open next year, their menu will expand with more apps, ramen options, and a chef's tasting menu. They will also accept reservations. 

Until then, you'll have to brave the wait which is not bad compared to the opening lines at Mensho (2-3 hour wait). I came 30 minutes before opening and I was first in line. During peak times, it looks to be about an hour wait. There's only seats for about 30 people (back dining area is closed) so come with a group of 4 or less. 

We started with the Cheese Royal ($5) which tasted like fermented blocks of cream cheese: http://bit.ly/2h3NXT7. The flavor is intense, almost pungent and better enjoyed with beer or sake. 

For ramen, we each ordered the Tori Paiten Ramen ($15) and added chashu ($4): http://bit.ly/2gZcuWt. If you're a tonkotsu ramen person, than I highly recommend ordering the tori paitan. The broth is deeply rich without being overly heavy like Mensho's tori paitan. Lots of opulent chicken and umami flavor from the kombu. The whole wheat noodles were perfectly thick, wavy, and al-dente through the end of the bowl. While the braised chicken wing was fall-off-the-bone tender, you only get one mid-joint, so definitely add the chashu which is meltingly tender. The ajitsuke tamago (marinated soft boiled egg) was flavorful with a delicious molten center.  

We decided to also order the bowl of the Hinodeya Ramen ($14) for comparison: http://bit.ly/2g66Tkk. If you're a shio (salt) ramen person than you'll probably enjoy this ramen over the paitan. When I first read about the dashi based ramen, I thought ehhh fish based broth? To my surprise, it's very good. The clear broth has a lot of concentrated seafoody flavor without being "fishy". This one is saltier and oilier than the paitan so several spoonfuls was more than enough for me, especially after having a bowl of the tori paitan.

Each table has a set of condiments: bonito, fried garlic, togarashi, and black pepper so you can doctor your ramen to your liking.

For dessert, we ordered the Kuro-Goma (Black Sesame) Ice Cream w/ granola ($5): http://bit.ly/2gNDf2h. The ice cream was super creamy and dense with lots of nutty sesame flavor. We enjoyed the Japanese granola (rice krispies) for crunch. 

Service is friendly and quick, though we somehow received our ramen after several groups of people who had ordered well after us. It's just opening kinks and I'm sure the kitchen will get into their groove soon. 

Mr. Diva and I both agreed (for once) that Hinodeya Ramen Bar currently has the best ramen in San Francisco in terms of broth, noodles, and quality of toppings. Mensho is excellent but it's hard to finish a bowl of their tori paitan ramen without feeling gross afterwards because of how heavy the broth is. 

One last thing, please be mindful of others waiting outside in the cold and not sit there chitchatting for hours after finishing your bowl of ramen. Take your tinder horror story about how dude picked you up in a hearse (but you decided to bang him anyways) to the bar down the block. 

Happy Slurping! I mean the slurping ramen kind of slurping...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Rating: 4.5 stars, because I just can't wrap my head around a $15 bowl of ramen...Even if it is delicious.

TL;DR - I think it's safe to say that Hinodeya is officially my favorite ramen spot in SF proper. 

I'm not sure how the line is now, but when I went we arrived at 11:40-ish and there was already a line. We were lucky enough to get seated in the first seating, and by the time we were done the line was EVEN LONGER O=

I typically like the creamier broths, but decided to get the Hinodeya Ramen since it's their star item. The dash broth was SO freaking delicious. I didn't taste any fishiness, which I don't enjoy and am pretty sensitive. Egg so good as well! The chasu was extremely tender and pretty much melted in your mouth. Lots of green onion as well, but I love 'em so yay! Overall, a very refreshing and light bowl of ramen that was still extremely satisfying and filling. The bf ordered the Tori Paitan, which IMO is SO MUCH better than Mensho's. It's flavorful without being too thick and creamy. It's a tad on the saltier side, but still good. The chicken wing meat was fall off the bone and nicely marinated/flavored. Kuro-Goma ice cream was also very good! The sesame flavor isn't too strong, but I liked it and it had a nice consistency without being too grainy.

I still haven't found ramen in the city that comes close to ramen in Japan. I think Hinodeya is close, but still isn't quite what ramen is in Japan. But again, it's close. And so good. *Terminator voice* I'll be back (and pray that there isn't a fat line out the door...).
author: Doris K.

description:
I was really impressed by this place. Came here on a Thursday evening around 6:30pm with a party of 5, and even though they did not take reservations, they have quite a large space and we were able to get seated fairly quickly (after about a 15 minute wait). Service was initially a little slow and they forgot one of our orders, but it was quickly rectified. I got the Hinodeya Ramen (house ramen, $14), which was a large serving of whole wheat noodles topped with chashu pork, soft cooked egg, dried seaweed, green onion, sesame seeds, and red pepper. The noodles were soft and chewy and the egg was cooked to runny perfection, but I didn't think the meat was as flavorful and tender as other ramen I have had. The broth was different - it was quite light and not as oily, which depending on what you are in the mood for, might just hit the spot. We also split a 300mL bottle of their sparkling sake ($15), which was very sweet and had a little lower alcohol content than usual (about 5%).

Overall I would say that the ramen and the drinks were about a 3.5 to a 4, but what really pushed them over to beyond 5 stars is the experience of having a birthday there. It was my friend's birthday and we had bought a cake from Schubert's to surprise her. Initially the restaurant told us that their policy was not to allow any outside food, and were not going to let us celebrate with the cake. However, several of the staff members were incredibly nice and decided to make an exception and allow us to have the cake. Not only that, but they brought out the cake with a massive sparkler, all came and sang happy birthday to her, took a Polaroid of all of us that they gave us to keep, and even gave her a birthday hat to wear for the photo! They then cut the cake and brought out the pieces on individual plates. I was really blown away by how nice they were and how much effort they put into making it a great experience for her and her us. I am truly very grateful - thank you so much for being so kind!
author: Amy C.

description: Been here a few times now and pretty solid. Never have had to wait too long- maybe 15 minutes. Very hip and Japanese atmosphere. Get the house special ramen and its very clean, but still pretty flavorful. No complaints here! Service is good.
author: Vivian D.

description: Okay let start by saying the hype is REAL! Do expect a line when you dine here. The ramen here is spectacular, the noodles were perfection itself, the umami broth, and that heavenly chasu pork!! The pork belly was so good we ended up ordering like 3 dishes alone. I am not ashamed! If you had eat your last meal this would be it. I dare say this is one of best ramens in the bay in my personal opinion. The fried yams were amazing. I would highly recommend to do the sake flight to pair with the meal. It comes with three selections: premeal, during meal, and post meal glass. The staff is super friendly and attentive. Lastly, they do a pre-open chant it was super cute! Loved the vibe here and can't wait to taste these delicious offerings again!
author: Gina H.

description:
Amazing dashi stock
The umami condiment I would like to find the recipe
But it was amazing from service to food
author: Bruce K.

description: Must be a five start Ramen so far at Bay Area. Comparable to the one I had in Tokyo. Soup looks clear, the taste completely surprising you, spectrum of flavors. I can tell they really spend time and ingredients in it. So does the noodles! Absolutely handmade and very fresh, you would love the texture. Tonkutson is fully cooked but still melting in your mouth with perfect amount of fat. Ramen here is really beyond any words, just try! Picture doesn't tell you everything. My first Yelp review! You guys deserve it.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I came here on a Thursday night around 5:30pm and the restaurant was only half full. It sure started to fill up right after. 

The restaurant has nice wooden tables and a good ambiance.

Service was very friendly. I think we interacted with almost all of the staff during dinner and each person had a smile on their face and was very helpful.

I tried the Karaage and the Tori Paitan Ramen. The Karaage was composed of sizable chicken chunks and the batter was crispy yet light. It was also served with a shishito pepper which I gobbled up, and matcha salt which had a very nice acidity that paired well with the fried chicken. For the Tori Paitan, it was a smaller serving that I expected however still enjoyable. I loved the noodles -- flat, slightly thick and al dente. I haven't had noodles like these in any ramen before. The soft boiled egg was perfect, the braised wing was tender and added some umami flavor to the bowl, and the broth itself had a good chicken flavor with a clean yet rich texture. My only gripe was the heavy amount of green onion. I enjoy green onion but the amount in the bowl was heavy and overpowering.
author: Maya S.

description:
Super flavorful ramen with perfectly cooked noodles! My friend and I came on a Monday night a few minutes after the restaurant opened for dinner at 5pm and the restaurant was already quite filled. However, we were luckily able to get a table the second we walked in. 

I ordered the Hinodeya ramen and I loved the bold yet light flavors! The soup base was super flavorful, with a dashi-like stock, but super light and perfectly salted. The noodles were also perfectly cooked, chewy and fresh. They also added toasted sesame seeds to the stock, which added extra fragrance to the entire dish. The ramen came with a piece of cha shu that was very good--one piece went a long way and was enough to fill your taste buds with a smoky, porky and rich flavor. There were also bamboo shoots that were crunchy and complemented the soft, chewy noodles well. I also enjoyed the soft boiled egg that came with it, since it had a smoky flavor and a soft, liquid center in the middle.

Overall, a great ramen place! I highly recommend coming, but be prepared for lines.
author: Sandra S.

description:
We visited Hinodeya at 7:30pm on a Sunday night and I was nervous that there would be a long wait since it's new (Mensho anyone?). We ended up only waiting about 10-15 minutes and were seated side by side at a communal table. It felt odd at first since we had just met for our first date and a little more privacy would've been nice.

Hinodeya is technically still in soft opening stage so not all of the options are available yet. Since there were two of us and we love to eat, we got both the Tori Paitan and Hinodeya ramen to share. I had been watching Midnight Diner on Netflix and there was an episode about fried yams so I talked my date into getting the Crispy Fried Yam as well. For $8, the yam was not a good value (compared to karaage at the same price and ramen for $14) but it satisfied by curiosity.

To my surprise, I liked the Tori Paitan ramen more because the broth is richer. As I'm getting older, I'm discovering that I never gave chicken a fair shot and I'm slowly learning to appreciate it more (but still no white meat!).
author: Yi Z.

description: From SoCal and this place tops most ramen shops down south! I like how they serve dashi broth instead of ur regular tonkotsu broth. Absolutely delicious! Will go back for sure. Pair ur ramen with the sake flight!
author: isle-de-M t.

description:
Let's get over with the good things that allowed this place to have 2 stars: very welcoming environment (place feels like an apartment) and some nice perks such as the warm towel. 
Now to the reason behind two stars. 
Food: My ramen standards have been set high since I ate at Mensho. I understand it's two different types of ramen, but this place is not up to par from a flavor profile point of view. The noodles in the ramen (house ramen) were pretty good. They had a decent bite and were properly cooked. The broth on the other hand left a lot to desire. It was a bit sweet due to the heavy amount of bamboo shoots and green onion. It was also a bit bland and was not rich. It almost felt like hot water with a cube of pork broth, if the pork broth was missing salt and pepper. The meat was mostly fat and still was somewhat tough to chew. The octopus looked pretty disgusting as it was very slimy. 

Service: after waiting for about 15 minutes, we went in and got seated by a gentleman who seemed very attentive. We were served by a lady who was, on the other hand, a bit less welcoming. She came off rude while we were trying to order. All in all we ordered after about 5 mins so I was happy. 
We had ordered the wasabi octopus and House ramen. The octopus was an appetizer but they brought the ramen first. As always one person's order came out before the other, so one person was eating while the other is awkwardly hanging out. After about 2/3 minutes they brought the second person order 
I had even forgotten about the octopus, since I don't like it but my girlfriend noticed we hadn't received it. 
I left half of the ramen in the bowl. It wasn't really that good. We flag down the waitress to ask about the appetizer and she brought it to us. We had appetizer after the main course. 
Lastly, we ask for the check and they hadn't even added all the items in the bill so I had to ask them to add the items before paying for it. They missed the octopus. 
All together: we got tea (it's 4 bucks for a small pot) ramen and octopus and spent $50 bucks. I don't think this place has a good value given the price they charge. Most likely won't be returning.

PS: their health score is only 79.
author: Ashish N.

description:
It was midweek on a cold night, and the line wasn't terribly long, so I decided to try this place out after hearing rave reviews. I got the house ramen, which has a wonderfully light, tasty broth. Not too salty. Not too rich. Noodles were the perfect amount of chewiness. Overall, a great balance of flavors. 

I slurped the noodles. I drank ALL the broth. A real Tampopo moment.
author: Denise I.

description:
Yikes.

My friends and I have this whole Ramen club going and this was our most recent destination. It's new, it's got this fancy Dashi broth, and I had high hopes! But dang, it's too bad this place falls flat in my ramen ventures (which, mind you, I've had ramen from so many places in the states!)

The interior is cool and there is indeed, usually a wait. For what, I'm still trying to pinpoint, maybe it's the anticipation of something great, which it could be if only...

Service was slow..... Okay, we had a group of 10 and the restaurant was fairly filled on a Wednesday night, but between drinks and apps to putting in our actual order, it was a solid 30 minutes. Not to mention, the server came, took 3 orders from our table, then disappeared... we got another server to come and get more orders (eventually) but then, it took forever for those bowls to slowly come out for us.

The Chicken Karage was good, as was the hot sake and the beer (can you really mess those up?) but apps were wicked pricey for the quantity that comes out. Even more expensive was the ramen! I ordered the Hinodeya Ramen (standard with pork) $14, and then I added $4 to get some chicken (I wanted to try both meats). You get a single slice of pork, only HALF an egg (WTF, that's the best part), and the bowls were really small! The side of chicken was 2 baby wings the size of my pinky doubled. And in the end, the dashi really was not so special. I prefer Goku in the Mission, and almost any other place in that plaza better.

Too bad :( Also, no vegetarian options for ramen. Tough break for my veg friends!!! Hoping they'll improve over time!
author: Nerissa C.

description: This place has the best Dashi! Omg the ramen is bomb, the noodles soak up all the flavor from the broth and the flavors are so comforting on a cold or hot day plus the Ume drink is really refreshing
author: Erin B.

description: I came here on a weekday right when they opened for lunch, so no lines!  I chose the Hinodeya ramen and it was delicious.  The broth was light and flavorful, with the red pepper giving it a slight spicy taste.  Noodles were chewy and perfect.  Only two pieces of chasu and half of a soft cooked egg, at $14 it's a bit pricey.
author: Karen L.

description: First time been here with my friend. Since both of us are the ramen lover, after did some research, finally we pick this spot to try. The inside decor is very simple, but make people feel very comfortable. We order their popular ramen which is the pork belly inside, my friend order their special limited ramen. After eat it, we feel it is little salty for us, but tasted is good. I really like their deep fried chicken it's really good. Since I order their two different kind of chicken wing, however the boiled one I didn't like, finally the server came over told me he can cancel that, order a new deep fried chicken for me. I'm really appreciate! Highly recommend this spot, good service, good food!!! Will come back.
author: Yueming G.

description: Thank goodness Japantown's got some decent ramen spots. Light, clean, and good tasting ramen with good texture and savory broth. Karaage was delicious, chewy, and meaty, served at a nice warm temperature with tasty dipping matcha salt. Interior decor has good vibes and lots of seating, but can get busy for obvious reasons.
author: David Y.

description:
TLDR: Delicious, but on the pricier end (yay, SF prices!)

Thankfully only waited maybe 20 minutes on the Friday before Christmas around 6. No reservations, no name system. The line moves fairly quickly as this is a ramen (fast food!) joint. Got our ramen within 10-15 minutes of ordering.

Not a fan of dashi (fish) broth, but thankfully, they had a chicken option!
Tori Paitan - half rich chicken broth, half dashi broth. Didn't taste any fish, which was a good thing! Rich in flavor but not thick and heavy. Thinner than your typical ramen broth due to the addition of dashi. Noodles were good but could have been more tender. Maybe I'll ask them for that next time! $15 for ramen is on the pricier end, but it was delightful, glad I tried it!

My friend got the Hinodeya ramen which comes with the  dashi broth, which was light and subtle. Very delicate but well rounded. I prefer heavy and hearty broths like tonkatsu, but this was a very welcome and refreshing change! I'd highly recommend it to any ramen lover to at least try.

APPS:
Kara aga with matcha salt was DELICIOUS. It has a lighter batter coating, in both thickness and in terms of color, than traditional kara age. Thin crispy exterior and JUICY white chicken meat! I was kind of doubting it when it came, as I like smaller, dark pieces, but glad I was proved wrong. They must brine the chicken very well as it was moist and very flavorful all the way through. YUM!

Also got the Tebasaki since we had both never heard of it, and you can't really go wrong with chicken wings! These, however, were more like stewed chicken wings (kinda like boiled chicken wings in some kind of soy broth), which came as a surprise (slight disappointment) - I think they should specify that this is NOT a fried dish. It was very tender though and you didn't need a second utensil to get the meat off! It was a'ight. Very similar to Chinese soy sauce chicken. One of these wings comes with the Tori Paitan ramen as well!
author: Emily C.

description:
Legit Ramen, My only complaint is my pork belly was all fat. I had 2 large pieces with zero meat on it.

I got the plum wine, which was no par for plum wine and super sweet.
author: melisa w.

description:
The menu is fairly limited. There were four ramen options on the menu. (There was a fifth, a special for that evening.)

I had the Hinodeya (House) Ramen. The broth was just ok for me. I really liked the ramen noodles. Perfectly cooked. Enjoyed the toppings as well--pork, soft egg, and bamboo shoots.

My cousin had the Vegan Ramen (soy milk broth with spinach noodles). He thought it was excellent.

Liked the Shishito Peppers also.

Service was friendly & efficient.
author: David W.

description:
I had much better luck with this place than my friends did. My noodles were cooked perfectly, the egg was soft boiled and the broth had good flavor. Also only had to wait like 15 minutes so thats always a win in my book. Only negative on my side is that you only get one small piece of pork. Place across the street gives you three times that. Just sayin. 

My friends came here on my recommendation the following night and both complained of greasy broth, overcooked eggs and such. 

My experience was good so I guess I'll be going back to see if it was a fluke or if they just had an off night.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night for dinner around 5:50pm - and it was crowded! There was quite a line outside of groups waiting and I waited about 50 min before my friend and I were seated. 

I ordered the hinodeya ramen ($14) while my friend ordered the tori paitan ramen ($15$) ! I loved the lighter flavor of the dashi broth and the slightly thicker and chewier noodle than you get at other places in the hinodeya ramen. Their soft boiled egg was perfect as well. Portion was just right for me too- I was a bit worried that I would still be hungry but I was full by the end!My friend's tori paitan was also delicious - broth is just slightly more creamy and strong chicken flavor to it. 

We also ordered a dessert- the matcha cappuccinos ($8) and it was awesome. Sort of gelatin like texture and the matcha was spot-on and not powdery tasting! 

Would recommend if you don't mind the long wait! Service was nice and pretty fast as well.
author: Kristie M.

description:
The food was good and filling. The portions are good too and the price is decent for SF. $15 for a bowl in SF is typical. If there is one thing, I wish they would offer spicier bowels of ramen instead of the 3 non-spicy alternatives. For a place that advertise as a Ramen house I would expect more Ramen options.

For those of you who truly want to experience what a Ramen House is should try this place in Sacramento called Ramen House Ryujin. Ramen House Ryujin blows all of the Ramen houses in SF out of the waters.

https://www.yelp.com/biz/ramen-house-ryujin-sacramento
author: Steve L.

description:
3.5 stars

Rather pricey bowl of ramen for just getting one piece of meat and a generous portion of filler bamboo shoot. Rather pricey everything actually but welcome to SF I guess. 

Dashi broth Hinodeya ramen was light and still rather tasty, but there was a lot of oil floating in the bowl. Tori paitan was similarly light and not heavy. Noodles are wavy and fresh but may have been just a tad overdone. The soft boiled egg though was absolute perfection. 

To me... the ramen is good/average but the karaage is much more memorable! Crispy golden tempura batter with organic skin-on chicken and a side of matcha salt. Call me crazy but I'll come back here just for the karaage.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Hinodeya has been on my radar for a while and I'm so glad I tried this place out. I know it's still in soft opening stages but I can't wait til they have a full menu. My bf and I came on a Sunday right when it opened and we still had a 30 min wait which is okay since we were able to walk to nearby stores and explore. Since being back from Japan, we were craving authentic ramen like what we had in Japan and this place did not disappoint!

Tori paitan ramen: 4/5: has a rich chicken flavor that is absolutely delicious! It came with a chicken wing, green onions and seaweed, I did add on chasu which made this phenomenal! I've never had a chicken wing braised so well that the meat literally fell off the bone. The broth was flavorful but it wasn't too heavy or oily which I liked and reminded me of ramen in japan. It had the right flavor and made me so happy! Will definitely be back for more!

I did have a sip of the hinodeya ramen broth which is a dashi and scallop broth, it was definitely on the lighter side and was well flavored. The chasu brings out a nice savory and meaty aspect to the broth and ties it all together. Though I do prefer the tori paitan, I wouldn't mind ordering the hinodeya ramen as well! 

We also tried the cheese royal and it was flavored cheese. The taste was amazing, I'm not sure what marinade they used but it's like crack, we couldn't get enough of this! A definite must order if you like cheese and enjoy Japanese flavors!

Overall, a great addition to the ramen scene in sf! Will definitely be back in the future for more! And this place will definitely be on my list next time I head back to japan!

Total for 2 w/ tax and tip: $63
author: Stella J.

description:
I went on a rainy Sat 12/10/16 and it was already super busy by 12pm.  I got the only single seat on the communal table.

I picked the Hinodeya ramen and it took a bit of a wait to get.

Small bowl w/ a few pieces of pork, 1 piece of seaweed, some noodles, soup, half an egg, and lots of bamboo shoots.  I thought it tasted just ok, nothing special.

I might go back to try other dishes and go earlier.

Charged it.
author: Ann L.

description:
As one of the most popular spots in San Fran's Japantown, we knew we had to make a visit when we were in town. We came in for late lunch, and there was a bit of line - it was also approaching closing time. We waited for about 15 minutes but were served pretty promptly. 

Hinodeya keeps its menu fairly straightforward, but they also offer a variety of sides ranging from salads to light Japanese bites. We ordered pretty much everything, but the Ramen stands out most. The broth was ligther than usual but still exudes the richness that is typically found in classic Japanese Ramen. 

We will come back next time we're in town!
author: Alicia K.

description: The service is very good. There was like 5 parties in line before me but the wait wasn't that long, probably 10 mins. We got the Hinodeya ramen and it wasn't good, the brought was salty. The noodle and the meat was good but I didn't like the broth.
author: Becky N.

description: Had the house ramen and it was really good! Though the style here isn't what I prefer...the house ramen is bonito Kombu broth, and I usually prefer tonkotsu. Overall it's good and I would recommend but I don't think I would come back anytime soon. Also, if you've had similar style broths in Japan than it might be a tough sale. Overall everything felt really authentic. If you want something besides miso and tonkotsu flavor then definitely give this place a shot!
author: Philip H.

description:
If you're looking for the "perfect portioned" ramen that doesn't leave you bloated after you finish, the dashi ramen here does not disappoint. The noodles here really stand out - I believe there is some buckwheat in the noodles which gives it an extra bounce. Overall I don't think you can really go wrong with any of the flavors they have to offer here. 

The kara-age was pretty good - it came with a side with matcha salt. Asahi on tap really hit the spot for me - and for some reason tasted smoother than previous ones I've had.

Service was extremely good, I felt like a royalty here.

I came here for dinner after having ramen for lunch so I was specifically looking for something lighter, this place really delivered.
author: Sean C.

description:
When a bevy of good ramen restaurants are concentrated in one place, you have to be on your extra "A" game to stand above the rest. Hinodeya does this with aplomb and is among the best ramen places in San Francisco's Japantown.
I had the tori paitan. The ramen noodles were just right: firm and supple, with a nice chewy bite. The broth was rich without being overwhelming: warm comfort on a cool, foggy San Francisco day. 
Highly recommended!
author: Michael G.

description:
Most likely going to be my favorite ramen bar in Japantown! We came on the third day of opening (the Friday after Thanksgiving) for dinner, got in line about a quarter after 5pm and the wait was about 35 minutes. Not all the tables were seated at the time we went despite a long line, and the bar seats were not ready yet, they were probably still in the process of a full official opening.

We got karaage for appetizer and Hinodeya ramen. Karaage was tender and tasty with the matcha salt (mostly salty flavor), with non-spicy pepper and spring onions among other green toppings that added to a nice presentation. For Hinodeya ramen, I liked the clear broth a lot - not so greasy that I could not drink the broth like several other ramen places, yet the dashi flavor was rich. Ramen came with one chashu slice, bamboo shoots, half a soft cooked marinated egg, seaweed, and green onions. They used curly flat whole wheat noodles, which were chewy, unique and my favorite kind of noodles.

All staff seemed knowledgable and well versed in Japanese as well, we heard them telling the back story of one of their sake. Service was prompt and friendly, and the interior was bright and modern with Japanese feel like the tablecloth and bag basket. Will certainly be back to try other items on the menu!
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
Really appreciate that they had a vegan ramen. It was just not particularly great. They use soy milk when it would be much better with coconut. Kind of felt like I was eating ramen cereal at times. 

The yam appetizer is amazing.
author: George R.

description:
This is the second time I came here. Quite typical Japanese ramen. Thick soup for chicken ramen, and very light soup for the housemade signature ramen. There are two small wings in the chicken ramen with some seaweed and one half egg. The quantity is not large. So if you are hungry, remember to order some sides. 

Terrific service with very friendly waiters. One star is reduced due to the too simple menu. There are not many kinds of choices here. But what they have right now is enough!
author: Victoria L.

description: Came here 10 minutes before they opened and there was already a line. Great customer service: staff are quick, attentive, and always check on you. Ordered House Special Ramen and I love it :) Broth tastes amazing, very flavorful, not thick and full of sodium like most ramen I've had. Ramen noodles were fresh. I ended the meal with dessert called Matcha Cappuccino. It was pretty good! It had red bean on the bottom, panna cotta, and matcha was not strong. I enjoyed the atmosphere, friendly staff, and most importantly the food here. Would definitely return and recommend this place!
author: Lynn T.

description: Pretty good ramen, nothing out of the ordinary. The soup was flavorful and the noodles were cooked perfectly. I liked that they had the options of different toppings that you can add, like the umami paste and the chili garlic. I also enjoyed the ambience. Went during lunch and got seated right away. It didn't take long to get our meal. Overall, a decent average ramen spot.
author: Rochell S.

description: One of the best ramen spots I've been to! It's honestly rare that I finish a bowl of ramen because the broth is usually so rich and sometimes too salty towards the end. I love that this place serves dashi ramen, which uses fish stock instead of the usual pork stock. The noodles are also a bit thicker (which I personally liked) than other places and made from whole grain. I'm glad I got to try it and would definitely come again!
author: Jeana Y.

description: I rarely give 5 stars unless I'm blown away, but the Ramen here is the BEST I've had in San Francisco by far. The line is usually. Out the door so I came on a quiet Thursday afternoon for Lunch right when they opened. Even though the menu was small I couldn't decide what to eat. I opted out for the House Ramen and some Barley Tea. The service was great. The food was great (I finished everything, even the soup!). Pricing was reasonable, but it's in Japantown where parking is a horror. Still worth the try though. Hands down I would definitely come back.
author: Daw M.

description: Very good ramen made with dashi soup stock (fish stock-based broth) and whole wheat noodles, need to queue during the dining hours.
author: ToughG N.

description:
I would give five stars, but the service wasn't that great. I was here about a week ago on a weeknight, and it took about 20 minutes to get our check. We would've waited longer if I didn't glare at one of the waiters. Once I got his attention, he asked "did you need something?" Like really? Why would you clear our tables and not ask if we wanted anything else until after I got your attention?

On top of that, there was a short line outside, and it seemed like the waiters and hosts were just walking around. It just seemed unorganized and the waiters' customer service skills probably needs improvement.

The 3 stars are mostly for the vegan ramen, which was delicious. I'll only come back if their service improves.
author: Savannah K.

description:
A Japanese restaurant with Japanese flavors!  YAY!!!
Sadly most Japanese restaurants in the Bay Area are catered to Asian Americans (intense flavors, overly spicy, salty or oily). Hinodeya in contrast has beautiful delicate flavors where the ingredients sing.
This place is my top choice for ramen in SF.
Come here if you are tired of the oily and salty Tonkotsu style.  Nice decor too.
author: S H.

description: Great place in Japanese town. It stats to line up before they officially open at 11:30am. I ordered Clam ramen and fried oyster. They are super fantastic. The tabera sauce (garlic onion wichill oil) on the table is totally awesome. Highly recommended.
author: Sean L.

description:
What's a trip to Japantown without getting some ramen? We came here on a Sunday night around dinner time and it was about a 20-30 minute wait. I was excited for this place as I heard that they made their broth dashi and I love dashi. I got the hinodeya ramen and thought it was pretty good. I liked that the broth was thicker and lighter in flavor but still had enough flavor. The noodles were pretty good and the cha sui was good too. 

Overall, it wasn't too bad of a wait and it was good ramen. Come here if you like a lighter broth but thicker in consistency.
author: Sophia Y.

description: Pretty solid ramen spot. This was our second choice as Marufuku was jam packed. It was over an hour wait for 2 people on a Tuesday night. We ended up choosing Hinodeya Ramen Bar and we were very happy. The broth was amazing and light. The noodles had a great texture. Would definitely come back the next time we visit SF.
author: Justin W.

description:
*** In Short ***

A lighter toripaitan than that served by rivals Mensho and Nojo.

*** In Depth ***

The summary really captures the entirety of Hinodeya, honestly. If you've had the toripaitan at Mensho and Nojo, you'll probably also agree that the former is far more flavorful, but also much, much richer, creamier, and heavier than the latter. Hinodeya serves up an even lighter version than Nojo does, all at the same price point as the other two, but with less of a wait than Mensho, at the very least.

Flavorful and filling, with well-cooked noodles, but lacking the flavor depth of Mensho, which still reigns king for me in this city overflowing (finally) with excellent ramen choices.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A mix of seating here ranging from two-tops to bar counter seating, with plenty of accessible options, and fairly easy maneuverability to get around.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description:
a friend was in town for his 30th birthday and we chose to eat at hinodeya because he loves karaage and hinodeya has good reviews for that. oh wait what? it's NOT a karaage house? lol. luckily, our other friend has tried the hinodeya ramen at ramen festival last year before it had a brick & mortar restaurant, so we are on board with this situation.

there was no wait for 6 on a thursday evening at 7 pm! unheard of, and i was quite pleased. i hate waiting for food.  but we ended up waiting for everyone to arrive anyway.  obviously we started with the chicken karaage, and ended up getting four orders of it before dinner was finished. it was a little intense and we went slightly overboard, but the fried chicken was done very well, and the matcha salt is a nice touch.  

i ordered the hinodeya ramen for dinner - we basically split between hinodeya and chicken - everyone was very happy with their choice! the broth was clear and light/refreshing, toppings were on point, and the ramen was done well.  i generally prefer my broth to be milky rich, so this was different for sure.  

the wait staff was super courteous throughout our meal and even gave our friend free dessert with sparklers. such a nice gesture!  i would come back again for sure - we also got 'i heart dashi' stickers for everyone. so cute!
author: Christina L.

description: The ramen is really really good. Right portions of everything. The salad is a highlight, not too greasy not too dry. Just right. House ramen is $14, and appetizers range from $4 to $10. So about $25 a person after tax and tips. Worth every dollar. The ambience is great too and the wait is not crazily long. Very good experience in general
author: Shiyi F.

description: Excellent broth and noodles with House special noodles. Crispy and juicy fried oysters! Wonderful service. Just food heaven!
author: Steve M.

description: Ramen is such a popular meal around and in Japantown, you'd have to really decide which place to go. I had this place bookmarked since it opened, but I didn't come try it till today. The outside looked tiny, but as soon as you walk through the entrance, you can see this restaurant is actually very spacious. This spot is cute, with bamboo rolled curtains as decor for each section, very cultured like. There was a wait when I walked in, but we got seated fairly quickly. Seems like this place is known for their House Ramen so me and my friend got the same thing. We got our food quickly after ordering. The broth was super clear, very flavorful, but a tad too salty for me. My favorite part of this was their ramen, it had the bouncy elastic feeling in my mouth as I chewed it. Their egg was boiled to just a little runny in the middle and tender. The chashu was tender, but not super soft to the point where it was falling apart. This spot is a different, the ramen is a must! I'd definitely come back to try their chicken karagae. Around $32 for both house ramen, not bad !
author: Lisa W.

description: Eatable only ... don't know what's the hype! Noodles are mahhhhh also ..  noodledance across taste better ....
author: Titus H.

description: This place was decent! Crowded even at lunchtime on a weekday - we had to wait a few minutes to get a table. The house ramen's good, but nothing special. The pork was too fatty and chewy, which made it especially difficult to eat with chopsticks. The other toppings and broth were satisfying, but again, just standard. The broth is pretty fishy (to be expected because of the type of broth), so it's not for everyone, but I still enjoyed it.
author: Megan B.

description: Ramen wasn't great. Tried it after seeing that Ramen Yamadaya was closed, and was thoroughly disappointed in the quality of not only the broth but the noodles too. For those who want authentic ramen note that their are hundreds of styles, and the true key is the broth and noodles not the yelp reviews.
author: Brendan M.

description: Hinodeya Ramen is one of my favorite ramen spots in SF and I experienced dining with a complete stranger for the first time. I was in Japantown, heard amazing things about this place so checked it out. Planned to sit at the bar for a quick bite, but met a solo diner in line so decided to sit at the communal table together. We end up chatting for 2 hours and exchanged food/travel stories. Food brings people together and the ramen is on point
author: Christine C.

description:
Still happy about that place! 
Best Ramen spot in San Francisco right now and super Kids friendly! 
This time we ordered some appetizer too! So good!!! 
We loved it!!!
author: Nadine B.

description: Delicious meal and good service- despite the busy Saturday afternoon. Kid friendly too, which was a plus.
author: G H.

description: It was pretty good but a bit in the salty side. I've been spoiled by the BEST ramen ever in Hawaii- Yotteko ya ramen
author: Jess H.

description: A ramen place that is kids friendly. The food was great. We had a side of stew chicken wings, house ramen and zen ramen. We will be back again!
author: Rachel L.

description:
I wanted to like this place after I saw the sign announcing it's upcoming opening a while back (especially with the statement that this is a "from Japan" ramen place).  However, not it's not terrible, I find that somehow the ramen here doesn't excite me.  Their broth in the dashi ramen is pretty good but I thought the ramen (at least in my opinion) was just okay and the pork was nothing special.  Also there were two times when I came for the clam ramen only for it to be sold out.  Last week when I arrived early enough to order it, I found it to be such a disappointment in that the clam meat was not very good.  My friend felt that, because they used a larger-size clam, it was not suitable for this type of cooking and they would've been better off using smaller manila clams.

The service is nice, I have to give them credit for that.  Also it's nice that, on their bill, there's no employee health tax surcharge (like a couple of the other ramen places in Japantown) and they calculate their suggested tip based on the before-tax total (which I feel it should always be).
author: H K.

description: Ordered the Karaage to start which was delicious, but a little pricey. It was interesting because it came with matcha salt and that didn't make it too salty. For my main dish I had the Hinodeya House Ramen. It might not be my #1 ramen in the area, but it definitely hits the spot. The broth was decent in flavor, the pork was standard, I only got half an egg which was a little disappointing, but the noodles are what make this dish interesting. The noodles aren't your typical ramen noodles, but if you eat as much ramen as I do it is a nice change of pace.
author: Michael C.

description:
It's been a while since I had a really good bowl of Ramen and boy oh boy did this hit the spot! It's in the heart of SF Japantown. Decor is simple and modern. There is a seating at  a bar in the front, along the walls and in the center of the restaurant. There are also sectioned of tables for groups in the back.

The broth....one word: DELICIOUS! I had the Hinodeya Ramen. It was perfect. Great flavor but not overly salty.

The noodles were cooked perfectly. They had a little bit of a chew and a great overall texture. They gave the perfect amount. I didn't have to ask for more, but I probably could have ate more if it was sitting in front of me :)

The add-ons. It came with chars, bamboo and 1/2 a soft boiled egg. I ordered extra charsu. The charsu was good. It was overly seasoned which was great because it let the broth shine.

Dessert was their black sesame ice-cream. Pretty good overall. Not sure how I liked the granola. It kind of charged the taste, but the crunch was nice. 

Staff was great and checked in on me. They are a friendly bunch and welcome each gets with a hearty group welcome, so it keeps things lively! 

Definitely a go-to for when I'm in the area.
author: Krystal T.

description:
Very Japanese style service and ramen, excellent flavor! Though the dashi-style ramen is different from the Tonkotsu flavors that are popular in San Francisco Ramen, this is a good place to try some of the varied ramen soups and noodles that Japan has to offer! Noodles are actually cooked properly, and the soup is flavorful but not too light. 

Definitely try to Lemon Pepper Ramen (limited release right now) if you want a cold, refreshing ramen. Otherwise, try to Vegan ramen for a thick and hearty soup that tastes meaty but is completely vegan!

Come by multiple times to try everything but beware of lines during peak times.
author: Wesley Y.

description: Small business but good food. The noodles had rich flavors. Will definitely go back if I visit San Francisco again.
author: Violet Z.

description: We've had alot of ramen in the city. Hinoyada brings a unique light and flavorful bowl to you. It's fkn amazing. I had house special s he had zen. Both perfect. Bamboo shoots and chilli oil as an app. Texture on the cold shoots is probably foreign to most American Pallets but the flavor is there. Don't skip on the umami paste and garlic chili paste to make  your ramen pop!!!
author: Dan W.

description: the location is tucked away and quiet in japantown which was a nice change from the usual bustle of the main strip. the house ramen here was exquisite- rich, creamy broth and well cooked noodles. they do not make ramen spicy and they only had chili oil as a spice option. i felt the overall experience was completely rushed - as soon as we sat down and ordered, the staff brought out both our appetizers and ramen at the same time. so we were trying to quickly finish the first dish so the second wouldn't get cold (it did anyway) which was frustrating and took away from the experience overall.
author: Alexandra K.

description:
Not a fan of their ramen, at least the ones we ordered. It's plain. 

Broth was diluted, tiny portion of chashu (thin and small).  Eh...

BUT chashu appetizer was good, the only thing i liked during my first (and only visit?).
author: Sarah L.

description: 5 stars to this restaurant and it's totally perfect ramen experience!  We were so impressed by this authentic and superb ramen dinner.  We dined in while visiting San Francisco and I have dreams about it ever since.  Two in our party got the vegetarian ramen which completely changed my whole outlook on why my sister is just fine living as a vegetarian.  The third member of our party got the traditional ramen and it was amazing also.  We got desert too it was cool and pretty but who cares about that at this place the ramen is the only superstar.  Peace
author: Heather M.

description:
A decent ramen shop. There were long lines for every ramen shop so we went to the one with the shortest line which was Hinodeya. I really didn't know what to expect so I ordered their signature ramen. The place has crowd seating like a big table with lots of people. I liked it but I got the sense that the people that came here didn't really know about ramen. Just some remarks like not knowing won ton in the salad was fried toppings and not actually won ton.
In any case we ordered their side dish of braised chicken. That's not what it's called but that's what it was.  It was like someone tried to make shoyu chicken but only put half the amount of shoyu. It was a weak shoyu chicken. Not impressive- sorry.

The ramen itself was decent. The noodles were slightly curly like Sun noodles but they were more flat rather than round. Like a derivative of Sun noodles. The broth was ok - not bad - it reminded me of a better SS saimin. I would say that the new top ramen places in Honolulu are better than this place. You are also kind of packed in since the tables are wide. 

I give it an ok rating but nothing special in terms of taste and noodles. The chicken is weak.
author: Aron N.

description:
Braised chicken - The meat was extremely tender, but I personally wasn't a fan of the skin being left on the chicken. Normally I'm fine with chicken skin but the soup that the chicken came with made the texture a bit too soggy. Although the chicken was flavorful, I thought that the taste of mirin (Japanese sweet rice wine) overpowered the soy sauce and the rest of the flavors. Would not order again. 

House ramen - this ramen is probably one of the most unique ramen I've ever tried! Contrary to ramen I'm used to eating, their house ramen broth was NOT heavy at all. Nonetheless, it was still just as flavorful as you'd expect from a good bowl of ramen. It didn't leave me feeling bloated afterwards or the next day. I'd definitely come again for this.
author: Catherine C.

description: Really tasty ramen with great service. Recommend the Zen ramen, which has a unique broth flavor and delicious mushrooms.
author: Carolyn F.

description: Really cool interior with calming music and kind employees. A bit pricey but my friends really wanted ramen so we went here. I got the chicken ramen while they got the house ramen and both were really salty. While the chicken wings in my ramen were fall-off-the-bone tender, the texture gave me the impression that they'd been sitting in the pot for days.
author: Justin L.

description:
I came here last Monday and everything about my experience was positive!

I know this is probably rare, but there was absolutely no wait and I got seated right away.  Also, Hinodeya is open on Mondays (a lot of ramen spots are closed), so that was an added plus.

I got the Tori Paitian ramen and it was very delicious.  The broth was the perfect amount of creaminess yet felt light and clean.  The noodles are made out of buck-wheat and the perfect texture.  My only real complaint was that the portion was a bit small - I love ramen and need lots of it!

My boyfriend got the Hinodeya ramen, which was equally as delicious.  The broth was lighter in texture but still packed with a ton of flavor. 

Another plus is that they have Asahi on tap :)

Next time, I'm going to come with a hungrier appetite and try some of the appetizers and sides!  Can't wait!!
author: Lisa Marie R.

description:
Hinodeya is the new ramen place that opened in place of Shalala. The line here was pretty long on a Friday night at 8pm. Their ramen is is pretty light and dashi-based (fish-based soup). I'd be back for more. I thought the price was a bit high for the quantity, but I guess it's pretty standard $14-15 San Francisco ramen prices.

I've only been here once so I've only tried the traditional Hinodeya ramen. The noodles are quite chewy :)
author: Annie Z.

description:
Delicious ramen as expected, nothing to disappoint for. Good soup, good noodle and other ingredients. Cozy and well designed setting, just a bit tight in the center. Unlike the many boring vegetarian items from other restaurants, their vegetarian ramen option seemed awesome too with the squash and milky soup base. Definitely worth the bucks, considering the many mediocre ramen places around the city that charge the same or more (e.g. the one next to Colma Target)... This is my new fav ramen spot to hit besides Ramen Yamadaya from right across. 

They had way more seating in the back but I guess their cooks/staff were not well prepped for more customers that were waiting out the door, yes, out the DOOR!
author: Leilani B.

description:
Yum. Another ramen bar! With, of course, a wait to match. We came even for a late lunch, right before closing, and there were still several people waiting in front of us.  Fortunately, we made it in right before they cut off the line!  It was definitely a much shorter wait than Mensho though and I thought this ramen was way better.

The portions are small, but the ramen is delicious.  The broth was perfect, comforting and soothing on a cold, windy SF day and not too over-powering.  We ordered the Tori Paitan and the Hinodeya and we thoroughly enjoyed both of them and the uniqueness of each of the broths.  The noodles were also perfectly fresh and chewy.

Again, my only complaint is that for the price tag, it was not a very satisfying meal.  Satisfying, in that, my taste buds were elated and I was warmed to the core on a chilly day.  But, disappointing, in that, we were hungry 30 minutes later.  We ended up picking up some sushi from a Japanese market to help fill us up.

I will definitely return but maybe not when I'm famished because then you'll meet hangry Jess...and I assure you, no one wants to meet her.
author: Jess Y.

description: Hinodeya is a solid ramen place, which is known for their traditional dashi stock (made from mushroom, kelp, bonito flake, and scallops). I have heard about how busy they are at dinner so we came in for an early lunch to avoid crazy lines. Our group ordered both the House Ramen (4/5) (thick noddles, chashu pork, bamboo, and soft boiled egg in light dashi soup base) and the Chicken Ramen aka. Tori Paitan (4/5) (thick noddles, 3 pieces of chicken wings, mushroom, and soft boiled eggs in creamy chicken stock). Both ramen dishes were flavorful and refreshing but I like the traditional taste of their house ramen a little more. The kara-age was fried to crispy heaven perfection (5/5). The matcha salt didn't do much flavor wise but it is pretty to look at. Service was good, the waiters and waitress were helpful in explaining the menu and bringing the food out. Wait was less than 5 minutes at noon on a Sunday. Overall, great meal, will come back for more.
author: Vivi L.

description:
Best ramen in the city.  Staff is incredible: friendly and great at their jobs.  My wife and I go here every other Sunday because it's so consistently good.

Get the Karaage.
author: Spencer H.

description:
I've always maintained that if you want good Japanese food, avoid Japantown.

But not anymore.

Wowza. The dashi broth of the house Ramen is homemade, fresh, decadent, and outrageously delicious. Perfect portion size, just enough. The dashi broth is a clear broth as opposed to the typical tonkotsu ramen broths at other ramen joints. I am a fan of this type of ramen broth, so maybe I am biased, but from what I can see, everyone agrees. 

I've been here a few times, if you come about 30 minutes after opening, you can avoid the line, as you are in between waves. Right after we arrived and got seated, the line got pretty long. No matter, it is worth the wait.
author: Anthony G.

description:
A totally new and refreshing take on ramen! 

Came on a Friday night when they just opened for dinner service. There was no wait and we were immediately seated in a semi-private space in the back (great space for larger groups).

All their ramen come with a dashi based broth (clear, cleaner, and lighter) versus the heavy tonkotsu broth at most other ramen joints in the Bay. The noodles were flat and wide and cooked perfectly al dente. 

Hinodeya Ramen: Their house ramen. Dashi style broth (made from bonito, kombu and scallop) with whole wheat noodles, chashu pork, soft boiled egg, dried seaweed and green onion.

Hamaguri Ramen: Littleneck clam, whole wheat noodles, dashi broth, green onion and shredded red pepper. Clam tasted fresh. Definitely recommend this if you're a clam or seafood fan and looking to try a different version of ramen.

Solid bowls of ramen and worth a visit but don't come here expecting the usual tonkotsu ramen.
author: Chris S.

description: This was our 3rd time here - this time because we were looking for a place for my friend who asked for soup which was the only thing she could really taste or tolerate on her current chemo treatments. I'm so happy that I did because the flavors are so delicious - and we are able to enjoy the conversation with efficient and kind service. The hinodeya ramen is perfect - asked for extra bamboo shoots and shiitake mushrooms. Also, the fried yams are unique and really tasty.
author: SY K.

description:
We liked this place. We would go here again. 

I thought the noodles were good, my Chinese spousal-unit thought the noodles were the best he's had in years. The broth was only OK, though, a little on the bland side. 

The service was A+ good. 

Prices were a little on the high side, we thought, maybe two bucks more than what we thought was appropriate for the mea. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
author: Tim W.

description:
(Droool) The best Ramen I've ever had in my life! 

The hamaguri ramen which is (as their menu says) umami-filled littleneck clams, whole wheat noodles, buttery dashi broth with garlic topped w/ green onion, and shredded red pepper. 

amazing!
author: Amanda N.

description: Excellent ramen, fast and friendly service and very warm and interesting decor. I was very impressed by Hinodeya. The ramen was the perfect amount of filling without being overwhelming or heavy. The fried oysters and chicken ramen are a must! This place does get busy but we were in and out all within about 40min for lunch. Will definitely be coming back!
author: Aiman F.

description:
Came here at 5pm on the Sunday of Cherry Blossom Festival.

I was looking for some legit ramen and yelp led me to this place! Surprisingly there was no wait at all!

We got the House Ramen and the Tori Paitian and both were delicious. The house ramen has a dashi based broth which was great! It was a clear light broth with a wonderful umami flavor. There was a nice fatty piece of pork in there as well but the broth really stole the show of that bowl.

The Tori Paitian is a completely different animal of a ramen. This too was delicious but the broth was rich like a tonkatsu. The fat coated the noodles so that they were velvety in every bite. Flavor wise, its distinctly different from a pork based broth. I feel that it is sweeter but also lighter.

Each bowl came with a fair portion of noodles that were different from any ramen noodles I've had. They are thick and wavy and chewy! By volume. you get a substantial amount of food just from the noodles. I walked away feeling like I had a full meal, as opposed to some places where the noodles just kind of vanish. 

Definitely give this place a try. It is a unique ramen experience compared to what is usually out there.
author: Christopher L.

description: If you get here before 7pm on a weekday you can watch the people pile up behind you.  The ramen was good. Soup was creamy.
author: Diane Z.

description: My favorite ramen amongst the new wave of ramen shops that seem to sprout up all over the city.  Their broth has a unique flavor compared to others. Noodles have a nice consistency.  Be prepared for the long line.
author: Eric C.

description:
This place had potential but ended up being a bit of a disappointment. To me, ramen is all about the broth and the broth here simply lacks the depth of flavor to bring me back again. 

The space is new and very nice. Service reminded me of places in Tokyo where you are treated like a king. Right when we walked in, we were greeted by a friendly server who sat us immediately and happily accommodated our request for a high chair. They even brought hand towels for us to wipe our hands before the start of the meal which is very commonplace at restaurants in Japan. Accordingly, I had very high hopes for the meal and was very excited about getting our food. 

We started with the Kara-Age which was very lightly coated in flour before frying so it was mostly chicken and not batter. Chicken meat itself was cooked well and was juicy but no seasoning was added. The order came with a side of matcha salt for us to sprinkle ourselves. I prefer my food to be seasoned before it leaves the kitchen so this really bothered me. For our main meal, we ordered the House Ramen which had a very unimpressive dashi broth. When I have ramen, the noodles are important but it's mostly all about the broth. The noodles here were stellar and super chewy and delicious. However, I don't consider noodles the highlight of a bowl of ramen so was really looking for more depth of flavor from that broth. There was spicy shallot chili oil and umami paste on the table to add yourself. I used both and still felt the broth was lacking the kind of richness that can only be imparted from hours and hours of cooking. 

The meal was filling and I could tell they used good quality ingredients. Portions were good and prices were reasonable as well. But the broth was just average and for that reason, I didn't find the bowl of ramen to be that good. I also would have liked the chicken to be seasoned before it came to the table. I think I would come back if other ramen places in Japantown had too long of a line but this is definitely not amongst my top 3 for favorite ramen restaurants.
author: Betty R.

description: A group of us wanted to eat ramen late at night. Hinodeya in Japan Town sounded good on yelp plus it was open till 2200 hrs. We were not disappointed. The Hinodeya house ramen is VERY tasty. Noodles had a great curly texture and there was a generous portion of meat topping. I can't do dirty and this place passed my cleanliness standard. It is clean AND aesthetically pleasing. The staff is extremely accommodating and friendly. I will definitely go back to Hinodeya when craving ramen.
author: KJ N.

description: Service was good. Appetizers were definitely better than the ramen bowls. Karaage was good. Liked the wasabi salt that came with it. Gyozas seemed fresh and were tasty. The house ramen broth was good but the noodles are just awful. It was clumpy in some parts n soggy as hell on other spots. Reminded me of overcooked top ramen noodles. The paiten was way too salty. Same issues with the noodles. The braised wings were something definitely worth a pass. Thank god I didn't have to pay for this meal.
author: Guess W.

description: Came here on a Friday evening with a large party. The timing worked out that we didn't have to wait a long time. I ordered their standard bowl of ramen. Overall, I thought the ramen was average. It wasn't bad, but nothing stood out to me. I'm not sure if it's the ingredient they used in their noodle or what, but I wasn't keen on either the flavor or the texture of the noodle. Overall, decent ramen place.
author: Sharon L.

description: This place is just okay. The Cheese Royal is basically 5 small cubes of cream cheese, not really with the $5. And the ramen noodles were dense and didn't really soak up any flavor from the broth. For the price we probably wouldnt visit here again. But it was clean, and the staff were friendly.
author: Mariah And Myles ..

description:
This place has become another one of my favorite ramen spots in SF because of how light yet flavorful their broth is. It's a bit on the pricey side (about $14-$18 a bowl depending on what you get) but at the same time that's like typical SF prices now for a GOOD bowl of ramen. 

Their house Hinodeya ramen ($14) is really good as it's a broth made of bonito, kombu and scallop which gives it more of a rich seafood flavor! The toppings it comes with are half an egg, a piece of pork chashu and bamboo shoots. I still haven't tried their tori paitan chicken ramen ($15) , which some of my friends who had it said it has really good flavor even though the broth is lighter in texture than the one at Mensho. They also have two other choices, the vegan ramen ($15) and Hamaguri ($18), a garlic clam flavor. All bowls of ramen come with whole wheat noodles, except the vegan one that has spinach noodles instead! I also tried their fried oysters here before which are really good and a great starter to share with others, and the pictures of the karaage look pretty bomb too. 

Also get the matcha cappuccino dessert here as a finisher! Normally I'd get dessert elsewhere as Japantown has a great selection of sweets to eat, but after seeing pictures of their matcha cappuccino it looked like something I had to try as a girl with a big sweet tooth. It's a delicious panna cotta with bits of matcha jelly cubes and red bean in middle! 

Service is great here and the environment is super clean! Definitely would come back and recommend this place to other ultimate SF foodies and ramen lovers :)
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Surprised that Hinodeya is so highly-rated.  It's not terrible, but have definitely experienced better elsewhere.  The broth lacked flavor and the texture of the ramen was strange.  The pork in my Hinodeya ramen was overcooked and tough.  Was not worth the 20-minute wait (so I certainly would not wait any longer than that).

I must say that the service was good.  Too bad the food wasn't all that.
author: Christine A.

description:
New ramen spot in my neighborhood! Pleased to say it's one that I would visit to satisfy a ramen craving :) Broth, noodles, well-balanced.

Hinodeya's special is their dashi broth ramen, which isn't something you see on the menu generally in the bay area. In comparison to tonkotsu and tori paitan, the dashi broth is lighter but, by default, full of umami. I think it's something that should be appreciated because most of the dashi we eat nowadays is instant dashi, not the nuanced, layered taste of house-made dashi. After you start having ramen that achieves these subtleties, you can note the differences between your packaged soup stock and something prepared with care in a restaurant. Hinodeya hits the spot for me in their dashi broth. 

The tori paitan broth definitely held the essence of chicken stock, but I crave the creaminess that Mensho creates.
author: Kathy Z.

description: The food was superb. Had the tori and the house ramen, the broth was so flavorful!!!!!
author: Virana S.

description:
I came here right at opening with a classmate after a full day of shenengians! 

We both decided on the House ramen priced at $14. It came with their house broth, and one piece of cha sui and veggies. Coming from that Mensho thick broth to this lighter broth was definitely a big difference. It is a dashi based ramen--a little bit of saltiness without having a fishy taste. It was kind of oily and I was really really thirsty afterwards! I had to get boba!

Ramen came with bonito, kombu, & scallop broth, whole wheat noodles, chashu, menma, marinated soft boiled egg. I would love to come back to try their other broths!
author: Alice Z.

description: So yummy! Second time here tonight and it was just as delicious as I remembered it to be. Broth is not too rich or creamy, was the perfect combination of savory yet not too overly salty...we left feeling satisfied yet not overly food coma pass out full! Definitely one of my future go to ramen bars in SF.
author: June L.

description:
I actually felt healthy after eating Hinodeya Ramen. However, this was the tiniest portion of ramen I had ever eaten. My friend and I were so hungry we ordered another bowl and split it, so I did get to try both kinds of ramen. If you're in the area, Hinodeya is worth stopping by. The noodles are really firm, the way I like my ramen noodles. Otherwise, gets lost in the pack of all the great ramen restaurants in the Bay Area.

[Food]
I love the fried chicken here. It was amazing - highly recommend this appetizer. The flavor was great and really juicy, and not too oily or salty. I tried the House and Tori Paitan Ramen. Maybe I was really hungry or I just eat a lot, but man those bowls were small. I do prefer a thicker, richer broth, but it was nice that after I had finished my ramen I didn't feel super thirsty. I think I preferred the Tori Paitan Ramen just slightly, but didn't have very strong feelings about the meal.

[Service]
We got there early and were seated immediately. The ramen did come out really slow for 5:00pm on a Friday afternoon. Our servers were friendly. 

[Décor]
The restaurant is actually a bit more spacious than your regular tiny ramen parlor. There is bar seating and larger tables for big parties. Nothing special about the interior design.

Overall, Hinodeya was an average ramen meal. I didn't go home dreaming about the noodles or the broth. My Japanese coworker, however, raves about Hinodeya so maybe its based on preference. I would give it a try if you're in Japantown and are looking for ramen, but wouldn't actively seek out Hinodeya again.
author: Alice Z.

description:
