For Japan Town in SF, this place is modest. Broth is light dashi flavored. 

The best way to judge ramen is how the kaedama tastes. This place was alright.
author: Ryo I.

description:
I came here on a cold Friday evening. Although there was a long line (~15 people) out the door, the line moved pretty quickly. The wait was about 10 min in total so don't let the crowd outside discourage you from trying this place. 

The menu consisted of two types of ramen: Hinodeya (house special) and Tori Paitan (chicken). I decided to try the Hinodeya, as it was their signature dish. The broth was tasty and flavorful and every component of the dish complemented the broth well. The noodles were the right texture and amount of chewiness. The egg was cooked perfectly with the egg yolk having a smooth consistency. 

On top of the food, the place was very sanitary. They even had containers placed next to tables to put your bag inside so it didn't have to touch the floor. The service was attentive and responsive. 

I really enjoyed my experience here and definitely will be coming here for ramen again!
author: Mina T.

description: Ohhh this is the beet ramen we have had in a while. We had the house ramen and the dashi broth was amazingly good. I generally prefer a fatty pork broth but I didn't miss it like I thought I would. That dashi erased it from my mind. The noodles were nice and springy... getting hungry as I write this. We would go back again but holding off 5 stars until I try more ramen places.
author: Patty Y.

description: Best vegan ramen ever. The broth was so rich and creamy and the spinach noodles are amazingly unctuous. I called it Japanese fettuccine Alfredo!!  Awesome friendly service. Great sake. Will be going here regularly!!
author: Eric M.

description: The house ramen was 10/10 deliciousness in my belly!Great service & staff was speedy !
author: Elizabeth L.

description: The vegan ramen is absolutely amazing!! The place appeared clean and the staff were friendly. We went on a Friday and didn't have to wait because we came early (5:15), it got very packed shortly after.
author: Erica P.

description:
Went to this new place on Sat. for lunch. There was already a line before they opened. I ordered the following:

-Cheese Royal (Very Good)

- Hinodeya Ramen: 
  Ramen, Egg, Soup (Very Good), Chashu (Good but no taste), Bamboo (OK), 

- Tebasaki: 
   Braised chicken wings w/ Dashi & Soy Sauce  (just OK)

- Matcha cappuccino:
  Matcha Green Tea Panna Cotta w/ sweet Red Bean, Nata de coco (gelatin like texture),    
  whipped cream, and matcha sauce (Good)

*The staffs were friendly & nice ^^
author: Wendy L.

description:
After walking around presidio, my friend and I came to jtown for some ramen, we were originally going for Marufuku Ramen; however the wait was too long and we were getting really hungry. 

So glad we made the switch and walked back to this place with NO WAIT (12:30pm on a Sunday). I ordered the Tori Paitan and she ordered the House Ramen with extra braised wings. 
The broth was so flavorful, yet it looked so light. We were getting ready to season the broth until we took the first sip and was like this is totally fine without anything added.There isn't really a single ramen place that I would finish my soup for Ramen, however I finished all the soup for this bowl.  Although, it seemed a bit pricey, we feel like it's totally worth because the broth tasted like they've been working on it for days. It's been 3 days since I've had this ramen and I'm still thinking about it today. Will be going back soon ^^ hopefully.
author: Kady S.

description:
A good and authentic Japanese ramen spot in Japantown! Glad I tried this place. Came here on a Saturday night ten minutes before opening. There was a line of about six to eight people ahead of me, on a rainy cold night. Not sure if the line is usually longer than this, but glad we didn't have to wait and were seated at the bar. 

First thing I noticed was the nice ambience that made me feel like I was back in Japan again. From what I heard, the staff are from Saitama. 

For two, we tried the Hinodeya ramen ($14), tori paitan ($15), and chicken karaage ($9). The chicken karaage included matcha salt, which is always a favorite. The chicken was cooked well, and the perfect amount of crispy and chewy. I liked the broth in the tori paitan more. The tori paitan came with creamier broth, a half mushroom, half a soft boiled egg, seaweed, and chicken wing. The Hinodeya ramen had a slice of chashu, bamboo shoots, and a half soft boiled egg. Both were good options and the egg tasted delicious. Noodles were thick and tasty. Portions were a bit small for the price, however. I wish there were more toppings. 

Overall a solid new addition to the area.
author: Christina G.

description: So amazing!!!! Best vegan ramen in sf!!! I went to mensho it however you spell it and t has NOTHING on this place!!! So good
author: Lauren L.

description: Fantastic place for a sumptuous lunch. The chicken ramen and chicken karage were superb and I was stuffed! Staff were quick and efficient. Thankfully there was no waiting time on a Monday at 1 pm. The staff greet whenyou enter and leave the place in a collective chant!
author: Ana P.

description:
Best vegetarian ramen and best service! 
I always feel amazing coming to this place. It's next level of hospitality for sure. 
I'm very particular about ramen and this place has been serving the best ramen in the city, seriously. I live by Japan town so I've tried it all :)
Enjoy!
author: Yulya M.

description:
Hinodeya Ramen is unlike any other ramen joint I've been to. This is high quality ramen that you don't want to miss out on.

I ordered the Hinodeya ramen, which is a fish-based broth with whole wheat noodles, green onions, chashu, egg, bamboo, and seaweed. Fish, you might ask? Yes - it was odd to me simply because the ramen I'm used to is typically pork or soy based. Fish is something a Vietnamese dish would use... but it works! Delicious and light. Once you finish the bowl's contents and that last drop of broth, a few things occur:

1. No instant regret, unless you stuffed yourself on appetizers prior (our group ordered the Karaage that came with matcha salt, that itself was a delight).
2. Stomach is not full and bloated, since the broth is light.
3. You're not thirsty as hell because it's not too salty.

For a party of 8 and a Saturday night, the wait was not bad. I'd say 15-20 minutes. The torrent of rain may have had something to do with that, though.

100% would come back when I'm in the city and I will try the other ramen options.
author: Kelvin B.

description:
The wait.. typical San Francisco. There IS a sign in sheet, but it is inside the restaurant. 

There were only 2 options when I went. The tori paitan and hinodeya. I really really really wanted try to the clam ramen but I'll have to return the full menu is offered. 

Started off with the cheese royale, an order of wings, and kara-age. The wings are boring, pass. They just taste like adobo. Nothing too special, and it is the same chicken wing that is in the tori paitan. Loved the cheese royale! Cubes of cheese  with hunks of wasabi. DELICIOUS. Kara-age was also nothing special, you can skip this. My friend and I were just really hangry. We ordered tea as well, and at $4 a cup THEY DO NOT REFILL! Good lord! FOUR DOLLARS A CUP! eek, methinks not....

I had the hinodeya ramen while my friend opted to try the tori paitan. Both of us found the hinodeya to have much better. While a very light broth, it packed a lot of umami. Do not overload your bowl of ramen with the fried garlic chips at the table! They will be overkill. The tori paitan..while good and hearty, got boring. It was like a light comforting chicken noodle soup. 

I normally do not mind communal seating. But at Hinodeya? They packed us in at that table TIGHT. I got seated near the end, a woman and her kid were at the edge and her husband was sitting opposite of me. They had some sort of disagreement which ended up with him only speaking to the kid, the both of them trying to feed the kid , the wife intermittently stating "oh so you're not going to talk to me huh? Only Mia? I see how it is"

Mia also kept trying to reach over and take my chicken wings. Mia, this is how you lose a hand. Don't you ever ever ever ever ever steal a hangry b1tch's chicken wangs. EVER.

Communal seating is ok when you don't pack us in like sardines. That made it unpleasant. Not the restaurants fault but I suppose they could've maybe not forced a bunch more ppl next to my friend... it would've been nice to be able to move at least 6 inches away from the bickering couple. I was elbow to elbow w/ the wife!
author: Susy C.

description: I came in with a friend and we both ordered the lunchtime Vegan Ramen. It wasn't until after we finished our meal that our server told us it was the first day they had it on the menu! It was delicious. The broth was clear, and deliciously salty and savory, the veggies were fresh and the noodles were perfect ramen noodles (very impressive for a vegan noodle). Excited to go back and try their dinner Vegan Ramen which sounds very different and unlike anything I've tried before. The place was upscale and very pleasant to be in. Great lunch spot tucked into Japantown.
author: Naomi A.

description: Exemplary ramen in a really nice setting. Everything about the Hinodeya Ramen was perfect, right down to the bamboo shoots. The broth really makes it, though - just fantastic. I'll be back the next time I can brave the line!
author: Erica W.

description: Probably my favorite vegan ramen in the City AND they're open for lunch which isn't too common for ramen joints. Only thing I'm sad about is that I didn't find this place sooner!
author: Susie D.

description: Nice ambiance and feels like Japan, but the food was mediocre and somewhat overpriced (I guess it's not fair to say that since this is SF after all). I had the clam ramen, and my husband had the tori paitan and a sake flight. The sake flight was great. For the ramen, I still think Mensho is better overall.
author: Esther Y.

description: We ordered the shishito peppers and chicken karagae for appetizer. Few of the peppers are spicy! Karagae is a bit dry. Also got the Tori (chicken) ramen and Hinodeya (charsiu) ramen. The ramen are thin noodles. Chicken is flavorful. Nice but not exceptional.
author: Wynne K.

description: Really good vegan ramen.  Seems like a perfect place to bring family if everyone isn't vegan.  The broth was soooo tasty and the waiters are very friendly.
author: Jivan Ivan B.

description:
What is this ramen heaven?! Me and my friend ordered the hamaguri ramen and both were deeply impressed. The broth was absolutely delicious - we both drank it all down! The clams used were super fresh and meaty. And the ramen was bouncy and chewy. Haven't been impressed with ramen in a while, this place is quite top notch for ramen in SF! 

I also ordered their Matcha Cappucino dessert. Which they labeled as matcha panacotta with red beans and coffee jelly. It was more like matcha mousse, but it was still pretty darn good. Wasn't overly sweet and the jelly and red bean added some texture to the dessert. 

Will be back to try all their ramen. They only have four ramens, so it definitely won't take me long :D
author: Maggie L.

description:
This brand new ramen spot in Japantown is a great weeknight experience. 

We were seated at a communal table on a Monday night. Because it's traditional to slurp your ramen, it was hard for me to focus on my conversation with all the slurping at the communal table. My boyfriend and I asked to be reseated and waited a few minutes for an awesome, more private table (I'd reccomend).

We went with the two most popular options and were not disappointed. I read that the wait is bad for Hinodeya, so a weeknight might be best.

-1 for the saltiness in every dish. I'm sure it's a sign of good ramen, but I could have drank a gallon of water after that meal!
author: Kerry G.

description:
Recommendation of the day: Their signature Hinodeya ramen! The fish broth was light compared to the typical tonkotsu broth (pork). 

Pros:
-Short line because it's new a new joint. We only waited for 5 minutes for two people on a rainy Friday night.
-Super friendly employees who greet every single customers as they walk to their table! 
- Our ramen came out 10 minutes after we ordered! Pretty fast service in my opinion. 

Cons:
-Located in Japantown so parking might be a pain in the butt. Highly recommend to pay for the parking structure instead of looking for street parking. 
-Only two type of ramen broth (fish or chicken broth) but I personally prefer pork broth.

P.S. Don't order too many appetizers and save room for desserts at the Japanese mall next door (Japanese crepe)!
author: Linda L.

description:
Honestly, feeling more like a 3.5 star experience, but I'll round up to 4. 

I stopped by on a rainy Friday night around 6:20pm, and the wait ended up being around 20 minutes for a party of two. Around the time our table was ready though I saw a line start to form outside so you might want to show up before 6:30pm to avoid too long of a wait.

We started with an order of the chicken karage, which was tasty and came with a little dish of matcha salt and lemon wedge to top them off. It arrived hot and crispy and I only wish it came with more and bigger pieces! My friend and I both ordered the Hinodeya Ramen. I enjoyed the broth which was clear, and lighter than most other ramen broths you'll see around, but still full of flavor. The noodles had a nice bite to them and the egg was perfectly cooked. Sadly there was only one piece of meat though and a little too many scallions, they formed a solid layer above my noodles. 

We ended with the black sesame ice cream which comes with small crispy bits that taste like rice krispies (don't know if that's what they actually were), topped off with some whipped cream and a single raspberry. It was light and creamy and the perfect way to end the meal. 

The reason my rating isn't higher is that the ramen was solid and tasty but not earth-shattering or something necessarily worth waiting in a long line for. The portions are also a little on the smaller end, although I was still satiated after the meal. 

Still worth a visit if the line isn't too long!
author: Vivian L.

description: Amazing atmosphere from the moment you walk in. The place is a bit small, but the area is clean and well-maintained. In my party of two, we were seated quickly and a waiter arrived at our table at the perfect time. I ordered the hinodeya ramen, which I can say for sure is the best ramen dish I've ever had so far. The serving size is just enough, and I left the place full and satisfied.
author: Rafael B.

description: Came in 10 minutes before the listed closing time, and there were five other people still waiting to be seated! They happily seated us and gave us a warm welcome. We were seated in the back of the restaurant and I thought to myself, "They are going to forget us back here and its towards the end of the night were going to be rushed."I WAS PROVEN WRONG! Service was amazing! Ordered in a timely manner and received food in a reasonable amount of time. 5 starts for the service!
author: Leica T.

description:
Hinodeya Ramen Bar is an excellent ramen spot in Japantown!

We got the Hinodeya ramen and it was great. It was unlike any Japanese ramen I've had. It felt as if I was eating udon instead of ramen. Most of the times when I eat Japanese ramen, I start to feel fat, but when I ate Hinodeya ramen, I felt healthy. The noodles weren't too thick or too thin and were very chewy. The broth was so rich in flavor and had a taste that hit the spot. The pork was also great; it didn't have too much fat and had more meat, which I really liked. The portion size is perfect for one person to get happily full.

The customer service is excellent. The workers are so kind and they're open to answering any questions about the menu and suggesting drinks (if you ask). Also, the ramen came out within 5 minutes of ordering so we didn't have to wait long for out food at all-- loved it (but we also went at around 9pm)!

Overall, a great ramen place. I highly recommend to check this place out if you're in Japantown.
author: Jen S.

description: This is by far my favorite ramen place in San Francisco. The broths are very rich and flavorful and I can tell the cooking staff puts care into the food. I tried the vegan ramen which at first I was hesitant to do, but it ended up being absolutely delicious! I got it the second time I went, too. I've had excellent service here each time I've gone. Well worth the wait in line!
author: Angela S.

description: I'm usually meh about Japanese ramen bc it can be really oily and greasy, leaving me with a non-so-great feeling, but this was by far the cleanest Japanese ramen I've had so far with amazing flavor. Had to wait a little, but it was a quick wait and well worth it.
author: Yuju P.

description:
Finally got to try this place. I had tried to go here a few weeks ago with a group of 6 but the line was ridiculous. This time it was just me and my boyfriend and we decided to try and grab a quick bite after we watched a movie at the Kabuki theater. Sure enough, no line!

We both decided to try the Hinodeya Ramen. Granted, there's only two options. That and the chicken broth one. Seeing as this place is named "Hinodeya" we just tried their main ramen. Overall? Pretty tasty. Noodles are different - more of a flat curly noodle. And their broth is clear. Obviously, this means that the ramen overall is not as thick and rich as others. That's not necessarily a bad thing - it's just different!

The standard option includes bamboo shoots, green onion (if you like green onions, you'll love it here. they really top it off), half an egg, and a thin slice of chashu pork. But again, since we're in SF and ramen bowls are a whopping $14 (yes, seriously), the price is a little off-putting...especially when you get one VERY THINLY sliced pork. Any extra? Pay an addition $3 (or $4...can't remember).

I may sound a little harsh here, but I expected a lot more with the great early reviews. I mean, there are items on the menu that are not ready yet since this place is brand new, but their main ramen was nothing spectacular. And quite empty. There are better ramen spots in Japantown.
author: Steph S.

description:
I had the Tori Paitan. It was delicious, and even though the chicken had bones, the meat slipped off easily. Everything tasted fresh and the shitaki mushroom was one of the fattest and most succulent I've ever had!!!
Definitely Vegan and Vegitarian friendly as well!
Only thing I'd warn is that there's a long wait line and if you're in a large group, it may take a while before they can seat you. On the other hand they do have private seating in the back, which made up for the wait time despite how cold it was at night.
author: Kat W.

description:
I'm not the biggest fan of Ramen because I usually find it too heavy and can never seem to finish my own bowl!

I went on a Sunday night so thankfully the wait wasn't bad at all. They even asked us if we would like to move to a private table that opened up after seating us at the communal table - I liked their attention to service.

I think Hinodeya makes some great ramen! I was starving when I came in and decided to order their namesake ramen on my own, thinking I surely wouldn't finish it. The broth is packed with flavor while staying light and clear. The pork was soft and just melted in my mouth. The noodles were cooked well, a bit more than al dente so they had good texture. I finished the whole bowl :)

If you prefer a denser broth or more of a chicken flavor, then order the Tori Paitan.

I'm glad Japantown has a solid Ramen spot now!
author: Sabina S.

description:
This is me and my boyfriend's favorite ramen spot in the city -- we've introduced it to (and converted to regulars) many a friend. We also frequently take our out of town visitors looking for a reasonably priced, delicious meal here. 

We usually order the Tori Paitan, which is, in my opinion, just the right richness (not as sickeningly rich as Mensho, but rich enough to feel slightly indulgent), just the right portion, and even more amazing with the garlic chili oil. Also, the hospitality and service is 5* in and of itself. And the wait times aren't bad at all for this quality of ramen. Plus, it's authentically Japanese (think it was opened by a 4th generation ramen family from Japan). 

I always leave feeling super satisfied!
author: Diana C.

description:
I honestly dont see what's so great about this place. Ordered their house special ramen. Well, it came with two pieces of pork, half of an egg, some seaweed, bunch of noodle, that's it. 
THe pork and the egg were definitely tasty while other stuffs were not quite. The ramen was still semi hard. If you are talking about something mind blowing, well, this blew my mind, no joke. The seaweed was wet and flavorless, as what you can expect after soaking your seaweed in water for a while. The soup was decent but kinda salty if you decide to drink it. So I won't recommend drinking the soup. 

I don't see why people would wait in lines to get in this place. I did it once and I would never do it again.
author: Mary J.

description: Didn't quite make it before opening lunch time and waited 40 minutes. The Hinodeya Ramen dashi broth is super light. With the overwhelming amount of tonkotsu ramen in SF, i had to learn to appreciate and pick up the subtleness of the seaweed and fish flavors. I preferred their Tori Paitan bowl. As everyone else has mentioned, it's not as heavy as Mensho's. The portions seemed fine to me. The price is just a bit steep but unfortunately the norm for either quality or hipster/trendy spots. It'd be nice if they had the option to order extra noodles! I'd come back though i'm a sucker for Yamadaya's tonkotsu just across the plaza.
author: Samantha L.

description: Happy that my friends were waiting in line or else I would have to join and stand for 45 minutes or so. Parking is tough around here because it is in japan town. Be warned. So I got to try the two main Ramen's that I forgot the names but you will see it on the main page. Overall the noodles were good and the broth nice and tasty. However there isn't enough meat in these. Just a wing. Bloop.
author: Amy H.

description: We went on Friday night and waited about 40 minutes to be sat. The line went pretty quickly considering how long it was. We ordered gyozas and edamame for our 3 year old, and each had the house ramen. The food was delicious and arrived quickly and piping hot. We loved that they have divided the restaurant up into little private dining rooms - very reminiscent of what it's actually like in Japan. They also had plastic bowls and flatware for our toddler - not take away stuff but real toddler dishes like we have at home. That was a great touch! This was a great meal and we would totally go back.
author: Kirstin G.

description: my sensei and I wanted to try this place out.  Nice location on a pedestrian only short block in JapanTown in SF.  found some gifts for friends while waiting.  Dinner was very well liked by both of us.  We had the house ramen, which proved excellent.  I had a yuzu flavored beverage, which was also excellent.  I want to go back about six more times at least.
author: David H.

description:
We went here on a Saturday afternoon about 1:00, and must have hit it at exactly the right time, as we only had a ten-minute wait.  The line outside was constant otherwise, so we got lucky.
The menu is very limited with a few types of ramen, some apps, and some sides.  The only thing keeping this from a 5-star was that I thought it was a little pricey.  We ordered three house ramen and one chicken,  I think the chicken was much more flavorful - and some chili oil really brought out the flavor.  All of us really liked our soup, so at least we weren't disappointed.  Comparing it to other hot pot and pho places, we agreed that this was one of the better ones.
Wait staff was friendly and efficient.
author: Lydia C.

description: I had two different ramen. I go Japan for work and this is not an authentic ramen. I think few people like it because it is vegan but it is not that good quality.
author: Kevin K.

description: Was on that ramen hiatus cause I couldn't find a good ramen place anymore. Totally worth that 20 minute wait. The place is a bit small but for the most part, people eat and leave quickly. Not much air ventilation as the place was pretty stuffy and warm. The tall gentleman server was the nicest. Accommodated to all our requests. There is no sign in sheet, just wait in line. Sometimes you might get lucky if you come in twos. Let's get to the House ramen. Soup base was clear, good, but too many sesame.... I really enjoyed the egg and the noodles are different but good. The chicken was alright.. would love to revisit when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Ann L.

description:
They have vegan ramen, which is great for me because my partner is vegetarian.  Even though I love ramen, unless there's vegan/vegetarian ramen, I can't pick a ramen joint when we are deciding where to eat.

We went to Hinodeya for lunch on a weekend when we were in the area. Service was great. Everybody was nice and friendly. Even though we sat at a communal table, it was comfortable.

I enjoyed clam ramen with an egg added. I would not say I loved it, but I'm happy to go back and try another ramen.
author: Akiko O.

description: Food was authentic. I have had better ramen though. The atmosphere had an authentic vibe as well. It wasn't anything super special though.
author: Angela C.

description: The vegan ramen is super great... The ramen itself is green. The soup is indeed creamy.
author: Willow W.

description: I love this spot! It is always busy and almost always has a line. However their ramen is the best I've had in the city. They are also very fast and efficient with flipping tables and seating people as fast as possible. Great service too.
author: Jackie S.

description:
After reading an article on Hoodline, I was excited for this place to open. The chef is a 4th generation chef/owner. His great grandfather opened Hinodeya in 1885. 

Luckily, a friend was willing to come with me. We waited an hour and a half...you could put your name down (no reservations during soft opening) and walk around the plaza or go across the street to Japantown Peace Center. The place fits maybe 30 people in the main area, and there are two curtained off rooms that fit 6-8 each in the back. That's why the wait is so long (and so many people have heard about the opening).

Their special ramen is the dashi--its broth is made from kelp and katsuobushi (the flakes you see on takoyaki and okonomiyaki). It's a lighter brother (vs miso which is milky and thicker). It had a lot of umami in it and I enjoyed it. The noodles were really good -- they were thicker and really chewy (in a good way). They held up well too, they didn't break down after being in the broth for a while. The egg was perfection. The only thing I didn't like was the meat...it tasted different from what I'm used to...I can't put my finger on it. The dashi ramen was $14, which is about average for a good bowl of ramen in SF. 

They had two additional ramens listed on the menu (one is a vegetarian one!), but they were greyed out. They're going to add them once they get operations down during soft opening; there's going to be more options on the menu (for those of you fretting about only having two ramen options on the menu)!

Oh, we both got the fried oysters to start. Yummmm. They give you tartar sauce, lemon, and a soy sauce mix, so you have options for dipping.
author: Katherine S.

description:
A solid authentic Ramen shop. 

Hinodeya doesn't have a lot of variety, but what they do have - they know how to do it right. I had the house Ramen. Although simple, every ingredient was cooked right. The broth was flavorful, the noodles chewy, and the meat tender. 

My friend had the vegan ramen which was surprisingly creamy and flavorful. I actually prefer this broth to the house Ramen. 

Definitely give this place a try!
author: Navi R.

description:
Quality over quantity here and pricey for what you get.  We came here on Super Bowl Sunday and no wait.  Yay.  We get seated and the menu very limited.  Only 2 ramen choices,  we did order the Kara-age because it came with matcha salt to see how it was.  The chicken came out hot and the matcha salt was decent.  I was not blown away by it.  It is like any Kara-age you get at any other Japanese  restaurant.  I thought the matcha salt would bring in another flavor to it, but it didn't.

I ordered the chicken ramen, even though the flavor was on point with good noodles, there was one chicken wing in it.  It was the smallest ramen I ever had for $15.00.  It was good to try, but don't think I'll be back again.
author: James L.

description: This ramen is solidly good/OK. We got the classic Hinodeya one. Very strong sesame-seed approach and semi-thick noodles. There is nothing wrong with it; there is simply better existing ramen in the city.. and even right across the street from this place!
author: Katie K.

description:
1.20.17 

I've been craving ramen more lately and started a ramen tasting spree about 3 weeks ago. This was my 3rd stop. (Of course I've had ramen plenty of times before this spree of mine) 
We arrived around 5:45pm and there was no wait for our party of two. We were seated at the bar. 
TLDR (Scroll down) :P 

RAMEN: 
Currently they only have 2 different ramen on their menu. Hinodaya (scallop, bonito based) and Tori Paniton (creamy chicken based). Both ramen are served with whole wheat noodles - which the health-conscious side of me loved! There are 2 more to be added including a vegan ramen. Of course we ordered both ramen in addition to 2 other dishes: 

+ Hinodaya ($14) I've actually never tried a ramen with a seafood based broth but it was a very clear and light broth. Not creamy at all. It was served with only one chasu, half an egg, bamboo shoots and scallions. I did enjoy the lightness but personally preferred the chicken ramen more. 
+ Tori Paniton ($14) Creamy chicken broth with a hint of sesame as with many other ramen broths. I really enjoyed the broth's consistency & taste as it wasn't too thick or oil. (Mensho in DT SF has a much thicker consistency to give a comparison). This bowl came with a chicken wing and half an egg. Which was a little awkward in my opinion. There could have at least been 2 or 3 wings. 
+  Kara-age w/ Matcha Salt ($8) the chicken was super fresh and not overly battered compare to many other Japanese places. There was more meat than batter :) As for the matcha salt. The matcha was extremely subtle and barely tastable. I would recommend sprinkling the matcha salt on the  chicken to actually taste it as opposed to dipping the chicken into the salt. It becomes too salty. 
+ Matcha Cappuccino ($8) THIS WAS BOMB. I'm the biggest fan of all the things matcha and this was so damn good. It's actually a matcha panna cotta but they call it a cappuccino because they add whipping cream on top and add Latte art. In the center is a small scoop of red bean (which wasn't overly sweet) and matcha agar agar. Everything just worked so well together. The sweetness and texture was perfect. 

SERVICE: 
It's one of those ramen shops where all the staff greets you when you walk in in Japanese. I'm pretty certain everyone there speaks fluent Japanese which adds to the authenticity of the place. (Pretty sure that's what they are going for when hiring their staff) Extremely friendly staff and food came out pretty fast.  

AMBIANCE: 
Very cute entrance! And the interior is pretty modern with a touch of traditional decor. They have family style seating where you might be seated at the same table as strangers if you are a party of 1-2. They seat parties of 1-10. 

Overall, the highlight of the ramen was the creamy egg, the whole wheat noodles and the broth. Loved the matcha cappuccino & will be back to try their other desserts. I wouldn't come here if you crave lot is protein with you ramen because this is a ramen bar that focuses primarily on flavor.
author: Samantha F.

description: So good.  Words can't do justice to how good their house made noodles are.  The vibe is fantastic as well.  Only criticism is they never answer their phone so when I want to get take out I have to go there to order and then wait 15 minutes.  But I recommend everyone to try this place.
author: Nikhil N.

description:
Arguably the best ramen in SF. My husband and I enjoyed dashi ramen bowls, edamame, green tea, matcha cappuccino, and the black sesame ice cream. The dashi ramen had a lovely rich broth that was so light. The broth was flavored with whole wheat ramen noodles cooked al dente, sesame, bonito, and delicious green onions, a tasty fresh egg, menma, and dried seaweed. The flavors combined left you with an amazing mouthfeel and ramen experience. Also, each of the vegetables were perfectly cooked so that their texture was not overly chewy and paired well with the broth. 
The edamame had the traditional simple taste, but was cooked well so no piece was cold or watery.
The green tea was the perfect temperature for the season and was brought out at a drinkable temperature along with their yummy desserts. We purchased the Kuro-Goma ice cream (black sesame) and the matcha cappuccino. The Kuro-Goma ice cream had a nice creamy texture and was paired with a crunchy granola that was fruity to taste. The matcha cappuccino was not cappuccino at all (which is good, because I'm not a coffee fan -- but I am a huge fan of green tea). This dessert had a lovely panna cotta base for the top layer and included vanilla whipped cream with matcha flakes. Further spoonfuls brought you to other layers with mochi, sweet red bean and matcha flakes. The whole meal was a five star experience from each dish being perfectly cooked and well flavored and the amazing experience brought by the staff. The staff was extremely friendly, efficient, and sweet even giving me an origami swan to take home. Their ordering system was on point too. Once you sign the list outside, they call your name and start preparing your order so you don't have to wait long once you get inside to focus on your ramen eating experience. I definitely will be back for another noodle night in the future.
author: Dawn B.

description:
Decent ramen but maybe just not my style. I ordered the Hineyda ramen, which had dashi based broth. My biggest issue was that I could definitely taste the dashi, but not the supposedly pork broth that it was. The soup was very light and clear but sort of lacking in flavor. I usually prefer light flavors and have a lighter palette so this being light on my standards was surprising. Basically expect no real meat flavor if you order this. 

The pork pieces were ok, not as soft/tender as other places but the egg was good. My favorite part about the ramen was probably the noodles. They are a bit different than the usual. 

Maybe I should come back to try the tori patan for more flavors...but not too impressed for the first visit.
author: Sophia H.

description: The service was quick and tried to seat us as soon as possible. There are only a few selections on the menu but you can't go wrong with the house ramen. They also give you little wet towels to wipe your hands with before eating.
author: Catalina H.

description: I love them. They were very nice and always smiled when interacting with us. The chicken ramen was amazing, so was their Tebasaki. I love their Tabera (chili oil with roasted garlic and onion)sauce and when I asked them how to make it, the waiter graciously told me the step by step recipie. He even sold me a small bottle of spicy sesame oil for 6 bucks. All in all I would definitely come back.
author: Joshua B.

description:
Ok I have to say this Dashi broth is like good sex! It keeps giving more than you expected! I think I am a bit lightheaded after a cold sake and standard house DashI Ramen with pork and shiitake  mushrooms! 
Fate drew us here from the Sonoma fires! Do not be fooled this is traditional Dashi!!!  fine subtle flavor that gets deeper as you keep going!
author: Shotsie G.

description: Don't let the word 'vegan' fool you into thinking that the flavor will be compromised. It's exactly the opposite! The chewy veggie noodles and savory toppings submerged in the steaming flavorful soy broth will definitely leave you in awe. I was in SF to visit so I'm heartbroken that I can't come here as often but if you're in town, I definitely recommend this place and especially the Vegan ramen. Perfect when you need refuge from the chilly SF weather!
author: June N.

description:
We got the Hinodeya Ramen and Tori Paitan

Tori Paitan had denser broth so would recommend that if you don't want clearer thin broth. Chicken was flavorful. Didn't like the hinodeya ramen broth as much, but still good. 

Portions were smaller than at some other nearby ramen spots, and overall we didn't like broth or toppings as much as say marufuku (but line was definitely way shorter..)

Other thing was their service was a little poorly timed. We sat at the bar and it seems like they kept trying to take our food away (along with the couple next to us)  My boyfriend was finishing up his bowl, and in the span of 2 minutes, 2 different waiters came by to grab his bowl, and he had to say he was still eating both times. Then when they finally took our food, one waiter brought us the check, and after he grabbed our credit cards, another waiter came by a few minutes later and gave us a dessert menu, telling us there was a mango special and we should try it! What? Is that on the house then, since we already paid?

Overall 4 stars for the food, minus 1 star for service making us feeling rushed and just confusing
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Came here on a Sunday at 6pm and it was pretty crowded, as there was a line out the door. 

I ordered the house ramen here and thought it was pretty tasty and the noodles had a good, firm texture. My complaints are that it was not very filling and only had a small slice of pork (mostly fat), and half an egg. Compared to other ramen I've had, this ranks above average. 

The service was okay and the ramen came out quick. My biggest issue is that it's kind of expensive ($14) for what you get. Overall, the ramen itself is good and but not a great value if you're just looking for a cheap noodle fix. 

Food: 4.25/5
Value: 2.75/5
Service: 3.75/5
Overall: 3.75/5
author: Brian G.

description: Very light broth and clean/fresh tasting. We had the ramen and karage. We also ordered an extra egg and more pork to split. The ramen came with a ton of toppings, but I didn't liked the inability to get corn or bamboo shoots. You literally can get one type of ramen only.
author: Lily P.

description: Love this place! Went there on Friday during lunch hour. They probably have bigger menu for dinner but I thought lunch menu is small. I ordered Hinodeya ramen. Dashi and scallop stock. Aroma of ramen made me so hungry. Soup was clear and noodle was thick and wavy which my favorite. Overall I love the taste of it. $14 for a bowel of ramen is pricey considering you can get under $9 in Japan but it's SF. Customer service was very nice. It was welcoming and friendly. Will definitely come back and try Paitan ramen.
author: Yuri S.

description:
We were fortunate enough to be a part of the reception "soft opening" at the northern Tokyo inspired Hinodeya. Masao took excellent care of us. They have multiple back private areas for large groups. Modern decor but still with the Japanese feel. 

AMAZING Kara age with matcha salt - a must have. The ramen is incredible too. Light (guilt free) broth, wheatier/chewier noodles.
author: Wendy K.

description: Two types of ramen available. The Hinodeya house ramen or chicken ramen. I had the Hinodeya house ramen which consisted of one thin slice of pork, half an egg, top ramen quality noodles in a watery almost flavorless broth $14. The chicken ramen had 1 chicken wing and a heartier broth with an odd chicken flavor $15.  One could tell just by seeing the Bowl put in front of you that it was not going to be a good adventure. We felt like we were robbed except not at gunpoint. The worst ramen I have had anywhere.
author: Steven B.

description:
The wait was very long, but very much so worth it. I do not think I have ever waited this long at a ramen joint but it did not seem to bother me even though I was starving all day. 

I really enjoyed the lighting and overall aesthetics (decoration, music, ambience). 

We tried the Karage with Matcha Salt and it was absolutely amazing. The lemon in combination with the salt was exquisite. 

I also got the House Ramen. It was very good, and the Tabera and Umami paste took it to new heights in terms of competing flavors that combine on the palate. 

My only issue with the place would be the service. It was very clear that my water was empty but I had to ask to have it be refilled. Not only that, they did not refill the water of the rest of the table! 

In summary, amazing food. The sticker that came at the end of the meal was a surprise, but a good one!
author: Jedd M.

description:
Hinodeya Ramen is the real deal.  While many other ramen establishments concentrate on the heavy tonkotsu broths, the signature dish here is a dashi based broth which has a lot of flavor but not as heavy as tonkotsu.  The Hinodeya Ramen might well be the single best one in San Francisco.

The primary gripe for this store is that it has a limited selection.  While they list a clam ramen and a vegetarian ramen on their take out menu, is was not avavilable for order.   Also, seating is cramped in this restaurant as we were forced to share a community table or sit at the counter.    For some reason, the previous business here (Shalala) made better use of the floor space and had a large dining area in the rear.  Furthermore, the sound level of this store is maddeningly deafening.  Workers are always shouting all the time and the acoutics seem to bounce the sound back down to the customers.  This is not a good quiet restaurant if you want to have decent conversation.  

Hopefully, they will make the vegetarian and clam ramen varieties availabler in the future.  For now, four stars until they get their menu up to speed and somehow fix their seating and sound problems.
author: Re-pley Z.

description: Very good dashi ramen one of the best I ever had. Waiting time was good no need to wait 1h30 to enjoy a delicious ramen
author: Laurent S.

description:
Was in the area and decided to check the place out based on reviews. The place is quite small, so they seat small parties together at the long tables. It definitely cuts the wait time, but I can imagine that it might be uncomfortable for some people. I like that they're open until 10pm on Sundays, because everything else in the area seems to close at 8pm.

I got the Hinodeya Ramen and loved it! The broth was really good and the noodles are very chewy. Their Cheese Royal is pretty good as well (small serving, but lots of flavor). For dessert, they didn't have Matcha Cappucino (I guess it's a seasonal thing), so I ended up getting Mango Pudding which is really good! 10/10 would go back :)
author: Katrina V.

description: We were trying to go to another ramen house which was closed, so we decided to try this one. I highly suggest Hindodeya Ramen Bar if your in the area! The food is delicious and the staff is very friendly! I suggest the house ramen and the mochi ice cream for dessert.
author: Sophia A.

description:
Really sad to be giving a three star reviews because I had really high hopes for this place since they said they are from Japan! The pictures all look delicious. We came on a weeknight around 6pm and there was only a short line. We waited for around ten minutes or less and sat at the communal table for a party of two. 

They are still in soft opening right now as of nov 2016 so service was a bit slow. They took our orders before those who sat before us. Communication between staff could be improved. We ordered two hinodeya dashi ramen and the fried chicken. Unfortunately the fried chicken never came. We didn't bother to follow up because we decided to order the chicken tori paitan ramen to share as well. 

To start, the dashi ramen comes with half a soft boiled egg, one seaweed, one small slice of chashu, handful of bamboo and green onion. The presentation was nice and the broth was clean. However, this is very different than other ramen as this is very clean and light. It's like the broth you use before you start cooking your jap soupy dishes. I make a lot of dishes using dashi broth so maybe I'm used to dashi but the broth was very plain to me. It's definitely a solid dashi but I can't say it was mind blowing. 

The tori paitan came with one chicken wing, egg, seaweed as well. The broth was def better than the standard dashi broth. But again, I did not have that OMG moment. If you come, I would recommend at least the paitan style as it clearly has more flavor. 

Overall, if you are in the area and there's no line, come here for a quick bowl. However, I wouldn't travel far or wait in a long line. It's a decent addition to the Bay Area with new options but I wouldn't add it as my to go ramen place. 

Have low expectations and be surprised. Don't expect strong flavors.
author: Sarah I.

description:
I'm sorry, this place is just not that good.  This is more like a 2.5, but since that's not an option when rating restaurants, I guess we'll round up.

The combination of super long wait time, pricey food, and mediocre ramen makes for a disappointing experience.  I did like the karaage chicken, which came with some type of matcha green tea dipping salt, which was unique. But when the start attraction, the ramen, is sub-par, then I won't be coming back.  

It's really too bad this place isn't better.  San Francisco needs more tasty ramen joints.  Unfortunately, this place doesn't cut it.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Love it!!! I had the special of the day which was umami clams, whole wheat noodles and a buttery dashi broth- along with an order of fried oysters. Absolutely delicious. The best tonkatsu sauce i've had so far! The staff was great and our food came out fast. The portions are small, but I finished my bowl and thought it was just enough food for me. If you are very hungry, you should order some apps. 
Also, the wait time can be long if you come late. I got there around 5:15 and had to wait about 15 minutes, others behind me had wait times of 30-45mins. 
My boyfriend compared it to ipudo's in new york and would personally rate it 3/5 stars. He had the hindoneya ramen. 
Overall, I would definitely come here again and would recommend it to others looking for a delicious meal that wont leave you stuffed.
author: Jade E.

description:
It was a cold night and was near the j town area so we decided to try this place especially since there was a line outside. We waited for 20 minutes outside before getting seated. We got seated at the community table and the place is lively and clean. We ordered the traditional and chicken ramen $14/$15. Hubs added an extra egg and we ordered the karaage for appetizer. Karrage came out first and it was delicious with and without their matcha salt. Our ramens came and both were yummy except the hubs soup was not very hot but was scarfed down. Ramen comes with one cha siu/chicken wing,
Half an egg, bamboo shoots/mushroom and green onions. 

After we were done I wanted to try their dessert and although it was good to try but I wouldn't order it again especially since the portion was small and it was 5 bucks.
author: W W.

description: We tried the tender chicken wings and they were very delicious. It was savory and slightly sweet, and the meat fell right off the bone. We ordered the pork ramen, and the broth was very tasty and hearty. The bamboo had a nice flavor, and the noodle portion was just right. The service was very good. The food was worth the price and I would highly recommend this place for a good experience.
author: Qingbo Z.

description: Vegan ramen to die for! Love this place and everyone should make a creamy ramen to perfection as they do.
author: Polly I.

description:
If you're looking for all of the flavor, but less of the fat, this place is gold! 

I'm always too scared to venture away from my usual tonkatsu out of fear of being unsatisfied, but I'm so glad I got the Hinodeya. The broth is so light and incredibly flavorful. Portions appear small, but was the perfect amount of food for me. I would suggest ordering extra meat, as the meal only comes with one slice of chashu.
author: Jasmin T.

description: $14 for signature Hinodeya ramen w/a nice clear pork broth, chashu, and 1/2 egg. Noodles are  curly and on the firmer side. Soup is flavorful and light-- a great contrast to heavy tonkotsu ramen! Line is reasonable, and great taste for value. Sake sampler for $10.
author: James S.

description:
I have eaten at Hinodeya several times and it has been consistently great. Maybe they were having an off night but last night it was not very good. The broth was too salty and not hot enough. The broth also lacked the rich complexity it had the last two times I was there
.Our ramen came so fast that I wondered if it was already prepared for another order and they just brought to our table
author: Nicole J.

description: Awesome ramen. Get there right at 5 or you won't get in. Relatively inexpensive for the area.
author: Joe B.

description: This place absolutely lived up to the reviews and the long line. I had a cold Japanese beer on tap and the Hinodeya Ramen. The broth was outstanding and the proportion of noodles just right.
author: Deb K.

description:
I get the tori paitan here every time. The broth is amazingly well balanced- light but so much flavor. It's great when you want a change from the typical miso or tonkotsu broths that seem to be more common. The noodles seem freshly handmade with a flat shape that is perfect for the lighter broth. One of the top 5 bowls of ramen I've ever had for sure.

Their menu is simple and limited to a handful of options which I love because usually means there's more focus on perfecting a handful of dishes instead of dozens.

Also somehow the draft beer here comes out ice cold and that makes me sooo happy.

I've been here for lunch and dinner, and will say there's less of a wait for dinner! If you come for lunch be prepared to wait.
author: Veronica T.

description: My favorite Bay Area ramen so far. The vegan and vegetarian ramen is amazing! It's hard to find good vegetarian ramen, but I prefer Hinodeya's veg ramen over most meat based ramen's I've tried in the Bay.
author: Ro-el C.

description:
The ramen was pretty good, however the wait was a little disorganized, there are no refills on the expensive tea, and I wasn't a fan of the chicken wing that comes with the Tori Paitan ramen.

When my friend and I showed up, there was a bit of a crowd but no sign in sheet. You kind of just have to wait there for some one to call on you. There was only 2 of us so we were able to sit at the bar. 

Note: if you get the barley or green tea, it's $4 and no refills. Mind blowing to me because not sure how tea cannot have any refills. It was not clear on the menu unless I flat out missed this. 

We got the karaage chicken as an appetizer. It was pretty good. Big pieces of chicken and it was crispy and came with some green tea powder.

We both got the tori paitan ramen. The noodles were unique and the broth was flavorful but I was a little thrown off by the soy sauce chicken wing. For a $15 ramen, I was expecting the meat to be more worthy. My favorite ramen in the city is still Mensho. Worth the wait because the broth, meat, and noodles are top notch!
author: Cicely T.

description: Very very good ramen. My carnivore friends agree that the vegan ramen is better than some their pork ramens. Glad they gave options for vegetarians and vegans. Cop the chili garlic oil on the side.
author: Aapta K.

description:
I got the Hinodeya House Ramen, but substituted the pork out for the shittake mushroom (which they did free of charge, which was very nice of them). 
The presentation was great, but it was too light for me. It didn't have a deep bold flavor, and I added a lot of garlic-chili oil to add some taste. The noodles and veggies in them were great. My friends got the vegan bowl. The couple bites I had from the vegan bowl were delicious!!! How did they make the soy milk so thick and creamy???? However, after a couple bites it starts getting really heavy because it feels like you're eating alfredo sauce. However, I'm definitely going to get the vegan bowl when I visit again. 

The customer service is great. They all great you when you walk in or whenever anyone is seated. The decor in there is elegant and top notch. 
Portion sizes are good, I got full from my bowl of House Ramen.
author: Hanna M.

description:
Dashi broth ramen with basic toppings. Authentic Japanese ramen spot in the heart of Japan town. If you do not mind waiting 45-1 hour for ramen then this is the place to be.

Had the fried oysters and also the cheese cubes which were also not too heavy. Would come back after the hype has gone away.

We went the first week they opened and it looked like there were not enough servers to tables. Also, there is a back area they were not able to open up due to the lack of staff at the time.
author: Yvonne F.

description:
Recently opened in SF, and I'm wicked happy to see another ramen outfit straight from Japan. They do a nice dashi ramen broth, which means it's nice and light. 

They're still working out the kinks in seating (took us 1h15m on Saturday arriving at 5:15pm).

Crossing my fingers that they'll bring their tsukemen over from the Saitama HQ!
author: Alex L.

description:
I had the clam ramen and added and egg to my ramen. 

The broth was very good had a lot of flavor but wasnt an overkill of seafood. 

Would recommend to anyone looking for a ramen fix.
author: Aisling O.

description:
New ramen spot in Japantown - pretty decent! We were told that they have a shop over in Japan and just recently opened one here in SF. 

What I liked most was that this bowl of ramen wasn't super heavy like other ramen places. The broth was actually really light and clear, but still super flavorful. Could've used more egg and chasu & less onions. 

Great service! I'll definitely be coming back if I'm in the area.
author: Winnie T.

description:
To start, we had the chicken karaage. Chicken karaage + ramen is always a perfect combination in my opinion. This did not disappoint. The chicken was piping hot. I wish it was crispier but it had good chunks of meat. It also came with matcha salt, which is something I have not seen before.
The Hinodeya ramen was very light, which I like! The broth is not thick like tonkotsu. The ramen texture was great and the soft boiled egg is a must. They only had two options for ramen, tori paitan and the Hinodeya ramen. I think the tori paitan is thicker so if that is what you please, that's the way to go. 
For dessert we tried the black sesame ice cream with granola. I thought the granola was kind of out of place.... I could've done without it, but the ice cream was good. 
We also tried the matcha cappucino- like a parfait, comes with matcha jelly, matcha mouse, azuki beans. The matcha jelly was my favorite part. 

Overall, it's expensive for ramen ($14), but consistent with SF ramen prices. I would come back if I'm not feeling something heavy.
author: Sara S.

description:
My roommate and were looking for the best ramen the day before a holiday when Top Ramen wasn't cutting it anymore and Hinodeya had (1) great reviews, (2) was open, and (3) was close to us. 

We got there 20 minutes past opening on a Monday and snagged the last two seats at the community table so, get here early if you don't want to wait. We waited for 25 minutes after we ordered to receive our food. The ramen was about average - nothing special. We both ordered the Hinodeya which had literally one piece of pork in it. I really liked the egg and the noodles were decent but nothing special. The chicken looked pretty good so if I came back I'd try that but I'd rather go to a different ramen spot first.
author: Salma R.

description: Went there during winter break for lunch. There is a communal table for groups or strangers . So that really helps reduce wait time. Great ramen. Although broth is not as oily as I liked it but still very crisp and flavorful.
author: Jack L.

description: Highly recommended for their Ramen!! I have tried their "traditional dashi" and "Hamaguri" Ramen. Both are very good! Different from "miso," "tonkotsu," and "shoyu" flavored Ramen most places offer.  I also have tried their "fried oysters" and "shishito" appetizers.  I would say "shishito" is one of the best I ever had. However, their "fried oysters" were over cooked.  They were almost burnt. Looking at photos of other fried dishes, they all look similar, dark brown and burnt. That was a disappointment!  I would go back and try other dishes but not fried dishes.
author: Fred K.

description: Had the vegan Ramen which was delicious! Asahi beer was great off the tap.  My wife liked the Karaage chicken and son liked the House Ramen. Fried oysters were awesome.
author: Michael P.

description:
This place is pretty good. The menu only has a few options but that's what you would expect from a ramen bar. I enjoyed my food and my experience. 

I gave it another half star because of the Naruto type music playing in the background. Really makes you feel like you're eating in the Konoha Leaf Village.
author: Thuan T.

description:
I always go to Waraku around the corner for awesome pork broth based ramen, but I wanted to try this place out and I'm glad that I did.

The decor is nicely updated and modern.

Because they do not offer pork broth on their menu, I went into this place thinking chicken broth can't be as good, but I was instantly delighted at the tastes and smells of the house ramen.  All the ingredients popped and the noodles were the right texture.  I admit I love pork better, but this is the next best alternative.

Try this place out.  You will definitely finish your entire bowl and leave wanting to come back.
author: John M.

description:
Waited 25min on Saturday @ 8pm (4 days after opening).

Hinodeya has a slight edge over Mensho Tokyo, I'd say, though people used to gravy-thick tonkotsu and paitan broths will have to adjust to this lighter, brinier taste. In any case, it arrives in SF as an immediate titan. 

We had the namesake dashi ramen. The noodles were so slippery, springy, and chewy, with a definitely hand-wrung waviness. It has the most al dente noodle of any ramen shop in SF, if you're one to care about that. 

The fried oysters we ordered were also fantastic, though the kara-age was even a step above, with slightly grilled scallions on top, and killer matcha salt. 

As some reviewers have noted: the default ramen topping only has one piece of meat, so you're well advised to order more toppings or an appetizer.

One thing we noticed is that all of their dishes rely on a very delicate, lightly grilled treatment of scallion to bring out their fragrance.

Anyway, we'll definitely be back here. Please don't tell your friends about this place : ) the wait is already long.
author: Ken H.

description: Has two kinds of vegan ramen. Both dope af The zen ramen has a clear broth and the vegan ramen has a creamy broth.
author: Taia C.

description: Great ramen. Great ambience and service. The staff makes a good effort to make you feel so welcomed. The food is really good. The waiting is shorter than surrounding ramen places with a great rating still. Go here.
author: Basim B.

description: This place is delicious! I love the broth. The menu is very limited, you only get 4 choices and they are all dashi broth. The menu is very limited. Be prepare to wait outside.
author: Tien N.

description:
House Ramen is good.  Broth and noodles I enjoyed

The rice bowl was not good tho.  Some special first class rice that was not that special.  Seem kinda dry and not very fluffy.  Maybe just a bad batch.
author: Pin C.

description:
Grand opening day: only two flavored ramen available. Ordered both

Hinodeya Ramen: first sip, soup is good! After two bites with ramen... soup became blend. There's bonito flakes on the table for you to add to the soup... still, a little light flavored to go with ramen

Creamy Chicken Ramen: good, but a bit greasy.

Other dishes are pretty good~ 

Even though the signature ramen was a bit blend, I do recommend people try out this place.
author: Erica C.

description: Great ramen! I had the chicken legs ramen and the chicken kaarage. Service is good and fast!
author: Haya D.

description: My fiance and I tried Hinodeya while visiting SF, and it was the best ramen (and probably Japanese food as a whole) we've had the pleasure of trying. The dashi ramen is incredibly flavorful and was the best we tried in the city. Normally I consider the broth as just a way to give the noodles flavor and don't enjoy it a ton, but I could've drank this broth by the bowl. We also tried the fried chicken, which was crispy outside and perfectly tender inside, and the rice bowl which was flavorful on its own but excellent with their condiments. The spicy garlic and umami sauces were great, and they brought out a matcha tea salt that was superb as well. The waitstaff was very friendly as well, yelling some sort of celebratory sounding Japanese saying every time new customers were seated. All of the food was outstanding, and the service was excellent - give this place a visit if you haven't yet.
author: Jared W.

description: Sat at the bar and rocked the clam ramen. Holy moly - somewhat religious experience. Incredible depth of flavour but SO light. Agedashi tofu was pretty good, light on the broth so if you like it heavy on the tofu you're in for a treat. Their barley tea is delicious! Texture of the ramen noodles was incredibly, perfectly, Japanese-al-dente. I understand why there's a line!
author: Lauren D.

description:
If you are looking for a recommendation,  GO HERE!!! 

I was in SFO for one night.  Where I live in GA,  there are no ramen places,  so I always make sure I get ramen when I travel. 

I got the Yamadaya Shoyu.  It had pork belly,  chashu,  nori ,  and all the usual toppings (they also offer other options).  I got no eggs,  cos I don't like eggs. The broth was creamy,  opaque,  thick,  and totally delish.  Not salty at all.  The noodles were chewy perfection.  

I also got an order of gyoza and rice for an addt'l $5.  They offer a list of options to create a "combo" for lunch.

I went on a Sunday (June 5,  2017) at 2pm.  Sat right down,  and ordered.  My food didn't take long at all. 

It is located upstairs,  so be on the lookout.  It is across from the peace center,  on top of a shabu shabu restaurant. 

I will definitely be back next time I'm out this way!!!
author: Karen P.

description:
Came in on Mother's Day around 7:45pm and got seated immediately. The place was pretty mellow and service was quick! We ordered the shishito peppers and the house ramen. We also had the barley tea to drink. Everything came out super fast!

The ramen broth was nice, flavorful, and clean. The noodles had a great chew. The egg with sesame seeds was yummy and the chashu pork was so good! I will definitely get extra meat next time since there is only one in the house bowl.

Since this is close to our house, we will definitely be back.
author: Julie T.

description:
One of my top 3 ramen places in SF. 

Love the noodles, not like the traditional ramen noodles we know but I think every perfecture in Japan has their take. Noodles have a really good texture, and really smooth. LOVE. I have to say that the noodles from here are the best I've had in SF. 

The broth is simple and light. Great for a cold winter day. The stock is made out of bonito.  

More of a lighter ramen but packs a heavy punch for my soul! 

P.S: Their spicy menma is really good too!
author: Janet K.

description: Pretty good ramen place. It's probably the best I've had but I'm not an expert and neither have I been to many ramen places. Good service and good food.
author: Karthik V.

description:
This is one of the best ramen spots in the Bay Area, hands down. I'm from SoCal, and have been searching for at least 4 years for something as good as DAIKOKUYA, Foo Foo Tei, or Kitakata Ramen Bannai and the like, and this comes close.

Hinodeya is located right across from Ramen Yamadaya (another one of my favs), and isn't overly priced. My wife ordered the Chicken Paitan, while I ordered the Hinodeya House Ramen and both bowls were done excellently. The noodles had a nice chew, the marinated & soft-boiled egg was cooked perfectly, and each bowl's broth was light, but extremely flavorful. If you're looking for something with a punch, Yamada might be better suited. However, they DO have a spicy chili oil + other mixed goodies at your table that you can spoon into your bowl. I found that the addition of the oil really elevated the dish, but I don't think it's absolutely necessary.

Although it isn't as fatty or as rich as I'm used to (compared to Daikokuya's Tonkotsu), the broth is just so damn good. I am probably in the minority who extremely dislike Mensho because of their dashi, so I'm glad that I found and have fallen in love with Hinodeya!

I also highly recommend getting the Aburi Chashu as a side-order or appetizer. It's done a bit differently than the chashu included in the bowl of the Hinodeya Ramen since it's drizzled with a bit of sauce and served over a bed of sliced green garlic (or maybe it's green onions...).

Definitely coming back!
author: Patrick K.

description: The vegan ramen is yummy -- creamy and flavorful. The Zen ramen is lighter given the clear broth.
author: Jenn F.

description: Really good ramen place. There isn't a number or a sign in sheet to write your name. You have to wait in line. The ramen price starts around $15. The waiter are nice.
author: Julie M.

description:
IF you are ramen lover and are boring with Tonkotsu broth, this is the place you have to visit.

I tried Hinodeya Ramen a few months ago. As we expect in the Japanese restaurant, the service was great. The Hinodeya Ramen comes with Kombu Dashi broth, half boiled egg, bamboo shoot, nori, and pork Chashu. Most of all, the broth is rich to feel its Kombu-based seafood broth. I was really surprised that this broth is so clear. The noodle is thicker than other ramen noodles, and it absorbs the rich flavor of the broth. The seasoned egg is perfectly cooked, and the chopped spring onions give the refreshed flavor.

My concern is that there is not enough parking space near the street and because this restaurant is in Japantown, it is hard to find the parking spot.
author: Jae Geun J.

description:
I love that more quality ramen places are starting to pop up in SF. Came here on the weekend, and was pleasantly surprised there wasn't a long line yet. Hinodeya recently took over the old Shalala space (farewell, my old standby). 

The space is completely remodeled, with a couple large communal tables and plenty of seating. The service is super friendly and fast. We were seated at one of the communal tables, which has bins under the benches for all your stuff. I thought it was weird that they placed us in side by side seats, facing strangers, but oh well.

My bf and I both ordered the Tori Paitan (with extra chashu) and split the chicken karaage. The chicken karaage came out first, and was nicely breaded and fried - with a side dish of matcha salt. I liked it, but prefer dark meat.

The tori paitan was flavorful and delicious - just a notch below Mensho's. If you prefer a less rich broth than tonkotsu or Mensho's ramen, you might like it. The noodles were perfectly cooked with a nice chewiness. The egg was delicate and so soft. The chashu was also really tender and good - so glad I got extra!

Overall, I was super impressed with the food and service. I still prefer Mensho over Hinodeya, but would definitely come back here.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Awesome Ramen!!!

I'm always in the neighborhood / craving ramen so I was super excited when my girl showed me Hinodeya's Yelp! Their service was awesome, we were seated right away and the food / drinks came super quickly.

The Hinodeya Ramen is a must try. The broth is flavorful but still light, it does not weigh you down like a janky pork broth. The noodles are super legit, like a fancy version of the packet noodles. I got two eggs (because eggs) and additional meat.

Shishito peppers were dank but not cooked enough to fill my craving like real fried shishitos.

Overall, super great ramen spot with excellent service, great decorations and pretty good prices. Will def return 10x.
author: Cole S.

description: Light dashi broth (Hinodeya Ramen) and the chicken paitan ramen were delicious. The chicken karaage with the matcha salt was the best part. I like the cleaner texture of the dashi broth and the chicken paitan is less thick compared to Mensho Tokyo Ramen. Definitely get the green tea cappucino as a dessert! It's a great way to end the meal.
author: Ellin C.

description: The house ramen was good with high quality ingredients, and refreshing, clear broth. Would I wait in line for an hour for again? Absolutely not.
author: Sheviche R.

description:
Hinodeya Ramen Bar is my absolute favorite ramen place in the city! I was getting tired of many ramen places in the city with similar flavours: shoyu, miso, shio and tonkotsu. They make dashi based ramen, which is pretty rare in the city to find. Their broth is super flavourful yet clean and fresh. 

I had original Hinodeya ramen, enjoyed so much and came few weeks later tried the clam ramen, which was also really, really good. My husband had Tori Paitan and he said it was very bold and flavourful but wasn't greasy nor heavy. Their noodles were very unique too, thicker/flat noodle, chewy and perfectly made. Ahh... my mouth is watering from thinking about it. 

I can't wait until I try their vegan ramen!

::Edit 12/16/17:: I had their vegan ramen and it was very disappointing. I had so many good reviews about their vegan ramen, was super excited to eat one after many attempts, but didn't work for me. The soup was too thick and too nutty to the point it felt greasy. I was so sad. I haven't been back to Hinodeya for months bc I was traumatized by the vegan ramen. I'll return soon...
author: Nana K.

description:
Great clear pork/chicken broth. It was very tasty and a nice alternative to the usual cloudy broth in most ramen.

Too many green onion, only half a soft boiled egg and a piece of pork that was less than stellar. The noodles were good but nothing better. I'd come back for the broth again but Hinodeya isn't going to be a regular spot or a suggested restaurant in Japan Town.
author: Joshua F.

description: Ordered the veggie Ramen, did not have many vegetables or toppings. The broth was good bur not worth it for the price you pay. Had a long wait too on a weekend evening. Dont think will be going back.
author: Spurthi D.

description:
I was so stoked for this to open, now that I've been I'm not going back. The food was over priced S&S saimin. 
Underwhelming, describes perfectly the dashi broth....which had an intense oily after taste. Maybe someone dropped a bottle of sesame oil into the pot?

The staff is great, space is fucking amazing! Private enclosed tables at the back, and super hipster communal tables in the front. They have a beautiful counter space... too bad no one gets seated there..that's like quintessential ramen shop seating

8$ for imaimo okazu is way steep, $2 would be more appropriate.
$14 for ramen kills me inside, it was worth maybe 7 or 8?
author: Garrett N.

description: Service was great! Ordered the Hinodeya Ramen and chicken kara-ge. The broth from the ramen was excellent. Will definitely be coming back to try the other ramen on the menu.
author: Janina V.

description:
food： 5/5
- got chicken ramen and bonito ramen they are both good
- lunch menu have only 2 options of ramen. Dinner menu will have 4
- got matcha cappuccino for dessert. Such a great surprise! Very impressed! Must try!

Place: 5/5
- nice decor and very clean
- service was good 

Overall: 5/5 
Will definitely come back again!
author: Sunny L.

description: Hinodeya is my go to ramen place in the city if I don't want to wait in a line for really tasty ramen. I've never had to wait in line during the weekdays around 6pm, but I think the weekend lines can get pretty long. I always get the Hinodeya ramen and the chicken karaage. The food and service have always been excellent the few times I have been here. I will definitely be back!
author: Carolyn Z.

description: The vegan ramen (with whole wheat noodles) were not so good. Too sweet. Maybe their vegetarian ramen will hit the spot next try. Crispy yams were fun as a unique side. Still trying to find vegetarian ramen in SF as good as Sacramento's Shoki Ramen House restaurant.
author: Ashley S.

description: Yum! This place is really good!  I got the house ramen and was super impressed.  The fried tofu was also delicious.  My bf had the vegan ramen and was equally impressed.  We will definitely be back!
author: Julia W.

description: very crowded on a Saturday for lunch but our service was pretty quick and did not feel rushed! I got the chicken ramen special and chicken was so tender and just fell of the bone. the ramen noodles were delicious and a great consistency and looked like they were handmade, I was a little disappointed in the broth as I felt it could have been more flavorful. We only noticed the chili oils at the end of our meal which were a great addition but unfortunately too late.
author: Rachel N.

description: Solid ramen in Japantown.  We started with the shishito peppers which were good, but a huge portion for 2.  As for the ramen, we tried the house ramen and then chicken ramen (but sub the chicken topping for the vegan topping). Both were very good.  It's popular, but we got there shortly after it opened and only waited a few minutes for a table.
author: Janelle F.

description:
Get the Hinodeya Ramen...
Undercooked pork, minimum toppings, lack flavor soup, egg not fluid enough, over priced
The stewed chicken wings... well, find a cookbook and do it at home, you will get the same thing.
author: Yilun L.

description:
Pretty darn good Ramen in Japantown. We had a group of 9 people are were nicely accommodated (literally only waited 5 minutes). I had the Hiniodeya Ramen, which had a great broth and a decent serving of noodle. 

I love gains and protein, so I wish they gave more chashu for the $14 charge.

All in all it was a great experience. Fast service, good food, clean place, average-pricy cost.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Hinodeya has quickly become my favorite ramen spot for oh so many reasons. It hasn't received quite the hype that Mensho has, and I'm hoping it stays that way so that the wait never ends up being too long!

With that being said, I've never had to wait more than 20 mins for a table in the 3 times I've been here. I've come on a Friday around 6pm twice and on a Saturday night with a large group around 8pm and still have never waited more than 20 mins. They have plentiful seating here (more seating in the back that you don't realize when you walk in). The staff greets you when you enter and leave, which I thought was a very friendly and personable touch.

They currently have 4 ramen options, which previously used to only be 2 when I first came here. They have a limited number of appetizers as well. What I've tried so far:

- Chicken karaage: cooked to perfection and paired well with a matcha salt
- Hinodeya ramen: to die for! This is my first time trying a dashi (fish) based broth. I've been accustomed to mostly pork and miso broths so I initially had my reservations on how a fish based broth would taste. But my oh my, I was so pleasantly surprised to discover how light but extremely flavorful the broth was! It is just completely packed with flavor, without being too salty or fishy. It doesn't give off a fishy taste at all, in fact. On top of that, the noodles and egg are cooked PERFECTLY. Always comes with a perfectly runny and flavorful soft boiled egg. *drool*
- Tori Paitan ramen: very delicious as well! Definitely much lighter than the tori paitan at mensho so you dont feel as terrible after eating it. Oddly enough, it has a similar flavor to the Hinodeya ramen. My only gripe is that it literally only comes with one braised chicken wing. I also don't care for the mushrooms too much. 
- Matcha tea: tasty and made from high quality matcha powder. However, it is $4, which is pretty steep considering many places offer tea for free. And no free refills.

What I love about Hinodeya is how light but flavorful the broths are. At a good ramen place, I normally end up drinking almost all the broth and then feel terrible/bloated/sleepy afterwards. Total Snorlax status. But at Hinodeya, the portions are perfect for me (not too large or small, just right) and I'm able to devour the entire bowl and still be able to function afterwards! 

They recently just released a garlic clam ramen as well as a vegan ramen with spinach noodles. I will be back, without a doubt, to try them both. ;)
author: Cheryl N.

description:
Great ramen. Would come back but only once we've exhausted some other options. Overpriced for what it is. Ramen ranges from $14-$18, whereas average for the bay area is $9-$12. 

The fried oysters were good but not great. We asked for tea but rescinded that order after they wanted to charge $4 per cup of green tea.

Overall we enjoyed the food. The ramen was the best so far in the Bay area. Orenchi tastes like day old mold compared to this place. 

There is no waiting list, first come first served. We seated very quickly. Service was also pleasant and fast. Orenchi made us wait 30 minutes after we ordered to get our food. We waited about 5-10 to get our appetizer, drinks and ramen. 

The bathroom was clean. They had a checklist for their daily inspections on the wall. Downside is there is only one bathroom.
author: Jewels V.

description: Best Ramen in Japantown!!! Vegan ramen was amazing didn't even know that's a possibility.
author: Mark C.

description: I came to this restaurant after being put on a waiting list of 73 people ahead of me at Marufuku Ramen. I only had to wait 10 minutes. They just ask how many(They don't take a name) and as soon as a table leaves they bring you back. We got some peppers as an appetizer and the house ramen. We enjoyed both!
author: Shontel O.

description: Good vibe, but the ramen itself was just meh. Given its very positive review on yelp, we thought the wait would be long. Luckily it wasn't the case. We waited for around 5 minutes before seated. Staff was nice and I love their interior design very much. I wish the ramen itself could be better tho.
author: Mario B.

description:
Came here on a whim because we were in the area on our way to Pearl Spa for an appointment. Got there pretty early, right after they seated their first round of people when they opened at 5:30.
