It's ramen, so the line tends to be pretty quick, especially because they don't have a very extensive menu. There is a 50% change you'll be seated at the bar or communal seating, just because of the kinds of seating they have available. The noodles here are definitely the highlight of the meal, and the broth is really light, which is nice. I did not feel like anything was too salty unlike other reviewers and already had the expectation for 1 piece of chashu, so wasn't too disappointed by anything. The bowls are not large, but there are enough toppings in it in ratio to the noodles/broth. 

Unfortunately, my friend found a piece of METAL at the bottom of her bowl of ramen. We pointed it out to the server who was very apologetic and it seems like it was causing a bit of a commotion, as they wanted to figure out how it got in. The manager eventually came to inspect as well, and they said they thought it was from their noodle machine. We get it, stuff happens. It's unfortunate, but at the same time, leaves a bad taste in your mouth. So we expected to be comped for a portion of our meal...ie an appetizer, or the bowl of ramen, something. We were in a bit of a rush to get to our appointments, so when the server asked us if we wanted a free dessert, we kindly declined, and when we got the bill, figured that he would probably just deduct an app. But no, we were not given a discount on anything, paid the full amount of everything because we didn't want dessert? Not sure how this etiquette really is, they were very apologetic, but didn't really seem to be willing to be flexible in how they could try to retain us as customers in good faith.
author: Annie S.

description: Truly enjoyed this place. It was open on New Year's Day when Marufuku was closed, and I'm glad that we ended up getting to try it! I liked the light taste of both the chicken Paitan and the House. I would definitely recommend it!
author: Sarah Y.

description:
The wait: I always see a line so I have delayed going to this place. But I arrived at 9 on a Wednesday night and there was no wait but it was still decently full in the restaurant.
The food: I love the umami paste and hot garlic that they have on the side. I pretty much dipped all my appetizers in that. 
Apps: Had the bamboo shoots (they were pretty good, but thought the chili could use more flavor), and the scallop rice (which was lightly flavored but just enough to make it delicious)
Ramen: I had Tori paitan which was good and less creamy than Mensho (which I personally prefer though I know many people who think Mensho's is the best). It's a dashi based soup so it was interested and different. I liked the broth more than mensho, and about the same as marufuku. While the broth was perfect for me, the noodles however, I had mixed feelings on. They were perfectly chewy but after halfway through eating, I noticed that they were actually pretty salty and I couldn't finish it. The chicken reminded me of Chinese soya chicken wings but more tender and fell off the bone. I tried the chashu from my bf's hinodeya ramen and I wasn't impressed - it was dry and not that flavorful. Mensho's chashu is a lot better. His broth was really good though.
author: Monica E.

description: Ordered the Vegan ramen. Not vegan. BEST RAMEN I'VE EVER HAD. So creamy so rich and the noodles were so chewy. I loved the sesame and the kale was perfect. Highly recommend!
author: Safa B.

description: Love this place and can't wait to go back! The broth is very light but super flavorful. No wait on a Sunday around lunch time, which is a big plus, and the inside is well-decorated.
author: WeiWei H.

description: Located in Japantown, this restaurant feels very authentic and the staff are all very friendly and attentive. Their house special is dashi broth, which is a lighter broth but still very intense in umami flavor. My favorite part was probably their noodles - they have the perfect amount of chewiness, and feel very homey. The main downside is the price - $14 seems a bit pricy for just one slice of meat and half an egg. And while I love green onions in my broth, the amount they give you is a little overwhelming. I also tried the clam ramen, which was delicious as well (a lighter broth, but infused with seafood flavor), but I wish included more toppings given the $18 price tag.
author: Audrey G.

description: 3.5 stars if I could. I don't understand the hype or the long line. Decent ramen in the Bay Area must be horrendous if this is the best it has to offer. I got the house Ramen. The only good thing about this ramen place were the al-dente noodles and it's amazing service. Broth was decent and that's about it. They charge you for hot tea which I found to be weird from a Japanese/Asian restaurant.
author: Eden W.

description: One of my fav ramen restaurants in SF ! The house ramen is super good!! If you add extra pork you are gonna be sooo happy ! Great service ! Love it !
author: Paola G.

description: So far one of the tastiest vegan ramen I have had. Plus they're super nice. Love it here! So savory and filling. Love the spinach noodle and all the toppings. Lines can vary from short to kind of long, but not too long of a wait as compared to overhyped places in San Jose or downtown San Mateo. When it is busy you may or may jot have to share some space at the longer tables. Wveryone is usually so focused on eating, no one seems to mind. One of my favorite spots at the moment
author: Jen H.

description:
3.5 stars--this was my first time trying a dashi ramen, and while the lighter broth was refreshing, it still left a lot to be desired. The flavoring was just a bit weak, mostly just tasted salt. The noodles and fixins were great though! We also had the bamboo shoots and matcha salt kaarage, which were very tasty. 

Customer service was excellent and attentive, especially for such a popular and crowded restaurant.
author: Benjamin A.

description: Excellent dashi! The house and zen ramen were great. Watch out if getting the spicy edemame though, not because it is too spicy but because it could blow you palate for more subtle flavours.
author: Joe P.

description: Only went here because everyone raved they have the best Ramen in San Francisco. I can gladly tell you 7/11 has better Ramen for 50 cents they call "Top Ramen!" Don't waste you're time, slow staff and when we asked for a refill we got, "Sorry no refills!" Ok that's fine charge me for another don't just say that drop off our check then bounce to never be seen again like some Samurai Ninja! Will never return to this Ramen restaurant again.... Just stick to pier 39 for food.
author: Andrew N.

description:
Came here on a Sunday for lunch and there was a bit of a wait. I came with a party of 3 and had to wait 20 minutes to get inside. Service was quick as they came to ask us what we wanted as soon as we sat down. 

-Hinodeya Ramen: Wanted to try this since it was their house specialty. The dashi broth was super light but flavorful at the same time. I liked the simplicity of the ramen plus the texture of the whole wheat noodles which were spot on. For the price, I hoped to get more for my money's worth, but overall I was pretty satisfied.

I'll definitely want to come back next time to try their tsukemen (dipping ramen)! I hope they can expand their lunch menu so I don't have to only come here for dinner to try it.
author: Elisa S.

description: There used to be a long line but we went close to closing so there was no line. We were greeted and seated immediately. It did take them a while to come take our order, we actually had to raise our hand since everyone just seemed to look at the door and not at the customers. The server took the order and our food came out shortly after. The soup was flavorful and rich. The noodles were a little over cooked to my taste. Overall the food was great but the service can use some work... especially when you are not busy.
author: Jan H.

description: Found this place via Yelp and had a great experience! Food was amazing, very authentic and fresh ingredients. Service was amazing as well even after how busy they were at the time I went. Attentive friendly service, guy we had as our waiter explained how the ramen we ordered was made, we ordered the house ramen *highly recommend*, and he made sure to check up on us frequently without being pushy. Prices were reasonable for the amount of food we got. Place was very clean, modern, new. Everyone else there was nice as well and I would definitely re-visit and recommend to anyone visiting the area.
author: Gretta A.

description: Such great service! The food is so good and the prices aren't bad. $14 dollars for the House Ramen (comes with green onions, eggs, bamboo, sea weed and meat). The karaage is also super yummy - $8 for 5 pieces. Can't wait to come back
author: Graci B.

description:
*Pescetarian friendly* if you make some modifications to the Hinodeya ramen (fish-based broth): make sure to ask to leave out the pork and the *pork oil*! The broth will be lighter without the pork oil but still so flavorful.

Vegetarian friendly if you arrive early in the evening when they have their *vegan ramen* still available. I recommend arriving before 7 pm on weekdays. Once they run out of the broth, it sells out for the night. The broth is garlic-soy based, thicker and not watery. One caveat is that the broth tends to be on the saltier side. 

Noodles are always al-dente and the eggs are perfectly soft-boiled with creamy yolks. 

I've shared this restaurant with friends, and several of them went back a few more times within a couple weeks on their own! 

Side note: I prefer to arrive earlier and wait a little bit for a non-communal table, as the communal tables are quite a drag and awkward as you are sitting closely face to face with strangers (either of you are trying to make conversation).
author: K. N.

description:
*** UPDATE: Thank you Brent for addressing the issue! I am a happy customer :) ***

I couldn't say anymore about the ramen than what other yelp reviewers have posted. The ramen and the broth were SOOOO good! I just wish it came as a bigger portion size.

The reason why I docked off the stars is because of the community table. The ends of the table have wooden planks underneath and upon standing up from our table, both me and my significant other injured ourselves from the sharp corners. It was so painful - I couldn't even stand up for a couple of minutes. We both had HUGE bruises on our thighs/knees afterwards.

Hinodeya, PLEASE fix your community table. I enjoy your food, but this is really unacceptable. I'll revise my rating if it ever gets fixed.
author: Vivian H.

description: My boyfriend and I decided to be adventurous and try a new ramen location, and it wasn't great. Don't get me wrong, service was very good, the servers paid attention to you, but the food was not that great. This location was great, hard to find parking as it's located in JapanTown. Everything else is closed at night, so there is not much to do around there. I've always been a huge fan for a place named Kaju eat's in SF that was fabulous. When we got here, we sat down and ordered one of each ramen which were $15 and $14 each. We also ordered a chicken karaage for 5 pieces for $8. The chicken came first, definitely hot and fresh. Sadly there was no pairing of spicy mayo or anything similar. Instead they gave you matcha salt which was disgusting when added on the chicken. Next came the two ramens, disappointed by the proportions, I thought maybe the taste would be amazing. We tried the clear soup ramen first, the soup was too clear, not much taste and pretty bland. There was only one piece of chashu which was very sad. Never have I seen such a thing, one piece. There was half an egg that was slowly soft cooked, and it was average. We then tried the soup for the other ramen, it was a lot more flavorful, but very small portions again. The chicken was great however. The chashu and chicken has amazing tastes, but too bad they give you such a small size. Overall the taste of the meat was great, soup was mediocre, noodles were pretty interesting, service was good. I would say this place is a 3/5 average.
author: Amy Y.

description: Vegan ramen was some of the best ramen I've ever had! I've done my fair share of ramen chasing and this was off the charts.
author: Alessandro S.

description: Disappointed! Raman was too hard. Wait too long! We just ordered Raman,but took 40mins, I don't understand why take that long,a lot of people waiting outside.it just used 15mins then finished the $14 small bowl...
author: Yan Z.

description: Amazing! Tried the house ramen and it was so flavorful. We were in line for about 10-15 minutes (you don't need to put your name in, you just make a line) and seated at the bar. We got our food really fast and the waiters were really nice. 10/10. Will be back!
author: Darlene E.

description: Excellent service and very good ramen. The rustic ambience is what one would expect when coming to an authentic Japanese noodle house.
author: Dan S.

description: Delicious ramen!! Initially suspicious when the ramen was clear but it was very flavorful. Had both the hinodeya ramen and chicken. Also make sure to try the homemade tabera (garlic and chili sauce).
author: Lauren Y.

description: Expect a wait if your party is more than 4 with no reservation, but the food was great. I got the chicken ramen. Definitely top tier.
author: Ryan D.

description: Friendly and great service. Went with a group of 9 and they were able to seat us together in the back. Gyoza and fried oysters were really good apps. Ramen was wonderful! I love the wavy type of ramen the best and their broth was delicious. Tip: order the extra side of soft boiled egg.
author: Rita W.

description: You know...it can be really hard for me to have a stand out ramen place because let's face it we've all had that instant packaged stuff growing up so ramen was not really anything special to me. This place proved me wrong. Ok first things first...small portions...ok no biggie. But the quality of the broth and all of the product inside of the bowl make it special. We also ordered tea and it was brewed right then and there. A little pricey but worth it if you want the real Japanese dining experience and food.
author: Guisela L.

description:
Soo good! Probably one of my favorite ramen places. Came here on Saturday around 11:30 and got seated pretty quickly. I got the hinodeya ramen and my boyfriend got the paitan ramen. The hinodeya ramen was so good!! Who knew a clear broth could be so flavorful. The texture of the noodles were perfect with the perfect bounce. My boyfriend said the Paitan was good and not too heavy. The consistency of the broth is thinner compared to mensho. The noodles were nice and chewy and danced in his mouth as he chewed on them. His words not mine. The price per bowl was kind of pricey and came to 20 around dollars per person with drinks but still worth. 

I'd definitely return but would probably come back when they open for the day. When we finished eating there was a pretty long line forming.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Definitely deserves a five star from this Japanese man.  I wish you had another location in the east bay, Hinodeya.  You are now one of the BEST, if not the VERY BEST in the bay area. 

There was a short line in front of the restaurant when I got there so I just waited for it to open at 11:30.

I can already see so-called foodies complaining "HOW CAN YOU NOT HAVE TONKATSU RAMEN?"  1) It's not TONKATSU, it's TONKOTSU 2) in Japan, tonkotsu is just one variety and it blew up in USA because of rich, occasionally greasy flavors but tonkotsu is just one of the popular styles.  There's soy-sauce base, miso-base, shio (salt) base, combined with dashi made of kelp, seafood, chicken, pork, beef, really all kids of combination.  

So no, they don't have tonkotsu here. 

And it's amazing. 

In order to understand the depth of ramen culture, you have to accept.  It's OK not to have tonkotsu.  I want to praise their courage not to have tonkotsu since it's become so popular in USA.  And Hinodeya, you do the non-fatty greasy broth the best in the bay.  

Don't get me wrong, I love tonkotsu too.  However Hinodeya just became my number one in the bay, I think so.
author: Taka T.

description:
Brent is the best wait staff ever. He took care of finding us a spot that is big enough and quiet enough for our newborn. He really went all out in helping us get situated. We are so happy.

Oh the food is great too.
author: Koalie W.

description:
This is the first time I got a ramen that isn't super oily or salty. Super amaze. My friend and I order the Hindeyo. I hope I got the name correctly. It's the one with translucent fish broth. The noodles aren't the amazing that's what my friend claims. I'm not a ramen expert so I wouldn't know. 

Order the fried oysters , that hit the spot. They had two sauce , the tarter sauce and the Japanese sauce that's brown. Must try the dessert if you have a sweet tooth. The matcha cappuccino is amazing. It's more like a Matcha moose with red bean filling and more green tea jelly surprise in the bottom. It's not bitter or too sweet which is perfect. 

I only gave 4 stars because they only have two kinds of ramen so I won't come back too soon but I will bring my ramen lovers here.
author: Miri L.

description: Way easy to get a seat at bar for a solo diner. Delicious broth and filling. Excellent high end nice decor. Fast service.
author: Susan T.

description: I don't really eat ramen anymore, so it was just by chance that I decided to come here -- I noticed the menu outside, with a fair number of different side dishes and non-ramen items. I tried the shishito peppers, aburi chashu, and fried crispy yams. All were great. My favorite was the shishito peppers, excellent flavor and texture. Each small dish was cohesive and had a slightly different set of flavors, depending on the sauces they were prepared in.
author: D P.

description: Ordered karage chicken, shiso peppers, and chicken ramen, dashi ramen. The chicken was very crispy and was delicious with sauces provided on the table. They gave a lot of shiso peppers. The ramen was light in broth and surprising very delicious! Overall food was good, but not the best I've ever had.
author: Joling S.

description:
I like the atmosphere of the place, you are announced in Japanese as soon as you enter the place, and the service is excellent! 

On the food side, I would say pretty much a 3-star experience. We both had the chicken ramen and for $15 I would've expected more. We also had the spice bamboo shoots which were not spicey at all.  I feel like if they are going to charge that much they should be loaded bowls. My advice is to take a cue from the Ramen Underground on 356 Kearney, a couple dollars less for much more.  Easy fix!
author: G W.

description: Hinodeya has a different kind of ramen than us bay area people are used to. Its broth is not creamy and thick with katsu fat, but more on a cleaner, fresher side with still some broth flavor. The best part about it was the noodles. The noodles were really quite unique and not something I've had before. I also got the braised chicken wings which also had the same broth. It was very good and a nice change from the fried chicken that we're all used to. The only thing I didn't like was how little chashu pork they give you. Like it's only 2 slices :( But the egg was on point.
author: Stephanie K.

description: My favorite ramen spot in SF, and believe me, I've tried A LOT. Super authentic ramen. Get the paitan if you're in the mood for heartier ramen. Chicken karage app is delicious. The sake flight is fun and priced reasonably at $10. No reservations and can get a bit crowded, but so worth the wait.
author: Kim O.

description:
Went there at 2 pm on weekend. Get seated immediately. They were out of Hamaguri Ramen, so we ordered the Tori Paitan and Hinodega Ramen. The dashi broth they served tastes like miso soup with mild smoky flavor from dried bonito. Not as rich as tonkotsu broth. All ramen has soft boiled egg, mushroom, seaweed, bamboo shoots, spring onions for the toppings. Tori Paitan ramen comes with one braised chicken wing, while the Hinodega ramen comes one thin cut of chashu pork. The texture of ramen is chewy and not overcooked, but with a little  unpleasant lye aftertaste. 

Overall, the food is just ok, not impressive. If you prefer mild flavor and not so greasy broth for your ramen, the dashi broth may be a good alternative. The portion is small for the price. However, service is good and seating is comfortable.
author: Yumi G.

description:
Hey warning to vegetarians, the place is currently doing a soft opening meaning they are not offering the vegan ramen.  I was disappointed when I stopped by today that after waiting 30 minutes for a table we were informed they did not offer the vegan ramen yet.   

I look forward to coming back when they offer their full menu.
author: Mace C.

description: Best ramen in Japantown. I like the chicken paitan to the hinodeya. Broth is on the light side, which is a good contrast to the typical tonkotsu broth.
author: Kent Q.

description: The Ramen here is stellar. Ordered "Hinodeya Ramen" The light transparent broth may seem light, but when it hits your tastes buds it has a depth of flavor not far from bone broths that cook for long hours from other ramen shops. The noodles are cooked to a perfect al dente that has a great chewiness and consistency absorbing great amount of broth as you take every slurp. Portion may be on the smaller side, but makes up for it in the taste. Service was fast and courteous making this an amazing experience.
author: Wesley H.

description:
Went here for Saturday brunch. Don't know what the hype is about or why there's even a line. Very average and under-seasoned ramen. One slice of pork in the house ramen. One chicken wing in the chicken ramen. Stingy with other toppings. Had a hot green tea on the side - they charge for refills! 

It's clean, though.
author: Kelly E.

description: Hinodeya does not disappoint.  My family's favorite ramen place in Japantown. Spectacular chicken karaage with matcha salt. If you favor vegetarian, give the vegetarian ramen a try, very flavorful.
author: L. R.

description:
This place makes broth with very rich flavor, but very light on the stomach.

Hands down the best in SF so far.
author: Austin N.

description: It has been a journey to find decent ramen around here, but I just say I am a fan of this place after tonight. We waited around 35-40 minutes before being seated for two. We chose bar seating. The only reason they didn't get 5 stars is because no one gave us the menu for the longest time when we sat down, so we helped ourselves and grabbed the menu since we sat next to them. We ordered the shishito peppers and aburi chashu to start. Our idea was to use the chashu for extra meat in our ramen which worked out great since it had 7 pieces :) flavor was delicious! Also a fan of the shishito pepper, the sauce/seasoning for it was delicious and cooked perfectly. I super liked their chili oil with crispy garlic and onion condiment, so I put a few spoons of it into my ramen and it definitely made it better. I am usually a richer and thicker broth person but was a fan of the lighter broth for the chicken ramen. I liked it more than the house ramen. Love the chewy textured noodles too! Would definitely return but always a wait for places nowadays. The matcha cappuccino was also ok, it didn't have any coffee flavor so that was good with me. There's red bean and matcha jello inside, yum! Recommend :)
author: Amanda C.

description:
Specialty here is chicken ramen. A buttery chicken brother with dashi flavors. The soup has these little beads of fat on top, really good. The noodles are fresh and chewy and the chicken cooked in dashi brother is really good. 

Get the chicken wing cooked in dashi appetizer, the chicken falls off the bone. 

I personally did not really like the other stuff in the ramen, the toppings and the giant shiitake weighed the flavors down a bit.

Only nigorizake choice here is sayuri, they have a good sake selection.
author: Megan L.

description: ok, now THIS is the best ramen in the city. big fan of their dashi broth which is flavorful but not overly salty. my go-to here is the house ramen w/ a side of karaage, which is the perfect combo imo. if I'm in the mood for something richer, I go for the paitan ramen which is also hella good. best part? they've got killer vegetarian ramen too. my gf gets the zen ramen which has a light broth w/ shitake, seaweed, kale, and goji berries. service is excellent, great staff, and zii always greets us like we're old friends. pro tip: line gets long here so go 15min before open, or grab a late night bowl of ramen around 9pm when the rush dies down.
author: Marky E.

description:
Ok, so the big 2 ramen shops in SF are Mensho and Nojo. 

Both are really good, both are really expensive (in ramen terms), and both have heavier ramens. I've lately been leaning towards Nojo purely because you can wait indoors, you're in a nice neighborhood, and you can put your name down and leave to pass the time. Mensho's quality (which I think is slightly better), isn't worth the 1+ hour wait. I've averaged about a 20-30 minute wait at any given time at Nojo.

In comes Hinodeya! In a Japantown with good (Yamadaya) but not great (Mensho/Nojo) ramen, it's about time that there's something more unique that comes along. Taking over the space that Kotetsu sadly occupied, my wife and I were curious about this new "dashi ramen" place that had a long line out the door.

Similar to Mensho, you have to wait in line and cannot leave the line once you're in it. Contrary to Mensho though, we only waited about 30 minutes on a Sunday night. The common theme between the big 3 is the Tori Paitan ramen. Where Mensho and Nojo are thick, Hinodeya is thinner, more watery, but with the same taste sans the feeling of bloatness afterwards. The other things you don't get, compared to Mensho and Nojo are more meat (there is 1 solitary chicken wing), and more appetizer options (where Nojo shines). However, with that said, we also left Hinodeya spending about the same money as we would at most other ramen shops in the city. 

In the end, if you ask me, Nojo still wins where they can justify the price because of the convenience, ambience, other food options, and boiling it down simply; the taste.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Very chic and clean, waiters are very friendly and efficient.  Two type of ramen, we tried both. If you don't like fishy broth taste, don't even try.
Tori Taipan: thick soup yet the bonito broth killed good chicken broth flavor.  Very little broth in a bowl. Noodle is semi hard and very good but again thick fishy broth killed them all.
Regular ramen is thin broth yet you taste more bonito flavor. 
Both of them are very small amount.
We ordered tea without knowing it's $4- a cup!
I think all of them are well over priced.  After we ate we were very thirsty.  Not sure too much salt in the broth??
author: Anna S.

description:
Hinodeya has been on my list of restaurants to check out for the past few months . . . and my boyfriend and I finally made our way over to try it! We waited for about 15 mins at 1pm on a Saturday afternoon. There were about 10-12 people waiting in front of us. The wait went by pretty quickly because we caught the tail end of tables who were finishing up their meals. 

The menu is limited with only two types of ramen and a few appetizers. We ordered two house ramen and the tebasaki (wings). We asked if they had hot tea and the waitress let us know that their teas are on their menus (see: not free). Thanks for letting us know though because some other restaurants definitely would have charged us $4 each for tea. 

The food came quickly. The wings were very soft and tender, but the flavor wasn't very special. The ramen came soon after and it was a different taste of ramen than we're used to. It was good and we enjoyed it. The soup was clear and had a clean taste to it. Overall, although the ramen was a different flavor than usual, we enjoyed the food. 

The ambiance in the restaurant is nice as well. I really enjoyed the light fixture/ decorations on the ceiling!
author: Jessilyn C.

description: The server was busy and did not seem like he cared we were waiting. Another party was paying their checks and sat for 35 of the minutes just chit chatting.He did say oh this party is the same size as yours once they are done you can have their seats. So another 18 minutes later they are still sitting and chit chatting. He could've said hello if you don't mind I have another party waiting. I'm sure they are better than this and we did go on a weekend. Maybe we will try another day.
author: Kenny W.

description: Love that more Japanese ramen shops are coming to SF.  I've been wanting to try this place every since I heard about it, and the recent rain definitely called for ramen.  We ordered one of each type of ramen, the tori paitan and the hinodeya.  I found both to be lighter than Mensho but still good.  However for the tori paitan I would have preferred more broth.  Maybe they purposely give less broth since it is richer.  Overall not cheap, smaller portions, but good flavors.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Delicious new place to get authentic ramen.  Not so sure about the yelling (you'll understand when you go) Not a cozy place but great service and good food.  There's not a lot on the menu but that's okay with me; less decisions to make!  Sit at the bar and your in and out in less than 30 minutes.  But add on time to wait for a seat.  It's popular. It's San Francisco.   You deal.
author: Darby W.

description: I treasure this restaurant! I've never had ramen with clams, but the menu intrigued me! I was super shocked at the amount of flavor in such a clear broth. Everything about it was perfect!
author: Kelly M.

description: We went right when they opened on a Saturday and while there was a line out the door, we all pretty much got seats. The menu is pretty simple. The chicken wings were ok- nothing special. The ramen was pretty good for SF. Would def come back but I would not wait in line for this.
author: Musetta S.

description: The soft cooked eggs in our ramen (two different bowl) were cold. And the chicken wings in the Tori Paitan were very disappointing. That's all I could comment.
author: Jessica Z.

description:
Came here on a Friday night with my wife where we were looking for some ramen on a cold evening and saw the line outside with folks waiting to score a table. Checking Yelp we initially decided to continue on and look at ramen or sushi places in the Peace Plaza as there were only 170 plus reviews for Hinodeya which told me that this place must have opened recently. 

After walking and perusing the various restaurants in the Peace Plaza and learning most would be closing in 40 minutes, we opted to give Hinodeya a chance and after a short wait of 20 minutes were seated at a communal table. We ordered the fried oysters which my wife said were just okay but I found them to be great as I squeezed fresh lemon on the pieces that I ate and chicken karrage with the matcha green salt. Both apps were hot when presented and not greasy.  We both ordered the Hinodeya ramen which we enjoyed. Like other yelpsters had stated in their revieews, the broth is fish based and definitely is lighter than most ramen broths that one is accustomed to. Keep in mind that the ramen comes only in one size unlike other ramen shops that might offer to bowl sizes. Service was definitely four stars and were thanked on several occasions for waiting for seats to open up. We definitely would come back here again when in J-Town and wanting ramen.
author: Richard H.

description:
The ramen soup base is not pork based / tonkatsu style, which I do find much more appealing when you are looking for a lighter ramen option. Soup overall was pretty flavorful, but $14 for a house bowl is pretty steep (even in SF) which id expect every component of the bowl to be a bit more well put together. 

The bowl was a decent portion and I left definitely feeling full. Way too many green onions. Pork chashu was just sad...minimal slice and it was almost complete fat. The wheat noodles I did enjoy quite a bit and I thought it complimented the light soup base very well. I think overall, the balance of the bowl needed some work. 

Also tried the Ka-rage chicken. Fried very well and the green tea salt was complimented it very nicely. However, $8 for 5 small pieces of chicken seemed way over priced. $4 for a small bowl of edamame had me shaking my head a bit too. 

I think if they can put some more work on cohesively bringing in all the elements in their ramen bowl it could be a 4 star - solid option for a dashi ramen house in SF. The overall cost of items on their menu made it hard for me to want to try anything beyond their cheapest bowl.
author: Christy C.

description: Portions are a bit small, but really good ramen with good ingredients. Hopefully, this place starts a trend of ramen shops intorducing the Bay Area clientele to styles other than super rich tonkotsu (or the new fad - tori paitan) broth. Their signature ramen is lighter in oils, but rich in flavor. It almost tastes like a "healthy" meal. Yes, they also have that rich tori paitan version as well, which rivals that "other place" over there in the TL.
author: Kazu O.

description:
We were in the area and it was quite late (after 8pm) and most of the restaurants in the area looked pretty dead (it's a Sunday). We decided to give it a try as the place looks authentic. The waiters were very nice and accommodating, but the food was very disappointing. 

We ordered both the house ramen as well as the chicken ramen, and some sides (fried chicken and stewed chicken). The stewed chicken is basically what you get when you order the chicken ramen, and god it's like some overcooked soy sauce chicken, something that even an amateur cook cannot mess up. The texture of the noodles is okay, but the soup bases are pretty disappointing. The portions are VERY small as well, so even with 2 sides, we ended up having to order those $5 bowls of rice to fill us up. If you only order ramen and want to feel full, I think you'd have to add a few of those add-ons, which means you will be paying upwards of $20 for the ramen alone. 

As I said, the service was very good, but sadly that's the only saving grace.
author: Essie L.

description:
I've been living in SF for about 3 years now and I've been searching far and wide for the best ramen in SF. I'm sure many of you agree that ramen here has been underwhelming to say the least. Today however, the search has finally ended. Hinodeya is hands down the best ramen in not only SF, but in the entire bay area!

My gf and I noticed this place through Yelp and noticed it was interesting that they feature a dashi broth and that it originally originated from Japan. That's always a good sign. We came on a Monday at 4:30 PM and were first in line, but a line quickly started to form. We were seated promptly at 5 PM.

We ordered:
Hinodeya Ramen: If the ramen is named after the restaurant, you have to give it a try. This featured their lighter dashi broth. The broth is definitely different from the usual Tonkotsu broths that are so common nowadays, but while it was lighter, it was still packed with tons of flavor. The noodles were cooked al dante and had the perfect chewiness. The bowl was also packed with green onions, bamboo, a half soft-boiled egg, and a melt in your mouth fatty piece of cha shu pork. The combination of the ingredients, broth, and noodles created a perfect bowl of ramen. My only complaint was that my bowl came out warm and wasn't piping hot.
Tori Paitan: This was perhaps even better than the Hinodeya Ramen. This bowl came out piping hot and the broth was FINALLY on point. All the other places that featured Tori Paitan including Totto in New York, Nojo, and Mensho were all either too grainy, too thick/heavy, and too salty. This broth however, was the perfect creaminess while packing tons of flavor but also not being too overwhelming. The braised chicken wing was so tender and literally melted in my mouth as it fell off the bone. The noodles were of course cooked perfectly and soaked the flavor of the broth. ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS. The only complaint was that the portion was slightly smaller. I want more!
Karaage: Traditional Japanese deep fried chicken. The chicken was crispy on the outside but definitely could've been a bit more crispy. The inside was very tender however and the mix of lemon and matcha salt was a great combination.

Overall, I'm so happy to have finally found the best ramen in not just SF, but the entire bay area. Despite the portions being slightly smaller, I can't wait to try their clam ramen once it becomes available and I will definitely be back here again and again. I can tell that word is spreading quickly about this place so I pray that Hinodeya will continue to maintain its high quality while it gains popularity.

#NoodlesInMyTimmy #YummyInMyTimmy
author: Tim L.

description:
Really great new Ramen place with "Dashi" ramen that I'd never heard of before.  I was a little worried that this would be a tourist trap given the location, but the food was good.  

Maybe not a good place for alcohol - the $9 house sake is not much larger than a shot glass and there are bars literally all around you with better Japanese options.
author: Jacob F.

description: My favourite ramen place in town!! The broth is just so good... I have no idea why exactly but it was great. A little less heavy than other places, which was good for me.
author: Kathy Z.

description:
The benefit of being a local is that you get to try "Hot and New" during major holidays without the wait...We showed up at five, waited 30 minutes and it was well worth it. Each of the good ramen houses in the City are unique and this one was truly authentic.

The service is perfect and the people are so knowledgeable! We had the local San Francisco sake and our waiter gave us the background on San Francisco's first sake company. Our waiter lived in Japan and told the party across from us that the bottle they were getting was from a small batch producer that they have to physically visit in Japan in order to bring the bottles back to the US.

Both ramens were great. The pork dashi is as clear as consume and as flavorful as any unfiltered broth. I am almost positive that the noodles are fresh and they are so good.
author: Rosie F.

description:
Came here on a weekday around 8:30pm and got lucky with no wait. 

I heard that Hinodeya's paitan ramen was a lighter version of Mensho, so I had to check it out. 

The restaurant has multiple tables, including two large tables that function as community tables. The service was great, especially with the host being very attentive. 

We ordered the fried oysters and chicken karaage as starters and our respective bowls of ramen. Tell me why the appetizers came mid way after we were finished with our bowls of ramen? Pet Peeve! Why would you bother calling them appetizers if they will come during the main meal?

The fried oysters weren't anything special, nothing unique. The chicken karaage, however, was delicious. The batter on it didn't feel like a heavy batter. It was almost as if they coated the karaage with chicken skin and fried it. Yum! 

The tori paitan was delicious as well. It comes with a chicken wing, but I added chashu to it for more protein. The only issue I have with the ramen is that for the price, the bowl size is significantly small. Don't be fooled but the rim of the bowl as it is curved so there is definitely less in here. The broth is lighter than Mensho's version, and I kind of liked that because I love to slurp up the broth after eating the ramen. They also include a soft boiled egg (cooked perfectly), which Mensho does not have. 

Overall, it's a good alternative to Mensho if you don't like the heavy creamy thickness of their Tori Paitan. But in my head, Mensho's bowl is superior. You leave content and full, whereas I wasn't completely full when I left. 

The food was good, so I may be back... but I think it's a matter of personal preference comparing the Tori Paitan dishes -- I'd still probably go to Mensho over Hinodeya.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
When I visited here Saturday afternoon there was no line but the hall was pretty full.
Ramen here is very delicious! Hinodeya ramen is bonito (Katsuo) based clear both which is not easy to find in other ramen place in Bay area. Also when I ordered Tebasaki (chicken wing) I thought it's fried but it's braised with Katsuo dashi, very soft and easy to eat.
author: Junho C.

description: One of the go to place in Japan town SF.  This Japanese owed and operate ramen shop is certainly a good place to go with your friends, both small groups and big groups.  Although there is always a line, it is usually within reasonable time and the food is certainly worth the wait.  The only thing needs to keep in mind is that they do not offer you to write down your name (similar to Mensho which is always crowd and you have to wait in line).  I tried their tori baiten and Hamaguri ramen.  The toti baiten is okay but the Hamaguri is impressive.  If one prefers seafood, Hamaguri will be your best bet.  They certainly spend time on the Hamaguri broth.  Besides food, the restaurant has nice ambience and upscale decor as well.  They also offer a private area for groups.  Overall it is a rare find in JTown.
author: Edison T.

description: Delicious ramen and chicken kaarage. My boyfriend was pleased with their vegan ramen. This will definitely be our go-to spot to get our ramen fix.
author: Erlinda C.

description: A welcome edition to the mushrooming ramen scene in SF, but this place is indeed different. This place is an overseas extension of a ramen chain from Japan so right of the bat it's authentic. But what stood out for me more than that was the excellent customer service. I walked in at 9:52p, eight minutes before closing and was welcome, seated, and told to get my order in asap. Many other places in the same circumstance might shoo me away. But on top of it, every waitstaff in the place welcomed me in a customary Japanese respect manner. I ordered the shoyu (clear) broth ramen and some barley tea. The soup came after some minutes and looked beautiful. The broth was clear with bits of melted fat floating on top. The noodles were noticeably homemade and the egg was artistically placed near the bottom of the bowl. The chashu pork was tender, but for the price, could have had one more piece. As promised, I slurped down my meal in quick time. The barely tea was robust, unique and worth the high $4 price tag. Funny, since I sat down, 2 other parties came in, one at 9:54 and the other at 9:58p, a mere two minutes before closing. Both were welcome. Now that's customer service! Great job Brent and team.
author: Brian J.

description: Ramen and service were both amazing! My boyfriend, friend, and I saw the rave reviews and decided to check the place out. My bf and I are vegetarian, so I made sure to check the menu to make sure that there's a veg option for us, and saw that they had a vegan ramen. When we showed up for lunch, however, we were informed that they only serve that for dinner. We were ready to leave, but our waitress told us she would ask the chef if they can make an exception and make it for us for lunch - and he said yes!! It was SO good.
author: Grace M.

description:
I spotted a line outside the cute little restaurant while wandering around Japantown (across the street from the mall), and upon inspection, I found out that it was their soft opening. One wall of the restaurant was lined with flowers welcoming the restaurant to the community--clearly this opening was very recent, and I was surprised that so many customers eagerly were waiting on a Sunday evening. Our estimated wait time was 30 minutes during which we were thoroughly entertained by the surrounding shops and nearby Peace Plaza, which was lit up by Christmas lights.

The restaurant was simply decorated, with a traditional Japanese atmosphere that was friendly and alive with conversation. There was a standing bar for those who were waiting and wanted to grab a quick drink, a semi-open kitchen for a peek of the cooking process, and a surprising amount of sitting space--two large communal tables and about the back  of the restaurant devoted to large groups. Note that there are no tables specifically for groups of 2, if you're particularly looking for a private date night. As communicated on the menu, Hinodeya specializes in "dashi ramen", a style that features a lighter broth without sacrificing any of the flavor. For the soft opening, there were two ramen options: Hinodeya Ramen (traditional) and Tori Paitan (w/ chicken), of which I ordered the prior. The wait unfortunately was a little bit longer than I would like, though all was forgotten with a piping hot bowl of ramen in front of me.

The noodles were probably the best I've ever encountered, with the perfect consistency and texture--chewy, soft, thick, and on the flatter end of the ramen noodle spectrum. The both indeed was clear and thinner than most of the ramen I've had in my life (bay area born and raised), though was packed with significant flavor (a noticeable fishy bonito flavor). The one piece of chashu pork was deliciously seasoned, one half of a perfectly soft boiled ramen egg, which was amazing, and garnishes including bamboo shoots and seaweed. In the end, this was one of the few ramen bowls I've had where I did not complain of saltiness at any point throughout the meal. Unfortunately, the portion size itself was light as well and, at the end, I was craving for more.

Overall: I would definitely come back for another round of this deliciously light ramen, though truth be told, the lightness of the meal left me a bit unsatisfied (perhaps next time for lunch?).
author: Vivian L.

description:
Great ramen!

Chicken ramen and chicken broth. Service was excellent, the host was way on top of things and the noodles were perfect! Great to find a place in San Francisco with chicken options as well as delicious pork ramen. I would say if you're getting ramen in Japan Town start here!
author: Nauti S.

description: Coming from Arizona, I actually had really high expectations and that probably was the reason why I was disappointed. We got the house ramen bowl and the proportion was so small, especially for the price. Although I'm a giant fatty who eats endlessly, the bowl probably filled me up 1/4 of the way. The broth was tasty and salty but I can easily get something similar in Arizona for a cheaper price. It was $14 for a bowl that would probably work best as a snack and not for a dinner meal. Again, I have the stomach that's like a black hole so at least you have room for dessert if you come here.
author: Heather L.

description: The best ramen I've ever eaten in San Francisco. I got the shells ramen and the crispy chicken.
author: Ping Hung W.

description:
14 dollar ramen.

To be more accurate, 14 plus tax, tip, transportation would nearly equal to 20. 
20 dollar supper....should be satisfying.

I left Hinodeya unsatisfied, rather disappointed because lamin' was nowhere near gourmet quality. 

I gave 1 star to Mensho for unimpressive ramen.
I would give 2 stars to this place for not-too terrible ramen. 
Variance is neglectable. 

Nijiya is selling great substituting undried ramens for 3.99 a pack (2-3 servings). All you have to do is boil water, add to soup concentrate and use the rest of hot water to cook noodle. Everything gets done in 3 minutes. Grocery ramens taste better than average restaurant-ramen. 

Nijiya however is missing one important ingredient to be used as ramen topping- roast pork. I don't know why they don't do Chashu a la carte. It takes time to simmer (technically not roasting except the first minutes) roast pork but they can do bunch at the same time and store them in the freezer for a period of time. 

I don't know what else I can say about Bay Area's ramen scene now. I don't have high expectation for Ippudo Berkeley that don't seem promising in any ways.
author: yota L.

description: Very good ramen, but pricey, and they charge for tea. Still, definitely worth a trip!
author: Doug W.

description: This place is great both for lunch and dinner. I had their vegan ramen noodles the first time I came here and it was delicious. It's too bad it's not in the lunch menu, but I had salad and vegetarian/vegan. The staff are amazing and very thoughtful.
author: Joseph M.

description: It's all about the broth for a great bowl of ramen. Hinodeya pro got the best clear broth in SF (Mensho the best creamy version), simply bonito + kombu + scallop 3 elements (as shown on the menu, but pro some more secrete ones?) Everything else, just some side kicks and plus...Do get here early, otherwise expecting long line.
author: Sidong H.

description: OMG! Their vegan ramen with soy milk and sesame is something amazing. I nearly had a Meg Ryan in "When Harry met Sally" moment.
author: Oksana C.

description:
A nice little Ramen place, the noodles and the broth are delicious.
 This place is more about quality than quantity, the desert is pretty good too,
 try the expresso desert.
author: Dave N.

description: Hinodeya is the first American branch of a Japanese chain that is unique in that it uses dashi broth, a tuna fish stock, usually used in traditional soups but not ramen, as opposed to more common pork stock broths or chicken broths. The result is a thinner lighter yet equally flavorful ramen broth. The egg was perfectly done, the pork slice, while small, was tasteful. I liked the way they sliced the scallions. There was a line but the line moves quickly as the restaurant is quite large and people don't stay long. Definitely a ramen bar I would return to. The soup has a lot of staying power.
author: Y C.

description:
So glad to have tried the brand new ramen shop Hinodeya Ramen SF, which just opened last week. Chef Masao Kuribara used to work at 3* Kitcho (Tokyo branch) and was an Embassy Chef (cooked for  the late Prime Minister of Japan and the Clinton's) before succeeding his father and taking over the restaurant group (now 4th generation).

Masao's ramen shop in Japan was ranked #1 in the 2014 Tabelog Best Ramen Awards for the Saitama region. He mentioned that he will be spending half the year in San Francisco to ensure Hinodeya's quality. The goal is to replicate the exact ramen they are making in Saitama using local ingredients. The signature bowl is Dashi flavored, which is very light and delicate. It was so good!

I can finally recommend another ramen shop in SF in addition to Mensho. The good news is that the lines aren't long yet, so go while you still can without waiting.
author: Jason W.

description:
Finally got to check out Ramen Hinodeya in Japantown last night and I was thoroughly disappointed. What we ordered:

Karage - soggy and chicken was rubbery. Basically it was overcooked and didn't have any flavor, luckily they give you a matcha green salt. So lemon and salt is a must to eat this.

Cheese Royal - came with 5-6 cubes of cheese that tasted and had the same texture as the Laughing Cow cheese. Remember those small cubed ones? Exactly what it was with sesame seeds, wasabi, and the matcha salt served cold. The cheese with the wasabi and the salt was interestingly good, but not mind blowing.

Hinodeya ramen - dashi broth, menma, chashu (2 pieces), nori, egg, and green onions. The broth was refreshing, but luke warm which I'm never a fan of. The best part of this dish were the noodles! They remind me of the korean kalgooksoo noodles, so it's chewy and delicious! :) 

Overall I wouldn't go here unless I was desperate. For the price and quality, it's not worth to go out of my way when there are other great ramen places in the city!
author: Jackie O.

description: First of all, the people here are great the bar tender and waiters are super friendly. Whenever we had a question, they had an answer with a smile. Their chicken ramen was my favorite. My boyfriend is obsessed with their Tabera sauce. When he asked how they made it, they went step by step in describing the process. The waiter even sold us a small thing of hot sesame oil. Their matcha cappuccino was amazing. The tebasaki was also very delicious and sweet. Overall, my boyfriend and i had a wonderful experience here. Everyone was smiling and genuine. Would definately recommend this place.
author: Becky Mae A.

description:
Only food was so great. Service wasn't good. 
Excited to trying new restaurant near my place. But basically no service at all. No explained about menu. No water refill. Just waiting for paycheck.
author: Soran R.

description:
I'm a tonkotsu broth fan so I'm naturally skeptical of all other broths.

We orderd hot barley tea ...no refills :(
edamame
chicken karaage with matcha salt... it tasted really old and maybe fried in the am and then refried

Dashi broth ramen (added chashu) very pleasant light broth.
author: Anne-Mary P.

description: Ok food, ok environment. Tori Paitan was too salty and they don't serve sushi lol. Great customer service tho.
author: Cee G.

description:
Walked by this weekend and the line was out the door. At least Ten parties waiting. But after work today, there was no line - yay

Perfect cold day for dashi soup base and ramen noodles. They only have two options available for their soft opening and I personally favor the hinodeya over the chicken one.  The toppings are what you expect from a ramen shop ( seaweed, half an egg, bamboo shoots) but they really skimmed down on the meat. One piece of chicken wing or thin slice of chashu in each bowl for $14-$15 is not filling enough. 

The service is fast and the staff smiles and checks up on you throughout the meal. They will great you as you get seated and as you exit. Personal dislike: I Did not like sitting at a long communal bench facing strangers throughout my meal through...

Ramen and ramen were good. 4 stars. I wanted to try. Tea is overprice and the ramen is on the smaller portion size. Not shareable. Minus a star for $$ and small bowl.
author: Vicky L.

description: I got the Hinodeya Ramen and I had high expectations since there was a line outside the door and I was a newer place. I was disappointed. It tasted pretty basic IMO and  it was pricier. Only one small cut of chashu and barley toppings. I tried my friends broth for the Chicken ramen and it tastes much better. Don't know if I will come back here.
author: No N.

description: I grabbed a spot in the late lunch hour as I had seen lines of people before waiting on this place. I have to say, the ramen was disappointing to me. I didn't like the overly dashi'd soup (at least in the context of ramen) and was expecting a more traditional deep pork broth for the house ramen. The chasiu was tough, but flavorful. I didn't understand the sesame seeds sprinkled over the top. I thought they were superfluous and they had a strong flavor that interfered with the soup.Also, I don't know what they mean by "whole wheat" noodles. They looked and tasted like regular egg noodles to me. Both my neighbors at the counter had the karaage, which looked really good...wish I had gotten that.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Amazing ramen, love this place.  Wait can be a bit long, so be prepared to come early than you plan to eat.  One of my fav ramen places in Japantown!
author: Orange O.

description: We were quickly seated and served drinks. Did service was also very prompt. Ordered the house Ramen which was delicious. Recommend the pork belly side as well (can't remember the name). Will come again.
author: Tim B.

description: This is good ramen. The hinodeya is pescatarian (if you order it without the pork chashu), which is awesome! Not very fishy, fairly light. The noodles are good consistency. Service is fast and friendly. Didn't have to wait too long on a Sunday afternoon for lunch. Portion size is medium. Would have liked the option to add more noodles, but didn't seem available. I'll definitely come back.
author: Scott H.

description: Great ramen spot in SF! I was in town for about 36 hours and always am looking to try ramen in every city I visit. After doing some extensive research, I settled on Hinodeya because of the dashi broth (a nice break from the tonkotsu broths found in many ramen shops). I walked over for lunch and got their house ramen and it was delicious! I loved adding the anchovy paste and chili paste which were set on the counter for your use. I would definitely go back on a regular basis if I lived in the city!
author: Justine H.

description: Service was super friendly! They give you a basket to put your bag. Sat at a communal table cause I was just one person. I took yelp advice and got the vegan ramen. Not too happy cause I prefer regular noodles and the ones that came were good but a bit al dente. The broth was creamy and I prefer a lighter broth but the vegetables and toppings that came on it were really good. It was a great experience just should've gone with my gut instead of yelp. If you don't mind something a little sweeter and creamier try the vegan ramen if you want something more savory try something else.
author: Atessa A.

description:
Love this place the Ramen and the Paintan Ramen is delicious  I Love the bone broth and the soft boiled eggs.....yummmmy of course the sha chui too. 
 The chicken karagae is spot on.  We also had the bamboo salad, interesting taste.
Too bad we didn't have time to try the dessert since we ran out of time and there were somewhat a long wait for our table couple with a soft opening  
Will definitely return again.  
The wait staff and team are very professional and friendly
author: P C.

description:
Hinodeya is an absolute delight. I have not felt this level of authenticity and flavor since I visited Kyoto. 

From the greetings of "ee-rah-shya-ee-mah-seh" to the Japanese waitstaff, you will not be disappointed by either the food or the experience.
author: Paul K.

description: its' pretty good, but I suppose I should have researched more before coming. we didn't realize until coming in that the soup is not based on bone broth, but is dashi. I like dash, but i can make it at home easily enough. Good bone broth is a different story entirely.
author: Paul P.

description:
The ramen was good.  It wasn't salty at all.  Service was great and friendly.  My party came early to wait in line so we were first round customers.  If I have to complain 1 thing, that would be the air conditioning was a bit too strong.  The cool air blowing at the table made all non soup based food cold quick.

That said, I will return as a repeated customer.
author: F L.

description: Best vegan ramen I've ever had.  Oh my lord.
author: Ana F.

description:
Came here on a rainy Friday night. With my gf. Waited about 15 minutes. 

We both got the Hinodeya Ramen. So good. Broth was very simple and clean, but full of favor. Usually I don't feel fantastic after drinking up the soup, but I felt great after this one. The best bamboo shoots, perfect noodles, yummy egg, and delicate and tasty chashu. 
Fairly spacious inside. Nice staff. Food comes out quickly. 

Great experience, will def come back.
author: Kai-Rui R.

description:
Delicious, fast, inexpensive, authentic and great service. Loved the fried oysters, spicy menma, and both ramen.

There was a line to get in but it went pretty fast.
author: Ashley T.

description:
I was tempted to leave a review after their soft opening, but, felt like I was too biased at that point. So I went opening night and once more for good measure. They still have a little room for improvement, but it's close enough that I'll give it 5 stars.

Hinodeya has 4 other locations, all in Japan. I've never been to those other ones, but I think they've done a good job of providing light-style broths to SF. The city is saturated with the shops specializing in the super heavy tonkotsu/tori paitan broths.

Right now, they have 2 bowls to choose from: Hinodeya (dash) and tori paitan. The dashi broth is a more delicate broth, but somehow, it's still got a lot of body and depth. The tori paitan is a lot lighter than what you might find in this city, but without sacrificing any of the flavor.

The appetizers are well done, too. Stick with nailing a few things, and leave the wide array of choices to the izakaya. The nagaimo is probably the most interesting item, and I recommend that.

There are two more soups upcoming, and I'm especially looking forward to the veggie option (sesame/soy? Yes, please!). I'd also hope for kaedama, but it actually seems like it'd clash with their style.
author: masa s.

description: Not bad ramen, but nothing special. The wait wasn't too bad and the service was pretty good. One bowl of ramen definitely isn't that filling so side dishes are a must. I recommend the fried oysters, but not the Hotate Rice...that were a huge disappointment.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
We have been here a few times now. 
There was a line always each time that we came here for ramen. There was no sign-in board any more, I was wondering how the host kept track of who came before who, and the sizes of the parties... he must remember the faces very well! 

Love the fried chicken appetizer here, with the matcha salt!! So crispy, and so delicious!! The fried oysters and the yams were not our favorite. They were good, just not our fave. 

Only two kinds of noodles, we went for the Hinodeya Ramen. Excellent noodles, excellent broth!! The pork was a bit on the dry side and sliced too thick for our liking. 

Desserts were so delicious!! Love the matcha cappuccino with the red beans at the bottom!! The sesame ice cream and the matcha ice cream were good too. 

Service was excellent. Very friendly service, and the meal progressed at a nice pace, we were never hurried even with the long line waiting. 

Definitely will come back again and again!
author: lovetoeat a.

description: Came here on a rainy night and it was the perfect night of a hot bowl of ramen! We ordered karaage to start - delicious! It came with a bit of this green salt (not sure what it was, but it was salty and yummy?). The four of us all ordered the tori paitan so unfortunately I can't comment on any of the other ramen selections - but the tori paitan was so good I can see myself only getting that when I go! The texture of the noodles was perfect. Chewy, perfectly al dente, so so good. The soup was milky and rich with the taste of chicken and dashi! It came with a small chicken wing, half a marinated egg, a mushroom, seaweed, and really fresh raw green onion. Definitely a simple assortment of toppings with a couple more topping options but not much (if you're used to having a wide array of toppings to pick from). I really enjoyed the ramen, though I could probably do with a bigger portion :p it was definitely filling though! (I just really love noodles)
author: Grace D.

description:
The line is long and cold, but it moves quickly. Don't try to put name in with the hostess- there is no hostess and there is no list. The menu is limited but yummy! 
We tried the (non fried) wings - delicious. 

Get the $15 Tori Paitan ramen versus the titled Hinodeya $14 ramen. It's smaller, but way more flavorful. 

The black sesame ice cream is amazing!!! Get it!
author: Morgan S.

description: This place definitely hit the spot. My friend and I were in Japantown for the cherry blossom festival and wanted to grab a bite. We got there around 12:30pm on a Saturday and there was plenty of seating (but a wait when we left). I ordered the chicken ramen. Yum!
author: Tiffany Y.

description: Hinodeya is so far the best ramen place I've tried in the japantown area. In particular the clear fish broth has great flavor and complements the noodles really well. I'm also a huge fan of their karaage, crispy and flavourful! Prices are a bit high for the size but I'll for sure keep coming back.
author: Cindy W.

description: We had the House ramen after a 45 min wait. 4 stars for the broth, ramen and pork itself were mediocre. Pork was tough and did not have the flavor you come to expect from a highly rated ramen place.  Broth though was light and flavorful. Ramen to broth ratio was also off with more broth than ramen.
author: S K.

description: best ramen i've had so far! in love with the broth but the noodles didn't seem fitting( in my opionion)! come early or there will be a line! Also order dessert the matcha cappuccino and the sesame ice cream. They were both goooood! Price is a bit on the higher side but very worth!
author: Bonnie Y.

description: I'm part Japanese and this is as close as you can get to great ramen in San Francisco. Especially if you like ramen that isn't too heavy and oily. Hinodeya ramen is lighter but still very flavorful with delicious noodles. Really friendly staff as well. Unlike Mensho, it usually has no line! Go to nearby Uji afterwards for dessert!
author: Amy R.

description: AVOID. I had the Zen Ramen but I only ate about a quarter of the bowl because it tasted terrible and made me feel ill. We paid and left and drove straight home where I threw up 4 times (unprompted).
author: John M.

description: One of the best ramen places I've been too especially in SF. The broth was amazing and the karaage can compete with any restaurant.
author: Derek S.

description: Delicious, authentic ramen for a reasonable price. Comparable to mensho minus the hour long wait. Their dashi style broth is bomb. Always like ending my meal with their matcha cappuccino - creamy and not super sweet. Their servers are also attentive and friendly.
author: Alice C.

description:
I was a bit skeptical about the fact that it's got clear non-Tonkotsu (pork bone) broth. They use Dashi instead. I'd never had excellent non-Tonkotsu Ramen before. 
We just happened to be walking around Japan town and saw the long line and checked it out on Yelp (not too bad 4 stars) and it was marked as "Nouveau et Tendance". 
So we decided to check it out; line was not bad at all, only 20 minutes of wait. 
We ordered the "Hinodeya Ramen", and first thing first, the clear broth is really tasty - I was proven wrong. The noodles, excellent, good balance of chewiness and firmness, perfectly seasoned; noodles by themselves already tasting really good.

Note: about an hour before closing time the crowd seemed to die down a lot. Not sure because it was a Sunday or something else.
author: Arie R.

description:
Their vegan ramen is sooooo devious, I went within a couple of weeks.
It is a little bit on the salty side, but considering all things, it is very yummy.

My friend ordered black sesame ice-cream, she absolutely loved it as well.
author: Yf W.

description: Their vegan ramen - 2 kinds, depending on when you go - is fantastic!! Really recommended! Delicious!
author: D. B.

description: I loved this place! This place is located in the heart of SF Japantown (surprise, surprise), so if you guys are looking for a cheap and good place to eat at, this is the place to go to. The restaurant is really clean and like most traditional Japanese restaurants I've been to, all the employees greet and thank you upon entering/leaving. We were seated in one of the private rooms, and although it was cute, I felt like the customer service is ignored in those areas. We ordered the Hinodeya Ramen and Salad, Takowasa, and Tebasaki. My husband was the one who ordered the salad, which was alright. The dressing was nice, but I personally felt the arugula didn't go well with it. I love the ramen and tebasaki! The broth wasn't overpowering and all of the ingredients were well cooked. I suggest adding more ingredients as you don't get a lot... (or maybe I'm just a pig. LOL.). I loved the tebasaki and how the meat just fell off the bones cleanly. I also love the fact that they plucked any extra pieces of the feather.. because I'm really picky when it comes to things like that! It wasn't too sweet at all and feel that it was well-balanced. As for the takowasa, it wasn't anything special. It's raw octopus with overpowered wasabi... and a piece of lettuce, so I don't really suggest ordering it the first time around unless you wanted something small and light.
author: Kaye T.

description: The day before we went to this place, I just tried the famous Paitan ramen at Ramen Menshou. I was disappointed because I didnt like it at all, and So I just realized I don't like thick broth. And then the next day we came to this place to fulfill the unfulfilled desire for ramen. I got the first item on menu which means like the most basic and original item. And I found it super delicious. It is super clear kind of broth, with lots of green onion. I finally realize this is the kind of ramen I like!
author: Claudia M.

description: Excellent service and very good food at reasonable prices.  Fried oysters, fried chicken, House Ramen and Vegan Ramen were all quite tasty.  We will return.
author: Steve B.

description: I beg to differ with the diner who did not like the fried yams.  Yes, white yams are bland. However they were fried to a delightful crunchy texture and the accompanying sauce was the perfect complement.  The spicy baby bamboo shoots are also terrific.  The prompt service is superb.
author: Bob S.

description: This is the absolute best ramen that I've ever had!!! So warming, comforting with great flavor. The only reason I'm deducting a star is because some of our group was vegan and that want available for lunch. Other than that, this place is AMAZING and worth the price!!!
author: Juno B.

description: We were craving ramen and went here right before they closed for the lunch crowd. We had the vegan ramen, chicken ramen and the ramen with clams and clam sauce. The ramen here is very good. We would go back. This place is definitely worth trying if you have not been here.
author: Nina C.

description:
Been here 3 times already and will continue to go back!

The Good:
- The ramen is amazing! Delicious broth (dashi-based, which is a nice change of pace if you want something lighter than tonkotsu and it's more complex than typical shio or shoyu) and fantastic noodles with a great bite.
- Hot appetizers; got the fried oysters and they were quite tasty and large.

The Bad:
- The wait... This is SF, so that's just how it goes, but it can be pretty rough if you don't go at odd hours.
- Braised wings are fine, but don't stand out.
author: Jeff W.

description: I love this place.  super happy servers with youthful enthusiasm.  also, they have VEGAN RAMEN!!!! yay!  super simple menu so the execute perfectly.  fast, easy and modest pricing.
author: Tiffany S.

description: Was excited to try this place but was disappointed. There was a line outside but went fairly quick. The ramen is pretty pricey for the portion and the broth wasn't memorable. Can get better ramen at iza and mensho.
author: Dana C.

description:
Changed the way I ever knew ramen could taste. I got the Hinodeya ramen, and the broth was so good. It had a base of bonito, kombu and scallop. 

I also wanted to get the Karaage, but they were out of it. I was disappointed at first and opted to try the Tebasaki wings at the server's recommendation. I was not sorry, nor did I miss the karaage after that. The wings were in this soy sauce "glaze", but it looked more like broth. It was really savory and tasted way better than it appeared. 

It's pretty pricey at around $14-15 for a bowl of ramen, but it's worth it. You can really taste the difference in the ingredients. Since this place is new, the menu was still in the works with additional items to come. Another thing is that you may have to share a table with others as the place isn't huge.
author: Stacey L.

description: The ratings not really reveals the quality and value of the ramens offerered in this place. Its  way too much overpriced for a smaller than usual size bowl with a little tiny dinky chicken wing and half of the boiled egg in it for a whopping $15! The cha-shiu ramen was a joke with just one very thin slice of cha-shiu and half of an egg. You can only call it a personal size appetizer. Soup base was average nothing impressive, but salty. I wouldnt recommend. There are better ramen  places in the city with the same or better quality and value out there.
author: Nydragon P.

description: Came here for many times and each time we ate happily. Food was really great and so did the service. Sometimes it was difficult to get a table.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Extremely patient and friendly wait staff, had an outstanding experience. They have a special for a flight of sake for $10 that was served with complimentary marinated cream cheese that was great. Ramen was good, nothing special, but really it was the wait staff that makes me give this place 5 stars.
author: Rockefeller B.

description: This place has the best Ramen in Japan town.  The Ramen is so balanced with taste for the mouth and beauty for the eyes.  Even with a regular sized bowl, one is left satisfied with the value.  Simply awesome Ramen!
author: Jimmy P.

description: Great texture on the noodles and the clear broth is a refreshing break from the fatty, porky ramen broths you might find at other restaurants in the area.
author: Ryan L.

description: I enjoyed house ramen again.  They added more pork!  They now serve hot loose green tea in a pot  for $4 with refile.  Staff are friendly and attentive!
author: Keiko N.

description: This is the ramen you've been looking for. Featuring their own unique dashi based broths these ramens are flavorful and savory/umami. Of particular note is their Tori-paitan (chicken stock based) ramen.  Unlike other Tori-paitan ramens ive had the broth is thinner and as a result lighter which gives the broth a very nice mouth feel. We also enjoyed the kareage appetizer which really hit the spot with beer. The atmosphere is modern and refined with many community tables to sit at and a few private booths in the back.  Worth the wait in line.
author: Raphael P.

description: Their ramen was perfect! Everything you want for a ramen. Tasted authentic! I didn't quite like the scallop(hotate) rice, scallop was hard and didn't like the fact that they didn't offer any donburi. I bet they can do much better if they have more choice with rice!
author: Shinji K.

description: I'm not a ramen expert. But I loved, loved my lunch here. Got the clam ramen, which I hadn't seen offered before. It was outstanding. Noodles were perfect, as you might expect. Was not sure if I'd be missing the meaty punch I'm accustomed to with tonkotsu ramen. Turns out, the lightness but deep flavor of the little clams was a home run. I was perfectly full without feeling heavy, ready to take on the rest of my day. My two companions both got the house ramen and were well pleased also, but I think I won with the clam ramen order. I also appreciated the draft Asahi beer from a perfectly maintained tap.
author: Peter W.

description: The broth was a bit bland, and nothing was really that hot, which was a bit of a letdown because it was cold outside. The menu is rather limited. If you're trying to decide between this place and Marufuku, go there instead. The two styles are different, but this style of ramen just isn't executed very well here. The service was excellent.
author: Jen H.

description:
I came here on a rainy Thursday and was greeted at upon entering. We were seated immediately and given little baskets to put our things into. The decor is nice with a couple 4 tables, 2 tables, and two big communal tables. 

We both ordered the Hinodeya ramen which had half an egg, lots of bamboo shoots, one slice of cha shu, and a clump of green onions. The noodles were flatter and more irregular than usual ramen, an interesting texture. The broth was delicious and unique, quite different from traditional ramen broths like miso and pork. The only bad thing was that the portions were pretty small for $14. I usually cannot finish an entire bowl of ramen myself but i easily finished a bowl here.

The service was great. They were extremely attentive and kind even when we stayed past our meal. 

Overall this place is worth trying if you're looking for a new taste of ramen. But if not, the price is a bit high for that portion size of a bowl of ramen.
author: Grace C.

description: Visiting San Francisco for a few days and decided to go try this place out. They only have 2 kinds of ramen noodle. The menu was very small. I tried the Hinodeya noodle. Broth was ok, nothing special about it. For a $14 Bowl of noodle you only get half a egg and 1 small slice of pork. If you want more eggs or pork they charge extra. I would prefer my noodle to be little more cooked. Their noodle was too chewy for my liking. Overall, it would have been nice if they added more pork and at least 1 whole egg for that price that they charge.
author: Choua K.

description: Not your traditional ramen from across the road, the broth was clear with no real taste, almost as if the broth was just warm water. My husband enjoyed his appetizers​ though.
author: Maria W.

description: A+ service, we put our camera bag on the floor and they put it in a box so it wouldn't be on the ground. Food was really good too, got the House Ramen with lots of Tabera lol. 10/10 would recommend
author: Julliene F.

description: Super yummy Daishi broth, which is lighter. I loved their special ramen. Limited bowls though. The time I went it was a clam ramen!
author: Jemma L.

description: Average ramen with very small portions for the price. You are better off going to underground or mensho tokyo.
author: Jeremy P.

description: My first ramen in San Francisco and it was amazing! Original Japanese coucine, beautiful atmosphere, and cheap ( by SF standards). Did I mentioned it's fast?  You can eat a ramen for 15usd.
author: Nicolás A.

description: I ordered a House Ramen. The soup base was tasty and the saltiness was not overwhelming.  Very good balance.  Love it.  The chicken wings were yummy.  As for location, it's in Japan town. It's accessible by a few Muni lines. I would visit again with friends.
author: Wing W.

description: Always consistently provide perfectly cooked noodle & flavor balanced soup. The service is wonderful too. You can tell they have pride on their work, one bowl at a time.
author: Reiko B.

description:
Great al dente while wheat noodle.  Amazing dashi-based broth.  Friendly service.  We asked for substitutions based on some items available on the menu, and they were very accommodating.  

Would have preferred the ramen to be less salty, but overall a great ramen option in the city!
author: Judy H.

description: There's definitely a wait so try to come right when they open! Ramen is delicious. Service is great (reminds me of Japan). I've been here twice and I will most definitely be coming back again. This is the place I bring my friends when they're visiting.
author: Karen T.

description:
Overpriced for the amount of meat you get in the ramen.  Orenchi(santa Clara), Mensho, and Ramen Dojo are definitely better.   

1. Tori Paitan broth was more flavorful than the Hinodeya Ramen.   
2.   Expect only ONE piece of meat in your ramen: Tori Paitan had only one chicken wing ($15) [Nothing like that chicken leg Nojo Ramen in Hayes gives you!]
Himodeya ramen had only one piece of chashu ($14)
