3. Karaage tasted good but couldn't really taste the matcha in the salt.
author: Brett C.

description: Went for lunch and they had a simple menu. Staff was nice. The ramen noodles was a bit tough and the soup base was decent. Since a bowl costs $14 and up, I expect more ingredients. The bowl of ramen had one thin slice of cha siu with half a egg, green onions and some bamboo shoot slices. Very disappointed and skimpy on ingredients.  On top of that, there is a charge for tea which is ridiculous.  I  dont understand the four star ratings.
author: N L.

description: The second time here and no disappointment even with the limited menu during cherry blossom weekend
author: Elpie K.

description: Best ramen in SF! From the ramen to the broth, it was perfection. As it's run by Japanese people it's has a very authentic Japanese taste and just the right amount. I would recommend the tori paintan and the karaage. Do not get the hotate gohan, the hotate tasted dry and unflavorful. Make sure to come at the opening time, it gets packed fast!
author: Miu K.

description: I thought this place was pretty good. They have four flavors of ramen. I tried the house flavor with Pork. It was flavorful and each of the toppings complemented the broth and noodles very well. I went around 6:30pm on a Friday and it wasn't too busy which was also nice.
author: Michelle B.

description: Loved this place! Had ramen.... definitely the tastiest in the area. We got there about 30 mins after it opened and it was already packed but still got a table for two almost immediately. Nice decor but still low key.
author: Laura D.

description: Great soup flavor.  Chicken base (I believe) with a hint of fish stock.  Nice ramen which is different from many other ramen places in San Francisco.
author: Pasha G.

description: Came here during cherry blossom festival. Food was delicious and service was good and really fast. They offered a high chair for my 11 month son.
author: Regina L.

description: Delicious.  Simple.  House Ramen and two appetizers and the service were all five stars.
author: Michael L.

description: Service was excellent but that was possibly the worst ramen I've had in my life. So disappointing since I read so many good reviews about it. The broth was flavorless and watery and the toppings were slim. The chicken ramen had one measly chicken wing and the hinodeya ramen had one small pork slice. A rip off for the price!
author: Marian C.

description: It was great to have a vegan ramen option. It was full of flavor, and color. It was delicious.
author: Minette V.

description:
The best ramen place we have been to in San Francisco or New York, and definitely the most authentic tasting. They are also very consistent and things tasted the same every time we've been here, unlike Ramen Yamadaya across the street which is very hit or miss. The only downside here is that there is very little meat in each bowl, but it works out if you get the Chicken Kara Age appetizer to go with your ramen.

The Kara Age is also very flavorful and has nice cuts of chicken (not overly fatty). 

I don't think the desserts are really that big of an appeal here.
author: Rachel L.

description: Absolutely delicious flavors!  The ramen broths are rich and flavorful  The chicken wings are amazing!  The salad was fresh with a  flavorful dressing.  The fried yam was wonderful. The only reason I may not return is that the ramen noodles are very short, so can not be slurped up properly!
author: T H.

description: Decided to try this place based on reviews here. I don't get the hype. They give you one small piece of chashu with a ton of noodles in borderline bland broth. Maybe I'm missing something but I won't be back.
author: BigArm K.

description: Place was good  but maybe not worth the hype.  Sadly i fell for it too.  We went there because there was a line outside already and assumed it would be amazing.  Found out when we got inside there were 4 open tables in the back throughout our whole meal....little suspicious.  The noodles were really great but the portion was smaller than then other places.  But that being said it was still very filling.  We had the Kara-age boneless chicken and it was good!  They gave us a side of matcha green tea salt which is cheap really don't add additional flavor... I think it's more of a novelty.  Overall I'm glad we went tonight but I probably won't be coming back anytime soon unless it was convenient.
author: Young-Ju O.

description: Yummy!!!! I'm not vegan or even a vegetarian, but their vegan ramen is divine!!! Who knew soy milk could be whipped up into something so delicious? Also delish was their house ramen. Accompanied by a barley tea, and you're set!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Best Ramen I've had in a long time. Had the House Ramen w/ the Dashi broth (seafood based rather than pork or miso) and it was incredibly flavorful! The chashu was tender and delicious and the noodles were really great too. Friendly service and cute ambiance as well- will definitely be back!
author: Naomi B.

description: Top notch service, speed and authenticity. They did very well in replicating an authentic experience. Love this style of Ramen cuisine as it favor lightness over the heavy oily kind. The broth was clear yet flavorful and the noodles cooked perfectly.
author: Kenny F.

description: Love Hinodeya's ramen!  I've been here 3 times now and each time, I've had a brief 5 - 10 minute wait, but the line moves surprisingly quickly.  Service -- whether you're dining at a table or at the bar -- is consistently efficient, polite, and friendly.  The menu is concise and I always order the house ramen.  It's the perfect portion size and a little on the lighter side.  The dashi broth is umami perfection, and the soft-boiled egg and bamboo shoots are my favorite toppings.  Best ramen I've enjoyed in Japantown!
author: Emily W.

description:
3.5 stars because the sevice was great. the food is good but not awesome. the ramen here reminded me of udon. 
if u like clean flavors and not heavy, oily ramen then u will love this place.
author: Julie L.

description: Ordered Paitan and it was good. I like how the chicken is soft and tasty; broth is creamy enough. Although, the ramen lacks broth and the noodles are too thick for me.
author: Aid G.

description: Agree with other reviews that if you are a carnivore, this place will be disappointing as there's literally one piece of chashu, if you are ordering the house ramen, or one chicken wing if its the other one. And that's all the protein you'd get in addition to half soft boil egg. However the broth itself is delicious and the texture of the noodle is great. Plus the service is decent. It's just for the price you'd imagine more decorated ingredients.
author: Siyu C.

description: It's a short walk from my apartment but I eat so much I kind of wish it was farther to work it off! That is a testament to the tastiness of their ramen. Top notch ramen.
author: Emily L.

description: Underwhelming. The flavors were just mediocre. $15-ish for a tiny bowl of noodles. I would rather spend $2 more for Mensho's chicken ramen Or there are a lot of other ramen places around that are much better and bigger for less cost.
author: Jessie S.

description: Good enough if you happen to be in the area. Of the two ramen choices, pork and chicken, go for the chicken, it's more unique and has good flavor. The fried oyster app I had was so so. Most disappointing was the flagship sake of the house, the bunraku daiginjyo from saitama, the home prefecture of the cook I was told. It didn't live up to the hype. Expect to pay a bit more here, too.
author: Alex B.

description: Very disappointed with this new ramen shop.  Small portion for $15 , I rather paid $18 at Mensho with a generous bowl.  Using stemless wine glasses to served very hot sake can burn you.  We told the server and all she said, that's what we use here.  Definitely will not go back.  Also,would be nice if they have a signed in sheet to avoid confusion.
author: Ed Y.

description: Comfortable, hot bowl of deliciousness. Their noodles are thicker and slightly wider than other ramen we're used to but we loved it, imagine al dente style freshly cut noodles. No matter what time or day, prepare for at least a 20-30min wait, but def worth it. So happy to see more places pop up in Japantown.
author: Angela L.

description: Impressed! The broth was definitely one of the best I have had. They even kindly brought extra broth when I asked. I was a little disappointed in the noodles, as they were more like udon noodles than the thinner ramen noodles that im more familiar with. Regardless, the taste was great.  The oversimplification of their menu leaves you wanting a little more options, but quality control is the outcome of it, and a good one too.
author: minnie l.

description:
This was my first time having dashi broth ramen (Hinodeya), and it is the best ramen I've had in SF.  I've always like dashi based soups, so having a ramen with it was great!  The broth is very flavorful and crisp.  Everything was fresh and well prepared.  The noodles had a good consistency.  I definitely want to try the other ramens when the full menu is available.   We also had an order of the karaage and fried oysters...both were also fried very nicely.  

The service was quick and the line wasn't too bad.  There was no sign-in sheet - just wait in line and the host will check in with you.  They will not seat until your entire party is present, which is fair as the restaurant is not very big (better floor plan and decor than sha la la that used to be here) and they want to keep the tables turning.  I plan to go back!
author: K L.

description:
Impressed that they had a broth made from konbu and bonito rather than the standard pork one often finds in ramen shops.  There was also a chicken based ramen, but that one tasted like chicken noodle soup on the menu of an elderly care facility (isn't that where all chicken noodle soups belong?).  Fried oyster appetizer was nicely fried but somehow did not taste much like oysters.  The ground bonito flakes on the table were nice since it was possible to increase the flavor of the ramen significantly (and it was far too bland as served).

Still, this is ramen.  Exactly why am I eating this?  Certainly not because I want to.  So, this is the least offensive ramen I can recall, but the extremely limited menu means that if you come with a group and are not a ramen person yourself, you are very much out of luck.
author: Richard P.

description: I am from Vancouver, and I had been disappointed with ramen in SF compared to Vancouver. But not anymore. Hinendoya Ramen is simply the best ramen I have had in the West Coast. The noodle that they choose has the right consistency, the egg is cooked just right, and the broth perfect. There are currently two types of ramen. One has very thick broth (with chicken stock) and the other one light (hinendoya ramen). I suggest trying both. The chicken karage is also the best I have tried anywhere! Let's hope they can keep the quality up after the main Japanese chef returns to Japan after training the staff.
author: James L.

description: OMG! My first ramen experience... so good! I had the vegan ramen bowl and it did not disappoint. In fact, it has me wanting to return to SF from LA just to have more. I stayed at at the Biltmore Hotel across the street. I asked a local where to get vegetarian food. He recommended this ramen place, and said there was one vegan option. I went in with some skepticism having not really had ramen proper before and concerned about the limited veg options... and was blown away!! I'll be on the hunt for a local version of a creamy based vegetarian ramen bowl like this. Any suggestions?
author: R C.

description:
I was going to go to the tasty spot across the alley last week but I heard all the hype and figured I'd try this place out.

My date and I waited only maybe 10 minutes and were seated around 6pm as the line started getting longer. We shared the two main options, the Hinodeya Ramen and the Tori Paitan. They were quite good - not as rich as other nearby options, but very flavorful, and with small portions of decent toppings (I actually thought the pork wasn't great, but my date very much enjoyed the chicken wing). Some reviews mentioned the portions being small - I disagree. They were each a very filling meal without needing appetizers or desserts.

Overall, I suppose I'd give it 3.5 stars if I could, but it just didn't live up to the hype. Maybe my taste buds aren't as refined as some, but next time I want ramen, I'm going to get a rich, salty, bucket of it for under $10.
author: Chris M.

description: We came here after finding a long line at another place. Were second in line for a table but didn't wait more than 2 minutes. Host greets guests by announcing something in Japanese and the kitchen staff responded with a similar cheer. Nice touch!  Ramen was delicious and service was prompt. A great experience. Would definitely return. We want to visit Japan now!
author: Jason S.

description: Don't get the hype. Just riding the ramen craze...They give you one, tiny slice of meat. Broth is watery. Noodles were ok. For that price go across the street to Ramen Yamadaya. They have a longer wait but its for a reason.
author: Jee Mee H.

description: Great service and tasty food. Good saki too. The only thing is the chashu is relatively lean
author: Alice L.

description: Maybe I'm not well versed in ramen, but this was the best ramen I have ever had in my entire life.
author: Roberta W.

description: Ramen was perfect texture, great service if you come late and extra spice.
author: David M.

description: This ramen place is good but don't expect it to taste like the ramen you're used to! They use a dashi soup base which is delicious and light. I would definitely come back here, it was worth the wait but it isn't the heavy, hearty ramen I'm used to. If I'm ever looking for ramen that's not too heavy, I'll come here. The karage is very good!!! I'm in love with the matcha salt they give you.
author: Christine A.

description: Huge selection of ramen. All of them are very tasty. Kind pleasant atmosphere and interesting decor. Friendly staff. Highly recommend.
author: Camerom B.

description: We tried their traditional Hinodeya ramen bowls.  I ordered an extra egg which was really good.  We also tried the karage.  Overall I thought it was decent.  There aren't options for changing type of noodles or broth.
author: Vincent S.

description: Ramen broth was more than decent, but meat seemed a bit undercooked. Girlfriend ordered the Vegan ramen which was crazy sweet, and a bit out of place.
author: Sam L.

description: This place is legit. I go to Japan pretty often and this is the closest thing you will get to real Japanese ramen. These people giving bad ratings probably haven't been to Japan before or eaten a real Japanese meal. You are all accustomed to the fake horse shit the non-Japanese chefs try to pass off as Japanese food in SF lol.
author: Swanson U.

description:
This place rocks!!! Such a great addition to the neighborhood.

From discussing with the staff, the broth for the ramen varies from other ramen shops: it's dashi based, aka. safe for pescatarians.  There is a locally made sake (Sequoia) on the menu which is really great.

A place well worth visiting. The staff is very friendly and always make the visit worth it. Now I go at least twice a week ;)

Check it out!!
author: Ben J.

description:
Dashi based soup is more subtle than the tonkotsu (pork bone) broth that has become popular.  There's often a line, but no sign up sheet, so line up and a staff member will take a count of the number in your party once inside. If you can sit at the counter, you may get seated quickly.  The service is attentive.  I like the fact that the menu is small but they do it well. 

The green tea is very good -- I think it was made with some matcha.

There are some condiments at the table -- the pepper, garlic flakes and another which I think is fish based.  But I didn't use them since the soup was flavorful on its own.

The decor is nice, and there are subtle touche like a basket that the bill comes in.
author: Dan C.

description: Best ramen in bay area. Everything about ramen is perfect. Service is spot on. Friendly and well trained stuff. And surprisingly there is no wait yet on week days. A restaurant truly deserves 5 star.
author: Aaron C.

description: Strange. How can ramen be refreshing and light? Well Hinodeya, you did it. There is this savory but ocean taste in their broth that is so light even my seafood-hating partner loved it. The tasty pork is actually not the highlight of their house ramen, nor is the beautifully textured wheat noodles, the perfectly soft boiled egg, no one ingredient outshines the other. There was not a time where I thought "I wish there was more of...". Unfortunately, Hinodeya is a ten hour drive for me. I will be dreaming of you.
author: Michelle S.

description: I had the house Ramen special with Pork.  One of the best Ramen shops with a very tasty and light soup base, whole wheat noodles with a smooth texture and perfect springy consistency.  The soft boiled egg was perfectly marinated with a semi raw yolk.  The cha-shu pork could have used some more seasoning and flavor.  The braised chicken wings had good flavor but the texture of the meat was a little too tender and soft.  Great service and nice atmosphere.  Note: there may be a bit of a wait during prime dinner time.
author: MacaSushi W.

description: After reading a few reviews about how the soup is plain or bland I was curious. I just went and tried it. I thought the soup was great, the noodles had a great fresh texture. The soup was not over powering or over salty like a lot of the places (yamadaya). It was a clean flavor of good Japanese dashi-no msg, not too salty. I thought it was very well done. The only gripe was for $14, the bowl could be a tad bigger.
author: Billy S.

description: Had the Hinodeya ramen. Had an interesting and different broth. We also had the kara-age which was a good as a shared appetizer.  Service was awesome, we told the server that we had a movie to get to and he made sure we were out in time for it. They look like they do desert well too, was jealously eyeing our neighbors desert. Perhaps next time!
author: Errol O.

description:
I love ramen, but not the biggest fan of tonkotsu broth--it's just too thick and I always feel a bit gross afterward. I've always preferred asari, shio, shoyu, that style. This is perfect for me. Lighter broth but with plenty of flavor, authentically Japanese (unlike a number of the places in Japantown), with noodles just right. The karaage is cooked just right, too, and comes with the pinch of matcha salt, which is more traditionally used for tempura, but works with the karaage as well.  

Also, they did a nice job with the interior!
author: shimon t.

description: tori paitan.  better at Mensho.  famous newcomer from Japan.  hinodeya uses fish dashi broth, this was good for the main ramen, light, clear but flavorful.  didn't like the whole grain noodle.  what happens when you bite into it is that it breaks into small pieces, so didn't like the texture as much.  egg ok, chicken piece classic flavor.  would choose the hinodeya, lots of menma.  karaage is standard, wouldn't get the fried yam.  tebayaki just ok.  can come here if marafuku too crowded.
author: Rob C.

description: Went there tonight with friends and ordered the vegan ramen and chicken ramen, as well as the black sesame ice cream and green tea.  Everything was delicious the restaurant itself is extremely popular ... on a Monday night, every table was packed from when we arrived until leaving around 8:30pm.  Many restaurants in Japantown feature not-so-great tourist food, but this place is actually delicious.  They only have a few main things on the menu - chicken, pork and vegan ramen were the main items although there are side dishes.  Definitely worth a visit and was very impressed with the food.  I will be back.
author: Laurence S.

description: The real deal ramen spot! Kara-age was also a crowd pleaser. Will def recommend to friends and family. We ate here during their soft opening so the menu does not yet include their vegan ramen. The staff (kitchen and wait) are from Japan. Info at the restaurant says this is the 5th location - 1st in the states. A great option for anyone looking to eat in Japantown or looking for legit ramen.
author: Nikki N.

description:
Best ramen in the Bay Area hands down.

They get all the details right.

Every item on the menu is considered and wonderful.

The staff are attentive and kind.

Go right now.
author: Ameya M.

description: Oh wow.   Where to start.   We went at 730pm on a Wednesday night --there was a line, as usual. But it wasn't as long as before (when we bailed), so we stuck it out. But, I feel like a line on a Wednesday speaks volumes on how fantastic this place is. We got seated fairly quickly.  We first got the aburi chasu (flame torches pork belly)--it was 100% as advertised, full of flavor & fragrance. Usually I find green onions overly biting with an annoying after taste--not this time. Perhaps the sriracha and saffron balanced it out. Delicious start to the meal. The Kara-age was nice and tender--sounds terrible but I don't usually care about cageless/free-range because the meat is sometimes tougher. Not this time--succulent and flavorful. But, the crown jewel of my meal was the Hamaguri Ramen.   The clams were plentiful, decently sized, not tough and rubbery, not overly meaty, but not scrawny either. They were the perfect balance of salty and savory. I was a bit concerned that the broth would be too thick because the description said "buttery dashi broth"--nope, not al all!  We topped off the meal with the Kuro-Goma ice cream w granola...  we shared it across 3 of us so that we would walk out full & satisfied, but not sick. Good call. It's been 4 nights since that meal and I'm still dreaming about it.
author: Chibimaru L.

description: Service was quick and attentive, ramen was good, the restaurant was very clean.
author: Mariko T.

description: The ramen here is great. The broth is light yet very flavorful and the noodles have just the right texture. It has been long overdue for a decent ramen shop to open up in Japan Town. The staff here are very courteous too -- a little taste of Japanese service. The only thing I don't like about this place are the prices, just some tea and ramen will run you over $20.
author: William C.

description: We went on a weekday.  The wait was short, but the food was average.  The ramen is on the lighter than I prefer and the portions were smaller than other ramen places in the area.  Solidly average and would only go back if the wait at other ramen places was ridiculous.
author: A B.

description: This is my favorite ramen place in San Francisco!! The staff here are really friendly and the service here is very fast. I got here at around 6 and there was no wait!
author: Kelly C.

description: The best. It's so simple, it's like home cooking like how your Oba-chan would make it. So good after a rainy, cold day. If I didn't live in LA I would come here everyday.
author: Amy O.

description: Awesome service here. Their hinodeya ramen uses a dashi broth different from your typical tonkatsu , shio or soy. Great service and friendly staff.
author: Kelly T.

description: We'd been searching for ramen equal to the ramen we've had in Japan.  We finally found it at Hinodeya.  Dashi was excellent, noodles flavorful, atmosphere authentic down to the shouting of orders and responses from the staff.  Servers were attentive, unfailingly polite, again, more like Japan than the US.  Highly recommend Hinodeya to serious ramen aficionados.
author: Norm C.

description: we are visiting sf area for the weekend and wanted try ramen and this place was the only place with more than 3 stars so we wanted try here. the staff member told us that it is going to be about 30 minute wait with 10 tables ahead of us. since its ramen place, we just assumed that turnover time for each table will be fast.... but NOT REALLY. we waited about 1.5hour. i dont know if it was short staffed but they are extremely slow. at one moment i wanted to get up and start to help them to just release my stress over looking at them and how they communicate eachother..... But i am giving 2 stars because ramen was not bad and staffs were friendly. I do not think it is worth to wait over an hour to eat a bowl of ramen. Not recommending this place if you are running a busy schedule or staying over other than Japan town or just hate waiting or super hungry.
author: Jiyoung K.

description: It's good and it's a lighter version of ramen broth. Not your typical heavy rich pork broth. This is dashi style ramen. They also have Paitan ramen which I think the "IT" ramen right now. Nojo ramen in Hayes Valley only serve Paitan ramen (chicken). Japanese people who work there which is thumbs up. I'm sure it's still very new, the ambiance needs to improve more. It feels more like Chinese restaurant vibe and flat. Needs more decoration, music, add more Japanese elements to it. It feels boring there. It's hard to find Black Garlic ramen in Bay Area. My favorite ramen places can be found in NYC and Los Angeles still and Kyoto, Japan ;-))
author: Clemencia S.

description: So glad this place opened up. Ramen in a Japantown is very mediocre. I think this place will blow up, great quality and flavor. Service is slow but they will figure it out
author: Evan K.
